('47', 0, 1, 2, 47) 1.CARDING OR ARCHERY
('47', 0, 2, 3, 68) The word pinjan 1 has become disagreeable in our language.
('47', 0, 2, 4, 127) Even in figurative language, it is a term implying censure.
('47', 0, 2, 5, 187) When a person keeps on pointlessly repeating the same thing, we say of him that he is doing pinjan.
('47', 0, 2, 6, 287) This usage of the word has become so established that we do not like the word 'pinjanshastra' 2 or 'pinjanvidya' 3. A new form of the tool used in carding,which is known as the "Bardoli Bow", is made of a bow shaped bamboo, and looks like a bow too.
('47', 0, 2, 7, 537) Hence I have made bold to use a word which has become endeared in the terminology of the Kshatriyas, i.e., 'dhanurvidya' 4
('47', 0, 3, 8, 660) instead of the word ‘pinjanshastra’.
('47', 0, 3, 9, 697) I apologize to the intellectual class for doing this.
('47', 0, 3, 10, 751) If other lovers of the language also get enraged at me for taking such liberties with a word with such an established usage, I beg their forgiveness too.
('47', 0, 3, 11, 905) I feel, however, that at a time when our language is developing, when new ideas are being brought into it, new discoveries are being made, when the scope for courage, etc., is being enlarged, we should be accommodating in the usage of those words.
('47', 0, 4, 12, 1153) The reader is not unfamiliar with the liberties I have been taking with words for many years.
('47', 0, 4, 13, 1247) I have given a new definition of the word Kshatriya.
('47', 0, 4, 14, 1300) The latter is not a person who knows how to kill others but rather one who acquires the art of sacrificing his own life so that others may live.
('47', 0, 4, 15, 1445) A Kshatriya is one who has well mastered the mantra of never retreating in the battle between gods and demons which is raging in this world.
('47', 0, 4, 16, 1586) A Kshatriya is one who is the very embodiment of compassion.
('47', 0, 4, 17, 1647) What knowledge of archery should such a Kshatriya possess?
('47', 0, 4, 18, 1706) While reflecting on this problem, just as a carpenter invariably thinks of a babul tree, is it any wonder if my mind turns towarding carding?
('47', 0, 4, 19, 1848) If we learn the craft of carding, if the young people acquire mastery over it, they would by daily devoting some time to it, serve hundreds of thousands of women.
('47', 0, 4, 20, 2011) Those who have mastered the science of spinning repeatedly declare that, if carding is properly done, if the strands in a sliver are separated and
('47', 0, 5, 21, 2158) 1 Carding 2 Science of carding 3 Knowledge of carding 4 Knowledge of archery
('47', 1, 0, 1, 2235) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 1, 1, 2, 2275) symmetrically arranged, the resulting yarn will easily be good, even strong and fine.
('47', 1, 1, 3, 2361) If someone makes slivers free of charge, that will berendering great service to those of our women who do not card today and are not likely to do so.
('47', 1, 1, 4, 2511) And if this is done, it will go a long way towards helping make khadi cheap.
('47', 1, 1, 5, 2588) The activity of spinning is progressing at snail's pace.
('47', 1, 1, 6, 2645) The same is not true of carding or what we may now call ‘dhanurvidya’.
('47', 1, 1, 7, 2716) Moreover, this vidya presupposes both physical and spiritual strength.
('47', 1, 1, 8, 2787) Let anyone who wishes, have a look at a carder's chest.
('47', 1, 1, 9, 2843) Every carder's chest is something that would make another envious.
('47', 1, 1, 10, 2910) It is round, expanded and beautiful.
('47', 1, 1, 11, 2947) The muscles of his arms too are likewise well developed.
('47', 1, 1, 12, 3004) If one carder is earnest, he can surely serve at least twenty women because he cards at least ten pounds [of cotton] in ten hours.
('47', 1, 1, 13, 3135) This amount of cotton is more than what is required by twenty women working ten hours, who spin yarn of ten to twelve counts.
('47', 1, 1, 14, 3261) From this it is clear that anyone who acquires this skill can find work to his satisfaction.
('47', 1, 2, 15, 3354) Moreover, the activity of spinning has been carried on as an independent trade from ancient times, and has been able to compete with other trades.
('47', 1, 2, 16, 3501) Today a carder demands and gets thirty rupees a month.
('47', 1, 2, 17, 3556) In the beginning the Ashram had engaged a carder on a wage of seventy rupees a month.
('47', 1, 2, 18, 3642) Even an ordinary carder can make eight annas a day today.
('47', 1, 2, 19, 3700) One has to have a book in order to acquire easily a knowledge of such a beautiful form of archery.
('47', 1, 2, 20, 3799) This has been included in Maganlal Gandhi’s book entitled “The Science of Weaving”.
('47', 1, 2, 21, 3883) However, that contains only the basic principles.
('47', 1, 2, 22, 3933) Again, this vidya has taken great strides since then.
('47', 1, 2, 23, 3987) The Gujarat Vidyapith has given a proper place to this great science, which is a prop of the nation and sustainer of millions of men and women.
('47', 1, 2, 24, 4131) It has laid down the examinations to be held and is realizing and increasing its importance day by day.
('47', 1, 2, 25, 4235) Hence the necessity has been felt for having a textbook on this subject.
('47', 1, 2, 26, 4308) In order to see to it that the text is a very useful one, a questionnaire has been issued by the Principal to those who have mastered the art.
('47', 1, 2, 27, 4451) The questions go into minute detail and occupy a fair amount of space and as only a particular section of readers would be interested in it, I do not publish them here.
('47', 1, 2, 28, 4620) However, those who are interested in this subject should write to the Principal, Gujarat Vidypith, Ahmedabad, and obtain a copy of the question naire.
('47', 1, 2, 29, 4771) His office will find it convenient if the words ‘Regarding dhanurvidya’ are written on the left hand side of the address.
('47', 2, 0, 1, 4893) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 3
('47', 2, 1, 2, 4940) Perhaps, it is necessary to add that the term has been accepted by the Vidyapith.
('47', 2, 1, 3, 5022) I have coined it for the very first time for this article.
('47', 2, 1, 4, 5081) I alone am responsible for its use.
('47', 2, 1, 5, 5117) Kakasaheb or the other office bearers can reject it.

('47', 2, 3, 11, 5510) 2. MY NOTE
('47', 2, 4, 12, 5521) SHRI HIRALAL'S SCHEME
('47', 2, 5, 13, 5543) Three experienced persons have independently pointed out the same defect in Shri Hiralal’s scheme published in Young India and Navajivan for a new type of spinning wheel.
('47', 2, 5, 14, 5714) Since others who are giving thought to this scheme also find this and other defects in it, I publish below one letter from among the many that I have here with me: 2
('47', 2, 6, 15, 5880) Let Shri Hiralal and others interested in innovations give thought to this.
('47', 2, 6, 16, 5956) Even if Shri Hiralal’s scheme is regarded as faulty and considered useless, his efforts will still be dear to me.
('47', 2, 6, 17, 6070) Such efforts are very necessary.
('47', 2, 6, 18, 6103) Although the farmer’s heirs did not discover in his field the golden egg mentioned in his will, they got by digging it up untainted wealth in the form of a golden harvest which proved even more valuable than the golden egg and the heirs learned the importance of body labour.
('47', 2, 7, 19, 6379) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 1 9 1929
('47', 2, 8, 20, 6415) 1 A thread 2 The letter is not translated here.
('47', 2, 8, 21, 6463) Hiralal had suggested the use of a hollow spindle.
('47', 2, 8, 22, 6514) The correspondent contended that it would result in untwisting the yarn, and making it weak and fragile.
('47', 3, 0, 1, 6619) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 3, 1, 2, 6659) 3. FIT FOR ALL TO READ
('47', 3, 2, 3, 6682) The Navajivan Prakashan mandir has just published Shri Mahadev Desai’s “History of Bardoli Satyagraha” 1. As it has been written by Shri Mahadev Desai, it is indeed authoritative and the reader can rest assured about the authenticity of each event mentioned in it.
('47', 3, 2, 4, 6947) At a time when the fragrance of a gigantic satyagraha has filled the air and people are eagerly looking forward to the coming year, everyone who desires to secure swaraj should know what kind of weapon satyagraha is, what its limits are, how Bardoli, the Sardar and the people of Bardoli employed it, what kind of triumph they achieved thereby, what fine after effects flowed from it and how far reaching they have been.
('47', 3, 2, 5, 7368) Hence this history is very opportune.
('47', 3, 2, 6, 7406) Everyone should make a detailed study of it.
('47', 3, 2, 7, 7451) Considering its subject matter, it is neither too long nor too short and it occupies 389 demy octavo pages.
('47', 3, 2, 8, 7559) It contains six illustrations the most useful of which is the one giving a map of Bardoli, showing all its principal villages.
('47', 3, 2, 9, 7686) The inquiry committee had visited 47 villages, which are indicated with the help of numbers.
('47', 3, 2, 10, 7779) Other useful details are also given.
('47', 3, 2, 11, 7816) Among other useful illustrations, that of a women’s meeting attracts special attention.
('47', 3, 2, 12, 7904) This history has been priced at only twelve annas.
('47', 3, 2, 13, 7955) 2 I hope that all will get a copy of this book, read it carefully, reflect upon it, and derive some inspiration from it regarding the kind of sacrifice they may in their turn be able to make at the altar of swaraj.
('47', 3, 3, 14, 8170) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 1 9 1929
('47', 3, 4, 15, 8206) 1 Bardoli Satyagrahano Itihas 2 The source has a footnote advising those ordering the book by post to send three annas extra for postage.
('47', 4, 0, 1, 8344) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 5
('47', 4, 1, 2, 8391) 4. SCHEME OF SELF RELIANCE
('47', 4, 2, 3, 8418) Of course, I did publish Shri Shivabhai’s article 1 but I have received three articles contradicting it.
('47', 4, 2, 4, 8523) The last one is from Shri Jethalal.
('47', 4, 2, 5, 8559) It is not easy to oppose him because he writes from his experience and adheres firmly to his views.
('47', 4, 2, 6, 8659) His rejoinder 2 runs as follows.
('47', 4, 2, 7, 8692) All lovers of khadi who have made a study of its science should consider this reply carefully.
('47', 4, 2, 8, 8787) If those who do not know this science master the arithmetic behind it, they will find it interesting and enjoymable.
('47', 4, 2, 9, 8904) Having said this, I may add that I cannot deviate from my basic statement.
('47', 4, 2, 10, 8979) I still feel that, in the widespread propaganda for khadi, the principle that those who spin should also weave cannot work.
('47', 4, 2, 11, 9103) That certainly is not the ideal situation.
('47', 4, 2, 12, 9146) At the very basis of this scheme lies lack of faith in human beings.
('47', 4, 2, 13, 9215) As weaving is a complete and independent activity, it cannot be carried on in every house and in attempting to do so, one would run counter to the previling principle of division of labour.
('47', 4, 2, 14, 9405) Man is as independent as he is dependent.
('47', 4, 2, 15, 9447) And he must be so in order that he may be able to preserve his humility.
('47', 4, 2, 16, 9520) If he can be visualized as a totally independent being, he will cease to be social animal and if, in turn, he ceaes to be that, he will cease to be non violent and will be unable to achieve a sense of unity with all living beings.
('47', 4, 2, 17, 9751) It has been said that, if all those who spin do not weave, they will not turn out good yarn.
('47', 4, 2, 18, 9844) This amounts to maligning the human race.
('47', 4, 2, 19, 9886) If those textile mills which only produce yarn can make fine yarn, why should not persons who merely spin on the spinning wheel do likewise?
('47', 4, 2, 20, 10027) Love will make them spin fine yarn.
('47', 4, 2, 21, 10063) The reader should bear in mind that it is a different matter that, in order to have a complete knowledge of spinning, it is necessary to have a knowledge of weaving also.
('47', 4, 2, 22, 10234) There should certainly be no need for every spinner to weave for himself in order to improve the quality of the yarn spun by him.
('47', 4, 2, 23, 10364) I am becoming increasingly convinced day by day of the need to make anindpendent effort to improve the quality of yarn.
('47', 4, 2, 24, 10484) The spinner
('47', 4, 3, 25, 10496) 1 “If Spinners also Weave?”, 18 8 1929 published in Navajivan, 18 8 1929. 2 Not translated here.
('47', 4, 3, 26, 10593) Taking into account the cost of cotton and wages for ginning, carding and spinning, the correspondent had shown that khadi produced thus would cost nearly three rupees a yard of 10 count yarn and 30 inches width.
('47', 5, 0, 1, 10806) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 5, 1, 2, 10846) stands to gain by such improvement.
('47', 5, 1, 3, 10882) Let us take full advantage of this and bring about an improvement in the quality of yarn.
('47', 5, 1, 4, 10972) We shall never be able to make innumerable women take to weaving.
('47', 5, 1, 5, 11038) Even at present we have been able, with some effort, to make the women produce better yarn.
('47', 5, 1, 6, 11130) The improvement that has taken place in yarn in the course of the last seven years is a hopeful sign.
('47', 5, 1, 7, 11232) Moreover, there are hundreds of thousands of expert weavers in the country and it is our duty to make use of their skill.
('47', 5, 1, 8, 11354) They too form a section of the people.
('47', 5, 1, 9, 11393) We have yet to win them over with ove.
('47', 5, 1, 10, 11432) We have still to convince them that in the reform of their trade lies the welfare of the country.
('47', 5, 1, 11, 11530) And it is through such mutual trust and dependence alone that we are going to march ahead.
('47', 5, 1, 12, 11621) I regard the question of competing with cloth made in textile mills…whether foreign or Indian…as a temporary and futile one.
('47', 5, 1, 13, 11746) When farmers store their own cotton, carry on all the activities up to that of spinning in their own homes, they will certainly get their own khadi made by paying the proper wage to the weaver and not touch mill made cloth.
('47', 5, 1, 14, 11970) The economics of khadi is unique.
('47', 5, 1, 15, 12004) It has soul whereas the economics of textile mills is soulless.
('47', 5, 1, 16, 12068) Hence the two difer in kind.
('47', 5, 1, 17, 12097) Just as the waters of the ocean and those of the Ganges being qualitatively different cannot be compared to each other, similarly there can be no comparison between cloth produced in textile mills and hand made cloth produced in villages.
('47', 5, 1, 18, 12336) However, no one should interpret my article to imply that, where the farmer is well to do and has a large family, he should not introduce weaving into his house; he certainly should do so.
('47', 5, 1, 19, 12525) My emphasis is on keeping the activity of spinning separate; there is a danger of suffocating it by combining it with weaving or of slackening the pace of the widespread use of the spinning wheel.
('47', 5, 1, 20, 12722) For the purpose of propaganda for the spinning wheel, it is necessary to realize and demonstrate the limits of weaving.
('47', 5, 1, 21, 12842) Whereas crores have to spin, only lakhs have to weave; while spinning will always remain primarily a subsidiary occupation, weaving will always remain chiefly an independent one.
('47', 5, 1, 22, 13021) On the revival of spinning depends the economic and, consequently, the oral upliftment of crores of people and in order to make the activity successful, it is necessary to bring about development in all sections of society such as weavers, business men and others.
('47', 5, 1, 23, 13286) Spinning is an activity which awakens religious sentiment and purifies the soul.
('47', 5, 2, 24, 13367) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 1 9 1929

('47', 7, 3, 5, 14790) But I had expected nothing less from you.
('47', 7, 3, 6, 14832) My rule always is never to criticize even strangers about anything said or done by them without first verifying facts through them whenever they are within reach.

('47', 7, 3, 8, 15054) The attention of our best men and women is given to her.
('47', 7, 3, 9, 15111) We are trying the method of no corporal punishment regarding her, though the temptation is often great.
('47', 7, 3, 10, 15215) But we have not lost hope.
('47', 7, 3, 11, 15242) I have personally tested the method for over 20 years with growing confidence.
('47', 7, 3, 12, 15321) Of course it does not apply to infants though even in their case, punishment is rare.

('47', 9, 15, 19, 18616) You are probably aware that the Indian National Congress has appointed a separate Committee this year for making special efforts for the removal of untouchability.
('47', 9, 15, 20, 18780) The work has obviously to be done through the Hindus, and the Congress resolution is explicit on the point.

('47', 11, 1, 2, 21952) 13. CONGRESS ORGANIZATION
('47', 11, 2, 3, 21978) Jairamdas reports that out of 172 possible District Congress Committees only 27 have been sending reports of work done in connection with the foreign cloth boycott movement inaugurated by the Congress, which is really the most important part of the Congress work in the sense that it affects the whole nation and it is a programme in which everyone can take part.
('47', 11, 2, 4, 22342) It is moreover a programme whose successful working cannot but produce a tremendous impression both on ourselves and the rulers.
('47', 11, 2, 5, 22471) Jairamdas further states that repeated reminders fail to bring even acknowledgements.
('47', 11, 2, 6, 22557) Some Provincial Congress Committees have ignored his appeals altogether.
('47', 11, 2, 7, 22630) Thus there is nothing from seven provinces, viz., Delhi, C.P. Hindustani, Burma, Assam, Andhra, Ajmer and North Western Frontier.
('47', 11, 2, 8, 22760) Out of a total of 2,230 reports bespoken only 86 have been received, i.e., 4 per cent!
('47', 11, 2, 9, 22847) The districts are distributed as follows: Berar 6 Punjab 15 Maharashtra 11 Utkal 6 Bihar 16 Kerala [3] Tamil Nad 9 Sind 8 U.P. 37 Bombay 7 C. P. Marathi 4 Karnataka 11 Gujarat 4 Bengal 32 169
('47', 11, 3, 10, 23039) There are more than 250 districts in British India.
('47', 11, 3, 11, 23091) Thus ony two thirds of the total number of districts are covered nominally by the Congress organization.
('47', 11, 3, 12, 23196) This is not a bright outlook.
('47', 11, 3, 13, 23226) The Congress is the one organization that appeals to the nation.
('47', 11, 3, 14, 23291) It is the one organization which, if efficiently worked, can without doubt secure freedom for the nation.
('47', 11, 3, 15, 23397) But it cannot do so if its component parts do not respond with the quickest dispatch to instructions from the central office, or if it does not cover every district and taluk, let alone every village.
('47', 11, 3, 16, 23598) Foreign cloth boycott is a matter largely of organization.
('47', 11, 3, 17, 23657) There are no two opinions about its desirability and even necessity.
('47', 11, 3, 18, 23726) But the ablest secretary will fail, if those who have to be organized are lazy or indifferent.
('47', 11, 3, 19, 23821) It is time for responsible workers throughout the provinces to ponder over the painful facts narrated by me, and to
('47', 12, 0, 1, 23937) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 13
('47', 12, 1, 2, 23985) remedy an evil which is so easily avoidable.
('47', 12, 1, 3, 24030) The Secretaries of District and Taluk Committees should know that failure to carry out instructions from headquarters brings them under the disciplinary resolution passed by the A.I.C.C. meeting at Bomaby.
('47', 12, 1, 4, 24236) Personally I should prefer to have only 16 swift moving, co operating committees instead of 169 indifferent, irresponsive and irresponsible committees.
('47', 12, 1, 5, 24388) The 16 real committees can show some work.
('47', 12, 1, 6, 24431) The 169 inactive, sleeping committees can only be a dead weight.
('47', 12, 1, 7, 24496) What shall we be?
('47', 12, 2, 8, 24514) Young India, 5 9 1929
('47', 12, 3, 9, 24536) 14. FORTHCOMING U.P. TOUR
('47', 12, 4, 10, 24562) Local organization have asked me for instructions regarding the forthcoming tour in the United Provinces.
('47', 12, 4, 11, 24668) I had thought that what I had said about the Andhra tour 1 would suffice, but I observe that the paragraphs then written escaped the attention of workers in the other provinces, as they were not then directly concerned.
('47', 12, 4, 12, 24888) To come then to the U.P. tour, organizers will please remember that I have just risen from a sick bed to which I was driven by my own ignorance and premature trustfulness.
('47', 12, 4, 13, 25060) Medical and other friends have therefore reconciled themselves to the tour on my promise that I would take as much rest as possible during the day, refrain from making long speeches or from undertaking much other exertion.
('47', 12, 4, 14, 25283) Therefore the organizers will beware of multiplying functions or expecting long speeches from me.
('47', 12, 4, 15, 25381) Nor must I be called upon to walk or mount huge platforms.
('47', 12, 4, 16, 25440) Even apart from medical instructions consequent on my convalescence, from the strict business point of view…and this tour is to be purely a business and businesslike tour…it is necessary to save time and expense.
('47', 12, 4, 17, 25653) I have a horror of touching the feet devotion.
('47', 12, 4, 18, 25700) It is wholly unnecessary as a mark of affection, it may easily be degrading.
('47', 12, 4, 19, 25777) It interferes with free and easy movement, and I have been hurt by the nails of the devotees cutting into the flesh.
('47', 12, 4, 20, 25894) The performance has often taken more than fifteen minutes to pass through a crowd to a platform only a few yards from the farthest end.
('47', 12, 5, 21, 26030) 1 Vide “Forthcoming Andhra Tour”, 7 3 1929
('47', 13, 0, 1, 26073) 14 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 13, 1, 2, 26114) The platform is comparatively a costly affair, and sometimes when unskilfully constructed, a dangerous contrivance.
('47', 13, 1, 3, 26230) It is therefore better to take my motor to the centre of the meeting and use it as a platform.
('47', 13, 1, 4, 26325) this proved a most effective and expeditious method in Andhra.
('47', 13, 1, 5, 26388) Reception Committees should on no account cut through the purses for the purpose of defraying decoration or feeding expenses.
('47', 13, 1, 6, 26514) There should be a separate collection where required.
('47', 13, 1, 7, 26568) All decoration should therefore be avoided.
('47', 13, 1, 8, 26612) Even where some decoration is resorted to, foreign cloth, foreign paper and the like shold be altogether excluded.
('47', 13, 2, 9, 26727) Noises at the meetings should be avoided.
('47', 13, 2, 10, 26769) This can only be done by some leading men going to the meetings in advance, and coaching the audience to observe silence, not to press, not to shout, not to smoke, not to attempt to advance towards me for touching the feet etc.
('47', 13, 3, 11, 26997) Strictest economy should be observed about housing and feeding me and my company.
('47', 13, 3, 12, 27079) The companions should have the plainest fare, no spices, no sweets.
('47', 13, 3, 13, 27147) Local fruit if obtainable may be given.
('47', 13, 3, 14, 27187) Expensive fruit must not be ordered from Bomaby, Calcutta or Delhi.
('47', 13, 3, 15, 27255) I carry a supply of dried fruit with me, and I should be thankful for it to be locally replenished wherever obtainable.
('47', 13, 3, 16, 27375) Lemons are a necessary article of food.
('47', 13, 3, 17, 27415) Unfortunately for me, I have been obliged to revert to goat’s milk.
('47', 13, 3, 18, 27483) It will be therefore necessary to procure for me about 4 lb.
('47', 13, 3, 19, 27544) of goat’s milk, and where possible, curds made from goat’s milk, in whose manufacture no other curds are mixed for fermentation.
('47', 13, 3, 20, 27673) A few drops of lemon added to boiled and cooled goat’s milk curdles it in twelve hours.
('47', 13, 3, 21, 27761) My lodgings should be so selected as to afford me quiet and privacy.
('47', 13, 3, 22, 27830) We carry enough cloth to make our own beddings.
('47', 13, 3, 23, 27878) but where anything in this direction is supplied, it should be entirely of khadi.
('47', 13, 3, 24, 27960) It hhas been a torture to me at times to be placed in luxuriously fitted rooms where everything is foreign, cloth included.
('47', 13, 3, 25, 28084) Work should not commence before 7 a.m.
('47', 13, 3, 26, 28123) and should not take more than two hours.
('47', 13, 3, 27, 28164) In every case it should stop at 10 a.m., and not reocmmence before 5.30 p.m.
('47', 13, 3, 28, 28241) and should not go beyond 8 p.m.
('47', 13, 3, 29, 28273) From 10 to 3, I should have the whole time to myself for rest and my editorial and other work.
('47', 13, 3, 30, 28368) Between 3 and 4, I should spin and see workers.
('47', 13, 3, 31, 28416) Workers’ meetings I hold to be necessary in every place, big or small.
('47', 14, 0, 1, 28487) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 15
('47', 14, 1, 2, 28535) Spectacular functions should be strictly avoided, except where they are meant to serve an educational purpose.
('47', 14, 2, 3, 28646) Organizers should remember that this is a khadi tour undertaken on behalf of the All India Spinners’ Association.
('47', 14, 2, 4, 28760) It is the largest national organization run on business lines for the sole purpose of bringing the message of the wheel to the homes of the seven hundred thousand villges of this vast country.
('47', 14, 2, 5, 28953) On its successful working depends the relief of the growing and grinding economic distress of the semi starved millions.
('47', 14, 2, 6, 29074) I want every pie I can get for this work.
('47', 14, 2, 7, 29116) One rupee in the chest of the A.I.S.A. means a day’s drink or a day’s drink cigar or a day’s sweets bringing diseases in their train.
('47', 14, 3, 8, 29250) Moneys collected from the populace should on no account be diverted for any other purpose.
('47', 14, 3, 9, 29341) The measses give trustingly.
('47', 14, 3, 10, 29370) The safest way to use their donations is for the propagation of the wheel.
('47', 14, 3, 11, 29445) Donations so used return to their kind charged with double interest.
('47', 14, 3, 12, 29514) In these collections, all should take part irrespective of party or status.
('47', 14, 3, 13, 29590) Even judges have paid me for khadi.
('47', 14, 4, 14, 29626) But I want to do other Congress work also.
('47', 14, 4, 15, 29669) I want to learn about and help in the organization of the Congress.
('47', 14, 4, 16, 29737) The addresses where presented should therefore be full of information:
('47', 14, 5, 17, 29808) (a) The population with its component parts in the area covered by the address;
('47', 14, 6, 18, 29888) (b) national schools with attendance;
('47', 14, 7, 19, 29926) (c) number of wheels and looms working, monthly production of yarn and khadi in quantity and value;
('47', 14, 8, 20, 30026) (d) monthly sale locally and outside of khadi produced;
('47', 14, 9, 21, 30082) (e) number of self spinners;
('47', 14, 10, 22, 30111) (f) number of volunteers and the nature of their work;
('47', 14, 11, 23, 30166) (g) number of members, men and women, according to religious denominations;
('47', 14, 12, 24, 30242) (h) state of Congress finance; (i) quantity of work done for boycott of foreign cloth, liquor and untouchability, and state of Hindu Muslim relations.
('47', 14, 13, 25, 30393) This is merely a sample of the information I should like to be supplied to me.
('47', 14, 13, 26, 30472) I should like a map drawn to scale of each taluk visited with the villages shown where Congress activity is carried on.

('47', 15, 3, 6, 31054) 15. NOTES
('47', 15, 4, 7, 31064) AFFLICTED SIND The pen refuses to move to record the tale of Sind’s woe.
('47', 15, 4, 8, 31137) Day after day, I follow the harrowing accounts in the daily Press, and realize our helplessness.
('47', 15, 4, 9, 31234) But we may not therefore sit idle.
('47', 15, 4, 10, 31269) Every rupee received will relieve some distress.
('47', 15, 4, 11, 31318) We have simply to do the little we can.
('47', 15, 4, 12, 31358) The widows’s mite coming from a pure heart goes much faster than millions given grudgingly.
('47', 15, 4, 13, 31450) All the contributions received will be spent through the very careful and tried agency of Professor Narayandas Malkani.
('47', 15, 4, 14, 31570) Let the donors not delay their contributions.
('47', 15, 5, 15, 31616) A NATIONAL INSULT The insulting and impossible (for a self respecting man) conditions imposed by the Union government on the Ali Brothers in respect of their contemplated visit to South Africa demonstrate once more the truth of the proverb: “The leopard cannot change his spots.” One had thought that after the friendly agreement arrived at the historic round table conference, after the wonderful work done by the Rt.
('47', 15, 5, 16, 32035) Hon’ble Sastri in South Africa, the insult offered to the Ali Brothers and through them to the nation by the Union Government was impossible.
('47', 15, 5, 17, 32177) In view of the undertaking voluntarily given by the Brothers, the Union Government could have felt sure that they would never deliver political speeches.
('47', 15, 5, 18, 32331) With reference to notabilities the convention is to assume correct contrictions.
('47', 15, 5, 19, 32412) And even when in such cases there is any doubt about such conduct, the convention is to ensure safety through diplomatic and courteous channels.
('47', 15, 5, 20, 32557) For instance, in this very case the Union Government, instead of conveying the restrictions to the Ali Brothers, could have secured their purpose through the Government of India…in so far as it was legitimate.
('47', 15, 5, 21, 32767) In no case could they exact pecuniary security or impose a
('47', 16, 0, 1, 32826) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 17
('47', 16, 1, 2, 32874) ridiculous time limit as the Union Government have sought to do.
('47', 16, 1, 3, 32939) It is to be hoped that the government of India will see that this palpable wrong is righted, the restrictions wholly withdrawn and the Brothers permitted to proceed to South Africa without hurting their self respect and without undue restrictions, direct or indirect, tacit or implied.
('47', 16, 2, 4, 33225) PURE CHEAP LITERATURE I have not much faith in the efficacy of cheap literature, however pure it may be, when it is pitted against dirty literature.
('47', 16, 2, 5, 33374) I believe in the contact of pure conduct.
('47', 16, 2, 6, 33416) But on the principle that something is better than nothing and that the spread of pure literature can do no harm even where it fails to do good, I welcome the enterprise of Sjt.
('47', 16, 2, 7, 33594) Mahavirprasad Poddar and his band of purist friends in publishing good, pure, healthy literature.

('47', 16, 2, 10, 33857) Much consists of khadi literature.
('47', 16, 2, 11, 33892) I recommend this for stocking in all khadi bhandars.
('47', 16, 2, 12, 33945) Full information may be had from Shuddha Khadi Bhandar, 132 Harrison Road, Calcutta.

('47', 16, 2, 18, 34434) Hiralal’s conception, objections which they hold to be radical and fatal to its success.
('47', 16, 2, 19, 34523) I have published one of the letters in Navajivan.
('47', 16, 2, 20, 34573) Shortly, the objection is that the hollow spindle will not wind the yarn if it is to work at both ends.
('47', 16, 2, 21, 34677) The twist received at one end will be undone at the other end 4. This is as far as a layman can describe a technical objection.
('47', 16, 2, 22, 34805) I have brought this to Sjt.
('47', 16, 2, 23, 34833) Hiralal’s notice, and suggested to him that he should now translate his theory into practice, and have a model made of his plan and work at it regularly, till he can make the next announcement not of a well reasoned specification, but of a complete charkha constructed according to his specification.

('47', 17, 3, 9, 35737) 16. INDIAN CULTURE
('47', 17, 4, 10, 35756) When I was touring in U.P. in 1924 a peasant called out to me near Ayodhya and threw a sheet of paper in my car.
('47', 17, 4, 11, 35869) I picked up that sheet and found that he had written on it many precious quatrains and couplets from Tulsidas’s Ramacharitamanasa.
('47', 17, 4, 12, 36000) This made me very happy and enhanced my reverence for Indian culture.
('47', 17, 4, 13, 36070) I preserved this sheet in my file hoping to publish it some day.
('47', 17, 4, 14, 36135) I would take it up every week and put it aside.
('47', 17, 4, 15, 36183) For, at the time I got it, I was not writing anything for Hindi Navajivan and I did not feel that it would be so useful for the Gujarati Navajivan.
('47', 17, 4, 16, 36331) Part of what he had written on it was published in both the Gujarati and Hindi editions in 1927. 1
('47', 17, 5, 17, 36430) As these days I am regularly writing something every week for Hindi Navajivan and also as my tour of U.P. is to begin shortly, I am publishing below the remaining part: 2
('47', 17, 6, 18, 36601) I have left out the words of praise.
('47', 17, 6, 19, 36638) This peasant brother has a neat hand and he has formed his letters with care.
('47', 17, 6, 20, 36716) Historians have testified that nowhere in the world are the peasants as civilized as in India.
('47', 17, 6, 21, 36811) This sheet of paper is proof of it.
('47', 17, 6, 22, 36847) Tulsidas has played a leading part in the preservation of Indian culture.
('47', 17, 6, 23, 36921) Without the awakening influence of Ramacharitamanasa of Tulsidas, the life of the peasants would become dull and dry.
('47', 17, 6, 24, 37039) One cannot say how it happened but it is unquestionably true that the life giving force in Tulsidas’s language is not found in other writers.
('47', 17, 6, 25, 37181) Ramacharitamanasa is a storehouse of gems of thought.
('47', 17, 6, 26, 37235) The above couplets and quatrains give us some idea of its value.
('47', 17, 6, 27, 37300) I firmly believe
('47', 17, 7, 28, 37317) 1 Vide “Our Culture” sub title Gift from a Peasant”, 8 9 1927 2 Not translated here
('47', 18, 0, 1, 37401) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 19
('47', 18, 1, 2, 37449) that the peasant writer did not have to put in much effort in the selection of quotations.
('47', 18, 1, 3, 37540) He has supplied them from his repertory.
('47', 18, 1, 4, 37581) We need not despair as to our morality, when we hear from a peasant’s mouth saying like, “Can an adulterer find salvation?”, “Can a kingdom stand without a knowledge of statecraft?”, “Is there any vice to match backbiting or any virtue to match compassion?” 1
('47', 18, 2, 5, 37841) and so on.
('47', 18, 2, 6, 37852) It is said these days that the peasants are living in darkness, that in our country tamas is predominant and that it must move on into rajas.
('47', 18, 2, 7, 37994) First of all I do not believe that tamas, rajas and sattva can be divided into such watertight compartments.
('47', 18, 2, 8, 38103) I feel that everyone has within him all the three gunas in some measure or other.
('47', 18, 2, 9, 38185) The difference is only of degree.
('47', 18, 2, 10, 38219) I firmly believe that in our country it is not tamas which rules supreme but sattva.
('47', 18, 2, 11, 38304) This sheet of paper is a proof of this.
('47', 18, 2, 12, 38344) If this had been an exception, it would not have served as a proof of the predominance of sattva in India.
('47', 18, 2, 13, 38451) But when we know that millions of peasants know by heart the quatrains and couplets of Tulsidas and that they also understand them, then we can say with a measure of certainty that people who have such ideas have a sattvik civilization and that these quatrains and couplets are a proof of it.
('47', 18, 3, 14, 38744) [From Hindi] Hindi Navajivan, 5 9 1929

('47', 19, 7, 17, 40648) 18. LETTER TO G.V. MAVALANKAR
('47', 19, 8, 18, 40678) September 6, 1929

('47', 22, 1, 2, 44542) 22. NOTE ON DISPUTE BETWEEN MILL OWNERS AND WORKERS 1
('47', 22, 2, 3, 44596) BOMBAY September 7, 1929
('47', 22, 3, 4, 44621) There are approximately more than 55,000 labourers employed in the textile mills of Ahmedabad.
('47', 22, 3, 5, 44716) In 1923, the mills were not in the same happy position in which they were in 1920 21; mill owners, therefore, cut the workers' wages by 15 1/2 per cent.
('47', 22, 3, 6, 44869) This reduction was not made through the medium of the panch in accordance with the agreement between the mill owners and the workers.
('47', 22, 3, 7, 45003) The latter resorted to a prolonged strike in which they were not successful.
('47', 22, 3, 8, 45080) For the last eight months or so, the labourers have been demanding that this cut should be restored.
('47', 22, 3, 9, 45181) Finally, this issue was entrusted to the panch, which includes Sheth Mangaldas Girdhardas and myself.
('47', 22, 3, 10, 45283) I regret to say that we could not reach unanimity about our decision.
('47', 22, 3, 11, 45353) The mill owners have raised the objection that the cut made in 1923 was effected with the consent of both the parties.
('47', 22, 3, 12, 45472) It was also argued that the cut was introduced through the panch and that, in whateverway the cut might have been effected, the workers had no right now to ask for its annulment.
('47', 22, 3, 13, 45651) Moreover, the owners maintain that the financial condition of the mills does not permit this and finally that the wages which the workers get at present are in excess of their needs.
('47', 22, 3, 14, 45834) As against this, the labourers say that 1. no verdict was given by the panch in 1923; 2. the labourers had not accepted the wage cut willingly but because of their inability to prolong the strike; 3. whatever the facts of the case, the wages received by the workers in 1923 were barely sifficient to meet their needs.
('47', 22, 3, 15, 46152) They have had to bear greater loss because of the cut.
('47', 22, 3, 16, 46207) From the evidence presented before the panch I have come to the conclusion that all the three points put forward by the labourers are valid.
('47', 22, 3, 17, 46348) I am of opinion that in matters regarding wages, etc.,
('47', 22, 4, 18, 46403) 1 This note, intended for submission to an umpire, was on the fresh issue raised by the Labour Union viz., that the cut in the workers’ wages effected in 1923 was not justified.
('47', 22, 4, 19, 46581) Vide “Letter to Gordhanbhai I. Patel”, 8 8 1929
('47', 23, 0, 1, 46629) 24 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 23, 1, 2, 46670) decisions given at any particular time do not hold good for ever.
('47', 23, 1, 3, 46736) Hence, whenever such cases are put forward by the workers or the mill owners, the panch is bound to examine the pros and cons and then give its verdict.
('47', 23, 1, 4, 46889) Two official publications were presented before the panch.
('47', 23, 1, 5, 46948) 1. Report on an Inquiry into the Wages and Hours of Labour in the Cotton Mill Industry, 1923 2. Report on an Inquiry into Working class Family Budgets of Ahmedabad, 1923 The actual average wage of an Ahmedabad mill worker amounts to Rs. 27 7 0 and, provided he is not absent even for a single day, it can go up to Rs. 33 7 6 (vide the first publication, pp.
('47', 23, 1, 6, 47306) The figures of expenditure presented from the side of labour indicate that the monthly expenditure of a family amounts to Rs.49 13 6 (see Appendix A).
('47', 23, 1, 7, 47457) These figures relate to a Hindu family.
('47', 23, 1, 8, 47497) The expenditure of a Muslim family is even more.
('47', 23, 1, 9, 47546) Hence, on the whole, the labourers do suffer a loss.
('47', 23, 1, 10, 47599) The expenditure figure accepted in the second publication mentioned above is Rs. 39 5 8 (vide p.
('47', 23, 1, 11, 47696) The reason for this discrepancy is that, as proved by that document, it does not take into account item No.
('47', 23, 1, 12, 47804) 22 (interest) and No.
('47', 23, 1, 13, 47826) 24 (social expenses), and the figures for item No.
('47', 23, 1, 14, 47877) 8 (milk) and No.
('47', 23, 1, 15, 47894) 14 (fuel) are lower.
('47', 23, 1, 16, 47915) In my opinion, this expense is necessary and reasonable.
('47', 23, 1, 17, 47972) The amount which has to be paid by way of interest is partly unavoidable and partly avoidable.
('47', 23, 1, 18, 48067) Interest which has to be paid on grocery which is bought on credit as the wages are low is unavoidable, whereas the expense on liquor and such things which is incurred by borrowing money can be avoided.
('47', 23, 1, 19, 48270) Hence the interest that is actually paid is not taken into account, but rather that which would have to be paid.
('47', 23, 1, 20, 48383) Social expenses are also inevitable.
('47', 23, 1, 21, 48420) Labourers, or for that matter anyone else, may starve but will see to it that social obligations of his family and caste are met.
('47', 23, 1, 22, 48550) Hence, even after hearing all that was said on the side of the mill owners, I find no reason to reduce the figures of expenditure presented by the labourers.
('47', 23, 1, 23, 48708) The various classes of textile workers deserve to be noted:
('47', 23, 2, 24, 48768) (a) Those numbering 13,482 who earn wage of Rs. 30 to
('47', 23, 3, 25, 48822) Rs. 40. Persons working in the weaving department mainly constitute this class.
('47', 23, 3, 26, 48902) It is made up exclusively of men…there are no women in it.
('47', 24, 0, 1, 48961) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 25
('47', 24, 1, 2, 49009) (b) Those numbering 32,828 who earn a wage of Rs. 6 to Rs. 30. This includes people working in the following sections of the textile industry: carding, blow room, frame, spinning, reeling, binding, engineering, etc.
('47', 24, 1, 3, 49225) Besides men, women as well as children are employed in these sections.
('47', 24, 1, 4, 49296) Their numbers are as folows: 1. Men workers 17,381 2. Women workers 6,602 3. Children (from 14 to 18 years of age) 2,263 4. Children (who work for half a day and under 14 years of age)
('47', 24, 2, 5, 49481) (NOTE: The figures given in b (2) include the 1,976 women who are employed in the winding department.
('47', 24, 2, 6, 49583) Their income, unlike that of the women working in other sections, does not add up to the income of the men working in this section.) These figures indicate that even in class (b), there remains a large section in which, as in class (a), only men are employed.
('47', 24, 2, 7, 49843) The wage earning class in section (b) earns only around Rs. 33. This is testified by the second publication mentioned above (vide table 1, p.11).
('47', 24, 2, 8, 49989) The families of workers belonging to class (a) do not generally work.
('47', 24, 2, 9, 50059) There are about 2,300 labourers whose income exceeds Rs. 40. In addition, there are 1,670 jobbers, 1,651 clerks, 1,171 watchmen and others.
('47', 24, 2, 10, 50199) There had, however, been no cut in their wages in 1923. NOTE: These figures have been extracted from publication No.1 in which detailed information has been given regarding all workers employed in the textile mills of Ahmedabad in August 1923. The total number in that year has been shown as 52,038 but since then there has been an increase in this number.

('47', 25, 14, 19, 52058) An argument advanced by the mill owners is that even today the mills are running at a loss.
('47', 25, 14, 20, 52150) I regard the evidence given in support of this as rather weak.
('47', 25, 14, 21, 52213) It is possible that a few mills are running at a loss; but the majority of them would not incur losses.

('47', 26, 1, 3, 52863) Labour, on its part, could not prove this and on this the panch has given a unanimous verdict.
('47', 26, 2, 4, 52958) It is my opinion that the other point has been proved by labour.
('47', 26, 2, 5, 53023) There is an understanding between my colleague and myself that the papers put before the panch should be sent by both these parties to a Sarpanch 2 .

('47', 26, 2, 8, 53424) If the Sarpanch feels that any further proof is necessary, he has the right to ask for it.
('47', 26, 2, 9, 53515) Besides the papers which have already been presented, if any of the parties wish to present any more facts relating to the point in question before the Sarpanch, they can do so after showing it to each other.
('47', 26, 2, 10, 53724) Finally since unrest is spreading among the labouerers as a result of the delay in the decision, the Sarpanch is requested to give his decision as early as possible.

('47', 27, 1, 2, 54397) 23. “IF SPINNERS ALSO WEAVE?”
('47', 27, 2, 3, 54427) I have received one or two similar articles.
('47', 27, 2, 4, 54472) I have published this one 1 as I felt that it was the best.
('47', 27, 2, 5, 54532) The others deal with the same subject but the treatment is not so good.
('47', 27, 2, 6, 54604) Shivabhai’s calculations appear to be effective.
('47', 27, 2, 7, 54653) 2 However, we should overlook this and understand the underlying principle.
('47', 27, 2, 8, 54729) Very often it has been the case that, whereas the results calculated by us or our conjectures are correct, the arguments or figures adduced in support thereof are either weak or incorrect.
('47', 27, 2, 9, 54918) What I feel basically is the fact that spinners can never become weavers on a large scale.
('47', 27, 2, 10, 55009) Hence, it cannot become an indivisible part of the scheme of self reliance, and no attempt should be made to do so.
('47', 27, 2, 11, 55125) The other pole of this scheme should be voluntarily accepted dependence on others.
('47', 27, 2, 12, 55208) In this case, it is futile to cite the examples of Bijolia and Bardoli.
('47', 27, 2, 13, 55280) The circumstances in both those places were of an unusual nature.
('47', 27, 2, 14, 55346) In ordinary circumstances, it is the case that everyone has moments of leisure when he must spin and get the yarn spun by him woven in his own village.
('47', 27, 2, 15, 55498) Not only is there no objection here to spinners learning to weave, but rather it is our duty to provide facilities for them to do so.
('47', 27, 2, 16, 55632) However, there is no need to carry on any propaganda for this.
('47', 27, 2, 17, 55695) Let me put this in another way.
('47', 27, 2, 18, 55727) If a brahmachari who lives by himself or a widow who has no means of support gins, cards, spins and weaves, that will be regarded as doing business at a loss.
('47', 27, 2, 19, 55886) Such a person will by weaving alone earn six to eight times as much as one who merely spins; and, he or she should indeed do so or find out some such independent occupation.
('47', 27, 2, 20, 56060) However, where there is a large family, one person can become a weaver.
('47', 27, 2, 21, 56132) It is my idea that we should enlarge the concept of our members.
('47', 27, 2, 22, 56197) Our ideal is not a Robinson Crusoe living on a desolate island, but a family which extends over the entire world.
('47', 27, 2, 23, 56311) In order to reach it, it is but a natural step forward to turn over village into a single family.
('47', 27, 2, 24, 56409) Man is a social animal.
('47', 27, 2, 25, 56433) His country is this small planet…the world.
('47', 27, 2, 26, 56477) In it everyone will carry on an all pervasive activity.
('47', 27, 2, 27, 56533) What extends over the family will be done by the family and the same applies, in its turn, to the town and the country as a whole.
('47', 27, 2, 28, 56664) However, this will be done not with a view to destroying one another,
('47', 27, 3, 29, 56734) 1 This article by Sitaram Purushottam Patwardhan is not translated here.
('47', 27, 3, 30, 56807) 2 Vide footnote 2, “Scheme of Self Reliance”, 1 9 1929
('47', 28, 0, 1, 56862) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 29
('47', 28, 1, 2, 56910) but rather to sustain one another.
('47', 28, 1, 3, 56945) In my view, the spinning wheel is a universal thing, while the loom is confined to either the family or the village.
('47', 28, 1, 4, 57062) The cooking fire and the spinning wheel are to be found in every home but the same cannot be said of the loom.
('47', 28, 1, 5, 57173) It can be clearly shown that this involves an economic disadvantage.
('47', 28, 1, 6, 57242) Whatever is basically harmful on economic grounds is also certainly harmful from the religious point of view.
('47', 28, 1, 7, 57352) Untainted wealth can never be opposed to religion.
('47', 28, 1, 8, 57403) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 8 9 1929

('47', 28, 4, 14, 57788) 25. MY NOTES
('47', 28, 5, 15, 57801) NATURE’S WRATH The fury that Nature has let loose on Sind is indescribable.
('47', 28, 5, 16, 57877) The thought of it stuns me and it reveals the might of Nature on the one side and our littleness on the other.
('47', 28, 5, 17, 57988) But man’s dharma is compassion above everything else.
('47', 28, 5, 18, 58042) When he is under its influence, he is led to do his utmost, aware of his own limitations.
('47', 28, 5, 19, 58132) We sympathize with a man or a family, if we can.
('47', 28, 5, 20, 58181) We get some satisfaction by sharing our food with anyone who is hungry.
('47', 28, 5, 21, 58253) Our humanity consists in giving away everything and still not feeing satisfied about it.
('47', 28, 5, 22, 58342) To give away everything is a noble human quality and there is no room for pride in something which is one’s inborn quality.
('47', 28, 5, 23, 58466) A Gujarati should notconsider himself different from a Sindhi when patriotic fervour is in the air.
('47', 28, 5, 24, 58566) Just as family members though having different names do not consider themselves different, so also we are all one though belonging to different States.
('47', 28, 5, 25, 58718) That is why we should share each
('47', 28, 6, 26, 58751) 1 Held under the presidentship of Jawaharlal Nehru and attended by 1,400 delegates

('47', 29, 1, 9, 59348) THE MEANING OF YAJNA A reader writes: 1
('47', 29, 2, 10, 59388) It is a fact based on actual experience that violence is involved in lighting a fire.
('47', 29, 2, 11, 59474) The Shastras have not said that the yajnas of the past did not involve violence.
('47', 29, 2, 12, 59555) However, they regarded as innocent the violence practised in the course of a yajna, just as we salve or cheat our conscience by regarding as innocent a diet of vegetables although we are aware that it involves violence.
('47', 29, 2, 13, 59775) If the rishis 2 and munis 3 of the past had sacrificed animals, it is my firm belief that at that time, the need for such sacrifice was felt; however, today there is no need for doing so; it is a savage and cruel practice.
('47', 29, 2, 14, 59998) I regard such acts of offering animals as sacrifices as not only not religious in this age, but as irreligious acts, and hence wish to see them stopped for good.
('47', 29, 2, 15, 60160) That the concept of yajna in the Gita has a universal and altruistic implication may be construed from the verses preceding and following that verse and from the central argument itself of the Gita.
('47', 29, 2, 16, 60359) Hence the meaning of yajna approved by the Gita is: It is an act which is performed solely for the sake of service or from a purely altruistic standpoint.
('47', 29, 2, 17, 60514) And here a narrow interpretation of the term has been wished or done to any living creature.

('47', 39, 3, 8, 77080) 40. A NOTE
('47', 39, 4, 9, 77091) September 9, 1929 I think the time has come for us to save ourselves from the nuisance of the handwritten monthly.
('47', 39, 4, 10, 77206) He who is convinced that his intellect is going to develop only through action will write only what is relevant to action.
('47', 39, 4, 11, 77329) This is worth pondering by us who live in the Udyog Mandir.

('47', 40, 1, 2, 78676) 42. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, BHOPAL 1
('47', 40, 2, 3, 78715) September 10, 1929
('47', 40, 3, 4, 78734) I confess that when yielding to the loving insistence of His Highness 2 and Dr. Ansari I accepted the invitation to visit Bhopal, I was prepared to find here the same regal splendour, the same wasteful blaze of luxury as one comes across in our other present day Indian States.
('47', 40, 3, 5, 79012) But to my agreeable surprise, I found His Highness living in a ‘palace’ which could be called as such only by courtesy, and which in fact would not stand comparison even with the lovely palatial residence of Dr. Ansari who was after all medical adviser to His Highness....
('47', 40, 4, 6, 79285) Gandhiji reiterated his belief that the existence of the Indian Princes’ rule was in no way inconsistent with the evolution of true democracy.
('47', 40, 4, 7, 79428) He was therefore no enemy of Indian States, and he entertained every hope of their reaching his ideal of democratic swaraj which he often interpreted as Ramarajya.
('47', 40, 4, 8, 79592) Using the word ‘Ramarajya’ in a Mussalman state and for an audience which had a very large number of Mussalmans in it, he immediately said: I warn my Mussalman friends against misunderstanding me in my use of the word ‘Ramarajya’.
('47', 40, 4, 9, 79823) By ‘Ramarajya’ I do not mean Hindu Raj.
('47', 40, 4, 10, 79863) I mean by ‘Ramarajya’ Divine Raj, the Kigdom of God.
('47', 40, 4, 11, 79916) For me Rama and Rahim are one and the same deity.
('47', 40, 4, 12, 79966) I acknowledge no other god but the one god of Truth and righteousness.
('47', 40, 4, 13, 80037) Whether the Rama of my imagination ever lived or not on this earth, the ancient ideal of Ramarajya is undoubtedly one of true democracy in which the meanest citizen could be sure of swift justice without an elaborate and costly procedure.
('47', 40, 4, 14, 80276) Even the dog is described by the poet to have received justice under Ramarajya.
('47', 40, 5, 15, 80356) In alluding to his belief in Hindu Muslim unity he recalled his friendship with the late Hakim Saheb Ajmal Khan and asked for contributions to the Ajmal Jamia college and in so doing mentioned the heroic sacrifice of Dr. Zakir Husain and his colleagues who had reduced their honorariums to what might be termed a starvation point.
('47', 40, 5, 16, 80687) He asked the Hindus to give up untouchability if they would save Hinduism, and he reminded both Hindus and Mussalmans, that if they would identify themselves with the poorest in the land they were bound to exclude from their wardrobes all

('47', 41, 1, 3, 81118) In response to his appeal for contributions for the Ajmal Jamia fund, a committee was formed at once to make house to house collections.

('47', 42, 1, 2, 82471) 44. RESOLUTION ON AJMAL JAMIA FUND 1
('47', 42, 2, 3, 82508) [September 11, 1929]
('47', 42, 3, 4, 82529) Whereas it is necessary to maintain the Jamia Millia, Delhi, as a memorial to the late Hakim Ajmal Khan Saheb, this meeting of the Trustees of the Ajmal Jamia Fund hereby resolves that out of the sums so far collected a sum of Rs. 1000/ be retained with the treasurer and the balance be transferred to the Jamia to constitute a reserve fund for permanent investments and meeting the deficit between the current income and expenditure and in future all sums received be handed over to the Jamia for the same purpose.
('47', 42, 4, 5, 83045) All sums received prior to the date and not passed through the hands of the Treasurer shal be accounted to him and this meeting authorizes the Treasurer to legalize the expenditure of that money by the Jamia authorities under the sanction of the President.
('47', 42, 4, 6, 83302) The Treasurer be authorized to appoint a duly certified auditor for the auditing of the accounts of the Fund.
('47', 42, 5, 7, 83412) From a microfilm: S. N. 15580

('47', 45, 1, 2, 86950) 50. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, AGRA 1
('47', 45, 2, 3, 86987) September 11, 1929
('47', 45, 3, 4, 87006) Gandhiji whilst thanking them 2 on their collection 3 and the admirable restraint which they had shown in presenting all their addresses at a single function declined to accept their plea in the Agra citizens’ address that hard times justified the limited size of their purse.
('47', 45, 3, 5, 87283) I know that the moneyed citizens of Agra could have made the purse bigger if they had wished.
('47', 45, 3, 6, 87377) Hard times cannot serve as a justification for them, for it is a notorious fact that famine conditions present opportunities for profiteering to the middlemen class of which they are not slow to take advantage.
('47', 45, 3, 7, 87588) Hard times instead of putting a curb on your generosity ought to serve as a stimulant in the present case, because khadi work for which the various purses are being raised is just the activity par excellence which is calculated to alleviate the distress caused by famine conditions.
('47', 45, 4, 8, 87871) He asked the audience to give substantially to the volunteers as soon as they approached them.
('47', 45, 4, 9, 87966) He had made it clear in his Andhra speeches that he did not want addresses framed, for he had no place to keep them and every rupee spent in framing meant the loss of one woman’s subsistence for 16 days.
('47', 45, 4, 10, 88170) He said he meant no disrespect if he wanted to auction them.
('47', 45, 4, 11, 88231) He had done so before and one address in Andhra fetched Rs. 10,000. 4
('47', 45, 5, 12, 88301) I am here to redeclare my faith in the potency of non co operation.
('47', 45, 5, 13, 88369) You have all got to prepare for January 1930 from now.
('47', 45, 5, 14, 88424) The A.I.C.C. has already laid down the conditions by fulfilling which alone, in its opinion, swaraj by non violent means can be attained.
('47', 45, 5, 15, 88562) It is the triple constructive programme, viz., the boycott of foreign cloth through khadi, the suppression of the drink and drug evil and the elimination of untouchability by the Hindus.
('47', 45, 5, 16, 88749) And since all this work can be effectively done through a proper Congress organization, the reorganization of the Congress by the enrolment of Congress members is a necessity.
('47', 45, 5, 17, 88925) Let me warn you solemnly that if we do

('47', 46, 3, 5, 89783) 51. MY LIMITATIONS
('47', 46, 4, 6, 89802) It is not without grief and great hesitation that I have been instrumental in a meeting of the A.I.C.C. being called for the purpose of electing the president for the forthcoming session of the Congress.
('47', 46, 4, 7, 90006) Friends have been sending me urgent wires and writing to me not to precipitate a crisis, to reconsider my decision and avoid the convening of the A.I.C.C. meeting.
('47', 46, 4, 8, 90170) I have been reluctantly obliged to disappoint them.
('47', 46, 4, 9, 90222) The only consolation I can give them is that their grief over my decision cannot be greater than mine.
('47', 46, 4, 10, 90325) I believe in waiting on God for guidance.
('47', 46, 4, 11, 90367) I have no light from within.
('47', 46, 4, 12, 90396) Confidence does not come to me.
('47', 46, 4, 13, 90428) I have a lively sense of what must be regarded as my limitations.
('47', 46, 4, 14, 90494) I have no faith in the council programme.
('47', 46, 4, 15, 90536) I have no faith in Government schools and colleges.
('47', 46, 4, 16, 90588) I have still less in the so called courts of justice where when justice is obtained it is found to be too dear, and where it is almost unobtainable when the question for decision is as between the ruling race and the subject race on a vital point.
('47', 46, 4, 17, 90836) I have no faith in spectacular demonstrations.
('47', 46, 4, 18, 90883) Whilst I want power for labour and its progressive welfare, I do not believe in its exploitation for a mere political end.
('47', 46, 4, 19, 91006) I believe in unadulterated non violence, I do not believe in the possibility of India (whatever other countries might have attained) attaining swaraj in terms of the millions by violent means.
('47', 46, 4, 20, 91199) I believe that unity between Hindus, Mussalmans, Sikhs, Parsis, Jews, Christians and others is essential for the attainment of swaraj.
('47', 46, 4, 21, 91334) I believe the removal of untouchability to be equally essential for our purpose.
('47', 46, 4, 22, 91415) Indeed I have no desire to obtain swaraj, even if it was possible, at the sacrifice of a single legitimate interest of a single minority.
('47', 46, 4, 23, 91553) I do not believe the Mussalman to be the natural enemy of the Hindu nor the Englishman of the Indian.
('47', 46, 4, 24, 91655) I want for my
('47', 47, 0, 1, 91669) 48 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 47, 1, 2, 91710) compassing my end the co operation of both the Mussalman and the Englishman.
('47', 47, 1, 3, 91787) My non co operation though it is part of my creed is a prelude to co operation.
('47', 47, 1, 4, 91867) My non co operation is with methods and systems, never with men.
('47', 47, 1, 5, 91932) I may not harbour ill will even agains a Dyer.
('47', 47, 1, 6, 91979) I regard ill will as beneath the dignity of man.
('47', 47, 1, 7, 92028) The reader should now have no difficulty, if he had been patient with me so far, in bearing with me for saying that I am no enemy of capital nor of Indian States.
('47', 47, 1, 8, 92191) I believe the one to be consistent with the highest status attainable by labour and the other with the highest status attainable by the people.
('47', 47, 1, 9, 92335) Need I repeat my growing faith in the life giving wheel and khadi?
('47', 47, 1, 10, 92402) I feel that among Congressmen there can only be a microscopic minority going with me in this long recital of credos.
('47', 47, 1, 11, 92519) With most one or the other of the credos must be a veritable stumbling block.
('47', 47, 1, 12, 92597) Is it any wonder, if I feel that as president of the Congress I should be a round man in a square hole?
('47', 47, 1, 13, 92701) The president of the Congress must be a man, not one commanding respect from a safe distance, but one who represents in every fibre of his being the sum total of what the nation stands for.
('47', 47, 1, 14, 92891) I dare not submit myself for that test.
('47', 47, 1, 15, 92931) But I know that if I am allowed to work in detachment, in spite of my limitations I can render useful service to the nation.
('47', 47, 1, 16, 93056) My advice therefore to the members of the A.I.C.C. and those who can influence them is not to press me to accept an office for which I seem to myself to be so ill fitted.
('47', 47, 1, 17, 93227) They will recognize that it is not want of will, it is the want of capacity, that deters me.
('47', 47, 1, 18, 93320) An incapable president is surely worse than useless.
('47', 47, 2, 19, 93373) Young India, 12 9 1929
('47', 47, 3, 20, 93396) 52. FOUR FUNCTIONS
('47', 47, 4, 21, 93415) During my day’s stay in Bombay on my way to Bhopal I had four interesting functions to attend to.
('47', 47, 4, 22, 93513) The first was the opening of a crafts block in connection with the national school in Vile Parle.
('47', 47, 4, 23, 93611) It is an institution to which several young men have dedicated their lives.
('47', 47, 4, 24, 93687) It should be the pride of the men and women of Bombay to support it.
('47', 47, 4, 25, 93756) An ill equipped national school is any day preferable to the best equipped school run under the aegis of an anti national authority, even as a humble, dilapidated hut is any day preferable to a palatial jail with all creature comforts anticipated.
('47', 47, 4, 26, 94004) The distinguishing feature
('47', 48, 0, 1, 94031) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 49
('47', 48, 1, 2, 94079) of the two varieties is, that in the national school the first lesson of the boys and girls is loyalty to one’s country without limitations, in the second even this indispensable thing is subject to loyalty to a foreign rule.
('47', 48, 1, 3, 94305) The second function was the laying of the foundation stone of a building which is to serve as a nucleus for the service of India’s women.
('47', 48, 1, 4, 94443) It is a creation of the energy and devotion of Sjt.
('47', 48, 1, 5, 94495) Karsandas Chitalia of the Servants of India Society.
('47', 48, 1, 6, 94548) He has set himself apart for mute service of the woman’s cause.
('47', 48, 1, 7, 94612) Though in my opinion the erection of the building is premature till he has found a steady, selfless, sober, tired woman who would devote herself to the cause and a few girls at least who would follow her, I have yielded to his superior faith and devotion, and not only laid the foundation but devoted a large part of the purse of nearly Rs. 25,000 presented to me ten years ago through his and Shrimati Jaiji Petit’s labours.
('47', 48, 1, 8, 95038) True service of any cause is rendered by raising of stout hearts than buildings.
('47', 48, 1, 9, 95119) Brick and mortar have no power to attract true hearts.
('47', 48, 1, 10, 95174) But they come into being whenever they are needed by true and stout hearts.
('47', 48, 1, 11, 95250) At any rate it is my prayer and hope that this building will fulfil the noble aspirations of Karasandas Chitalia.
('47', 48, 1, 12, 95364) I know that he would not have been happy without it.
('47', 48, 1, 13, 95417) The third function took place at Vanita Vishram for helping the blind.
('47', 48, 1, 14, 95488) I must again make the confession as in the case of Karsandas Chitalia, that it was not the demonstrable strength of the cause as the faith and devotion of Sjt.
('47', 48, 1, 15, 95648) H. D. Chhatrapati, and Sjt.
('47', 48, 1, 16, 95676) B. Khambhatta that induced me to preside at the function.
('47', 48, 1, 17, 95734) I had the privilege of knowing the blind brother of Sjt.
('47', 48, 1, 18, 95791) H. D. Chhatrapati, i.e., Dr. Nilkanthrai Chhatrapati.
('47', 48, 1, 19, 95845) But being wholly immersed in the cause of the starving millions who are worse than the physically blind, I have not been able to take any active interst in the latter.
('47', 48, 1, 20, 96013) It required the magnetic touch of these two friends to draw me.
('47', 48, 1, 21, 96077) there is at Tardeo the Happy Home for the Blind.
('47', 48, 1, 22, 96126) It was for this institution that the meeting was called.
('47', 48, 1, 23, 96183) How happy that Home is the curious and philanthropically minded reader must find out for himself or herself.
('47', 48, 1, 24, 96292) The conductors invite scrutiny, but they also invite all (a) to furnish the Home with funds, (b) to send the blind they can get hold of, and
('47', 48, 2, 25, 96433) (c) to induce Municipalities and the like to do likewise.
('47', 49, 0, 1, 96491) 50 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 49, 1, 2, 96532) It is stated that there are 15,00,000 of totally blind people in India and that nearly 70 per cent of these are curable if treated in time.
('47', 49, 1, 3, 96672) They state also that the number of partially blind is 2 times as much as that of the totally blind.
('47', 49, 1, 4, 96772) Chhatrapati also mentioned the interesting but painful fact, that the blind beggars in Bomaby received from 4 to 5 rupees daily and that the money mostly went into the pockets of the conductors whom the blind beggars employed.
('47', 49, 1, 5, 96999) If therfore instead of our charity being blind, as it undoubtedly is today in many cases, it became enlightened, and if then we refused to pay anything to the beggars but took the trouble of sending them to the home or homes designed for them and helped the homes, we should save the nation’s money and in the bargain make the blind fit for earning their livelihood as they can be made without much difficulty.
('47', 49, 2, 6, 97410) The fourth function was a visit to the new and more commodious abode of the A.I.S.A. Khadi Bhandar at 396, Kalbadevi.
('47', 49, 2, 7, 97528) During its seven years’ existence it has sold nineteen lakhs rupees worth of khadi.
('47', 49, 2, 8, 97612) It employs today 31 salesmen, 18 tailors and a varying but large mumber of washermen, dyers and printers.
('47', 49, 2, 9, 97718) For tailoring it pays yearly over Rs. 15,000, for washing over Rs. 9,500 and for dyeing, etc., Rs. 8,800. Khadi is stocked today in 1,660 separate items.
('47', 49, 2, 10, 97872) The slow yet marvellous evolution that khadi has undergone during the short period of its revival is stimulating and encouraging.
('47', 49, 2, 11, 98002) A visit only should be enough to convert the sceptic who would go there with an open mind.

('47', 51, 1, 2, 101065) 55. COMMUNICATIONS WITH SPIRITS
('47', 51, 2, 3, 101097) Several correspondents have been inquiring whether I receive communications from the spirits of the dead, and whether I do or not, whether I believe in the possibility of, and if yes, approve of, such communications.
('47', 51, 2, 4, 101314) The latest inquirer writes as follows: 1
('47', 51, 3, 5, 101355) I have had the occasion to know a bit of the Indian Spiritualist Society of Bombay.
('47', 51, 3, 6, 101439) Recently a boy was drowned in the Tilak tank, Deccan Gymkhana, Poona, and the parents of the boy have sought communication with his spirit through this Society.
('47', 51, 3, 7, 101600) I am informed the boy spirit has spoken to them.
('47', 51, 3, 8, 101649) In his book Subhadra or Life after Death Mr. V.D. Rishi, the organizer of the I.S. Society; writes that during his experiences at the seance the spirit of his wife as also other spirits have communicated to him that they take much pleasure and feel a sort of relief to talk to their relatives and friends on this earth.
('47', 51, 3, 9, 101969) They have thanked him often and often for the good he has done to them by the spread of the science of spirit communication.
('47', 51, 3, 10, 102094) Mr. Rishi believes that scientists have not done proper justice to this branch of science .
('47', 51, 3, 11, 102186) to know exactly what is life after death.
('47', 51, 4, 12, 102228) Could you not … for the benefit of so many who are seeking and those who might yet seek intercourse with the spirits as also for my own benefit …very kindly express your views (publicly if you so please) on this matter, advancing some convincing arguments against what has been mentioned above .
('47', 51, 4, 13, 102524) My answers must be categorical.
('47', 51, 4, 14, 102556) I never receive communi cations from the spirits of the dead.
('47', 51, 4, 15, 102618) I have no evidence warranting a disbelief in the possibility of such communications.
('47', 51, 4, 16, 102703) But I do strongly disapprove of the practice of holding or attempting to hold such communications.
('47', 51, 4, 17, 102802) They are often deceptive and are products of imagination.
('47', 51, 4, 18, 102860) The practice is harmful both to the medium and the spirits, assuming the possibility of such communications.
('47', 51, 4, 19, 102969) It attracts and ties to the earth the spirit so invoked, whereas its effort should be to detach itself from the earth and rise higher.
('47', 51, 4, 20, 103104) A spirit is not necessarily purer because it is disembodied.
('47', 51, 4, 21, 103165) It takes with it most of the frailties to which it was liable when on earth.
('47', 51, 4, 22, 103242) Information or advice therefore given by it need not be true or sound.
('47', 51, 4, 23, 103313) That the spirit likes communications with those on earth is no matter for pleasure.
('47', 51, 5, 24, 103397) 1 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('47', 52, 0, 1, 103434) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 53
('47', 52, 1, 2, 103482) contrary it should be weaned from such unlawful attachment.
('47', 52, 1, 3, 103542) So much for the harm done to the spirits.
('47', 52, 1, 4, 103584) As for the medium, it is a matter of positive knowledge with me that all those within my experience have been deranged or weak brained and disabled for practical work whilst they were holding or thought they were holding such communications.
('47', 52, 1, 5, 103826) I can recall no friend of mine who having held such communication had benefited in any way.

('47', 52, 4, 8, 103975) This is a calamitous year for Sind .
('47', 52, 4, 9, 104012) Sind is a dry tract and the average annual rainfall is hardly 5".
('47', 52, 4, 10, 104078) But the total rainfall this year varies between 25" and 50".
('47', 52, 4, 11, 104139) All this has fallen within a period of less than 3 weeks .
('47', 52, 4, 12, 104198) Not one district has escaped the disaster.
('47', 52, 4, 13, 104241) The central parts of Sind have suffered most.
('47', 52, 5, 14, 104287) A few days back it rose to 73" .
('47', 52, 5, 15, 104320) The Punjab rivers are in full flood .
('47', 52, 5, 16, 104358) This tremendous volume of water is expected to reach Sind within 24 hours .
('47', 52, 5, 17, 104434) Government has .
('47', 52, 5, 18, 104451) .kept special trains ready for an emergency .
('47', 52, 6, 19, 104497) The People's Flood Relief Committee, which did some useful work during the floods of 1927, has been revived.
('47', 52, 6, 20, 104606) It started with a generous donation of Rs. 10,000 from the Gujarat Provincial Congress Committee and has since collected a sum of about Rs. 15,000 in Sind.
('47', 52, 6, 21, 104762) But misfortunes never come single, and rains, pests and pestilence have disorganized the trade of Karachi and Hyderabad.
('47', 52, 6, 22, 104883) The zamindars are unable to pay because of the losses of crops, and the merchants are hard hit by cholera in Upper Sind and floods in the Punjab.
('47', 52, 6, 23, 105029) We are therefore obliged to appeal for funds outside our province.
('47', 52, 6, 24, 105096) There was a noble response from Bombay during the floods of 1927, when the People's flood Relief Committee received nearly 2 lakhs of rupees from the Bombay Central Relief Fund.
('47', 52, 6, 25, 105274) The distress is much more acute now, and my Committee is confident that its appeal for funds will not be made in vain.

('47', 53, 4, 7, 105976) Shri Mahavir Prasad Poddar writes: 1
('47', 53, 5, 8, 106013) I have no doubt at all that if the profit motive in introduced into the sale of khadi, it can never become popular.

('47', 53, 5, 10, 106298) If the expenses are more, they should not be recovered from the buyers, rather we should beg for donations to make them up.
('47', 53, 5, 11, 106422) The proposal is that if possible the expenses should be less than 6 per cent.
('47', 53, 5, 12, 106500) The ideal thing would be for us not to charge more than what is spent on production up to weaving, etc.
('47', 53, 5, 13, 106604) If it is found necessary a little profit can be charged on the sales.
('47', 53, 5, 14, 106674) When khadi becomes as popular as ghee it will begin to sell among the millions and then the profit should not be more than 3 per cent.
('47', 53, 5, 15, 106809) Secondly, we should also hope that the millions of peasant of our country following what has come to be called the self reliance system in khadi will be able to spin for themselves and have enough khadi woven for their needs.
('47', 53, 5, 16, 107035) If they can produce more khadi they will sell it themselves.
('47', 53, 5, 17, 107096) Whether this golden time ever comes or not, the idea of making money by sale of khadi should be shunned.
('47', 53, 5, 18, 107201) Khadi is certainly a powerful means of finding livelihood for the poor.
('47', 53, 5, 19, 107273) But it cannot be a means of making money.
('47', 53, 5, 20, 107315) Every industrious person has a right to a livelihood.
('47', 53, 5, 21, 107369) But no one has a right to amass wealth.
('47', 53, 5, 22, 107409) To be sure, amassing wealth is theft.
('47', 53, 5, 23, 107447) He who takes more money than he needs for his living whether knowingly or unknowingly others of their living.
('47', 53, 5, 24, 107557) Artha, i.e., good, is of two kinds…swartha or individual good and paramartha 2 or the higher good.
('47', 53, 5, 25, 107656) The latter is what one should seek; it is not opposed to dharma.
('47', 53, 5, 26, 107721) Individual good which is opposed to dharma should be shunned.
('47', 53, 5, 27, 107783) Khadi shastra is the shastra of paramartha and therefore it is true
('47', 53, 6, 28, 107851) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('47', 53, 6, 29, 107888) It dealt with the question of profits in Khadi.

('47', 56, 6, 19, 113509) 60. DISCUSSION WITH WORKERS, AGRA 1
('47', 56, 7, 20, 113545) September 13, 1929
('47', 56, 8, 21, 113564) Workers from Agra and the districts who were over 31 in number, met Gandhiji at his residence in an informal gathering...”It is so late in the day and we have so few trained workers for khadi work; what can we do?”they bitterly complained to Gandhiji.
('47', 56, 8, 22, 113816) Gandhiji, as he proceeded to lay bare his grief to them sharply retorted:
('47', 56, 9, 23, 113890) 1 This appeared under the title “The U.P. Tour II”.
('47', 57, 0, 1, 113942) 58 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 57, 1, 2, 113983) Whose fault?
('47', 57, 1, 3, 113996) By the sheer strength of its size and numbers the U.P. can dictate terms to the whole of India.
('47', 57, 1, 4, 114092) What is then the meaning of this helplessness which I see before me?
('47', 57, 1, 5, 114161) A Kripalani from Sind can today come and create in your midst a splended field for khadi work.
('47', 57, 1, 6, 114256) Round about you is the spectre of starvation and want.
('47', 57, 1, 7, 114311) Look how people are dying on all sides without anyone to give them even a decent cremation.
('47', 57, 1, 8, 114403) You have an unlimited opporutnity for khadi work before you, if only you knew how to use it.
('47', 57, 1, 9, 114496) If you believe that the cure for starvation lies in khadi, you will not mind whether you are many or whether you are few.
