('47', 57, 2, 13, 114908) I am prepared to place all my present companions at your disposal.
('47', 57, 2, 14, 114975) They know carding and spinning.
('47', 57, 2, 15, 115007) I shall shift for myself without their services, if you think that you need them for teaching you spinning and carding....
('47', 57, 3, 16, 115130) “If we send all our best workers into khadi work,”they objected, “it would either mean a complete paralysis of our political activity, or if with the khadi work they carry on their political activity, the latter will jeopardize the former, as in the event of their arrest their khadi work would come to a standstill and the public would lose confidence in the movement.” That shows that you have not yet learnt the A.B.C. of the soldier's art.
('47', 57, 3, 17, 115574) A soldier never worries as to what shall happen to his work after him, but thinks only of the immediate duty in front of him.
('47', 57, 3, 18, 115700) Garibaldi never thought about his crops, when he left his farm and his plough in response to the call of duty.
('47', 57, 3, 19, 115811) General Smuts never paused tothink of his splendid practice at the bar or of his still more precious farm when he joined the fight.
('47', 57, 3, 20, 115943) Botha had a flock of 40 thousand sheep.
('47', 57, 3, 21, 115983) They did not worry him when he plunged into the life and death struggle.
('47', 57, 3, 22, 116056) Neither of these great generals doubted that if their property was seized by the enemy, as in fact it was, it would only be for the time being, and was bound to be ultimately restored to them or their descendants when the fighting was over.
('47', 57, 3, 23, 116297) Even so ought to be the case with khadi workers.
('47', 57, 3, 24, 116346) As for the public viewing with distrust an enterprise whose conductors were liable to be marched off to jail for its cause, what is likely to happen is just the reverse.
('47', 57, 3, 25, 116516) When public opinion is sufficiently roused, far from condemning the jail going
('47', 58, 0, 1, 116595) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 59
('47', 58, 1, 2, 116643) worker, it would be the shirker who would find it morally impossible to stay outside the jail.
('47', 58, 2, 3, 116738) The last question asked by the workers was as to how they could utilize the services of their womenfolk for the movement.
('47', 58, 2, 4, 116860) “By freeing them from the incubus of purdah,”replied Gandhiji and proceeded to describe vividly how the backward condition of the women in the U.P. was due to her subjection by man and how she would respond the moment her disabilities in this respect were removed.

('47', 68, 1, 2, 130903) 76. A LETTER
('47', 68, 2, 3, 130916) AGRA, September 14, 1929 I cannot give a satisfactory reply to your letter from this distance.
('47', 68, 2, 4, 131011) I must know many more details.
('47', 68, 2, 5, 131042) But some points can be clarified.
('47', 68, 2, 6, 131076) A wrong should never be concealed.
('47', 68, 2, 7, 131111) If there has been a lapse, it should be immediately made public.
('47', 68, 2, 8, 131176) This applies particularly to a turstee.
('47', 68, 2, 9, 131216) It is quite easy thus to lay down a principle.
('47', 68, 2, 10, 131263) But so long as the erring person who is expected to confess is not able to see his error, the difficulties of such a problem multiply no end.
('47', 68, 2, 11, 131405) Nobody can be forced to repent his error.
('47', 68, 2, 12, 131447) Nobody will, or should, till he sincerely sees his error.
('47', 68, 2, 13, 131505) Take, for instance, my attitude in the case of the calf.
('47', 68, 2, 14, 131562) People could have lovingly tried to show me my error.
('47', 68, 2, 15, 131616) But what was the use of attacking me?
('47', 68, 2, 16, 131654) If it failed to make me see my error, may not the same be true in this case?
('47', 68, 2, 17, 131731) But I must be fully acquainted with all the facts to know whether it is so.
('47', 68, 2, 18, 131807) However, where do I have the time for that?
('47', 68, 2, 19, 131851) And how can it be done through correspondence?
('47', 68, 2, 20, 131898) I therefore wish to show another and easier way.
('47', 68, 2, 21, 131947) The duty of ahimsa arose from the imperfections of man.
('47', 68, 2, 22, 132003) Ahimsa means forgiveness, which in turn means generosity.
('47', 68, 2, 23, 132061) We should try to be generous to the guilty.
('47', 68, 2, 24, 132105) This is very necessary in the management of institutions.
('47', 68, 2, 25, 132163) Where there is generosity there will be patience.
('47', 68, 3, 26, 132213) From a copy of the Gujarati: Kusumbehn Desai’s Diary S.N. 32578/11
('47', 68, 4, 27, 132280) 77. LETTER TO RANCHHODLAL
('47', 68, 5, 28, 132306) AGRA, September 14, 1929
('47', 68, 6, 29, 132331) RANCHHODLAL, The desire for more and more of everything is not confined to the labourers but has spread in the whole society.
('47', 68, 6, 30, 132457) The labourers have only been infected by the example of those considered affluent.
('47', 68, 6, 31, 132540) The argument that labourers should be given higher wages only if they reform their lives and use the increase in wages for improving themselves is like the condition that we can get swaraj only if we reform ourselves.
('47', 68, 6, 32, 132758) The only relevant consideration for deciding whether the labourers should get more is whether what they are
('47', 69, 0, 1, 132866) 70 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 69, 1, 2, 132907) getting at present is enough for their subsistence.
('47', 69, 1, 3, 132959) If it is not, they must get more.
('47', 69, 1, 4, 132993) It is for their servants, that is, the Majoor Mahajan, to see that the increased wages are used well by the labourers.
('47', 69, 1, 5, 133112) I may not have told you, but I am trying to do something exactly like that.
('47', 69, 1, 6, 133188) If the arbitrators recommend building of houses for labourers in lieu of cash increase in wages, parsonally I would sign the award.
('47', 69, 1, 7, 133320) 1 I know that this would lead to many complications.
('47', 69, 1, 8, 133373) The house assigned to a worker should in the end become his own property.
('47', 69, 1, 9, 133447) But once the mill owners become servants of the workers, all complications will automatically be resolved.
('47', 69, 1, 10, 133554) Now for an ideal mill: It will take ages for our workers to be able to run an ideal mill.
('47', 69, 1, 11, 133644) Why do you think it a futile hope that an unselfish capitalist may set up an ideal mill?
('47', 69, 1, 12, 133733) Cadbury has opened an ideal factory.
('47', 69, 1, 13, 133770) Lever Brothers have built an ideal settlement for their workers.
('47', 69, 1, 14, 133835) Some such effort has also been definitely made by Narottamdas at Sholapur.
('47', 69, 1, 15, 133910) Tata certainly laid the foundation of such a settlement at Jamshedpur.
('47', 69, 1, 16, 133981) It is unfortunate that the person who laid that foundation is no more.
('47', 69, 1, 17, 134052) Your own effort, even if it be on the very smallest scale is in the same direction.
('47', 69, 1, 18, 134136) If the mill owners and the workers are not to bepermanent enemies of each other, ideal capitalists have got to arise.
('47', 69, 1, 19, 134254) I think it to be quite easily practicable.
('47', 69, 1, 20, 134297) The beginning may be gradual.
('47', 69, 1, 21, 134327) We can discuss this further when we meet.
('47', 69, 2, 22, 134369) From a copy of the Gujarati: Kusumbehn Desai’s Diary.

('47', 69, 3, 24, 134437) 78. LETTER TO PRABHUDAS GANDHI

('47', 79, 1, 6, 156987) However, although national schools may have to be run under the shade of a banyan tree, although only a handful of children may attend them, let nationalist teachers never lose their faith.
('47', 79, 1, 7, 157177) I believe that the school in Vile Parle is of this type and hence I regarded myself as fortunate in having visited it.
('47', 79, 2, 8, 157296) NEW BUILDING FOR KHADI BHANDAR The Khadi Bhandar of the All India Spinners’ Association in Bombay is a symbol of the progress of khadi and a measure of Shri Vithaldas Jerajani’s love for it.
('47', 79, 2, 9, 157487) From the standpoint of swaraj the progress made by this Bhandar may well appear to be very slight.
('47', 79, 2, 10, 157586) However, viewing it as a store, its progress may be regarded as good.
('47', 79, 2, 11, 157656) From a small building it moved to a somewhat large one and when even this was found to be inadequate, it has been shifted to a new and still larger building at No.
('47', 79, 2, 12, 157820) 396 Kalbadevi.
('47', 79, 2, 13, 157835) A visit to this new place was the fourth function on the 7 th.
('47', 79, 2, 14, 157898) 1 What a contrast between the coarse variety of khadi produced at its inception… to persons crazy about khadi like myself that would appear to be beautiful even today… and the 1660 varieties and textures being produced today!
('47', 79, 2, 15, 158124) What a contrast between the swaraj flag made then and the woolen khadi flag made today with permanent dyes!
('47', 79, 2, 16, 158232) But let me give below the account of this progress which was written down in a beautiful hand and read by Shri Jerajani: 2
('47', 79, 3, 17, 158355) The original bhandar was opened in January 1920 in the Morarji Gokuldas Market.
('47', 79, 3, 18, 158435) The sales during six months in that year amounted to Rs. 28,276. Last year, they amounted to Rs. 3,97,282. The total sales for seven years amount to Rs. 19,60,072. However, this

('47', 80, 1, 2, 158862) is an insignificant figure considering the boycott, even the store at Kalbadevi is of no significance.
('47', 80, 1, 3, 158965) This Bhandar should have its own building.
('47', 80, 1, 4, 159008) If the idea of boycott really catches on, if the love of khadi runs in the blood of every Indian child, there will be a khadi bhandar in each locality in Bombay, not merely the one we have at present.

('47', 80, 1, 7, 159527) BEGGARS FOR ANTYAJA SERVICE The Kathiawar Antyaja Committee has sent Shri Ramji Jutha Hirani and Shri Ramnarayan Nagardas Pathak to East Africa and other places to collect funds for their work.
('47', 80, 1, 8, 159721) Shri Ramji is a worker in Vartej Antyaja Ashram and Shri Ramnarayan, a worker in the Chhaya Antyaja Ashram.
('47', 80, 1, 9, 159829) The ideal thing is that the burden of such expenditure in Kathiawar should be borne by the people living in Kathiawar itself.
('47', 80, 1, 10, 159955) However, today we are facing tasks with regard to which public opinion has not been sufficiently educated.
('47', 80, 1, 11, 160062) There are some who regard untouchability as their dharma.
('47', 80, 1, 12, 160120) In these circumstances, people who love the Antyajas and would serve them should hold out their hands and beg for their sake.
('47', 80, 1, 13, 160246) It is in keeping with this practice that these two workers have been sent to East Africa.
('47', 80, 1, 14, 160336) I hope that the Indian residents of East Africa, and especially the Gujaratis, will give them as much as they consider proper and to the best of their capacity.
('47', 80, 1, 15, 160497) At present the Antyaja Committee is running three ashrams and ten schools.
('47', 80, 1, 16, 160572) Approximately, 800 boys and girls are taking advantage of these.
('47', 80, 1, 17, 160637) Is there any compassionate person who will not help them?
('47', 80, 1, 18, 160695) I had told these gentlemen that I would notice their begging mission in the issue of the very week when they would leave.
('47', 80, 1, 19, 160817) However, owing to heavy pressure of work I could not keep my promise.
('47', 80, 1, 20, 160887) Had Shri Mulchand Parekh, the Secretary of the Committee, not reminded me of it, I might still have forgotten about it.
('47', 80, 1, 21, 161007) I have not written this in order to justify my error but in order to confess it.
('47', 80, 1, 22, 161088) We should beware of making promises to anyone, but when we do, we should promptly carry them out.
('47', 80, 1, 23, 161186) As I could not do so in this instance, I beg forgiveness of these two friends and of the Antyaja Committee.

('47', 102, 5, 14, 196152) 116. JUDGE’S INDICTMENT
('47', 102, 6, 15, 196176) I condense the following from a newspaper report:
('47', 102, 7, 16, 196226) It is extremely common for advocates for the defence in criminal cases to argue that the prosecution story is an entire concoction by the police, and in the vast majority of cases no evidence whatever, whether elucidated in cross examination or offered in examination in chief, is ever produced in support of this argument.
('47', 102, 7, 17, 196550) Now either the contention is raised on directinstructions of the client, or it is deliberately raised by counsel without any instructions from the client.
('47', 102, 7, 18, 196705) In the former case the accused has aggravated the heinousness of the offence with which he is charged.
('47', 102, 7, 19, 196808) In a clear case of this kind the tribunal trying the case should take this into account as a circumstance warranting an increase in the sentence.
('47', 102, 7, 20, 196954) In the latter case where the legal practitioner has acted without reasonable cause he is guilty of the grossest professional misconduct.
('47', 102, 7, 21, 197091) Cross examination on these lines is often grossly absued, and it is the duty of the trying judge, if he has any suspicion when an advocate begins an attack upon the prosecutor or a witness, to demand from the advocate an assurance that he has good grounds for making the suggestion.
('47', 102, 7, 22, 197374) If such is not forthcoming, cross examination on these lines should be promptly stopped.
('47', 102, 7, 23, 197463) If an assurance is given, but if it appears on the termination of the trial that no such grounds had existed, the tribunal should bring the conduct of the advocate to the notice of the High
('47', 103, 0, 1, 197653) 104 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 103, 1, 2, 197695) I make these observations in order that a check may be placed on a growing and serious evil.
('47', 103, 2, 3, 197788) These are the remarks of the Chief Justice of the Patna High Court.
('47', 103, 3, 4, 197856) I have said enough in these columns to show that justice is practically unobtainable in the so called courts of justice in India.
('47', 103, 3, 5, 197986) But I was unprepared for a Chief Justice (assuming that he is correctly reported) becoming the framer of a gratuitous indictment against lawyers and their clients.
('47', 103, 3, 6, 198150) These remarks of the Chief Justice of the Patna High Court, in my opinion, amount to a threat to the accused persons and their counsel.
('47', 103, 3, 7, 198286) If the fear of an increase in sentence or being disbarred hangs like Damocles’ sword on the accused person or his counsel as the case may be, it would be impossible for either to impugn the conduct of the police.
('47', 103, 3, 8, 198499) Whatever the learned Chief Justice’s experience may be, the experience of the man in the street is, that in a vast number of cases the police story is manufactured, and the growing evil is not in the accused or his counsel, but it is in the police who therefore need to be checked in their excessive zeal to fasten a particular crime upon someone.
('47', 103, 3, 9, 198847) The ordinary policeman is in mortal fear of degradation or dismissal, if he cannot secure convictions.
('47', 103, 3, 10, 198950) It becomes therefore his interest to manufacture a case in the absence of reliable evidence.
('47', 103, 3, 11, 199043) The judge therefore whose duty is to presume the innocence of every accused person coming before him would think twenty times before he puts a single obstacle in his way.
('47', 103, 3, 12, 199214) Where is the lawyer who has not often felt the truth of the statement which he makes but which he is unable to prove?
('47', 103, 3, 13, 199332) And even a Charles Russel will be hard put to it to demonstrate the truth that he feels within himself if for fear of being disbarred in case he fails to prove his charge, he is hampered in the course of his cross examination or examination in chief?
('47', 103, 3, 14, 199583) The Piggot forgeries would never have been proved but for his fiery cross examination.
('47', 103, 3, 15, 199670) A lawyer who believes in the innocence of his client, whether he is prompted by him or no, is bound, in order to discover the truth, to impugn by way of cross examination or otherwise the prosecution story.
('47', 103, 3, 16, 199877) This however is common sense and common law, but both are at a discount in India’s courts of justice.
('47', 103, 3, 17, 199979) When it is a question of the prestige of the Government which in its turn depends upon the prestige of the police, the judges consider it their duty to protect that prestige by turning prosecutors themselves.
('47', 103, 3, 18, 200188) It is sad, but it
('47', 104, 0, 1, 200206) VOL. 47 : 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 105
('47', 104, 1, 2, 200256) is true.
('47', 104, 1, 3, 200265) The Chief Justice of the Patna High Court is to be congratulated upon his boldness in emphasizing the fact.
('47', 104, 1, 4, 200373) Young India, 19 9 1929

('47', 107, 3, 6, 207600) 119. REASON V. FAITH
('47', 107, 4, 7, 207621) I said in my article “Image Worship” 1 that faith begins where reason fails.
('47', 107, 4, 8, 207698) That is to say, faith is beyond reason.
('47', 107, 4, 9, 207738) Many readers argued from this that if faith is beyond reason, it can only be blind.
('47', 107, 4, 10, 207822) My view is just the opposite of this.
('47', 107, 4, 11, 207860) That which is blind cannot be faith.
('47', 107, 4, 12, 207897) If someone asserts with full conviction there are flowers in the sky the assertion cannot be considered valid.
('47', 107, 4, 13, 208008) For the experience of the vast masses of people contradicts it.
('47', 107, 4, 14, 208072) Belief in the existence of flowers in the sky is not faith; it is crass ignorance.
('47', 107, 4, 15, 208155) Whether there are flowers in the sky is something that is amenable to rational inquiry and such an inquiry will prove the falsity of the assertion.
('47', 107, 4, 16, 208303) On the contrary, when we say, “God is”, no one can prove that the proposition is false.
('47', 107, 4, 17, 208391) However hard we might try through reason to disprove the existence of God, some doubt would still remain in the mind of everyone.
('47', 107, 4, 18, 208521) On the other hand the experience of millions proves the existence of God.
('47', 107, 4, 19, 208595) In every matter, faith must be supported by empirical knowledge.
('47', 107, 4, 20, 208660) For ultimately experience is the basis of faith and everyone who has faith must at some time pass through experience.
('47', 107, 4, 21, 208778) He who has faith, however, does not desire experience for true faith does not admit of doubt.
('47', 107, 4, 22, 208872) This does not mean that one having faith becomes dull witted.
('47', 107, 4, 23, 208934) He whose faith is pure always has a sharp wit.
('47', 107, 4, 24, 208981) His reason tells him that faith is higher than experience, that it transcends experience, that it reaches where reason cannot.
('47', 107, 4, 25, 209108) The seat or reason is the mind, that of faith is the heart.
('47', 107, 4, 26, 209168) It has been the uniform experience of man that the heart is a thousand times more
('47', 107, 5, 27, 209250) 1 Vide “Image Workship”, 28 8 1929
('47', 108, 0, 1, 209285) VOL. 47 : 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 109
('47', 108, 1, 2, 209335) potent than the mind.
('47', 108, 1, 3, 209357) Faith makes ships sail; faith makes men do great deeds…even move mountains.
('47', 108, 1, 4, 209433) None can vanquish one who has faith.
('47', 108, 1, 5, 209470) The wise are always afraid of defeat.
('47', 108, 1, 6, 209508) The child Prahlad was perhaps to some extent lacking in intellect but his faith was unshakable as the Meru 1 Faith does not admit of argumentation.
('47', 108, 1, 7, 209656) Therefore the faith of one man is of no use to another man.
('47', 108, 1, 8, 209716) One man with faith will ford a river, while another who blindly follows him will surely be drowned.
('47', 108, 1, 9, 209816) That is why Krishna says in chapter XVII of the Gita: A man is what his faith makes him.
('47', 108, 1, 10, 209905) The faith of Tulsidas was unsurpassed.
('47', 108, 1, 11, 209944) It was his faith that presented to the Hindu world a treasure like Ramayana.
('47', 108, 1, 12, 210021) The Ramayana is a work filled with learning, but the effect of its learning is nothingcompared to the effect of its bhakti.
('47', 108, 1, 13, 210145) Faith and reason belong to two different spheres.
('47', 108, 1, 14, 210195) Faith helps us to cultivate inner knowledge, self knowledge, and thus leads to inner purity.
('47', 108, 1, 15, 210288) Intellect helps us to acquire external knowledge, worldy knowledge, but it has no causal connection with inner purity.
('47', 108, 1, 16, 210407) Men of great intellect are also sometimes the most depraved in character.
('47', 108, 1, 17, 210481) But it is impossible to associate moral depravity with faith.

('47', 108, 1, 20, 210686) The Gita and the Ramacharitmanasa provide the answer.
('47', 108, 1, 21, 210740) It can be had through devotion, through cultivating the company of the good.

('47', 113, 7, 20, 219326) My advice to many has been that they should begin by regarding themselves as trustees oftheir business, and that, while they ran it in this spirit, they should make their personal life plain and simple, maintaining themselves at the least possible expense.

('47', 117, 5, 19, 225215) 135. DOES A VILLAGE MEAN A DUNGHILL?
('47', 117, 6, 20, 225252) Mr. Curtis who toured India in 1918 and who played some role in framing the Montagu Chelmsford reforms has in the course of an article about our villages, said that compared to villages in other countries, Indian villages seemed to be raised on dunghills!
('47', 117, 6, 21, 225508) It is understandable that we do not find this criticism palatable, but no one can deny the truth in it.
('47', 117, 6, 22, 225612) If we approach any village, the very first thing we encounter in the dunghill and this is usually placed on raised ground.
('47', 117, 6, 23, 225735) On entering the village, we find little difference between the approach and what is within the village.
('47', 117, 6, 24, 225839) Here too there is dirt on the roads.
('47', 117, 6, 25, 225876) At any time, children may be found defecating on the streets and in by lanes.
('47', 117, 6, 26, 225954) As for making water, even adults will be found doing it anywhere.
('47', 117, 6, 27, 226020) If a traveller who is unfamiliar with these parts comes across this state of affairs, he will not be able to differentiate between
('47', 118, 0, 1, 226151) VOL. 47 : 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 119
('47', 118, 1, 2, 226201) the dunghill and the residential part.
('47', 118, 1, 3, 226240) As a matter of fact, there is not much of a difference between the two.
('47', 118, 2, 4, 226312) However ancient this habit may be, it is, nevertheless, a bad habit and should be eradicated.
('47', 118, 2, 5, 226406) The Manusmriti and other Hindu religious scriptures, the Koran, the Bible, and the injunctions of Zoroaster…all give detailed suggestions regarding maintaining the cleanliness of roads, courtyards, homes, rivers and wells.
('47', 118, 2, 6, 226629) However, today we are simply disregarding this so much so that there is a good deal of filth to be found even in our places of pilgrimage.
('47', 118, 2, 7, 226768) Perhaps one could say that there is more of it in these places.
('47', 118, 3, 8, 226832) I have seen thousands of men and women dirtying the banks of the Ganga at Hardwar.
('47', 118, 3, 9, 226915) Piligrims defecate at the very spot where people sit, wash their faces, etc., in the Ganga and then again fill their pots at the very same spot.
('47', 118, 3, 10, 227060) I have come across pilgrims defiling lakes in the same manner at places of pilgrimage.
('47', 118, 3, 11, 227147) In doing this we destroy the dharma of compassion and disregard our duty to society.
('47', 118, 4, 12, 227232) Such recklessness leads to pollution of air and water.
('47', 118, 4, 13, 227287) Is it surprising then that cholera, typhoid and other infectious diseases follow as a result of this?
('47', 118, 4, 14, 227389) It is dirty water which is the very source of cholera.
('47', 118, 4, 15, 227444) The same can be largely said of typhoid too.
('47', 118, 4, 16, 227489) It is no exaggeration to say that almost 75 per cent of diseases are caused by our insanitary habits.
('47', 118, 5, 17, 227591) Hence the primary duty of a village worker is to educate villagers in sanitary habits.
('47', 118, 5, 18, 227678) Speeches and leaflets occupy the lowest place in such education.
('47', 118, 5, 19, 227743) This is so because these insanitary habits have taken such deep root that the villagers are not prepared to listen to the volunteers, and, even if they do so, show a singular lack of enthusiasm to act accordingly.
('47', 118, 5, 20, 227957) If leaflets, etc., are distributed, they will surely not read them.
('47', 118, 5, 21, 228025) Many will not even know how to read and, not being inquisitive, those who can read, will not read them out to the others.
('47', 118, 6, 22, 228147) Hence it is the dharma of the volunteers to give object lessons.
('47', 118, 6, 23, 228212) Only if they themselves perform the tasks that have to be performed by the villagers, will the latter follow their example; then doubtless they will positively do so.
('47', 118, 6, 24, 228379) Even so, patience will certainly be required.There is no reason to conclude that people will start doing things on their own just because we have served them for a couple of days.
('47', 119, 0, 1, 228559) 120 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 119, 1, 2, 228601) A volunteer should first of all collect the villagers together and explain their dharma to them.
('47', 119, 1, 3, 228698) And at the same time, he should start cleaning operations, whether or no he can recruit volunteers from amongst the villagers.
('47', 119, 1, 4, 228825) He should obtain from the very village a spade, a basket or a bucket, a broom and a pickaxe.
('47', 119, 1, 5, 228918) If assured that these articles will be returned to them after use, the people will probably not refuse to lend them.
('47', 119, 1, 6, 229035) The volunteers should now inspect the roads and go round to all the places where there are any human excreta.
('47', 119, 1, 7, 229145) They should collect all faeces in their baskets with the help of the spade and cover up those spots; wherever they find that people have urinated, they should collect the wet earth from those spots in those very baskets and throw over it clean earth from the surrounding area.
('47', 119, 1, 8, 229422) If there is any other filth lying around, they should sweep it with the broom and make a heap in one corner and remove it in the same baskets after having diposed of the excreta.
('47', 119, 1, 9, 229601) Where to dump the excreta is an important question.
('47', 119, 1, 10, 229653) It is a question both of cleanliness and of economics.
('47', 119, 1, 11, 229708) If permitted to lie around, the thing emits a foul smell.
('47', 119, 1, 12, 229766) Flies which sit on it and then sit on our bodies or our food spread infectious diseases all round.
('47', 119, 1, 13, 229865) We would give up eating many sweets and other items of food if we examined them with the help of a microscope.
('47', 119, 2, 14, 229976) To the cultivator the dirt is gold.
('47', 119, 2, 15, 230012) If put in the fields, it becomes fine manure and increases the yield.
('47', 119, 2, 16, 230082) The Chinese are experts in this matter and it is said that they save crores of rupees by preserving excreta like gold and, at the same time, avoid the incidence of many diseases.
('47', 119, 3, 17, 230261) Hence the volunteer should explain this matter to cultivators and, if permitted to do so, should bury it in their fields.
('47', 119, 3, 18, 230383) If any farmer, through ignorace, disregard the sanitary methods suggested by the volunteer, the latter should find a spot in the dunghill and bury the excreta there.
('47', 119, 3, 19, 230549) Having completed this task, the volunteers should now approach the garbage heap.
('47', 119, 3, 20, 230630) Garbage is of two types.
('47', 119, 3, 21, 230655) The first is that which is suitable material for manure … such as peels and skins of vegetables, grain, grass, etc.
('47', 119, 3, 22, 230771) The other type includes bits of wood, stones, sheets of iron or tin, etc.
('47', 119, 3, 23, 230845) Of these, the first type should be kept in fields or at places where manure from it can be collected, and the second should be carried and buried at places where pot holes, etc., need to be filled in.

('47', 120, 1, 2, 231096) As a result of this, the village will remain clean and people who walk bare footed will be able to do so fearlessly.

('47', 122, 1, 2, 235696) 136. OX V. BULLOCK
('47', 122, 2, 3, 235715) A young man wants to know why although a bull does not fetch as good a price as a bullock, it is regarded a sin to castrate the bull.
('47', 122, 2, 4, 235849) This question has already been discussed in Navajivan.
('47', 122, 2, 5, 235904) However, many people may not recall it.
('47', 122, 2, 6, 235944) It is a question that arises readily.
('47', 122, 2, 7, 235982) One cannot say that there is no harm involved in castration.
('47', 122, 2, 8, 236043) The Shastras have taught us both our ideal dharma and our practical dharma.
('47', 122, 2, 9, 236119) The latter not only permits castration but enjoins it.
('47', 122, 2, 10, 236174) This is a very ancient custom, as old as the custom of drinking cow’s milk.
('47', 122, 2, 11, 236250) The reader must also be aware that horses and such other domesticated animals are castrated when this is found necessary.
('47', 122, 2, 12, 236372) The facts are as follows.
('47', 122, 2, 13, 236398) All undertakings (or volunatry actions) are tainted, and from this standpoint, castration too is tainted since the calf subjected to it does suffer, however slightly it may be.
('47', 122, 2, 14, 236575) It is tainted again, as the calf has no knowledge of what is done and would prevent it if it could.
('47', 122, 2, 15, 236675) However, we do not seek solutions to such problems by regarding them as matters of absolute dharma.
('47', 122, 2, 16, 236775) Relative dharma does not proceed on a straight path like a railway track.
('47', 122, 2, 17, 236849) It has, on the contrary, to make its way through a dense forest where there is not even a sense of direction.
('47', 122, 2, 18, 236959) Hence in this case, even one step is sufficient.
('47', 122, 2, 19, 237008) Many circumstances have to be considered before the second step is taken and, if the first step is towards the north, the second may have to be taken towards the east.
('47', 122, 2, 20, 237176) In this manner, although the path may appear crooked, since it is the only one which is correct, it can also be regarded as the straight one.
('47', 122, 2, 21, 237318) Nature does not imitate geometry.
('47', 122, 2, 22, 237352) Although natural forms are very beautiful, they do not fit in with geometrical patterns.
('47', 122, 2, 23, 237441) If it is desirable for us to drink cow’s milk and use the bullock for ploughing, it is our dharma to castrate the calf; not doing so would amount to an irreligious act.
('47', 122, 2, 24, 237610) In this manner, something which when regarded independently is the very opposite of dharma, becomes dharma when considered with reference to a given situation.
('47', 122, 2, 25, 237770) If we do not subject calves to castration, do not run dairies, do not conduct tanneries, do not put the bones, hides and intestines, etc., of the cow to practical use and still wish to drink cow’s milk, we shall become beef eaters like the Westerners or, in the alternative, our cattle wealth will be destroyed.
('47', 122, 2, 26, 238082) This latter is taking place today.
('47', 122, 2, 27, 238117) Experienced people are
('47', 123, 0, 1, 238140) 124 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 123, 1, 2, 238182) aware that the cow which decreased the burden of the earth, or in other words, yielded more milk than the quantity of fodder that it consumed, that very cow has become a burden to India.
('47', 123, 1, 3, 238369) In other words,it yields much less in proportion to what it consumes.
('47', 123, 1, 4, 238439) Hence, many persons, through ignorance and carelessness, have started keeping buffaloes and drinking their milk.
('47', 123, 1, 5, 238552) Myriads of cows are sent to Australia for being slaughtered.
('47', 123, 1, 6, 238613) Innumerable cows are slaughtered in India and their beef is exported to Burma.
('47', 123, 1, 7, 238692) Countless others die a premature death.
('47', 123, 1, 8, 238732) No one has the figures of cows which perish in this manner.
('47', 123, 1, 9, 238792) Those that still survive live as if on sufferance.
('47', 123, 1, 10, 238843) They are not given sufficient fodder as they do not yield sufficient milk.
('47', 123, 1, 11, 238918) If we had not become apathetic to our dharma, if we had not been indifferent to it, we would have studied the science of cattle breeding in the same way we study the other sciences and would relinquish those ancient superstitions or ancient practices which have lost their utility or become harmful today.
('47', 123, 1, 12, 239224) For many years now, I have in effect come to the conclusion and have tried to persuade others that it is the dharma of everyone wishing to serve the cow to see to it that those calves which do not belong to the best pedigrees and are therefore not fit to beget cows are castrated while still very young and reared as bullocks.
('47', 123, 1, 13, 239551) It is a sin to disregard the necessary dharma which is in keeping with the times under the pretext of following an imaginary but ideal dharma which is not practicable.
('47', 123, 1, 14, 239719) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 22 9 1929

('47', 130, 5, 15, 251577) 147. A LETTER
('47', 130, 6, 16, 251591) KANPUR, September 23, 1929 I have your question.
('47', 130, 6, 17, 251640) There is on the whole an element of violence in all means.
('47', 130, 6, 18, 251699) But that is unavoidable at present, because the method of punitive law has been practised since ages.
('47', 130, 6, 19, 251801) In trying to reform it at present, we make the principle of means into a fetter.
('47', 130, 6, 20, 251882) When though conforming to many violent customs we are still able to advance dharma a step further, we would certainly say that in spite of the means being faulty the action was on the whole non violent.
('47', 130, 6, 21, 252085) The principle that all undertakings are morally impure applies here.
('47', 130, 6, 22, 252154) It is morally wrong to keep oneself alive by drinking milk, but people have been doing that.
('47', 130, 6, 23, 252247) Hence, if by keeping oneself alive in that way one is able to render real service, the action will count as non violence.
('47', 130, 6, 24, 252369) That is why our forefathers treated the violence of actions performed as part of yajna as non violence.
('47', 130, 6, 25, 252473) Today we clearly see the sin of killing animals and do not regard that act as non violent.
('47', 130, 6, 26, 252564) When society has advanced a step further and eliminated punishment from
('47', 131, 0, 1, 252636) 132 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 131, 1, 2, 252678) law, anyone who gives a place to punishment even in law will be considered guilty of violence.
('47', 131, 1, 3, 252773) Ask me if you have still not followed the point.
('47', 131, 2, 4, 252822) From a copy of the Gujarati: Kusumbehn Desai’s Diary.

('47', 132, 8, 17, 255848) KANPUR, September 23, 1929
('47', 132, 9, 18, 255875) BHAISHRI ISHWARBHAI, The performance of shraddha can be made a purely religious practice.
('47', 132, 9, 19, 255965) Feasting has no place in it.
('47', 132, 9, 20, 255994) Shraddha means remembering the dead, dwelling upon and extolling their good qualities and emulating them.
('47', 132, 9, 21, 256100) This includes everything that the scriptures may have considered beneficial.
('47', 132, 9, 22, 256177) I do not believe that wearing a particular metal can either increase or decrease bodily strength.
('47', 132, 9, 23, 256275) Even if such were the case I would not encourage such possession.
('47', 132, 9, 24, 256341) The events narrated in the Ramayana are not history.
('47', 132, 9, 25, 256394) The poet has included in it whatever he thought instructive.
('47', 132, 9, 26, 256455) The episode of the
('47', 132, 10, 27, 256474) 1 Omissions in the letter are as in the source.

('47', 133, 1, 2, 256564) deer skin could be intended to show that even a woman like Sita could succumb to temptation.
('47', 133, 1, 3, 256657) The deer has often been used as a symbol of craving.
('47', 133, 1, 4, 256710) And it should not be difficult to imagine what can follow once a person yields to temptation.
('47', 133, 1, 5, 256804) That the poet’s description may not conform to our present ideas of morality is another matter.
('47', 133, 1, 6, 256900) The Ramayana cannot be judged by picking out isolated incidents and condemning them.
('47', 133, 1, 7, 256985) It can be judged only by the effect it has had and still has on the people.
('47', 133, 1, 8, 257061) One should remember that man is happy or unhappy as a consequence of his previous actions.
('47', 133, 1, 9, 257152) But this law is not meant to make men callous.
('47', 133, 1, 10, 257199) Just as man reaps the fruits of his previous actions, his present actions will also bear fruit.
('47', 133, 1, 11, 257295) Hence, a process of addition, subtraction, multiplication and division is continuously going on.
('47', 133, 1, 12, 257392) The process is influenced by the actions of others as much as by one’s own.

('47', 137, 1, 2, 263825) 155. SPEECH TO STUDENTS, KANPUR 1
('47', 137, 2, 3, 263859) September 24, 1929
('47', 137, 3, 4, 263878) MAHATMAJI, REPLYING, SAID:
('47', 137, 4, 5, 263905) The words in which you have indicated your affection would be most welcome only if all the students that are present here have room in their hearts.
('47', 137, 4, 6, 264054) But I am afraid this is only the spirit of the speakers and, if that is true, then those words have not the same value.
('47', 137, 4, 7, 264174) All religions have preached self control as the first step towards progress.
('47', 137, 5, 8, 264251) Pointing to the students, he said they were self willed, but had no purity.
('47', 137, 6, 9, 264327) roaming amongst thousands of students, he had come to the conclusion that unless
('47', 137, 7, 10, 264408) they had real purity and simplicity of heart, all institutions like the Young League,
('47', 137, 8, 11, 264494) etc., would be of no use.
('47', 137, 8, 12, 264520) His 45 years’ experience told him that without it people
('47', 137, 9, 13, 264577) were useless.
('47', 137, 9, 14, 264591) The students had desire, but that alone did not help in the matter.
('47', 137, 10, 15, 264659) Further, Mahatmaji compared the students to a person addicted to drugs, who
('47', 137, 11, 16, 264735) under their influence spoke in plenty and showed various activities, but, when back to
('47', 137, 12, 17, 264822) the normal state, did not amount to anything.
('47', 137, 12, 18, 264868) Mahatmaji made a reference to the
('47', 137, 13, 19, 264902) absence of the students of the Agriculture College, whom he called cowards because
('47', 137, 14, 20, 264985) they allowed themselves to be confined even when they did not like the orders, but
('47', 137, 15, 21, 265068) got ready to obey them because fear dominated their hearts, lest they might lose some
('47', 137, 16, 22, 265154) job of Rs. 50 after finishing their studies.
('47', 137, 17, 23, 265199) Pointing to the students present, he said: “You must have done the same if
('47', 137, 18, 24, 265274) your Principal gave a similar order.” He begged to be excused for being plain and
('47', 137, 19, 25, 265356) asked, if he was not plain to them, to whom would he be so?

('47', 145, 5, 22, 283743) 160. TWO VALUES OF A RUPEE
('47', 145, 6, 23, 283770) It is remarkable but true how the value of a coin varies in accordance with the way in which it is used.
('47', 145, 6, 24, 283875) If you spend a rupee in buying a death dealing instrument for murdering someone, that rupee is dipped in blood, worthy only to be thrown away, whereas if you spend that same rupee for buying food for a starving man it may mean life to him.
('47', 145, 6, 25, 284115) The rupee so spent is thus charged with life giving properties.
('47', 145, 6, 26, 284179) The one has earned hell for the user, the other has brought heaven nearer to its user.
('47', 145, 6, 27, 284266) Similarly every rupee spent in purchasing khadi according to the calculations carefully worked out by the Foreign Cloth Boycott Committee brings relief to the starving.
('47', 145, 6, 28, 284435) It is distributed as follows:

('47', 146, 3, 11, 285497) 161. SIMPLIFYING MARRIAGE
('47', 146, 4, 12, 285523) A correspondent sends me an account of a marriage ceremony performed in Karachi.
('47', 146, 4, 13, 285604) At the time of the marriage of a girl 16 years old, the daughter of a moneyed man Sheth Lalchand, the father is reported to have curtailed the expenditure to a minimum and given the marriage ceremonial a religious and dignified form.
('47', 146, 4, 14, 285838) The report before me shows that the whole ceremony did not take more than two hours, whereas generally it involves a wasteful expenditure spread over many days.
('47', 146, 4, 15, 285999) The religious ceremony was performed by a learned Brahmin who explained to the bride and the bridegroom the meaning of what they were called upon to recite.
('47', 146, 4, 16, 286156) I congratulate Sheth Lalchand and his wife who actively supported her husband upon initiating this belated reform, and hope that it will be copied largely
('47', 147, 0, 1, 286311) 148 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 147, 1, 2, 286353) by other moneyed men.
('47', 147, 1, 3, 286375) Khadi lovers will be glad to know that Sheth Lalchand and his wife are thorough believers in khadi, and that both the bride and the bridegroom were clothed in khadi and are themselves convinced khadi wearers.
('47', 147, 1, 4, 286584) This marriage ceremony calls to my mind the scene I witnessed at the Agra students’ meeting.
('47', 147, 1, 5, 286677) 1 They confirmed the information that was given to me by a friend, that in the United Provinces young men studying in the colleges and schools were themselves eager to be married early, and expected their parents to go in for a lavish expenditure involving costly gifts, and equally costly and sometimes even more costly entertainments.
('47', 147, 1, 6, 287014) My informant told me that even highly educated parents were not free from the pride of possession, and that so far as expenses went they beat the Comparatively uneducated wealthy merchants.
('47', 147, 1, 7, 287204) To all such the recent example of Sheth Lalchand and the less recent example of Sheth Jamnalal Bajaj should serve as a stimulus in cutting down expenditure.
('47', 147, 1, 8, 287361) But moe than the parents it is the duty of young men firmly to resist premature marriage, more especially marriage during student life, and at all cost to resist all expenditure.
('47', 147, 1, 9, 287540) Indeed not more than Rs. 10 should be required for the performance of the religious ceremonial, and nothing beyond the ceremonial should be considered a necessary part of marriage rites.
('47', 147, 1, 10, 287727) In this age of democracy, when the distinction between the rich and the poor, the high and the low, is sought to be abolished, it is for the rich to lead the poor to a contented life by exercising self restraint in all their enjoyments and indulgences, and let them remember the verse in the Bhagavad Gita, “Whatever leaders of society do, the others will follow.” 2 The truth of this statement we see daily verified in our experience, and nowhere more vividly than in marriage ceremonies and rites in connection with the dead.
('47', 147, 1, 11, 288255) Thousands of poor people deprive themselves for this purpose of necessaries of life, and burden themselves with debts carrying ruinous rates of interest.
('47', 147, 1, 12, 288409) This waste of national resources can be easily stopped if the educated youths of the country, especially sons of rich parents, will resolutely set their faces against every form of wasteful expenditure on their account.

('47', 148, 1, 2, 288756) 162 REASON V. AUTHORITY
('47', 148, 2, 3, 288780) A correspondent has sent me the September number of Prabuddha Bharata in which the editor has answered my endeavour to reply to his recent articles on the cult of charkha and khadi.
('47', 148, 2, 4, 288962) If that answer has satisfied the editor and satisfied the reader, I cannot carry my own arguments any further, and must leave the final answer to time and experience.
('47', 148, 2, 5, 289129) But one thing in the editorial reply deserves notice.
('47', 148, 2, 6, 289183) The editor questions the propriety of my remark that “the inferential invocation of the authority of the illustrious dead in a reasoned discussion should be regarded as a sacrilege”.
('47', 148, 2, 7, 289366) The editor resents this, more specially because Prabuddha Bharata is an organ of Swami Vivekananda’s order.
('47', 148, 2, 8, 289474) I must however adhere to my statement.
('47', 148, 2, 9, 289513) I think that the duty of avoiding in a reasoned discussion inferences from the writings of the founder of an order devolves more specifically upon its members and its organ, for to sceptics the authority of the founder will be of no avail, even as the authority of Shri Krishna is of no use to one who is not his follower.
('47', 148, 2, 10, 289836) And experience has shown that in every case where there is an appeal to reason, any inference drawn from the writings of a great person, however illustrious he may be, is irrelevant and calculated to confuse the issues at stake.
('47', 148, 2, 11, 290065) I would like the editor and the reader to note also that I have not criticized the citing of the specific writings of great men, but I have suggested the impropriety of drawing deductions from their writings instead of leaving the reader to draw his own from such writings.
('47', 148, 2, 12, 290339) Thus, for instance, have not the so called Christians distorted the undiluted message of Jesus?
('47', 148, 2, 13, 290435) Have not sceptics drawn opposite deductions from the identical sayings of Jesus?
('47', 148, 2, 14, 290516) Similarly have not different Vaishnavite sections drawn different and often opposite deductions from the same texts in the Bhagavad Gita, and is not the Bhagavad Gita today quoted in support even of assassination?
('47', 148, 2, 15, 290730) To me it is as plain as a pikestaff that where there is an appeal to reason pure and undefiled, there should be no appeal to authority however great it may be.
('47', 148, 2, 16, 290890) Curiously the correspondent who has sent me the Prabuddha Bharata has also sent me two apposite quotations from Sister Nivedita’s writings.
('47', 148, 2, 17, 291030) Here they are:
('47', 148, 3, 18, 291045) Like others, he (Vivekananda) had accepted without thought the assumption that machinery would be a boon to agriculture, but he could now see that while the American farmer, with his several square miles to farm, might be the better for
('47', 149, 0, 1, 291282) 150 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 149, 1, 2, 291324) machines, they were likely to do little but harm on the tiny farmlands of the Indian peasantry.
('47', 149, 1, 3, 291420) The problem was quite different in the two cases.
('47', 149, 1, 4, 291470) Of that alone he was firmly convinced.
('47', 149, 1, 5, 291509) In everything including the problem of distribution, he listened with suspicion to all arguments that would work for the elimination of small interests, appearing in this as in so many other things as the perfect, though unconcious, expression of the spirit of the old Indian civilization (The Master as I Saw Him, p.231)
('47', 149, 2, 6, 291831) His (Vivekananda’s) American disciples were already familiar with his picture…that called to his own face a dreamy delight…of the Punjabi maiden at her spinning wheel listening to its ‘Shivoham Shivoham’ (Ibid, p.
('47', 149, 2, 7, 292045) 95) Whether these extracts correctly represent the master or not is more than I can say.

('47', 149, 4, 9, 292157) 163. NOTES
('47', 149, 5, 10, 292168) THE BAN ON THE ALI BROTHERS The following cable, which I have extended, has been received by me from the Secretaries of the South African Indian Congress:
('47', 149, 6, 11, 292323) At an emergency Executive meeting held at Durban on the situation arising out of restrictions imposed upon the Ali Brothers’ contemplated visit to the Union by the Union Government, the subject occupied the earnest consideration of the Committee and the following resolution was passed:
('47', 149, 7, 12, 292610) “South African Indian Congress Executive as representing the Indian community of South Africa deeply deplores conditions imposed by the Union Government upon the contemplated visit of the Ali Brothers to the Union, and hereby requests the Agent of the Government of India to take all the necessary steps for the removal of all such conditions.”
('47', 149, 8, 13, 292955) We know now what the result of the Agent’s intervention has been.
('47', 149, 8, 14, 293021) the obstinate refusal of the Union Government to waive the restrictions, especially in view of the unsolicited and gentlemanly assurance of the Ali Brothers not to engage in any political controversy or discussion during their sojourn in South Africa, shows in what estimate even the Government of India is held by the Union Government.
('47', 149, 8, 15, 293358) That estimate will persist so long as the Government of India is an irresponsible Government and therefore remains a body whose wishes can be flouted with impunity by any foreign Government, whether it may be one occupying the Dominion Status
('47', 150, 0, 1, 293601) VOL. 47 : 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 151
('47', 150, 1, 2, 293651) or one wholly unconnected with Great Britain.
('47', 150, 1, 3, 293697) I fear that we will have to submit to such humiliations so long as we, through our own disunion, dissensions and the like, remain impotent and powerless to help ourselves.
('47', 150, 2, 4, 293869) THEY KNOW
('47', 150, 3, 5, 293879) It has often been said that khadi propaganda means harm to the mill industry, and this has been said even by some Congressmen who should know better.
('47', 150, 3, 6, 294029) Of course so far as I am concerned, khadi should hold the field even though it might ostensibly damage the mill industry; surely the vital welfare of the starving millions should have predominance over the material advancement of the few rich people.
('47', 150, 3, 7, 294280) But as a matter of fact khadi propaganda has not only done no harm to the mill industry but it has resulted in demonstrable advantage to that great industry.
('47', 150, 3, 8, 294438) The confirmation of this view comes from no less a source than Mr. J.A. Wadia who, when asked at shareholders’ meeting, “whether khaddar propaganda had in any way affected the sale of Indian mill made cloth”, as chairman, promptly replied that ‘he was absolutely in favour of khaddar’.
('47', 150, 3, 9, 294724) He added that ‘it was owing to khaddar that their consumption of locally made yarn had gone up considerably.
('47', 150, 3, 10, 294833) Mahatma Gandhi was not against Indian mill cloth.
('47', 150, 3, 11, 294883) His propaganda was benefiting the mill industry.’ I hope that this unsolicited testimony will dispel the suspicion working in the minds of many that khadi had damaged the indigenous mill industry.
('47', 150, 3, 12, 295080) A little reflection will show that it can do no damage to the mill industry for the simple reason that against the crores of rupees worth of cloth that the mills produce annually the All India Spinners’ Association can show no more than 30 lakhs.
('47', 150, 3, 13, 295327) But the khadi propaganda has produced in the people a love for swadeshi on a scale unknown before, and it has resulted in preference being given by the poor villagers to indigenous mill cloth over foreign cloth.
('47', 150, 3, 14, 295539) But the reader may note what many mills have done to khadi.
('47', 150, 3, 15, 295599) They have unscrupulously and unfairly resorted to the manufacture of coarse cloth, and have not felt ashamed even to label it khadi with the pictures of the charkha printed upon that spurious stuff.
('47', 150, 3, 16, 295798) This is the return some of them have made khadi for the swadeshi spirit it has been instrumental in infusing amongst the people.
('47', 151, 0, 1, 295927) 152 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 151, 1, 2, 295969) LOOSE THINKING A correspondent writes:
('47', 151, 2, 3, 296008) In the course of an article you have said at one place: “Where marriage is a sacrament, the union is not the union of bodies but the union of souls indissoluble even by the death of either party.

('47', 151, 3, 5, 296316) At another place in the course of the same article you say: ‘I consider remarriage of virgin widows not only desirable but the bounden duty of all parents who happen to have such widowed daughters.’ How do you reconcile the two views?
('47', 151, 4, 6, 296551) I find no difficulty in reconciling the two views.
('47', 151, 4, 7, 296602) In the giving away of a little girl by ignorant or heartless parents without considering the welfare of the child and without her knowledge and consent there is no marriage at all.
('47', 151, 4, 8, 296783) Certainly it is not a sacrament and therefore remarriage of such a girl becomes a duty.
('47', 151, 4, 9, 296871) As a matter of fact, the word ‘remarriage’ is a misnomer in such cases.
('47', 151, 4, 10, 296943) The virgin was never married at all in the true sense, and therefore on the death of her supposed husband it would be the most natural thing, it will be a duty, for the parents to seek for her a suitable companion in life.

('47', 164, 2, 3, 320007) September 28, 1929 I know my name was proposed and elected by a majority of votes, but I find myself quite unfit for such a heavy responsibility, though it is a great honour.
('47', 164, 2, 4, 320182) I, therefore, utilize this opportunity to explain to you that it is my weakness indeed that I am shrinking from it and the same I have explained so many times through Young India.
('47', 164, 2, 5, 320362) What I felt most was for Pt. Malaviya who had no mind to come over here.
('47', 164, 2, 6, 320435) His mission in coming over to this place was only to persuade me, but I find that he is going back dejected.
('47', 164, 2, 7, 320544) While I do not want to undertake this responsibility, I do not mean that I shall keep myself aloof from the Congress programme.
('47', 164, 2, 8, 320672) Suggestions have come from certain quarters that if I do not accept it, I shall commit another unprecedented mistake.
('47', 164, 2, 9, 320790) Anyhow I could not be convinced, and my conscience does not permit me to shoulder the responsibility.
('47', 164, 2, 10, 320892) I assure you that in every programme adopted by you at the Lahore Congress, I would be with you.
('47', 164, 2, 11, 320989) I feel I can do more work by not becoming the President of this year’s Congress and I assure the house that I am firm on my words of responsibility that I gave at Calcutta.
('47', 164, 2, 12, 321162) This crown, though, the thorny crown of the Congress, is unacceptable to everyone.

('47', 166, 1, 5, 324237) The bride should in fact be a child.
('47', 166, 1, 6, 324274) There is no help if the bride, although young as compared to the bridegroom, is mature enough to understand the situation and has married him of her own free will.
('47', 166, 1, 7, 324438) There are such young women who, being tempted by wealth, sell their virginity to old men and then commit misdeeds.
('47', 166, 1, 8, 324553) Who can deal with them?
('47', 166, 1, 9, 324577) Measures can be adopted only in cases where the bride is a child, not old enough to understand, and where the father or some other guardian has sold her solely for money.
('47', 166, 1, 10, 324748) Old men will stop looking for child brides where young men can prevent one or two such instances and the former can satisfy their desires by searching out mature widows.
('47', 166, 1, 11, 324918) The second question is as follows: 1
('47', 166, 2, 12, 324955) Speculation clearly constitutes gambling and does not benefit the public at all.
('47', 166, 2, 13, 325036) There is no doubt that it adversely affects business.
('47', 166, 2, 14, 325090) Wealth gained through speculation is like wealth obtained by theft.Public opinion should be cultivated in order to prohibit speculation.
('47', 166, 2, 15, 325227) This is a very ancient corrupt practice and has become widespread today.
('47', 166, 2, 16, 325300) It will continue in one form or another so long as the human race does not give up greed.
('47', 166, 2, 17, 325390) Young men will be unable to cope with all the evils in the world, but much can be achieved if they themselves become pure.
('47', 166, 2, 18, 325513) Now the third question: 2
('47', 166, 3, 19, 325539) A bridegrooms party of this kind is as fit to be abandoned as a caste feast.
('47', 166, 3, 20, 325616) It is a useless expense and is detrimental to the solemnity of the religious ceremony.
('47', 166, 3, 21, 325703) Young men who are about to marry should oppose firmly both the feast and the marriage party consisting of the bridegroom’s relatives.
('47', 166, 4, 22, 325837) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 29 9 1929
('47', 166, 5, 23, 325874) 1 This is not translated here.
('47', 166, 5, 24, 325905) It referred to the fact that educated young men took up jobs with speculators despite their dislike of this form of gambling, but later themselves engaged in private speculation.
('47', 166, 5, 25, 326084) 2 This is not translated here.
('47', 166, 5, 26, 326115) It related to the propriety of holding wedding feasts and of large numbers joining the bridegroom’s party.

('47', 167, 1, 2, 326264) 182. MY NOTES
('47', 167, 2, 3, 326278) FASTING OR TRUE CONDUCT?
('47', 167, 2, 4, 326303) A reader writes to say: 1
('47', 167, 3, 5, 326329) It seems that this association has not examined the consequences of fasting and truthful conduct.
('47', 167, 3, 6, 326427) Otherwise this question would not have arisen.
('47', 167, 3, 7, 326474) Fasting has no independent power to control one’s emotions.
('47', 167, 3, 8, 326534) These are often found to have become enfeebled in an individual who is fasting.
('47', 167, 3, 9, 326614) Those who fast on the Ekadashi and such other occasions, become so ill tempered during these fasts that those around them shudder to approach them.
('47', 167, 3, 10, 326762) Had there been any independent power in fasting which would lead one to restrain one’s emotions, many persons who die of starvation would have been blessed long ago.
('47', 167, 3, 11, 326928) It could indeed be claimed, however, that anyone who wishes to restrain his emotions would derive some … however little … help from fasting.Truthful conduct, however, is the best means of restraining one’s emotions.
('47', 167, 3, 12, 327144) It has unlimited power to control one’s emotions and this power never fails to bring about results.
('47', 167, 3, 13, 327244) Hence fasting cannot be compared to truth at all.
('47', 167, 3, 14, 327294) Anyone who is not truthful cannot succeed in controlling his emotions, whereas anyone who is truthful can readily exercise control over his emotions.
('47', 167, 3, 15, 327444) One cannot help doing so while practising truth.
('47', 167, 3, 16, 327493) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 29 9 1929
('47', 167, 4, 17, 327530) 183. NOTE TO JAYKRISHNA BHANSALI
('47', 167, 5, 18, 327563) September 29, 1929 Even the trees and plants converse with a person who is wholly devoted to God, for he sees Him and His sport even in these.
('47', 167, 5, 19, 327706) We have not understood all this joy of bhakti.
('47', 167, 5, 20, 327753) If we understand it, the beauty of bhakti would immeidately be heightened for us.
('47', 167, 6, 21, 327835) [From Gujarati]
('47', 167, 7, 22, 327851) Bapuna Patro 7: Shri Chhaganlal Joshine, p.164

('47', 168, 1, 2, 328247) 184. SPEECH AT LUCKNOW
('47', 168, 2, 3, 328270) September 29, 1929 Mahatmaji performed the National Flag hoisting ceremony this morning in the Municipal Hall.
('47', 168, 2, 4, 328381) After the ceremony was over, Mahatmaji begged pardon of the public for the delay in his coming.
('47', 168, 2, 5, 328477) I am grateful for the honour you have done me in giving me this opportunity but I would ask you to understand the full significance of this tri coloured flag.
('47', 168, 2, 6, 328636) It is not merely a piece of khadi without any meaning.
('47', 168, 2, 7, 328691) The red colour in the flag signifies sacrifice, the while, purity and the green, hope.
('47', 168, 2, 8, 328778) The three colours stand for one ideal, that of unity.
('47', 168, 2, 9, 328832) It is the duty of the citizens to see that when once it is unfurled, it should never be allowed to drop down.
('47', 168, 3, 10, 328942) The Bombay Chronicle, 30 9 1929

('47', 170, 9, 17, 331993) LUCKNOW,
('47', 170, 10, 18, 332002) September 30, 1929
('47', 170, 11, 19, 332021) Devdas gave me the news about your father’s death.
('47', 170, 11, 20, 332072) I thought of writing to your immediately, but before I could do so the matter went out of my mind.
('47', 170, 11, 21, 332171) I soon recover from the shock which death gives me, and console others so that they, too, may do the same.
('47', 170, 11, 22, 332278) I see more clearly day by day that there is no difference at all between birth and death.
('47', 170, 11, 23, 332368) The two are aspects of the same state and we keep on passing from one to the other.
('47', 170, 11, 24, 332452) I have often watched mice playing such a game.
('47', 170, 11, 25, 332499) In the prison cell I had to do the same thing myself.
('47', 170, 11, 26, 332553) I used to walk fro one walled side to the other and back again.
('47', 170, 11, 27, 332617) So, then, which side did I leave and to which did I move?
('47', 170, 11, 28, 332675) I have been talking philosophy, but it is full of truth and you should draw from it as much
('47', 171, 0, 1, 332767) 172 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 171, 1, 2, 332809) consolation as you can.
('47', 171, 1, 3, 332833) In any case, time is doing its work of erasing all memories.
('47', 171, 1, 4, 332894) Were it not so, God knows in what plight we would have been.
('47', 171, 1, 5, 332955) [From Gujarati] Bapuni Prasadi, pp.

('47', 173, 2, 3, 334678) LUCKNOW, Silence Day [September 30, 1929] 1
('47', 173, 3, 4, 334722) PRABHUDAS, I got both your letters.

('47', 173, 3, 11, 335146) The rule that, despite illness, one should go on doing one’s best at a place where it is one’s special duty to serve, does not apply to you.
('47', 173, 3, 12, 335287) It was so for Maganlal in regard to the Ashram.
('47', 173, 3, 13, 335335) It was his dharma to die 2 serving the Ashram, which he fufilled to perfection and I believe that, in that way, he in a large measure gave new life to the example of Bharat.
('47', 173, 3, 14, 335509) If such a time comes for you, we will consider what you should do.
('47', 173, 3, 15, 335576) If you feel the slightest inclination to take an injection, you need not at all consider what I would desire.
('47', 173, 3, 16, 335686) In such matters, one’s own inclination is the only thing that matters.
('47', 173, 3, 17, 335757) If this does not cover answers to all your questions, ask me again.
('47', 173, 4, 18, 335825) Blessings from BAPU

('47', 178, 1, 2, 342976) 199. THE HINDU WIFE
('47', 178, 2, 3, 342996) The following 1 is a summary of a long letter of a brother describing the miseries of his married sister: Some time ago my sister was married to a man whose character was hidden from us.
('47', 178, 2, 4, 343183) This man has been discovered to be a rake ...
('47', 178, 2, 5, 343229) She remonstrated.
('47', 178, 2, 6, 343247) The man could not brook this ...
('47', 178, 2, 7, 343280) My sister is heart broken.
('47', 178, 2, 8, 343307) We are helpless.
('47', 178, 2, 9, 343324) What would you advise her and us to do?
('47', 178, 2, 10, 343364) This is one of the most shameful aspects of Hinduism, where woman is left entirely at the mercy of man and has no rights and privileges.
('47', 178, 2, 11, 343501) Thousands of such women are groaning and weeping.
('47', 178, 2, 12, 343551) As long as Hinduism is not purged of these and such like evils, can there be any hope of progress?
('47', 178, 3, 13, 343650) The writer is an educated man.
('47', 178, 3, 14, 343681) His is a much more graphic description than the summary is of his sister’s distress.
('47', 178, 3, 15, 343766) The correspondent has sent me his full name and address.
('47', 178, 3, 16, 343823) His condemnation of Hinduism, though pardonable under intense irritation, is based on a hysterical generalization from an isolated instance.
('47', 178, 3, 17, 343964) For millions of Hindu wives live in perfect peace and are queens in their own homes.
('47', 178, 3, 18, 344049) They exercise an authority over their husbands which any woman would envy.
('47', 178, 3, 19, 344124) It is an authority which love gives.
('47', 178, 3, 20, 344161) The case of cruelty brought to light by the correspondent is an illustration not of the evil in Hinduism, but of the evil in human nature which has been known to express itself under all climes and among people professing different faiths of the world.
('47', 178, 3, 21, 344414) The facility for divorce has proved no protection against a brutal husband for a plaint wife incapable of asserting and at times even unwilling to assert herself.
('47', 178, 3, 22, 344577) It is therefore in the interest of reform for reformers to avoid hysterics and exaggerations.
('47', 178, 4, 23, 344671) Nevertheless the occurrence to which this article draws attention is not an altogether uncommon occurrence in Hindu society.
('47', 178, 4, 24, 344796) Hindu culture has erred on the side of excessive subordination of the wife to the husband, and has insisted on the complete merging of the wife in the husband.
('47', 178, 4, 25, 344956) This has resulted in the husband sometimes usurping and exercising authority that reduces him to the level of the brute.
('47', 178, 5, 26, 345077) 1 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('47', 179, 0, 1, 345114) 180 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 179, 1, 2, 345156) The remedy for such excesses therefore lies not through the law but through the true education of women as distinguished from unmarried girls, and through cultivating public opinion against unmanly conduct on the part of husbands.
('47', 179, 1, 3, 345387) In the case in point the remedy is incredibly simple.
('47', 179, 1, 4, 345441) Instead of the brother and other relatives feeling helpless and weeping with the distressed girl, they should clothe her with protection, educate her to believe that it is no part of her duty to placate a sinful husband or to seek his company.
('47', 179, 1, 5, 345685) It is quite evident that the husband himself does not care for the wife.
('47', 179, 1, 6, 345758) She may therefore without breaking the legal tie live apart from her husband’s roof and feel as if she had never been married.
('47', 179, 1, 7, 345885) Of course there are two legal remedies open even to a Hindu wife for whom a divorce is unobtainable, and that is to have the husband punished for common assault and to insist upon his supporting the wife.
('47', 179, 1, 8, 346090) Experience tells me that this remedy is in most cases if not in all worse than useless, and it never brings any comfort to a virtuous woman and makes the question of husband’s reform more difficult if not impossible which after all should be the aim of society, more so of every wife.
('47', 179, 1, 9, 346375) In the present instance the girl’s parents are well able to support her but where it is not possible, the number of institutions that would shelter to such ill treated women is growing in the country.
('47', 179, 1, 10, 346576) There still remains the question of the satisfaction of the sexual appetite on the part of young women thus leaving the inhospitable roofs of their husbands or being actually deserted by them when the relief given by divorce is unobtainable.
('47', 179, 1, 11, 346818) But this is really not a serious grievance in point of numbers, for in a society in which custom has discountenanced divorce for ages, a woman whose marriage proves unhappy does not want to be remarried.
('47', 179, 1, 12, 347022) When public opinion in any social group requires that particular form of relief, I have no doubt that it will be forthcoming.
('47', 179, 1, 13, 347148) So far as I understand the correspondent’s letter, the grievance is not that the wife cannot satisfy her sexual appetite.
('47', 179, 1, 14, 347270) The grievance is not that the wife cannot satisfy her sexual appetite.
('47', 179, 1, 15, 347341) The grievance the gross and defiant immorality on the part of the husband.
('47', 179, 1, 16, 347416) For this, as I have said, the remedy lies in a revision of the mental attitude.
('47', 179, 1, 17, 347496) The feeling of helplessness is imaginary as most of our ills are.
('47', 179, 1, 18, 347562) A fresh outlook, a little original thinking, is enough to dispel the grief brought about by defective imagination.
('47', 179, 1, 19, 347677) Nor should friends, and relatives in such cases be satisfied with the mere negative result of isolating the victim from the zone of tyranny.
('47', 179, 1, 20, 347818) She should be induced to qualify herself for public service.

('47', 180, 2, 4, 348060) 200. THE THOUSAND HEADED MONSTER
('47', 180, 3, 5, 348093) The monster of untouchability shows his deadly fangs from his thousand mouths nowhere more persistently than in the South.
('47', 180, 3, 6, 348216) Thus writes a correspondent from that quarter:
('47', 180, 4, 7, 348263) Whereas it has been apprehended in orthodox circles that the preachers of untouchability are apt to confound the issues and implications involved in the principle by an attempt to push it to an undue extent so as to create unnecessary friction, I wish to elicit from you a definite pronouncement as regards the scope and extent of untouchability, in the light of the undermentioned observations offered in the form of questions.
('47', 180, 5, 8, 348692) Though I do not think that the “preachers of untouchability”or rather of anti untouchability have done anything so as to create any avoidable friction, it is best to deal with the questions that often arise even in the minds of men who are not in any way mischievously inclined, and who would, if they could, endorse the anti untouchability movement but who are unknowingly to themselves obsessed by agelong prejudices.
('47', 180, 5, 9, 349112) The correspondent’s first question is:
('47', 180, 6, 10, 349151) Do you think that the principles of varnashrama dharma are inconsistent with the formation of Indian nationality?
('47', 180, 7, 11, 349265) In the first place, varnashrama has nothing to do with untouchability or with castes as we know them today.
('47', 180, 7, 12, 349373) In the second place, varnashrama, as I know it, is in no way inconsistent with the growth of Indian nationality.
('47', 180, 7, 13, 349486) On the contrary if it has the meaning that I have given to it, it is calculated to promote a truly national spirit.
('47', 180, 7, 14, 349602) The second question is:
('47', 180, 8, 15, 349626) Do you think that sins of touch and sight are of Vedic origin?
('47', 180, 9, 16, 349689) Though I cannot speak with authority based on first hand knowledge, I have full confidence in the purity of the Vedas, and therefore have no hesitation in asserting that the sins of touch and sight have no support in the Vedas, but scholars like Sjt.
('47', 180, 9, 17, 349940) C.V. Vaidya and Pandit Satavalekar can speak with much greater authority than I can lay claim to.
('47', 180, 9, 18, 350038) I would, however, add that no matter what is credited
('47', 181, 0, 1, 350092) 182 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 181, 1, 2, 350134) with Vedic origin, if it is repugnant to the moral sense, it must the summarily rejected as contrary to the spirit of the Vedas, and perhaps what is more, as contrary to fundamental ethics.
('47', 181, 1, 3, 350324) The next four questions may be condensed as follows: Don’t you think that the karmakanda is based upon a knowledge of the laws of magnetism, and that the rules regarding touch and sight, birth pollution and death pollution are intended for the purification of the mind?
('47', 181, 1, 4, 350594) In so far as they are so intended, they have a certain relative value, but the Vedas, the Upanishads, the Puranas and all the other Shastras as also the other religion of the world proclaim in no uncertain terms that purification of the mind is an inward process, and that the magnetism produced by the inter action of physical bodies is nothing compared to the other subtle magnetism of mind upon mind, and the outward purificatory rites become soul destroying, when they result in making man arrogate to himself superiority over fellow human beings and in making him treat them virtually as beasts or even less.
('47', 181, 1, 5, 351208) The seventh question is:
('47', 181, 2, 6, 351233) Do you think that the procedure adopted by jivanmuktas, that is those who have in the present body attained salvation, who are above rules of the do and don’t, are conducive to the spiritual growth of ordinary folk?
('47', 181, 3, 7, 351449) I do not think that anybody, however highly evolved he may be, who lives on the earth and among earthly beings, can be himself above the obligations binding on common mortals, and therefore these rules have to appeal to reason and must never be allowed to crush the spirit within.
('47', 181, 3, 8, 351730) The rules about untouchability have been demonstrated and can be demonstrated to be injurious to the growth of the spirit, and they are wholly contrary to all that is best and noblest in Hinduism.
('47', 181, 3, 9, 351927) Then the question is:
('47', 181, 4, 10, 351949) Do you not believe in varna dharma?
('47', 181, 5, 11, 351985) I do in the manner often explained in these pages.
('47', 181, 5, 12, 352036) In my opinion varna dharma has nothing to do with untouchability or superiority of one division over another.
('47', 181, 5, 13, 352146) The next question is:
('47', 181, 6, 14, 352168) Exceptions to untouchability are contained in the following verse:
('47', 182, 0, 1, 352235) VOL. 47 : 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 183
('47', 182, 1, 2, 352285) “Auspicious occasions, pilgrimages, political agitations, occasions of fright or fear, festive occasions of deities, poverty.” These exceptions go to prove the rule.
('47', 182, 1, 3, 352451) Will you please press this authority into your service and prescribe a limit to it?
('47', 182, 2, 4, 352535) The wise man who conceived this verse has taken in the broad sweep of his exceptions every conceivable occasion.
('47', 182, 2, 5, 352648) I would, therefore, like the protagonists of untouchability to present the reader of Young India with occasions which will not be covered by fright or fear, poverty or auspicious occasions.
('47', 182, 2, 6, 352838) And this correspondent has also not seen the terrible poverty of thought of those who hug untouchability in that in the various provinces sanction for untouchability merely rests upon tradition.
('47', 182, 2, 7, 353033) No one has yet given an intelligent definition of ‘untouchable’, ‘unseeable’ and ‘unapproa chable’.
('47', 182, 2, 8, 353133) The last question is: In the attempt to spiritualize politics, what is the limit to which you want to relegate untouchability?
('47', 182, 3, 9, 353260) There is no limit.
('47', 182, 3, 10, 353279) The very beginning of spiritualization of politics rests in the banishing, root and branch, of untouchability as it is practised today.
('47', 182, 3, 11, 353415) Untouchability attaching to birth or a calling is an atrocious doctrine repugnant to the religious sense of man.
('47', 182, 4, 12, 353528) Young India, 3 10 1929

('47', 187, 1, 2, 362430) 206. LETTER TO M. HINDHEDE
('47', 187, 2, 3, 362457) CAMP AZAMGARH, October 3, 1929
('47', 187, 3, 4, 362488) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your letter and your pamphlets.
('47', 187, 3, 5, 362549) 1 I am sorry to have to inform you that my experiment having apparently proved a failure I had to suspend it for a more auspicious occasion when I could have more leisure.
('47', 187, 3, 6, 362721) I must confess that I have not yet found the substitute for milk.
('47', 187, 3, 7, 362787) I have been recommended soya bean milk which I have not yet tried, soya bean not easily procurable in India.
('47', 187, 3, 8, 362896) I am trying, however, to procure it.
('47', 187, 3, 9, 362933) There is no difficulty about living healthily without milk but there is considerable difficulty in becoming strong after having lost it by protracted illness.
