('47', 188, 4, 8, 364760) H. W. B. MORENO
('47', 188, 5, 9, 364776) CAMP AZAMGARH, October 3, 1929
('47', 188, 6, 10, 364807) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('47', 188, 6, 11, 364840) I do not know how to console you.
('47', 188, 6, 12, 364874) You sent me a report and you did not want me to hide my thoughts.
('47', 188, 6, 13, 364940) I could not serve you by so doing.
('47', 188, 6, 14, 364975) Why is ‘half borns’ 1 a most degrading epithet?
('47', 188, 6, 15, 365023) It has a well known meaning and I have seen it used in writings which are not intended to ridicule the Anglo Indians.
('47', 188, 6, 16, 365141) Should I be wrong in stoutly resisting any claim that may be put forth by anybody as by the ruling race?
('47', 188, 6, 17, 365246) This must be so of course because the claims put forth by the ruling race are being resisted and are now in the melting pot.
('47', 188, 6, 18, 365371) I know that your birth is not a matter of your choice but the attempt that is being made to conceal the birth is a matter for sorrow even as an attempt made by Indians living in the colonies or in Europe has appeared to me to be a matter for sorrow when they have vainly tried to conceal their birth.
('47', 188, 6, 19, 365672) Perhaps I am in much closer touch with Anglo Indians who do not even know the name Anglo Indian and who only know that their male parent was a European who had deserted them and their mothers.
('47', 188, 6, 20, 365865) Are you sure that the leaders are “now prepared to throw in their lot with the Indians”?
('47', 188, 6, 21, 365954) I know that such is your own personal wish but such by no means is the opinion
('47', 188, 7, 22, 366033) 1 Vide “the Anglo Indian”, 29 8 1929
('47', 189, 0, 1, 366070) 190 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 189, 1, 2, 366112) even of the majority of leaders.
('47', 189, 1, 3, 366145) You ask me in the last paragraph of your letter to reproduce it in Young India.
('47', 189, 1, 4, 366225) I shall gladly do so if you insist but I would dissuade you from so insisting.
('47', 189, 1, 5, 366304) Your letter lends itself to much hostile criticism.
('47', 189, 1, 6, 366356) The Anglo Indian problem is far deeper than you seem to imagine and it cannot be dealt with by mere writing in the newspapers.
('47', 189, 1, 7, 366483) It can be dealt with by enlightened Anglo Indians realizing the gravity of the position and stooping to lift those who have neither a fair skin nor money to live up to the dangerously artificial life that the leaders are living.
('47', 189, 1, 8, 366712) I must confess that I am not so much interested in the affairs of the microscopic well to do minority of Anglo Indians as I am in the multitude that are living in a state of awful isolation neglected by their own and despised by those who consider themsleves to be full born.

('47', 190, 7, 10, 368305) GAZIPUR, October 3, 1929

('47', 190, 8, 13, 368422) But insted of letting the worry grow, try to overcome it.
('47', 190, 8, 14, 368480) Prabhudas writes and tells me that he is more worried about my worrying on account of you both than about his fever.
('47', 190, 8, 15, 368597) If it becomes clear that the plains will not suit him, we will let him remain in Almora.
('47', 190, 8, 16, 368686) There is work there too, and he has already formed contacts there so that he will have no diffculty in staying on.

('47', 190, 8, 20, 368987) I have written to Imiya, Kusum and Vasumatibehn too.
('47', 190, 8, 21, 369040) The difficulty about slivers, therefore, will disappear.
('47', 190, 8, 22, 369097) What have you been doing during their absence?
('47', 190, 8, 23, 369144) I think that when you are short of slivers there you should even get them from the Ashram and supply them.
('47', 190, 8, 24, 369251) The reputation of a person or thing becomes established when all people have the same experinece of that person or thing.
('47', 190, 8, 25, 369373) I wish, therefore, that the work there may be reduced in scope as much as you like but should be systematized.
('47', 190, 8, 26, 369484) At present you are getting work done with the
('47', 190, 9, 27, 369530) 1 Son of G.D. Birla
('47', 191, 0, 1, 369550) 192 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 191, 1, 2, 369592) help of whoever is available to you.
('47', 191, 1, 3, 369629) Instead of doing that, you should now think what the minimum number is that you require, and arrangements should be made accordingly.
('47', 191, 2, 4, 369763) This must be fixed as a rule, that we should get slivers made exclusively through the new volunteers who are being trained.
('47', 191, 2, 5, 369887) We shall then know who are capable of being trained.
('47', 191, 2, 6, 369940) What will it cost to send one maund of slivers from the Ashram?
('47', 191, 2, 7, 370004) Calculate this.
('47', 191, 2, 8, 370020) It is necessary to estimate the likely expenditure if the work in Vijapur is organised into an institution.
('47', 191, 2, 9, 370128) We shall consider afterwards how much to add to the cost of the khadi produced there.
('47', 191, 3, 10, 370214) I have two things in view: one, to provide work to the really poor women there and, two, to run an ashram on an extremely small scale but well organized.
('47', 191, 3, 11, 370368) You are, however, the centre in all this as Vinoba is in Wardha.
('47', 191, 3, 12, 370433) Wardha has developed along its own lines as planned, and Vijapur along a different line.

('47', 191, 3, 16, 370647) As one of the oldest inmates of the Ashram, you seem to have settled down there in peace.
('47', 191, 3, 17, 370737) I would, therefore, be happy if an independent weaving school could be run there as a branch of the Ashram and following the rules of the Ashram.
('47', 191, 3, 18, 370883) Think about all this and write to me.

('47', 193, 6, 16, 373974) From that time till October 2 I had to work much more than I wished or had expected.

('47', 193, 6, 20, 374283) I liked all that because it suited my way of life.

('47', 195, 1, 2, 375630) 217. LETTER TO H.B. TEJUMAL 1
('47', 195, 2, 3, 375660) CAMP GORAKHPORE, October 4, 1929
('47', 195, 3, 4, 375693) DEAR FRIEND, 1. It is necessary to pray because prayer is food for the soul as food is for the body.
('47', 195, 4, 5, 375794) 2. The body cannot live on prayer.
('47', 195, 4, 6, 375829) For the body, honest labour is prayer.
('47', 195, 5, 7, 375868) 3. It is a misuse of God’s gift to use prayer for curing diseases.4. It is a greater misuse to harness prayer for one's promotion of life or such material comforts.
('47', 195, 6, 8, 376033) 5. Prayer is most helpful in spiritual progress and for subduing animal passions.
('47', 195, 7, 9, 376115) 6. Harinama cannot be overpraised but Harinama in prayer has its limits.
('47', 195, 8, 10, 376188) 7. If the prayer of one is more quickly answered than that of another it is a clear indication that the other lacks earnestness to that extent.
('47', 195, 9, 11, 376332) Yours sincerely,
('47', 195, 10, 12, 376349) From a photostat: S.N. 15359
('47', 195, 11, 13, 376378) 1 In reply to his letter dated September 29, 1929, which read: “Kindly reply yourself for the satisfaction of my soul and each question may kindly be separately answered: (1) Is it necessary to pray and why?
('47', 195, 11, 14, 376586) (2) Can a person live on prayer alone, doing no work whatsoever for his livelihood, etc.?
('47', 195, 11, 15, 376676) (3) My son has recently got a chorneal opacity of one eye as a result of small pox.
('47', 195, 11, 16, 376760) All surgeons and doctors opine that he will be permanently blind.
('47', 195, 11, 17, 376826) Can it be corrected by prayer?
('47', 195, 11, 18, 376857) (4) I am a doctor in Barrage on temporary list and there is no chance of becoming permanent.
('47', 195, 11, 19, 376950) Can I, by prayer, become permanent, and rise in position, pay, comforts and happiness to my heart’s satisfaction?
('47', 195, 11, 20, 377064) (5) Is prayer helpful in spiritual progress and in subduing the animal passions.?
('47', 195, 11, 21, 377146) (6) There is too much praise of Harinama in our religious scriptures, so much so that one who concentrates on Harinama, has no more to do for this world and the next.
('47', 195, 11, 22, 377313) All that he needs, will he get by Harinama?
('47', 195, 11, 23, 377357) What is your opinion?
('47', 195, 11, 24, 377379) (7) Why the prayer of one soul is quickly answered and that of another not heard at all?
('47', 195, 11, 25, 377468) What is the reason?” (S.N. 15358)

('47', 197, 1, 2, 378547) 220. LETTER TO GIRI RAJ 1
('47', 197, 2, 3, 378573) CAMP GORAKHPORE, October 4, 1929
('47', 197, 3, 4, 378606) MY DEAR GIRI RAJ, I have your letter.
('47', 197, 3, 5, 378644) I am glad you have taken long boots to protect your legs.
('47', 197, 3, 6, 378702) I hope you have now thoroughly recovered.
('47', 197, 3, 7, 378744) You must keep your health.
('47', 197, 3, 8, 378771) Dead cattle hide is certainly enough for our wants.
('47', 197, 3, 9, 378823) Have I told you that we are exporting nine crores worth of dead cattle hide out of India?
('47', 197, 3, 10, 378913) You must remember that millions in India go barefooted.
('47', 197, 3, 11, 378969) Sir Nalini Ranjan Sarkar told me that the reason why many tanneries have failed was because the leather want was limited in this country.
('47', 197, 3, 12, 379107) Anyway I did not expect you to raise such an academic question because it is exactly on such academic questions that many of the evils in the world are sustained, as for instance meat eaters justify meat eating on the plea that the earth will be overrun by the animals they ate if they became vegetarians.
('47', 197, 3, 13, 379413) Birth control people justify birth control on the ground among others that there would be over population if there was no artificial control.
('47', 197, 3, 14, 379555) Even war has been justified on the ground that without it we should perish of pestilence and disease.
('47', 197, 3, 15, 379657) Celibacy is condemned for one reason among the others that the earth will cease if all became celibates.
('47', 197, 3, 16, 379762) Does it not strike you that it will be time enough to consider the question when we have absorbed nine crores worth of dead cattle hide?
('47', 197, 3, 17, 379899) I am writing to Pratap Pandit and enclosing the letter with this.
('47', 197, 3, 18, 379965) Your argument about machinery is not happily worded.
('47', 197, 3, 19, 380018) Surely we can run a tannery both for the instruction of villagers and for supplying the wants of those who need foot wear made out of dead cattle hide.
('47', 197, 3, 20, 380170) The main consideration about machinery is that it should not displace the labour of those who cannot otherwise be employed.
('47', 197, 3, 21, 380294) You will find that this one argument answers all objections.
('47', 197, 3, 22, 380355) We do not want to displace hand processes.
('47', 197, 3, 23, 380398) We want to cultivate hand processes to perfection but where it is found to be absolutely necessary let us not hesitate to introduce machinery.
('47', 197, 3, 24, 380541) Do you know that some of the most delicate life saving appliances would have been impossible without the aid of some machinery?
('47', 197, 3, 25, 380669) After all the simple charkha is also a machine.
('47', 197, 3, 26, 380717) What we
('47', 197, 4, 27, 380725) 1 In reply to his Hindi letter (S.N. 15612) dated September 28, 1929
('47', 198, 0, 1, 380794) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 199
('47', 198, 1, 2, 380843) must dread is huge machinery run not by hand but by non human power such as steam, electricity, etc.
('47', 198, 1, 3, 380944) But even this need not be tabooed.
('47', 198, 1, 4, 380979) If this is not still clear to you, you must continue to challenge my arguments.

('47', 201, 0, 1, 385701) 202 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 201, 1, 2, 385743) 226. ACADEMIC V. PRACTICAL 1
('47', 201, 2, 3, 385772) A student writes:
('47', 201, 3, 4, 385790) Very often you give replies to your critics which are quite correct in the academic sense; they give a sort of temporary satisfaction to the mind but in actual practice leave the riddle as unsolved as ever.
('47', 201, 3, 5, 385997) Take for instance your saying, “Only a coward fights on the strength of numbers.” It is all right in the abstract.
('47', 201, 3, 6, 386112) It does for the time being bring one a sort of mental reassurance, but of what avail is it in actual practice?
('47', 201, 3, 7, 386223) You preach your gospel of soul force to all and sundry.
('47', 201, 3, 8, 386279) But do you think that there is any chance of your utopian advice being seriously taken by those who have not faith even in the spinning wheel and khadi?
('47', 201, 3, 9, 386432) Won’t your preaching be, like pouring water over a duck’s neck, utterly futile?”
('47', 201, 4, 10, 386513) I certainly hope that my advice about soul force is not altogether wasted though it might seem unavailing for the time being.
('47', 201, 4, 11, 386639) As an English proverb says, “Constant dropping will wear away a stone.”And it is my faith that what seems utopian to the correspondent today will be regarded as practical tommorrow.
('47', 201, 4, 12, 386821) History is replete with such instances.
('47', 201, 4, 13, 386861) If the word ‘soul force’ appears a meaningless term to our students today, it only shows to what an abject plight we are reduced.
('47', 201, 4, 14, 386991) For is it not most tragic that things of the spirit, eternal verities, should be regarded as utopian by our youth, and transitory makeshifts alone appeal to them as practical?
('47', 201, 5, 15, 387167) We have an ocular demonstration of the futility of mere numbers before us evey day.
('47', 201, 5, 16, 387251) What stronger proof of the proposition can be needed than that a nation of three hundred million Indians is today being ruled by less than one lakh Englishmen?
('47', 201, 5, 17, 387411) The very sight of a lion puts to flight a thousand sheep.
('47', 201, 5, 18, 387469) The reason is plain.
('47', 201, 5, 19, 387490) The sheep are aware of their weakness, the lion of its strength.
('47', 201, 5, 20, 387555) And the consciousness of strength in the latter over powers the numerical strength of the former.
('47', 201, 5, 21, 387653) By analogy may we not deduce that ‘soul force’ may not after all be a mere chimera or figment of imagination but a substantial reality?
('47', 201, 6, 22, 387789) I do not wish to disparage the strength of numbers.
('47', 201, 6, 23, 387841) It has its use but only when it is backed by the latent spirit force.
('47', 201, 6, 24, 387911) Millions of ants
('47', 201, 7, 25, 387928) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Navajivan, 6 10 1929. This is a translation by Pyarelal.
('47', 202, 0, 1, 388029) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 203
('47', 202, 1, 2, 388078) can kill an elephant by together attacking it in a vulnerable place.
('47', 202, 1, 3, 388147) Their sense of solidarity, consciousness of oneness of spirit in spite of the diversity of bodies, in other words, their spirit force, makes the ants irresistible.
('47', 202, 1, 4, 388311) Even so that moment we develop a sense of mass unity like the ants, we too shall become irresistible and shall free ourselves from our chains.
('47', 202, 1, 5, 388454) It is my firm faith that the students of our national schools, a mere handful though they may be, if they are inspired by a real spirit of sacrifice and service and a living faith in their ideals, will stand the country in far greater stead than all the students in Governemnt educational institutions put together.
('47', 202, 1, 6, 388770) That quality is more than quantity is sound theory because it is true in practice.
('47', 202, 1, 7, 388853) Indeed I hold that what cannot be proved in practice cannot be sound in theory.
('47', 202, 1, 8, 388933) When Galileo declared that the earth was round like a ball and turned on its axis, he was ridiculed as a visionary and a dreamer and was greeted with abuse.
('47', 202, 1, 9, 389090) But today we know that Galileo was right, and it was his opponents, who believed the earth to be stationary and flat like a dish, that were living in the cloudland of their ignorance.
('47', 202, 1, 10, 389274) Modern education tends to turn our eyes away from the spirit.
('47', 202, 1, 11, 389336) The possibilities of the spirit force therefore do no appeal to us, and our eyes are consequently riveted on the evanescent, transitory, material force.
('47', 202, 1, 12, 389489) Surely this is the very limit of dull unimginativeness.
('47', 202, 1, 13, 389545) But I live in hope and patience.
('47', 202, 1, 14, 389578) I have an unshakable faith in the correctness of my proposition, a faith that is based on my and my companions’ experience.
('47', 202, 1, 15, 389702) And every student, if only he has got the faculty of patient, dispassionate research, can experimentally prove this for himself: 1. That mere numbers are useless.
('47', 202, 1, 16, 389865) 2. That all force other than soul force is transitory and vain.
('47', 202, 1, 17, 389929) It goes without saying, that if the above propositions are correct, it should be the constant endeavour of evey student to arm himself with this matchless weapon of spirit force by dint of self discipline and self purification.
('47', 202, 1, 18, 390157) Young India, 6 10 1929

('47', 203, 1, 2, 390222) 227. CONCERNING GOD
('47', 203, 2, 3, 390242) A friend writes: 1
('47', 203, 3, 4, 390261) This problem confronts many people; hence I should like to discuss it here a little.
('47', 203, 3, 5, 390346) As the friend has observed, there may be weakness in my writing, but I am not aware of it.
('47', 203, 3, 6, 390437) I have of course written what I have learnt from experience.
('47', 203, 3, 7, 390498) But the experience is indescribable.
('47', 203, 3, 8, 390535) I can give you only a glimpse of it and that can only be done in ordinary language.
('47', 203, 3, 9, 390619) How can one compare divine intervention with human intervention?
('47', 203, 3, 10, 390684) God and His laws are not disparate.
('47', 203, 3, 11, 390720) Neither karma nor God spares anyone.
('47', 203, 3, 12, 390757) Both are the same thing.
('47', 203, 3, 13, 390782) One thought makes us cruel, another makes us humble.
('47', 203, 3, 14, 390835) In this world an extraordinary sentient power is at work and we recognize it by whatever name we wish.
('47', 203, 3, 15, 390938) But it does intervene daily in all our tasks.
('47', 203, 3, 16, 390984) Every one of our thoughts is karma, which has its fruit.
('47', 203, 3, 17, 391041) The fruit is subject to divine law.
('47', 203, 3, 18, 391077) Hence either God or His law does intervene in all our actions whether or not we are conscious of it or acknowledge it.
('47', 203, 4, 19, 391196) Nothing is accidental in this world.
('47', 203, 4, 20, 391233) What happens is subject to law.
('47', 203, 4, 21, 391265) Only our ignorance is so great that we are not aware of its working.
('47', 203, 4, 22, 391334) How can I construe it as an accident if a snake passes by me and still does not bite me?
('47', 203, 4, 23, 391423) Why should not I regard it as God’s grace?
('47', 203, 4, 24, 391466) Or why should I not look upon it as due to my religious merit?
('47', 203, 4, 25, 391529) The sting of pride born of religious merit is more poisonous than a snake bite.
('47', 203, 4, 26, 391609) Pride melts away in the presence of divine grace.
('47', 203, 5, 27, 391659) As there is an article 2 about faith in this very issue, I do not repeat it here.
('47', 203, 5, 28, 391741) I have no use for blind faith.
('47', 203, 5, 29, 391772) I put my intelligence to work where I see a palpably wordly reason.
('47', 203, 5, 30, 391840) But when the intelligence tires out, I push faith to the fore and attach little importance to accidents.
('47', 203, 5, 31, 391945) But I cannot kindle faith in God by rational argument.
('47', 203, 6, 32, 392000) 1 The letter is not tranalated here.
('47', 203, 6, 33, 392037) It had referred to Gandhiji’s following statement in An Autobiography, Pt. V. Ch. XXI: “The rule of not killing venomous reptiles has been practised for the most part at phoenix, Tolstoy Farm and Sabarmati.
('47', 203, 6, 34, 392244) At each of these places we had to settle on waste lands.
('47', 203, 6, 35, 392301) We have had, however, no loss of life occasioned by snake bite.
('47', 203, 6, 36, 392365) I see, with the eye of faith, in this circumstance the hand of the God of Mercy.
('47', 203, 6, 37, 392446) Let no one cavil at this, saying that God can never be partial, and that He has no time to meddle with the humdrum affairs of men.” 2 Vide “Reason v.
('47', 204, 0, 1, 392596) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 205
('47', 204, 1, 2, 392645) have tried here a little logic.
('47', 204, 1, 3, 392677) It is good if there is someone to whom this argument appeals.
('47', 204, 1, 4, 392739) I cannot impart to others faith in God through my writings.
('47', 204, 1, 5, 392799) I must admit that my experience is of use only to me.
('47', 204, 1, 6, 392853) A doubting heart must seek the company of the Good.

('47', 204, 3, 10, 393053) A twelve year old boy writes: 1

('47', 205, 1, 2, 394340) 229. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL JOSHI
('47', 205, 2, 3, 394372) GORAKHPORE October 6, 1929
('47', 205, 3, 4, 394399) CHHAGANLAL, I have your letter.
('47', 205, 3, 5, 394431) As I have not become the President, my responsibility for doing something in January—according to my nature and to the teaching of the Gita—has doubled now, in the same way that the responsibility of a voluntary worker is greater than that of a person who works for money.
('47', 205, 3, 6, 394704) To put this in the language of the Gita, there is a possibility of attachment in work done with a crown on one’s head, whereas work done without such a crown is more likely to be free from attachment.
('47', 205, 3, 7, 394905) And if my responsibility has increased, that of the inmates of the Ashram also increases.
('47', 205, 3, 8, 394995) If the country is able to do nothing and if I see the fitness of the Ashram inmates, something can certainly be done through them.
('47', 205, 3, 9, 395126) None of you, therefore, has any reason to despair or to be complacent.
('47', 205, 3, 10, 395197) This, of course, does not mean that I have now a plan of action.
('47', 205, 3, 11, 395262) That will come when God inspires it.
('47', 205, 3, 12, 395299) My life is ruled by faith.
('47', 205, 3, 13, 395326) You can read this at prayer time.

('47', 208, 1, 2, 399407) 233. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL JOSHI
('47', 208, 2, 3, 399439) GORAKHPORE, Silence Day, October 7, 1929
('47', 208, 3, 4, 399480) CHHAGANLAL, I have your letter.
('47', 208, 3, 5, 399512) I enclose with this Chhaganlal Gandhi’s.
('47', 208, 3, 6, 399553) The suggestion that if anyone from Mansa offers to come and learn [carding] he should be taken in, seems all right to me.
('47', 208, 4, 7, 399675) I return the telegrams sent by you.
('47', 208, 4, 8, 399711) I have thrown into the waste paper basket the heap of other telegrams which came here straight.
('47', 208, 5, 9, 399807) The locusts have done much damage here too.
('47', 208, 5, 10, 399851) We shall know now what the result there has been.
('47', 208, 6, 11, 399901) My free time today is over, and so I shall write no more.
('47', 208, 7, 12, 399959) Blessings from
('47', 208, 8, 13, 399974) BAPU [PS.] Today’s post arrived after this was written.
('47', 208, 8, 14, 400030) I am surprised to read about the pain which Kaki suffered.
('47', 208, 8, 15, 400089) How did it come on all of a sudden?
('47', 208, 8, 16, 400125) I am also likely to hear from Kaka.
('47', 208, 8, 17, 400161) It cannot be said that your weight has increased.
('47', 208, 8, 18, 400211) It would be good if you could go out.
('47', 208, 8, 19, 400249) You should certainly not allow your health to waste away.
('47', 208, 8, 20, 400307) If Jayanti meets me in Hardwar, it will be all right.
('47', 208, 8, 21, 400361) But you should now have the whole programme with you.
('47', 208, 8, 22, 400415) He may see it and select any place from it which suits him.
('47', 208, 8, 23, 400475) However, 14 15 at Hardwar seems convenient.
('47', 208, 8, 24, 400519) Before that, I have to visit small villages.
('47', 208, 8, 25, 400564) I had a letter from Narandas.
('47', 208, 8, 26, 400594) You should win over a man like him.
('47', 208, 8, 27, 400630) I am simply in love with his straightforwardness, purity and frankness.
('47', 208, 8, 28, 400702) We, that is, chiefly you, ought to be able to use his services fully.
('47', 208, 8, 29, 400772) This, however, is my view and my wish.
('47', 208, 8, 30, 400811) What matters is your view and your wish.
('47', 208, 9, 31, 400852) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 5466
('47', 209, 0, 1, 400896) 210 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 209, 1, 2, 400938) 234. LETTER TO KISHORELAL MASHRUWALA
('47', 209, 2, 3, 400975) GORAKHPUR, Silence Day, October 7, 1929
('47', 209, 3, 4, 401015) KISHORELAL, I do not remember to have written to you about your note on the Gita.
('47', 209, 3, 5, 401097) I liked it.
('47', 209, 3, 6, 401109) I am of the view that the Sanskrit text need not be printed along with the translation.
('47', 209, 3, 7, 401197) This translation 1 is not intended for those who wish to read the Sanskrit.
('47', 209, 3, 8, 401273) They will manage somehow.
('47', 209, 3, 9, 401299) This attempt is meant for those who do not know Sanskrit or know so little of it that it cannot help them to follow the meaning.
('47', 209, 3, 10, 401428) Nevertheless, we can make a pocket edition available to those who wish to go to the Sanskrit text after reading this translation.
('47', 209, 3, 11, 401558) We should free ourselves from the slavery to Sanskrit.
('47', 209, 3, 12, 401613) If the path of the Gita is for women, Vaishyas and even Shudras, it should be possible to explain it, and it should be as intelligible in any other language as in Sanskrit.
('47', 209, 3, 13, 401786) Hence, in my view, one part should consist only of the Gujarati translation, the second of a concordance and the third of the Sanskrit text.
('47', 209, 3, 14, 401927) Anyone who so wishes can buy all the three parts together or only one.
('47', 209, 3, 15, 401998) Kaka has discussed this idea at some length with Mahadev and Swami.
('47', 209, 3, 16, 402066) It is my impression that Kaka and Swami have fully understood my point of view.
('47', 209, 3, 17, 402146) I believe that Mahadev has some reservations.
('47', 209, 3, 18, 402192) Vallabhbhai also has taken some interest in this matter.
('47', 209, 3, 19, 402249) He has opted for a separate Gujarati edition.
('47', 209, 3, 20, 402295) What is relevant is this: is the translation of it literary quality, simple and intelligible?
('47', 209, 3, 21, 402389) If not, it should be consigned to the flames.
('47', 209, 3, 22, 402435) I would not feel unhappy if it was.
('47', 209, 3, 23, 402471) I had intended to attempt something like the present translation for my own amusement and better understanding.
('47', 209, 3, 24, 402583) To add to it, Swami was after me that I should give a translation that would reflect my views and should only venture to put forward my explanation of the teaching of the Gita.
('47', 209, 3, 25, 402760) I had no right [to talk on the subject] till I did that.
('47', 209, 3, 26, 402817) I was convinced by this argument of his.
('47', 209, 3, 27, 402858) My experience proved its correctness, and I have therefore reaped the fruit of my effort.
('47', 209, 3, 28, 402948) It would now be an additional reward if wepublish it for the people.
('47', 209, 3, 29, 403017) If necessary, you may still consider the matter from this point of view also.
('47', 209, 3, 30, 403095) Interest Nath also in the subject.
('47', 209, 3, 31, 403130) Ask him to pay at least a flying visit to the Ashram when he has the
('47', 209, 4, 32, 403199) 1Anasaktiyoga; vide “Anasktiyoga”
('47', 210, 0, 1, 403233) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 211
('47', 210, 1, 2, 403282) Mahadev has taken away your note with him.
('47', 210, 1, 3, 403325) You may have known about it.
('47', 210, 1, 4, 403354) He and Kaka together are vetting the translation.
('47', 210, 1, 5, 403404) How is your health and Gomati’s?
('47', 210, 1, 6, 403437) So, Surendra has stayed on there.
('47', 210, 1, 7, 403471) Has he calmed down?
('47', 210, 1, 8, 403491) You must be keeping an eye on Giriraj 1. God keeps my cart trundling along.
('47', 210, 1, 9, 403567) If you ask me how it does, I cannot answer.
('47', 210, 1, 10, 403611) It is certainly not doing so through my strength.
('47', 210, 1, 11, 403661) What wonder, therefore, that my faith in God daily grows stronger?
('47', 210, 1, 12, 403728) Blessings from BAPU From the Gujarati Original: C.W. 10711. Courtesy: Gomatibehn Mashruwala

('47', 211, 1, 2, 404439) 237. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL JOSHI
('47', 211, 2, 3, 404471) GORAKHPORE,
('47', 211, 3, 4, 404483) October 8, 1929
('47', 211, 4, 5, 404499) CHHAGANLAL, I send with this Ayodhyaprasad’s letter to me and a copy of my reply to him.
('47', 211, 4, 6, 404588) Go through both.
('47', 211, 4, 7, 404605) I do not follow what he wants to say.
('47', 211, 4, 8, 404643) I do not understand what he says about Mathuradas either.
('47', 211, 4, 9, 404701) Nor do I understand what his complaint is.
('47', 211, 4, 10, 404744) Write to me and explain if you know what it is.
('47', 211, 5, 11, 404792) I have gone through Ranchhodbhai’s speech.
('47', 211, 5, 12, 404835) I found in it nothing worth reproducing.
('47', 211, 5, 13, 404876) I went through Parnerkar’s speech too.
('47', 211, 5, 14, 404915) It does not give an account of the progress made by the goshala, but explains what needs to be done.
('47', 211, 5, 15, 405016) It is not necessary to print the speech.
('47', 211, 5, 16, 405057) A report of this kind should give figures of the increase in the yield of the cow’s milk, the fodder consumed, the cow’s weight, the percentage of fat in milk, the average price of the cows, the expenditure on maintaining crippled and infirm cattle and that on maintaining milch cows only, the profit earned from castrated bulls and the expenditure involved in not castrting the bulls, a comparison of the prison [sic] cows and the kankareji and other cows in Gujarat, a comparison of the cows in Gujarat with cows in Hissar, a comparison of cows with buffaloes, etc.
('47', 211, 5, 17, 405625) A report containing such information would be of great value.
('47', 211, 5, 18, 405687) We ought to have such a report with us, for we have now started a school and train students, and also intend to institute certificates in this field as we have in khadi work.
('47', 211, 5, 19, 405862) We wish ultimately even to award degrees.
('47', 211, 5, 20, 405904) We ought, therefore, to have a report of the kind I have set out.
('47', 211, 5, 21, 405970) We see some reports of this kind which have been published as books and become famous.
('47', 211, 5, 22, 406057) Ours is an unexplored field so that all our reports can be of that kind.
('47', 211, 5, 23, 406130) I expect such reports from our workers.
('47', 211, 5, 24, 406170) Show this letter to Parnerkar and Valji.
('47', 211, 5, 25, 406211) Surendera, too, may read it.
('47', 211, 6, 26, 406240) Were necessary reforms carried out at the time of the Exhibition?
('47', 211, 6, 27, 406306) Are the dung and urine of the cattle fully utilized?
('47', 211, 6, 28, 406359) Has the uncleanliness to which I had drawn attention been removed now?
('47', 211, 7, 29, 406430) I heard a startling thing in Agra.
('47', 211, 7, 30, 406465) Whereas the hide of one of our cows weighs about 20 lb., that of a cow in Europe weighs about
('47', 212, 0, 1, 406559) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 213
('47', 212, 1, 2, 406608) I believed till now that we supplied to the whole world hide for the soles and heels of shoes.
('47', 212, 1, 3, 406703) I discovered in Agra that in Europe they always make the soles and heels from the hide of cows and bulls, and that their hide is stronger than even the hide of our buffaloes.
('47', 212, 1, 4, 406878) There may be some exaggeration in this, but all this is interesting information.
('47', 212, 1, 5, 406959) I have not yet read Surendra's report fully.
('47', 212, 1, 6, 407004) I shall also let you know the thoughts which occur to me after I have read it.
('47', 212, 1, 7, 407083) I return with this Parnerkar's report.
('47', 212, 1, 8, 407122) I dictated the paragraphs above at half past five in the morning in Gorakhpur.
('47', 212, 1, 9, 407201) I am dictating what follows in Basti.
('47', 212, 1, 10, 407239) I got the post sent to this address.
('47', 212, 1, 11, 407276) We cannot give to Prabhashankar the bungalow reserved for the doctor, for the latter may now arrive any day.
('47', 212, 1, 12, 407385) Moreover Ratilal and Prabhashankar are at present on extremely unhappy terms with each other.
('47', 212, 1, 13, 407479) The latter harrassed even Dr. Mehta a good deal.
('47', 212, 1, 14, 407528) He cannot, therefore, be lodged in the doctor's bungalow.
('47', 212, 1, 15, 407586) If there were a vacant room in the Ashram, we would have certainly offered it to him.
('47', 212, 1, 16, 407672) Write to him, therefore, and tell him that apart from Dr. Mehta's bungalow there is nothing else in the Ashram and that a part of the bungalow is occupied by Manilal Kothari, and the ground floor, which is vacant, was especially got vacated for Dr. Mehta; add further that all the rooms in the Ashram are occupied.
('47', 212, 2, 17, 407987) My certificate to Budhabhai is not to be treated as gospel truth.
('47', 212, 2, 18, 408053) I can state only the impression which I have formed from a distance; if I imagined anything contrary to that impression or refused to state, when the occasion demanded, what my impression was, that would be a blot on my vow of truth.
('47', 212, 2, 19, 408287) Hence, the certificate I gave was the only one I could give though in point of fact it might be understood.
('47', 212, 2, 20, 408395) I think you should attach more weight to what Harihar and others, who have come into contact with him, may have to say.
('47', 212, 2, 21, 408515) If, therefore, you meet Budhabhai, tell him only what you think right and feel no hesitation in doing so.
('47', 212, 2, 22, 408621) You will thereby have done your duty as friend and served Budhabhai's true interests.
('47', 212, 2, 23, 408707) If he has beaten his wife, he has of course committed a sin.
('47', 212, 2, 24, 408768) He has no right at all to beat her.
('47', 212, 2, 25, 408804) If he does not speak with her, that also is difficult to understand, though of course sometimes this can be a form of satyagraha.
('47', 212, 2, 26, 408934) I understand what you say about Madhavlal.
('47', 212, 2, 27, 408977) I have no letter from him.
('47', 212, 2, 28, 409004) Ordinarily, we can say that we cannot give him money for
('47', 213, 0, 1, 409061) 214 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 213, 1, 2, 409103) his wife.
('47', 213, 1, 3, 409113) Madhavlal is slow of understanding, and so we should take no offence at what he says.
('47', 213, 1, 4, 409199) If we can tolerate his dullness, he may even become intelligent.
('47', 213, 1, 5, 409264) Take him into confidence and have a talk with him when he is alone.
('47', 213, 1, 6, 409332) Tell him all that you think.
('47', 213, 1, 7, 409361) Having taken him in and let him stay for so long, we cannot abandon him.
('47', 213, 1, 8, 409434) He seems to be sincere, and so he cannot but be of some use.
('47', 213, 1, 9, 409495) We should find out in what way he can be used.
('47', 213, 1, 10, 409542) It is necessary to take the advice of an experienced engineer about how to change the course of the river.
('47', 213, 1, 11, 409649) Such an engineer can suggest some practical means.
('47', 213, 1, 12, 409700) Fever seems to have claimed many victims and harassed them a good deal.
('47', 213, 2, 13, 409772) Blessings from BAPU [PS.] I have not revised this.

('47', 213, 4, 15, 409867) 238. LETTER TO VALJI G. DESAI
('47', 213, 5, 16, 409897) GORAKHPORE, October 8, 1929
('47', 213, 6, 17, 409925) BHAISHRI VALJI, I am enclosing Bhai Nagindas's letter and his article.
('47', 213, 6, 18, 409996) He desires the article to be published as a Supplement to Young India.
('47', 213, 6, 19, 410067) Though its basic idea is true and the figures, etc., given in it are valuable, the article has not been written so as to be readily understood by the man in the street.
('47', 213, 6, 20, 410236) I believe it can be very much abridged.
('47', 213, 6, 21, 410276) If you can find the necessary time, you may make out of it a new article, short and pointed.
('47', 213, 6, 22, 410369) If that is not possible, for want of time or for any reason, you may return both.
('47', 213, 7, 23, 410451) Blessings from BAPU [PS.] I have not revised this.

('47', 214, 3, 4, 410689) BHAISHRI, You are aware of Bhai Jagjivandas's efforts in connection with milk supply to Bombay and about the B.B.C.I. rates for carrying milk and its containers.
('47', 214, 3, 5, 410851) From what he writes it appears as if the officers are merely arrogant in not acceding to his request, but I hesitate to believe this.

('47', 214, 3, 8, 411138) What about salt?
('47', 214, 3, 9, 411155) I have not yet been able to write about it myself; but I have been revolving it in my mind.

('47', 214, 6, 17, 411562) 240. LETTER TO BHUPENDRA NATH BANERJEE 1
('47', 214, 7, 18, 411603) CAMP BASTI, October 8, 1929
('47', 214, 8, 19, 411631) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter for which I thank you.
('47', 214, 8, 20, 411686) I have preferred to observe silence over the self immolation of Jatindra Nath Das because I feel that by writing on it I would have done more harm to the country's cause than good.
('47', 214, 8, 21, 411867) There are many things on this earth on which I hold decided opinions but I retain those opinions to myself when I think that expression of those opinions can serve no useful purpose.
('47', 214, 8, 22, 412050) Yours sincerely, SJT.

('47', 215, 7, 11, 412868) 242. LETTER TO GIRI RAJ
('47', 215, 8, 12, 412892) CAMP BASTI, October 8, 1929
('47', 215, 9, 13, 412920) MY DEAR GIRI RAJ, I have your letter.
('47', 215, 9, 14, 412958) I fear you may not go to the V.G. Institute.
('47', 215, 9, 15, 413003) If Prof.
('47', 215, 9, 16, 413012) Chhaya would give you private tuition and if you want it you may take it.
('47', 215, 9, 17, 413086) But really speaking you ought to be able to do all this by self study.
('47', 215, 9, 18, 413157) This condition of helplessness that we find around us must be got over.
('47', 215, 9, 19, 413229) You have had sufficient training to enable you to prosecute further studies in practically any branch without the help of any instructor.
('47', 215, 9, 20, 413367) The use of a laboratory may be necessary.
('47', 215, 9, 21, 413409) That can be easily arranged but I would like you not to be in a hurry.
('47', 215, 9, 22, 413480) The first thing is to become a practical tanner.
('47', 215, 9, 23, 413529) When you have done that you will find the theory to be much easier to grasp and a previous knowledge of practice would help you in checking wrong deductions from theory.
('47', 215, 9, 24, 413699) I know of many who possess full theoretical knowledge of tanning, who cannot tan a single hide.
('47', 215, 9, 25, 413795) I would, therefore, like you to concentrate your attention just now upon becoming a perfect practical tanner, even to hold his own against the village tanner.
('47', 215, 9, 26, 413954) You will find this to be no light task and you will remember that village
('47', 216, 0, 1, 414028) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 217
('47', 216, 1, 2, 414077) tanners have no knowledge of chemistry.
('47', 216, 1, 3, 414117) The modern system of education has made everything so difficult and therefore so inaccessible to the vast majority of people.
('47', 216, 1, 4, 414243) Our business is to reverse the process.
('47', 216, 2, 5, 414283) From a microfilm: S.N. 15615
('47', 216, 3, 6, 414312) 243. LETTER TO JAIRAMDAS DOULATRAM
('47', 216, 4, 7, 414347) CAMP BASTI, October 8, 1929
('47', 216, 5, 8, 414375) MY DEAR JAIRAMDAS, Jamshedji Mehta has written to me two letters giving me chapter and verse that his Committee is in no way official except that it has an official nominally [as] its preisdent who was elected at a public meeting and not officially imposed.
('47', 216, 5, 9, 414633) He tells me also that the whole responsibility is entrusted to the Executive Committee.
('47', 216, 5, 10, 414721) Kripalani who paid a flying visit to Hyderabad recently confirms this.
('47', 216, 5, 11, 414792) I therefore propose to lift the embargo on the Gujarat money held by Malkani but I am awaiting his letter.
('47', 216, 5, 12, 414899) If meanwhile you have to say anything to me please write or telegraph.
('47', 216, 5, 13, 414970) Here is a a copy of my programme.
('47', 216, 5, 14, 415004) I can understand your difficulty about domestic affairs.
('47', 216, 5, 15, 415061) You shall certainly attend to them but it is too early to say how things will shape themselves in December and January.
('47', 216, 5, 16, 415181) We shall of course meet before then when we shall be able to discuss the programme for the next year.
('47', 216, 5, 17, 415283) You will give me your impressions of your tour in Karnatak as also in Gujarat.
('47', 216, 6, 18, 415362) Yours sincerely, Enclosure: Programme SJT.

('47', 217, 1, 2, 415543) 244. LETTER TO O.B. DE SILVA 1
('47', 217, 2, 3, 415574) CAMP BASTI, October 8, 1929
('47', 217, 3, 4, 415602) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter for which I thank you.
('47', 217, 3, 5, 415657) You have an expert in Ceylon itself trained at the Ashram and in charge of spinning work.
('47', 217, 3, 6, 415747) His name and address are as follows: Jaivardhan Jairamdas 59 Wellam Pitya, Colombo With reference to the Labour Conference any Asiatic organization can be represented at the Conference.
('47', 217, 3, 7, 415933) I am sure you have only to apply.
('47', 217, 3, 8, 415967) If there is any difficulty you will please let me know.
('47', 217, 4, 9, 416023) Yours sincerely, MR. O.B. DE SILVA “LAURISTON” MUTWAL COLOMBO (CEYON)
('47', 217, 5, 10, 416093) From a photostat: S.N. 15202
('47', 217, 6, 11, 416122) 1 In reply to his letter (S.N. 15201) dated September 20, 1929, which read: “You must be aware that the charkha has no vogue here..
('47', 217, 6, 12, 416254) .But unemployment and a financial breakdown have given a nasty shock to our habitual complacency.
('47', 217, 6, 13, 416352) .There is only one cotton mill here, and the field for a charkha programme is ready to be worked.
('47', 217, 6, 14, 416450) When we have arranged the finance could you give us for even one month a helper from your Ashram?
('47', 217, 6, 15, 416548) There is further an Asiatic Labour Conference being held in Bombay.
('47', 217, 6, 16, 416616) Ceylon is left put.
('47', 217, 6, 17, 416636) Could you not use your influence to discover why?.

('47', 222, 5, 8, 423585) 253. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL JOSHI
('47', 222, 6, 9, 423617) BASTI, October 9, 1929
('47', 222, 7, 10, 423640) CHHAGANLAL, I dictated yesterday a long letter to you.
('47', 222, 7, 11, 423695) I forgot to mention one thing, and that was your reference to confidence.
('47', 222, 7, 12, 423769) I smiled as I thought what an imperfect means of communication language is.
('47', 222, 7, 13, 423845) It was after your explanation that I could understand the meaning of your words “deserving the confidence”.
('47', 222, 7, 14, 423953) But in the context in which you wrote the sentence, I understood it to mean that you were eager to make an effort to win my confidence.
('47', 222, 7, 15, 424089) I could not see that you were referring to your effort to deserve the confidence which you already enjoyed.
('47', 222, 7, 16, 424197) But now I understand.
('47', 222, 7, 17, 424219) That effort, of course, you should always make.
('47', 222, 7, 18, 424267) But worry should have no place in it at all.
('47', 222, 7, 19, 424312) The effort not to lose the confidence of a person after we have won it indicates attachment on our part.
('47', 222, 7, 20, 424417) Man is so imperfect a creature that he may place confidence today and withdraw it the next day over a trifle.
('47', 222, 7, 21, 424527) What difference does it make whether or not we enjoy the confidence of such a person?
('47', 222, 7, 22, 424613) We should, however, aspire to be worthy of the confidence of the entire world, for if we are able to take a single breath, the reason is the whole world’s confidence in us.
('47', 222, 7, 23, 424786) If that were not so, people would have killed one another long ago.
('47', 222, 7, 24, 424854) Hence, being worthy of other people’s confidence is no more than devotion to duty and this we should practise without attachment.
('47', 222, 8, 25, 424984) What I ask from you, therefore, is a mind at peace with itself in the midst of any amount of work and an attitude of extreme generosity towards the environment.
('47', 222, 8, 26, 425145) When you acquire these, you will find your work quite easy, for your words will then penetrate directly
('47', 223, 0, 1, 425249) 224 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 223, 1, 2, 425291) to the heart like an arrow and neither Madhavlal on one side nor Narandas on the other will ever misunderstand your meaning.
('47', 223, 1, 3, 425416) I have made this letter short.
('47', 223, 1, 4, 425447) If, therefore, you find it difficult to follow my meaning, return it along with your question and I will try to explain more clearly.
('47', 223, 2, 5, 425581) I expect to get details of the passing away of Kaki.
('47', 223, 3, 6, 425634) Blessings from

('47', 225, 6, 19, 428200) 258. CONGRESS ORGANIZATION
('47', 225, 7, 20, 428227) These columns have repeatedly insisted that a perfect Congress organization almost means attainment of swaraj.
('47', 225, 7, 21, 428338) This will not be true of every country.
('47', 225, 7, 22, 428378) It is true of India because of its peculiar position.
('47', 225, 7, 23, 428432) We are ruled by the hypnotic spell that the British rule has cast over us.
('47', 225, 7, 24, 428507) But British rule means British organization more than its military strength.
('47', 225, 7, 25, 428584) Military depotism on the part of a handful of foreigners alien in language, culture and habits can do very little if they had no organization to which the people were made by very subtle methods to respond.
('47', 225, 7, 26, 428791) The moment that spell is broken, that moment the rule disappears.
('47', 225, 7, 27, 428857) The British can then remain only as friends and servants of the nation at its will.
('47', 225, 7, 28, 428941) The guarantee for the safety of their persons and legitimate interests will be the goodwill and honour of the nation, instead of the mounted forts which after all are a poor protection for a handful against an awakened nation counted in myriads.
('47', 225, 7, 29, 429187) The test of a perfect Congress organization is simple:
('47', 225, 8, 30, 429242) 1. The Congress must be represented in every village.
('47', 225, 9, 31, 429296) 2. Every member must know what the Congress means and must respond to the demands made upon him by the Congress.
('47', 225, 10, 32, 429409) 1 From the contents; vide “Letter to Raojibhai M. Patel”, 27 10 1929 2 Wife of Raojabhai M. Patel.
('47', 226, 0, 1, 429508) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 227
('47', 226, 1, 2, 429557) The Congress is the only truly national political organization in the country.
('47', 226, 1, 3, 429636) It is the oldest of its kind.
('47', 226, 1, 4, 429666) It has had the services of the most distinguished sons and daughters of the nation.
('47', 226, 1, 5, 429750) It is admittedly the most powerful organization in the land.
('47', 226, 1, 6, 429811) It ought not to be difficult for such a body to expand itself and find its flag flying in every village.
('47', 226, 1, 7, 429916) Let us with this end in view study the very interesting and instructive bulletin just issued by the Secretary.
('47', 226, 1, 8, 430027) It contains an exhaustive analysis of the returns received from the provinces of their work regarding the enrolment of members in terms of the A.I.C.C. resolution passed at the Bombay meeting.
('47', 226, 1, 9, 430220) Here is the consolidated table: PROVINCE QUOTA MEMBERS ENTROLLED 1. Ajmer 1,120 14,594 2. Andhra 36,763 29,000 3 Assam 8,337 (?) 4. Bihar 72,588 78,107 5. Bengal 1,24,413 93,385 6. Berar 7,688 7,688(?) 7. Burma 2,000 1,904 8. C.P. Hindustani 20,505 28,827 9. C.P. Marathi 6,586 11,651 10. Bombay 17,000 11,889 11. Delhi 6,954 6,071 12. Gujarat 7,396 15,990 13. Karnatak 13,244 10,038 14. Kerala 7,747 3,265 15. Maharashtra 21,720 24,608 16. N.W.F.P. 2,000 2,000(?) 17. Punjab 51,784 27,490 18. Sind 8,200 2,615 19. Tamil Nad 51,784 4,500(?) 20. United Provinces 1,07,724 67,849 21. Utkal 12,421 6,945
('47', 226, 2, 10, 430821) TOTAL 5,87,908 4,48,16 The reader should not be satisfied with this table.
('47', 226, 2, 11, 430896) He must procure the bulletin and study the analysis given for each province and each district wherever it was available.
('47', 226, 2, 12, 431017) It will repay perusal, if he is at all patriotically inclined.
('47', 226, 2, 13, 431080) Barring Ajmer whose membership is
('47', 227, 0, 1, 431114) 228 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 227, 1, 2, 431156) under dispute, Gujarat tops the list with double its quota.
('47', 227, 1, 3, 431216) Besides Gujarat, Bihar, C.P. Hindustani and Marathi and Maharashtra are the only provinces that have done more than their quota.
('47', 227, 1, 4, 431345) Berar and N.W.F.P. have just done their quota.
('47', 227, 1, 5, 431392) The rest have not been able to reach it.
('47', 227, 1, 6, 431433) It will be remembered too that the requirement was one in every four hundred of the population, barring the Indian States population and barring Burma and N.W.F.P. This was low enough in all conscience.
('47', 227, 1, 7, 431636) There was a penalty attached to non fulfilment of the provision.
('47', 227, 1, 8, 431701) A fair effort was undoubtedly made by the workers in general to reach the quota required from their respective provinces.
('47', 227, 1, 9, 431823) At the Lucknow meeting the A.I.C.C. waived the penalty as it would have meant disqualifying most of the provinces.
('47', 227, 1, 10, 431938) But this waiver should really mean redoubled effort by the defaulters to make good their debt.
('47', 227, 1, 11, 432033) There is however a deeper truth underlying the figures presented by the bulletin.
('47', 227, 1, 12, 432115) We have not yet got enough workers nor have we penetrated the villages.
('47', 227, 1, 13, 432187) Many districts supposed to be backward have not been touched.
('47', 227, 1, 14, 432249) For Congress workers no district is backward, or if it is, it should command their greater ear and attention.
('47', 227, 1, 15, 432359) The backward portions of Bardoli are showing the greatest constructive activity.
('47', 227, 1, 16, 432440) The backward Champaran of yore has to its credit the highest number of marks.
('47', 227, 1, 17, 432518) It has 15,000 members enrolled against its quota of 4,522. It is invariably the experience that where solid, honest and sustained work has been done, people considered the most backward have responded in a most surprising manner.
('47', 227, 1, 18, 432748) Though, then, much has been done, infinitely more needs to be done for the attainment of our goal.
('47', 227, 1, 19, 432847) We may not be satisfied with the negative result that we are numerically better than the other political organizations.
('47', 227, 2, 20, 432967) Indeed there should be no competition between the Congress and the other organizations.
('47', 227, 2, 21, 433055) If we would be true to ourselves, the Congress would be admitted by all to be the only national organization to which the members of the other organizations, whilst retaining their own, would deem it a pride to belong.
('47', 227, 2, 22, 433274) For this consummation Congressmen should show striking results in constructive effort and broadest toleration towards those holding opposite views, so long as they do not come in conflict with the avowed object of the national organization.
('47', 228, 0, 1, 433515) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 229
('47', 228, 1, 2, 433564) Nor may we be satisfied with mere nominal membership.
('47', 228, 1, 3, 433618) The workers have to keep themselves in touch with the newly entrolled members.
('47', 228, 1, 4, 433697) They have to share their sorrows.
('47', 228, 1, 5, 433731) The new members may be strangers to khadi when they are enrolled.
('47', 228, 1, 6, 433797) The only requirement of membership is signing the creed and paying the trifling monetary or yarn subscription.
('47', 228, 1, 7, 433908) But a member loses the privilege of voting at Congress elections and other meetings, if he does not habitually wear khadi.
('47', 228, 1, 8, 434031) It is the duty of workers to explain this clause to the new members as also to give them the history of the Congress.
('47', 228, 1, 9, 434149) The workers should share their sorrows and their troubles, so that it may be noised abroad that the Congress is an instrument never of oppression and ever of real service to everyone in distress.

('47', 229, 2, 9, 436407) THE RIGHT WAY
('47', 229, 3, 10, 436421) One of the fine results of the new awakening is that young men are realizing more and more fully the dignity of labour and the dignity of callings that do not carry with them any breach of morals.
('47', 229, 3, 11, 436618) Thus in Ghazipur I found a barber who was educated there.
('47', 229, 3, 12, 436676) He was a schoolmaster in a primary school belonging to the Municipality of Ghazipur, but had not given up his hereditary calling and was adding to his meagre salary of Rs.17 nearly Rs.10 from his profession.
('47', 229, 3, 13, 436884) He said he could easily earn much more as a barber if he gave the whole of his time to it.
('47', 229, 3, 14, 436975) This barber schoolmaster is a convinced khadi wearer, and he told me that all his people spun during their leisure hours and they were all wearing khadi.
('47', 229, 3, 15, 437129) A barber is now undergoing a khadi service course at the Udyoga Mandir though he has not abandoned his calling.
('47', 229, 3, 16, 437241) I wish that these examples will prove far more contagious than they have hitherto done.
('47', 229, 3, 17, 437329) It is not enough that stray lawyers and doctors spin and weave, or stray barbers and tailors do national service, but thousands of professional men, artisans and agriculturists should, whilst following their callings, render national service by qualifying themselves, the literary professions by realizing the dignity of labour and the labouring professions by realizing the dignity of literature, and all doing everything to uplift the nation and refraining from doing anything that would degrade it.

('47', 230, 1, 2, 437904) 260. TULSIDAS 1
('47', 230, 2, 3, 437920) Several friends on various occasions have addresed to me criticisms regarding my attitude towards Tulsi Ramayana.
('47', 230, 2, 4, 438034) The substance of their criticisms is as follows:
('47', 230, 3, 5, 438083) You have described the Ramayana as the best of books, but we have never been able to reconcile ourselves with your view.
('47', 230, 3, 6, 438204) Do you not see how Tulsidas has disparaged womankind, defended Rama's unchivalrous ambuscade on Vali, Rama as an avatar in spite of his gross injustice to Sita?
('47', 230, 3, 7, 438365) What the poetic beauty of the book compensates for everything else?
('47', 230, 3, 8, 438433) If it is so then we venture to suggest that you have no qualifications for the task.
('47', 230, 4, 9, 438518) I admit that if we take the criticisms of every point individually they will be found difficult to refute and the whole of the Ramayana can, in this manner, be easily condemned.
('47', 230, 4, 10, 438696) But that can be said of almost everything and everybody.
('47', 230, 4, 11, 438753) There is a story related about a celebrated artist that in order to answer his critics he put his picture in a show window and invited visitors to indicate their opinion by marking the spot they did not like.
('47', 230, 4, 12, 438962) The result was that there was hardly any portion that was not covered by the crititics' marks.
('47', 230, 4, 13, 439057) As a matter of fact, however, the picture was a masterpiece of art.
('47', 230, 4, 14, 439125) Indeed even the Vedas, the Bible and the Koran have not been exempt from condemnation.
('47', 230, 4, 15, 439212) But their lovers fail to discover those faults in them.
('47', 230, 4, 16, 439268) In order to arrive at a proper estimate of a book it must be judged as a whole.
('47', 230, 4, 17, 439348) So much for external criticism.
('47', 230, 4, 18, 439380) The internal test of a book consists in finding out what effect it has produced on the majority of its readers.
('47', 230, 4, 19, 439492) Judged by either method the position of the Ramayana as a book par excellence remains unassailable.
('47', 230, 4, 20, 439592) This however does not mean that is absolutely faultless.
('47', 230, 4, 21, 439649) But it is claimed on behalf of the Ramayana that it has given peace to millions, has given faith to those who had it not, and is even today serving as a healing balm to thousands who are burnt by the fire of unbelief.
('47', 230, 4, 22, 439867) Every page of it is overflowing with devotion.
('47', 230, 4, 23, 439914) It is a veritable mine of spiritual experience.
('47', 230, 5, 24, 439962) 1 The Hindi original of this appeared in Hindi Navajivan, 10 10 1929. This is a translation by Pyarelal.

('47', 237, 0, 1, 450936) 238 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 237, 1, 2, 450978) 268. KHADDAR AND UNTOUCHABILITY: DUTY OF INDIAN MUNICIPALITIES
('47', 237, 2, 3, 451041) CAMP HARDOI,
('47', 237, 3, 4, 451054) October 12, 1929
('47', 237, 4, 5, 451071) I have been asked by the Editor to answer the following question for this Gazette:
('47', 237, 5, 6, 451154) What can Indian municipalities do in the matter of khaddar and untouchability?
('47', 237, 5, 7, 451233) My answer is as follows:
('47', 237, 6, 8, 451258) In the matter of khaddar a muncipality can help…
('47', 237, 7, 9, 451307) First, by prescribing the use of khaddar for the uniform of its employees.
('47', 237, 7, 10, 451382) This will be effective only if the members will themselves wear khaddar.
('47', 237, 8, 11, 451455) Secondly, by making all purchases of cloth for hospitals and the like in khaddar only.
('47', 237, 9, 12, 451542) Thirdly, by introducing the takli and carding bow in all the schools under its control.
('47', 237, 10, 13, 451630) Fourthly, by removing all duty upon khaddar and by giving grants to khaddar depots within municipal limits.
('47', 237, 11, 14, 451738) In the matter of untouchability a municipality can help…
('47', 237, 12, 15, 451795) First, by promoting the reform by insisting upon inspectors of municipal schools securing admission therein of a minimum number of ‘untouchable’ boys and girls
('47', 237, 13, 16, 451955) Secondly, by opening model schools specially for the instruction of ‘untouchable’ children.
('47', 237, 14, 17, 452047) Thirdly, by opening night schools for grown up ‘untouchables’ in its employ.
('47', 237, 15, 18, 452124) Fifthly, by inducing trustees of temples to open them to ‘untouchables’, and where this is not possible, by building attractive temples in suitable places, specially for the use of ‘untouchables’, but generally for public use, and encouraging the public to make use of these temples in common with the ‘untouchables’.
('47', 237, 16, 19, 452442) Sixthly, by giving grants to schools, temples and clubs, etc., that would specially cater for ‘untouchables’.
('47', 238, 0, 1, 452552) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 239
('47', 238, 1, 2, 452601) Untouchability is perhaps the greatest evil that has crept into Hinduism.
('47', 238, 1, 3, 452675) The nearest approach to it to be found in the West was untouchability of the Jews, who were confined to the ghettos.
('47', 238, 1, 4, 452792) I do not know the historical origin of this disease.
('47', 238, 1, 5, 452845) Socially it seems to have arisen from the desire of the so called superior classes to isolate themselves from those whom they regarded as inferior.
('47', 238, 1, 6, 452993) It is the excrescence of varnashrama dharma which has been misrepresented as the cast system with which, as seen in the multitudinous castes of latter day Hinduism, the original four divisions have little to do.
('47', 238, 2, 7, 453205) Untouchability in its mildest form takes the shape of not touchaing or having any social intercourse with the ‘untouchable’.
('47', 238, 2, 8, 453330) In its extreme form it becomes unapproachability and even invisibility.
('47', 238, 2, 9, 453402) The approach of a man within a defined distance or his very sight in some parts of the extreme south pollutes the ‘superior’ classes.
('47', 238, 2, 10, 453536) The ‘unapproachables’ and the ‘invisibles’ are very few in number, whereas the ‘untouchables’ are roughly estimated at sixty million.
('47', 238, 2, 11, 453670) In my opinion this is a highly exaggerated estimate.
('47', 238, 3, 12, 453723) Though I regard myself as a staunch Hindu believing in and having great veneration for the Vedas and the other Hindi religious books, and though I claim, not as a scholar but as a religiously minded man, to have made a serious attempt to understand the Hindu scriptures, I can discover no warrant for this brutal doctrine of untouchability in it.
('47', 238, 3, 13, 454070) Save for a few texts of doubtful authority in smritis, the whole doctrine of ‘untouchability’ is utterly repugnant to the spirit of Hinduism whose glory consits in proclaiming non violence to be the basis of religion and which lays down the bold formulae that all life, including the meanest crawling beings, is one.
('47', 238, 4, 14, 454387) But to a reformer like me this philosophical foundation of Hinduism affords but little comfort in the face of the cruel fact that professors of that religion regard innumerable fellow beings as beyond the pale of society solely on the ground of their birth in a particular group of men and women in every way like them.
('47', 238, 4, 15, 454707) But this untouchability will soon be a thing of past.
('47', 238, 4, 16, 454761) Hindu society has beocme conscious of the hideous wrong done to man by this sinful doctrine.
('47', 238, 4, 17, 454854) Hundreds of Hindu workers are devoting themselves to the uplift of these suppressed classes.
('47', 238, 4, 18, 454947) Among them may be named late Swami Shraddhanandji and the late Lala Lajpat Rai.
('47', 238, 4, 19, 455027) These, however, may not be regarded as orthodox.
('47', 238, 4, 20, 455076) Pandit Madan Mohan Malviyaji, who is accepted by all Hindus as an orthodox
('47', 239, 0, 1, 455151) 240 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 239, 1, 2, 455193) Hindu, has thrown in the weight of his great influence on the side of reform.
('47', 239, 1, 3, 455271) Everywhere one sees the process of emancipation silently but surely and steadily going on.
('47', 239, 1, 4, 455362) The so called higher class Hindus are conducting schools and building hostels for them, giving them medical relief and serving them in a variety of ways.
('47', 239, 1, 5, 455516) The effort is absolutely independent of the Government and is part of the process of purification that Hinduism is undergoing.
('47', 239, 1, 6, 455643) Lastly, the Indian National Congress adopted removal of untouchability as a vital part of its constructive programme in 1920. It may not be superfluous to add that while untouchability is undoubtedly a grave social wrong, it has no legal sanction behind it.
('47', 239, 1, 7, 455901) So far as I am aware, there is no legal disability against the ‘untouchables’.
('47', 239, 1, 8, 455980) The reformer has still a stiff task before him in having to convert the masses to his point of view.
('47', 239, 1, 9, 456081) The masses give intellectual assent to the reformers’ plea, but are slow to grant equality in practice to their outcaste brethren.
('47', 239, 1, 10, 456212) Nevertheless, untouchability is doomed, and Hinduism is saved.
('47', 239, 1, 11, 456275) And, as I have indicated above, our municipalities can do much to bring about this salvation.
('47', 239, 1, 12, 456369) M. K. GANDHI The Calcutta Municipal Gazette, Fifth Anniversary Number, Saturday, 23rd November, 1929; also S.N. 19854

('47', 244, 6, 11, 462666) In any case there would be other letters from the Ashram.

('47', 244, 6, 13, 462778) If you let Dwarkanath remain or keep him, we should pay him Rs.60. I think it would not be right to pay Rs.150 to Dinkarrai at present.

('47', 244, 6, 15, 463004) They will have no rent to pay.
('47', 244, 6, 16, 463035) Their manner of living will also change somewhat, so that, if they wish, they can easily reduce their future requirements.
('47', 244, 6, 17, 463158) If he has, therefore, no special requirements outside, I would prefer to pay them Rs.75 when we have had experience of him and can send him anywhere without hesitation.
('47', 244, 6, 18, 463327) Then he may, if he wishes to save money, be paid Rs.150. For the present we should think of keeping him in the Ashram in the hope that he will become an ideal dairy worker.
('47', 244, 6, 19, 463500) We should, therefore, decide to pay him according to our standard.
('47', 244, 6, 20, 463567) The Managing Commitee may take all this into account and decide what it thinks best.

('47', 245, 0, 1, 463716) 246 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 245, 1, 2, 463758) 279. GUJARATIS’ LOVE
('47', 245, 2, 3, 463779) When I am being inundated in every place by love, it would be pointless and even invidious for me to measure or compare the affec tion showered on me in the different regions.
('47', 245, 2, 4, 463955) the best way to acknow ledge this debt of love is to imbibe it silently or, if one may say so, to endure it.
('47', 245, 2, 5, 464064) Though I know this, I cannot always observe the rule.
('47', 245, 2, 6, 464118) Where there are Gujaratis, they single me out for favoured treatment and they do not expect me to repay my debt of love even to the extent of my acknowledging it.
('47', 245, 2, 7, 464281) One such recent incident took place in Kanpur which I cannot forget.
('47', 245, 2, 8, 464350) There the Gujaratis invited me to a separate meeting and considering their numbers and the extent of their business they gave me quite a decent sum when compared to the collections made there.
('47', 245, 2, 9, 464543) The amount was Rs. 1,152. But I am an avaricious man.
('47', 245, 2, 10, 464597) Therefore the collections of the citizens of Kanpur struck me as meagre.
('47', 245, 2, 11, 464670) I complained to Dr. Murarilal and he endorsed the complaint.
('47', 245, 2, 12, 464731) It was decided to make collections in the city.
('47', 245, 2, 13, 464779) It was after this was arranged that I went to the meeting of Gujaratis.
('47', 245, 2, 14, 464851) There also I lodged a similar complaint.
('47', 245, 2, 15, 464892) The meeting took up the complaint forthwith and added Rs. 1,039 14as 6 pies to the sum of Rs. 1,152. Apart from this, the children and their teachers contributed Rs. 25 4 as.
('47', 245, 2, 16, 465067) Thus, the total collection amounted to Rs. 2,217 2as 6 pies.
('47', 245, 2, 17, 465128) The money that Gujarati women contributed is not included in this.
('47', 245, 2, 18, 465195) I have all the details before me but it is not necessary to give those names.
('47', 245, 2, 19, 465273) This article has not been written to record donations or names of donors.
('47', 245, 2, 20, 465347) It is the overflow of my feelings.
('47', 245, 2, 21, 465382) There is no exaggeration if I say that such love keeps me alive and increases my optimism.
('47', 245, 2, 22, 465473) One can expect Rs. 200 from the man who donates Rs. 100, but not a pie from one who donates nothing.
('47', 245, 2, 23, 465574) The Gujaratis who feed me with this potion of love should not sit back contented.
('47', 245, 2, 24, 465656) I have written often and reiterate that foreign traders rule over us and hence if Indian traders are vigilant, the winning of swaraj will be child’s play.
('47', 245, 2, 25, 465811) If gunmen were ruling over us, some revolutionaries would have proved the necessity of guns.
('47', 245, 2, 26, 465904) But where the Government is carried on for the sake of trade, it can be easily seen that if trade goes, the Government will also follow suit.
('47', 245, 2, 27, 466046) That trade can be captured in two ways: One is to become like the foreign trader, the other is not to let that trade go on.
('47', 245, 2, 28, 466170) Now his main trade is that in cloth, the others are organized behind it.
('47', 245, 2, 29, 466243) Many of his cargo ships are dependent on the cotton trade.
('47', 245, 2, 30, 466302) And if the
('47', 246, 0, 1, 466313) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 247
('47', 246, 1, 2, 466362) cotton trade goes, the steamers too come down crashing.
('47', 246, 1, 3, 466418) This is not my assertion but that of an English writer.
('47', 246, 1, 4, 466474) Hence those Gujaratis and other Indians who contribute money are to a small extent doing atonement.
('47', 246, 1, 5, 466574) True atonement consists in purifying one’s trade.
('47', 246, 1, 6, 466624) The giving up of a trade which harms the nation is alone the true atonement.
('47', 246, 1, 7, 466701) Those who contribute money say themselves that they have become conscious of this.
('47', 246, 1, 8, 466784) When those who have understood act according to that understanding, one should take it that swaraj has been won.
('47', 246, 1, 9, 466897) And this alone will be true swaraj.
('47', 246, 1, 10, 466933) This biggest of trades is in the hands of Gujaratis and Marwaris.
('47', 246, 1, 11, 466999) Here the world ‘Gujaratis’ should be understood in its larger connotation as referring to those who speak the Gujarati language, so that the term includes all the people who live in Gujarat such as Muslims, Parsis, Christians and others.
('47', 246, 1, 12, 467237) Therefore, if these two provinces wake up, the other provinces will surely do so of their own accord.
('47', 246, 1, 13, 467339) I daily look forward to that auspicious time.
('47', 246, 1, 14, 467385) The Gujaratis’ love for me fills me with the hope that their contribution towards this end will be a large one.
('47', 246, 1, 15, 467497) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 13 10 1929
('47', 246, 2, 16, 467535) 280. A RUINOUS VICE
('47', 246, 3, 17, 467555) A gentleman from distant Uganda writes: 1
('47', 246, 4, 18, 467597) We can call this a national vice.
('47', 246, 4, 19, 467631) It betrays our rudeness and apathy towards our neighbours.
('47', 246, 4, 20, 467690) That this vice still persists despite the awakening among us shows our indolence.
('47', 246, 4, 21, 467772) It of course spreads diseases and we are rightly maligned for it in the West.
('47', 246, 4, 22, 467850) This vice is contrary to religion.
('47', 246, 4, 23, 467885) When I returned to our country in the year 1915, this filthy habit had caught my attention well enough and I tried to find out what the various religions had to say about it.
('47', 246, 4, 24, 468060) I do not remember where the collection of extracts is at the moment.
('47', 246, 4, 25, 468129) But during this tour I came across one or two stanzas from the Hindu Shastras whose gist I give below:
('47', 246, 5, 26, 468232) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('47', 246, 5, 27, 468269) The correspondent had referred to the Indians’ bad habit of spitting almost anywhere…near them, on the road or in a railway carriage…and thereby causing the spread of infection through flies.
('47', 246, 5, 28, 468461) He had also alluded to the practice, prevalent in Paris, of carrying small boxes for use as spittoons.
('47', 247, 0, 1, 468564) 248 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 247, 1, 2, 468606) No one should urinate or defecate or spit into rivers, ponds, etc.
('47', 247, 1, 3, 468673) —Krishnayajurveda No one should urinate or defecate in the middle of a village or a town or in temples, cremation grounds, open spaces, watering places or on roads.
('47', 247, 1, 4, 468838) —CHARAKA One should not indulge in such acts as rubbing the nose, gnashing the teeth, biting the nails, cracking one’s finger joints, digging the ground [with one’s toe], plucking grassblades or playing with the earth, etc., etc.
('47', 247, 1, 5, 469068) —CHARAKA From this we now see that that civilization has been destroyed.
('47', 247, 1, 6, 469141) Or one may say that at the time when the above treatises were written, these habits were prevalent among the people and therefore the saints drew our attention to them.
('47', 247, 1, 7, 469310) But these habits have not been corrected till today.
('47', 247, 1, 8, 469363) Whatever the state of affairs in the past, we should devise remedies to get rid of them now.
('47', 247, 1, 9, 469456) The correspondent regards as unacceptable two of the remedies adopted in the West.
('47', 247, 1, 10, 469539) They are no doubt disgusting but how can we hope for plesant remedies when our body itself is a storehouse of urine and excreta?
('47', 247, 1, 11, 469668) We should perform these activities in such a way that we ourselves and our neighbours are spared the risk of spread of disease.
('47', 247, 1, 12, 469796) Only this much is possible.
('47', 247, 1, 13, 469824) While walking on a public road, if one coughs and has to spit out phlegm, there is no other way but to spit into a handkerchief or a spittoon such as a clean box.
('47', 247, 1, 14, 469987) If one has to spit into a handkerchief, the handkerchief which has been used once should be folded and put into the pocket in such a way that neither the hand nor the pocket gets soiled.
('47', 247, 1, 15, 470174) Only a man who has got tuberculosis and is obliged to spit very often needs to keep a small box.
('47', 247, 1, 16, 470271) But there are many occasions when it is not necessary to do so.
('47', 247, 1, 17, 470335) When we are seated in a train, one should take the trouble to spit out of the window.
('47', 247, 1, 18, 470421) When going along a road, one should seek a lonely spot which is not frequented and spit, etc., in a bush or in some corner there.
('47', 247, 1, 19, 470551) To one who has the power of discriminating between good and evil and who cares for the convenience of others, easy solutions will readily suggest themselves.
('47', 247, 1, 20, 470709) Before setting out on a short or long journey, a thoughtful man will so arrange the calls of nature as to cause the least inconvenience to others.
('47', 247, 1, 21, 470856) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 13 10 1929

('47', 248, 6, 16, 471766) 282. LETTER TO ISHWARLAL JOSHI
('47', 248, 7, 17, 471797) MORADABAD, October 13, 1929
('47', 248, 8, 18, 471825) ISHWARLAL, If Chhaganbhai permits you, you may certainly have one year off.
('47', 248, 8, 19, 471901) I would advise you to go to Madras.
('47', 248, 8, 20, 471937) There you will be able to communicate with people only in English.
('47', 248, 8, 21, 472004) I would put you in Rajagopalachari’s Ashram so that you may learn English and also help him.
('47', 248, 8, 22, 472097) One cannot learn English by reading a book for eight hours.
('47', 248, 8, 23, 472157) But one learns it easily if one speaks and hears only English.

('47', 249, 7, 17, 473270) 284. SPEECH AT MORADABAD
('47', 249, 8, 18, 473295) October 13, 1929
('47', 249, 9, 19, 473312) Amidst the cries of “Long Live Revolution” and “Vande Mataram”, Mahatma Gandhi was received at the railway station by a large concourse of people.
('47', 249, 9, 20, 473459) He and his party statyed at the house of Moulvi Abdul Salam where a grand dinner was given in his honour.
('47', 249, 10, 21, 473565) In the morning Mahatmaji performed the opening ceremony of the Brijratan Hindu Public Library.
('47', 249, 10, 22, 473660) He put to sale a chain attached to the library lock which fetched Rs. 76.
('47', 249, 11, 23, 473734) On the town hall grounds he received addresses from the municipal and district boards and put to sale the caskets in which the addresses were presented.
('47', 249, 11, 24, 473887) He was very
('47', 250, 0, 1, 473899) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 251
('47', 250, 1, 2, 473948) keen on the collection of funds while the audience wanted to have a long speech on the burning problems of the day.
('47', 250, 2, 3, 474064) When a purse of Rs. 2,385 was presented to him he was requested to accept it in the spirit in which shri Krishna had accepted rice offered by Sudama.
('47', 250, 3, 4, 474214) Mahatma Gandhi, however, said that whereas Sudama had given his all which consisted of only rice, Moradabad with its large population had contributed very little.
('47', 250, 3, 5, 474377) he had received a telegram saying that Moradabad was not prepared to offer a large purse, but received later a telegram from the students saying that they were working hard to collect funds and were inviting him.
('47', 250, 3, 6, 474590) He asked where those students were then.
('47', 250, 3, 7, 474631) If they could not offer a purse befitting the position of Moradabad why did they invite him?
('47', 250, 4, 8, 474724) Referring to the addresses, he said that the best use he could make of the caskets was to sell them as he did not want them for himself.
('47', 250, 5, 9, 474861) He complained of a circular issued by the district board asking teachers to see that their pupils abstained from talking of the freedom of the country.
('47', 250, 5, 10, 475013) He did not want to see their children wearing the chains of slavery and characterized such a circular issued by a board with an elected chairman and a majority of elected members as shameful.
('47', 250, 5, 11, 475205) People generally got themselves elected for personal gain which he condemned.
('47', 250, 6, 12, 475283) Referring to the municipal board address, he said that though it boasted of the absence of communal friction he would call this state of affairs a mere armed neutrality.
('47', 250, 6, 13, 475453) He would like to see real love between the communities and by having such love Moradabad could set an example to the whole of India.
('47', 250, 6, 14, 475586) It was doubly the duty of the young men of these provinces to make the Congress a huge success as India had successively selected two Presidents, father and son, from U.P.

('47', 252, 1, 7, 478481) In this case the husband does possess a fairly good knowledge of Gujarati.
('47', 252, 1, 8, 478556) I do not mind if the other members of his family do not have such knowledge.

('47', 252, 1, 10, 478758) The members of the husband’s family cannot stand in the way of their doing so.
