('47', 256, 6, 13, 486380) 290. STATEMENT ON AHMEDABAD LABOUR DISPUTE1
('47', 256, 7, 14, 486424) DEHRADUN,
('47', 256, 8, 15, 486434) October 16, 1929
('47', 256, 9, 16, 486451) Shethshri Mangaldas has sent me for my comments a copy of the statement presented to the Sarpanch.
('47', 256, 9, 17, 486550) I have gone through it.
('47', 256, 9, 18, 486574) I think that a number of points made in it are improper.
('47', 256, 9, 19, 486631) According to my understanding, the insistence that the cut in wages effected in 1923 was binding for all time had been given up.
('47', 256, 9, 20, 486760) Moreover, even in his statement, Sheth Mangaldas does not insist that the labourers cannot demand, after the cut of 1923, that the same be abrogated and hence, though he has written at length about it, there is no propriety in my giving a reply to it.
('47', 256, 9, 21, 487012) As an arbitrator, he gave no award in 1923. This much is clear that for whatever happened in 1923 he is not to blame, but if there is anyone to be blamed it is the Mill owners’ Association.
('47', 256, 9, 22, 487202) According to me there is truly speaking only one point before the Sarpanch for decision: Whether the wages which the labourers receive today are less than their expenditure in the light of the prices of foodgrains, etc., obtaining today and if they are less, whether at
('47', 256, 10, 23, 487472) 1 Between the Mill owners’ Association and the Ahmedabad Labour Union; Mangaldas Girdhardas and Gandhiji acted as arbitrators and K. M. Jhaveri as the Umpire.
('47', 256, 10, 24, 487631) For Gandhiji’s comments on the award, vide “An Important Award”, 12 12 1929.
('47', 257, 0, 1, 487708) 258 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 257, 1, 2, 487750) least in order to make up the deficit their wages should be increased or not.
('47', 257, 2, 3, 487828) The evidence given from the side of the labourers on this point clearly proves that the total of all their earnings is less than the necessary expense which they incur every month.
('47', 257, 2, 4, 488009) In Sheth Mangaldas’s statement I have not been able to see any rebuttal of this submission.
('47', 257, 2, 5, 488101) Therefore there is not much that I can add to what I have said in my verdict 1. But I should draw the Sarpanch’s attention to one thing.
('47', 257, 2, 6, 488238) The cut in wages is a question of life and death to the labourers.
('47', 257, 2, 7, 488305) To the mills it was and is one of effecting a cut and maintaining it with a view to increasing their reduced profits.
('47', 257, 2, 8, 488423) I hold that, as long as the mills make some profit, one cannot effect any cut in the living wage of the labourers.
('47', 257, 2, 9, 488538) Prior to the cut, this living wage was not a living wageat all.
('47', 257, 2, 10, 488602) It is however true that the prices of foodgrains today are lower than those prevailing in the year 1923. Nevertheless it is a sad and surprising thing that the evidence put before the arbitrator proves that the expense incurred by the labourers today on foodgrains at those lower prices is higher than their wages.
('47', 257, 2, 11, 488917) The figures presented by the labourers have been supported in two ways.
('47', 257, 2, 12, 488989) An examination of the wages received and the calculation therefrom of the total savings and of the figures emerging from two Government enquiries makes it clear that the Government reports also support the statement of expenditure presented on behalf of the labourers.
('47', 257, 3, 13, 489258) I feel that both the mill owners and Sheth Mangaldas have failed to understand the present condition of the labourers.
('47', 257, 3, 14, 489377) It is to be hoped that the Sarpanch will appreciate that position.
('47', 257, 4, 15, 489444) If the Sarpanch has nothing specific to know from me, I have nothing more to say.
('47', 257, 5, 16, 489526) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: S.N. 14979
('47', 257, 6, 17, 489571) 1 Vide “Note on dispute Between Mill Owners and Workers”, 7 9 1929

('47', 260, 10, 11, 493128) 295. IS IT VILLAGE UPLIFT?
('47', 260, 11, 12, 493155) Some time ago prominent notice was taken in the public press of Mr. F. L. Brayne’s work for the uplift of the villagers in the Gurgaon district in the Punjab.
('47', 260, 11, 13, 493314) Mr. Brayne was in charge of that district.
('47', 260, 11, 14, 493357) These notices attracted my attention, and I felt that if the account given by Mr. Brayne was a true picture of the progress made in Gurgaon, it was worthy of close study and imitation.
('47', 260, 11, 15, 493542) I therefore requested Lalaji’s Society 2 to undertake local inspection of the actual work done.
('47', 260, 11, 16, 493638) Lala Deshraj, a graduate member of the Society, was deputed for the work.
('47', 260, 11, 17, 493712) He has prepared an exhaustive report of his inspection.
('47', 260, 11, 18, 493768) I reproduce it 3 with but slight omissions.
('47', 260, 11, 19, 493812) It will repay perusal.
('47', 260, 11, 20, 493835) Mr. Brayne has procured cautiously worded certificates of his work from the Viceroy as also the Governor of the Punjab.
('47', 260, 11, 21, 493955) But I would not anticipate Lala Deshraj.
('47', 260, 11, 22, 493996) My remarks I reserve till the reportis fully published.
('47', 260, 11, 23, 494052) 4 The reader will have to wait for another issue of Young India to see the conclusion of the report.

('47', 261, 1, 2, 494510) 296. POSITION OF WOMEN
('47', 261, 2, 3, 494533) A fair friend 1, who has hitherto successfully resisted the matrimonial temptation, writes:
('47', 261, 3, 4, 494625) There was a women’s conference yesterday at the Malabari Hall at which many sound speeches were made, and many resolutions passed.
('47', 261, 3, 5, 494756) The question of the evening was the Sarda Bill.
('47', 261, 3, 6, 494804) We are so glad you uphold the age of 18 for girls.
('47', 261, 3, 7, 494855) Another important resolution dealt with the laws of inheritance.
('47', 261, 3, 8, 494920) What a help it would be if you wrote a strong article on this subject in Navajivan and Young India !
('47', 261, 3, 9, 495021) Why should women have either to beg or to fight in order to win back their birthright?
('47', 261, 3, 10, 495108) It is strange—and also tragically comic—to hear man born of woman talk loftily of ‘the weaker sex’ and nobly promising ‘to give’ us our due!
('47', 261, 3, 11, 495249) What is this nonsense about ‘giving’?
('47', 261, 3, 12, 495287) Where is the ‘nobility’ and ‘chivalry’ in restoring to people that which has been unlawfully wrested from them by those having brute power in their hands?
('47', 261, 3, 13, 495442) Wherein are women less important than men?
('47', 261, 3, 14, 495485) Why should their share of inheritance be less than that of men?
('47', 261, 3, 15, 495549) Why should it not be equal?
('47', 261, 3, 16, 495577) We were discussing this very heatedly with some people a couple of days ago.
('47', 261, 3, 17, 495654) A lady said, “We don’t need any change in the law.
('47', 261, 3, 18, 495705) We are quite content.
('47', 261, 3, 19, 495727) After all, it is but fair that the son, who carries on the name and family traditions, should have the greater share.
('47', 261, 3, 20, 495845) He is the mainstay of the family....” We said, “And what about the girl?” “Oh”, intervened a strapping young man who was there, “the other fellow will look after her!” There you are.
('47', 261, 3, 21, 496028) The ‘other fellow’!
('47', 261, 3, 22, 496048) Always the other fellow!
('47', 261, 3, 23, 496073) The other fellow is an absolute nuisance!
('47', 261, 3, 24, 496115) Why should there be another fellow?
('47', 261, 3, 25, 496151) Why should it be taken for granted that there will be another fellow?
('47', 261, 3, 26, 496221) They talk as though a girl were a bale of goods to be tolerated in the parental house until ‘the other fellow’ comes round, and then coolly handed over to him with a sigh of relief.
('47', 261, 3, 27, 496403) Really wouldn’t you be wild if you were a girl?
('47', 261, 3, 28, 496451) I do not need to be a girl to be wild over man’s atrocities towards woman.
('47', 261, 3, 29, 496526) I count the law of inheritance among the least in the list.
('47', 261, 3, 30, 496586) The Sarda Bill deals with an evil far greater than the one which the law of inheritance connotes.
('47', 261, 3, 31, 496684) But I am uncompromising in the matter of woman’s rights.
('47', 261, 3, 32, 496741) In my opinion she should labourunder no legal disability not suffered by man.
('47', 261, 3, 33, 496819) I should treat the daughters and sons on a footing of perfect equality.
('47', 261, 3, 34, 496891) As women begin to realize their strength, as they must in proportion to the education they receive, they will naturally resent the glaring inequalities to which
('47', 261, 4, 35, 497052) 1 Raihana Tyabji; vide “Letter to Raihana Tyabji”, 9 10 1929
('47', 262, 0, 1, 497113) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 263
('47', 262, 1, 2, 497162) they are subjected.
('47', 262, 1, 3, 497182) But to remove legal inequalities will be a mere palliative.
('47', 262, 1, 4, 497242) The root of the evil lies much deeper than most people realize.
('47', 262, 1, 5, 497306) It lies in man’s greed of power and fame and deeper still in mutual lust.
('47', 262, 1, 6, 497380) Man has always desired power.
('47', 262, 1, 7, 497410) Ownership of property gives this power.
('47', 262, 1, 8, 497450) Man hankers also after posthumous fame based on power.
('47', 262, 1, 9, 497505) This cannot be had, if property is progressively cut up in pieces as it must be if all the posterity become equal co sharers.
('47', 262, 1, 10, 497631) Hence the descent of property for the most part on the eldest male issue.
('47', 262, 1, 11, 497705) Most women are married.
('47', 262, 1, 12, 497729) And they are co sharers, in spite of the law being against them, in their husbands’ power and privileges.
('47', 262, 1, 13, 497835) They delight in being ladies this and what not, simply for the fact of being the wives of particular lords.
('47', 262, 1, 14, 497943) Though therefore they may vote for radical reform in academic discussions over inequalities, when it comes to acting up to their vote, they will be found to be unwilling to part with the privileges.
('47', 262, 1, 15, 498142) Whilst therefore I would always advocate the repeal of all legal disqualifications, I should have the enlightened women of India to deal with the root cause.
('47', 262, 1, 16, 498300) Woman is the embodiment of sacrifice and suffering, and her advent to public life should therefore result in purifying it, in restraining unbridled ambition and accumulation of property.
('47', 262, 1, 17, 498487) Let them know that millions of men have no property to transmit to posterity.
('47', 262, 1, 18, 498565) Let us learn from them that it is better for the few to have no ancestral property at all.
('47', 262, 1, 19, 498656) The real property that a parent can transmit to all equally is his or her character and educational facilities.
('47', 262, 1, 20, 498768) Parents should seek to make their sons and daughters self reliant, well able to earn an honest livelihood by the sweat of the brow.
('47', 262, 1, 21, 498900) The upbringing of minor children will then naturally devolve upon the major descendants.
('47', 262, 1, 22, 498989) Much of the present imbecility of the children of the wealthy will go, if the latter could but substitute the worthy ambition of educating their children to become independent for the unworthy ambition of making them slaves of ancestral property, which kills enterprise and feeds the passions which accompany idleness and luxury.
('47', 262, 1, 23, 499319) The privilege of the awakened women should be to spot and eradicate age long evils.
('47', 262, 1, 24, 499403) That mutual lust too has played an important part in bringing about the disqualifications of the fair sex hardly needs any demonstration, Woman has circumvented man in a variety ofways in her unconsciously subtle ways, as man has vainly and equally unconsciously struggled to thwart woman in gaining ascendancy over
('47', 263, 0, 1, 499719) 264 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 263, 1, 2, 499761) The result is a stalemate.
('47', 263, 1, 3, 499788) Thus viewed, it is a serious problem the enlightened daughters of Bharat Mata are called upon to solve.
('47', 263, 1, 4, 499892) They may not ape the manner of the West which may be suited to its environment.
('47', 263, 1, 5, 499972) They must apply methods suited to the Indian genius and Indian environment.
('47', 263, 1, 6, 500048) Theirs must be the strong, controlling, purifying, steadying hand, conserving what is best in our culture and unhesitatingly rejecting what is base and degrading.
('47', 263, 1, 7, 500211) This is the work of Sitas, Draupadis, Savitris and Damayantis, not of amazons and prudes.
('47', 263, 2, 8, 500301) Young India, 17 10 1929
('47', 263, 3, 9, 500325) 297. MY SILENCE
('47', 263, 4, 10, 500341) I had hoped that by this time my correspondents had realized that, if I was silent on any question that agitated the country, the silence was maintained in its interest or on similar valid grounds, and that therefore they would not deluge me with inquiries and protests regarding my deliberate silence over the self immolation of Jatindranath Das 1 and the question of hunger strikers generally.
('47', 263, 4, 11, 500737) At Gorakhpur in one of the addresses received by me the question was directly put to me, and I was in courtesy bound to answer it.
('47', 263, 4, 12, 500868) My answer was that the silence was observed entirely in the national interest.
('47', 263, 4, 13, 500947) I had felt that an expression of my opinion was likely to do more harm than good to the cause for which brave Jatindra fasted unto death.
('47', 263, 4, 14, 501085) There are occasions when silence is wisdom.
('47', 263, 4, 15, 501129) This I hold to be such an occasion.
('47', 263, 4, 16, 501165) I may inform the reader that there are very many important questions affecting the nation on which, though I hold strong and decided views, I maintain absolute silence, for I believe that it often becomes the duty of every public man to be silent even at the risk of incurring unpopularity and even a much worse penalty, as it undoubtedly becomes his duty to speak out his mind when the occasion requires it, though it may be at the cost of his life.
('47', 263, 4, 17, 501616) So far as the philosophy of hunger strikes is concerned, I have given the fullest expression to my general views in these pagesmore often than once.
('47', 263, 4, 18, 501765) It is therefore unnecessary for me to expound them any further.
('47', 263, 4, 19, 501829) I regret
('47', 263, 5, 20, 501838) 1 A political worker who, while being tried in the Lahore Conspiracy case, went on fast in the Lahore jail as a protest against the discriminatory treatment meted out to Indian prisoners.
('47', 263, 5, 21, 502026) He died on September 13,1929, the sixty fourth day of his fast.

('47', 264, 1, 2, 502139) that I can give my numerous correspondents no further satisfaction.

('47', 264, 1, 4, 502326) For I hold that even a criminal is entitled to decent treatment and decent food.
('47', 264, 1, 5, 502407) I also hold that an under trial prisoner must be presumed at least by the public to be innocent, and for that matter what I have heard about Jatindranath Das is all in praise of him, and I have been assured that he was no more capable of doing or contemplating violence than I should be myself.

('47', 264, 3, 7, 502726) 298. SYLLABUS IN INDIAN ECONOMICS
('47', 264, 4, 8, 502760) Our economics syllabus is not concerned with world economics, but with Indian economics.
('47', 264, 4, 9, 502849) We know from experience that the economics of each country varies in some ways from the economics of other countries.
('47', 264, 4, 10, 502967) Looked at from the point of view of the towns and the villages, the difference may be more pronounced.
('47', 264, 4, 11, 503070) The following syllabus is chalked out on the assumption that the civilization of India is dependent on the condition of the villages and their full growth.
('47', 264, 5, 12, 503226) FIRST TERM
('47', 264, 6, 13, 503237) Teachers should take the pupils with them and visit some village and, there, get the pupils collect facts relating to the economy of the village and thus give them a practical lesson in economics; that is, make them ascertain its population, the number of men, women, boys and girls living in it and prepare statistical tables; then compile a statement of the occupations, the number of people employed in the various occupations, and the income accruing from them.
('47', 264, 6, 14, 503703) They should also measure the area within its boundaries, calculate the per capita area of land, find out what crops are raised on the land, how it is manured, what kind of farm implements are used, what the expenditure on agriculture is and how much the produce.
('47', 264, 6, 15, 503966) Then they should get them to collect figures for the produce and expenditure during the past ten years and from that deduce whether agriculture is a profitable occupation or a losing concern.
('47', 264, 6, 16, 504158) Let them find out thenumber of live stock, the expenditure on them, the amount of milk, etc., their feed, availability of a stud bull in the village, the utility of
('47', 264, 7, 17, 504323) 1 Vide “Letter to C. Rajagopalachari”, 18 10 1929,
('47', 265, 0, 1, 504374) 266 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 265, 1, 2, 504416) calves, the extent of pasture land, and if such land is not available whether there is enough space for the cattle for movement and fresh air.
('47', 265, 1, 3, 504559) Whether the farmer keeps accounts, and if so, what manner of accounts he maintains should be inspected.
('47', 265, 1, 4, 504663) How much leisure the farmers get and how they spend it should also be ascertained.
('47', 265, 1, 5, 504746) After this extensive observation and investigation the pupils should draw their own conclusions and give suggestions for the improvement of the village.
('47', 265, 1, 6, 504899) The pupils’ reports should be written in ink neatly and in a good hand.
('47', 265, 2, 7, 504971) SECOND TERM
('47', 265, 3, 8, 504983) All the information gathered by various groups of such students should be collated, the results of their findings should be compared with those of other agricultural countries and then the differences between India and those other agricultural countries should be analysed.
('47', 265, 4, 9, 505257) THIRD TERM
('47', 265, 5, 10, 505268) The results of these independent investigations should be compared with the economic data taught in India and any additions or deletions that are necessary should be made and through such practical training alone should the student learn the economics of India.
('47', 265, 6, 11, 505530) NOTE: If every year new students undertake the study of economics according to the aforesaid syllabus, it will entail no harm.
('47', 265, 6, 12, 505657) On the other hand, such work may lead to new conclusions or may progressively confirm the accepted theories.
('47', 265, 6, 13, 505766) There should be no need to go to a village which has already been studied and surveyed.
('47', 265, 7, 14, 505854) [From Hindi]
('47', 265, 8, 15, 505867) Hindi Navajivan, 17 10 1929
('47', 265, 9, 16, 505895) 299. THE DUTY OF A VOLUNTEER
('47', 265, 10, 17, 505924) As I am getting to know the volunteers during my tour of the U.P. I find that they badly need training.
('47', 265, 10, 18, 506028) The volunteers’ ideals are pure, they are not lacking in love but the energy which should spring from idealism and love is missing for want of training.
('47', 265, 10, 19, 506181) They have very little organizing capacity.
('47', 265, 10, 20, 506224) Because of this, rather than any help forthcoming often new difficulties crop up.
('47', 265, 10, 21, 506306) It is therefore essential to
('47', 266, 0, 1, 506335) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 267
('47', 266, 1, 2, 506384) train them.
('47', 266, 1, 3, 506396) They may well be volunteers at heart but nothing much will be achieved by that.
('47', 266, 1, 4, 506476) Even for the easiest of jobs, some training is required.
('47', 266, 1, 5, 506533) Even the work of a scavenger cannot be performed without training.
('47', 266, 1, 6, 506600) How can the work of a volunteer succeed without it?
('47', 266, 1, 7, 506652) The volunteer is the soldier of the nation.
('47', 266, 1, 8, 506696) Ultimately we hope to win swaraj through him.
('47', 266, 1, 9, 506742) The members of a national organization should possess great qualities.
('47', 266, 1, 10, 506813) The volunteers 1. should be capable of maintaining order in large gatherings; 2. should know the national language; 3. should be able to communicate their thoughts to other volunteers through signals; 4. should be able to stop noise; 5. should be able to clear a way through a mass of people; 6. should be able to march to drum beat; 7. should be able to render first aid in case of injury; 8. should be able to put up with people’s abuses, acrimony, assault, taunts, etc.; 9. should be able to endure Government’s punishment, such as imprisonment, etc.; 10. should possess the qualities of patience, truthfulness, firmness, bravery, ahimsa and the like.
('47', 266, 1, 11, 507468) Besides, in my view, the volunteers should always wear khadi.
('47', 266, 1, 12, 507530) They should also spin regularly by way of yajna.
('47', 266, 1, 13, 507579) In order to impart this kind of training every province should have volunteer training centres as also textbooks suitable to our country.
('47', 266, 1, 14, 507717) All the strength necessary in a ‘violent’ soldier is essential for a non violent soldier also—except the violence part of it.
('47', 266, 1, 15, 507843) But compared to the violent soldier, the non violent soldier requires many more qualities.
('47', 266, 1, 16, 507934) The readers must be aware of them.
('47', 266, 2, 17, 507969) [From Hindi]

('47', 269, 4, 11, 511848) My experiment among the 44 was carried on without milk and without any cooked food and the vast majority failed hopelessly.

('47', 275, 6, 12, 519786) He once gave as a donation a cow that was a burden to him.
('47', 275, 6, 13, 519845) Nachiketa gently asked his father why he had done so and what he expected to gain by such a donation.
('47', 275, 6, 14, 519947) The father cursed N. who took it in good part [and] wrested from Yamaraj 2
('47', 275, 7, 15, 520022) a change of heart for the father.
('47', 275, 7, 16, 520056) Love melts mountains.
('47', 275, 7, 17, 520078) Not to speak to father when you have something against him will be sin.
('47', 275, 7, 18, 520150) Most probably he has good reasons for his action but supposing he is in error, he will retrace his steps the earliest when he is warned by loved ones.
('47', 275, 7, 19, 520301) Therefore the sooner you speak to father the better.
('47', 275, 7, 20, 520354) Only you should have no anger in you.
('47', 275, 7, 21, 520392) I am sure he will take it all in good part.
('47', 275, 7, 22, 520436) You should wean him too from speculation.
('47', 275, 7, 23, 520478) He needs to hoard wealth for nobody now.
('47', 275, 7, 24, 520519) Even you in spite of your frail body can earn your way.
('47', 275, 7, 25, 520575) God has given you a voice that would any day support you.
('47', 275, 7, 26, 520633) And after all God alone is responsible for our maintenance if we would but trust Him.

('47', 279, 0, 1, 524758) 280 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 279, 1, 2, 524800) 320. ANARCHY OF THOUGHT
('47', 279, 2, 3, 524824) As a small example of unrestrained imagination, I publish the following letter 1: I receive many similar and even worse letters.
('47', 279, 2, 4, 524953) Friends have sent me newspaper cuttings containing similar views.
('47', 279, 2, 5, 525019) Where there is freedom of expression, such things are bound to happen.
('47', 279, 2, 6, 525090) It only shows how incoherently one can think.
('47', 279, 2, 7, 525136) This disorder exposes weakness of mind.
('47', 279, 2, 8, 525176) Because of this weakness, the thought process works haphazardly instead of in an orderly manner and no correlation gets established.
('47', 279, 2, 9, 525309) Many times this happens owing to anger also.
('47', 279, 2, 10, 525354) The effects of anger resemble those produced by wine and opium.
('47', 279, 2, 11, 525418) In the first fit, an angry man runs amuck.
('47', 279, 2, 12, 525461) And then after the fit is past, the anger works like an opiate and dulls the rational faculties just like opium.
('47', 279, 2, 13, 525574) Like opium, it consumes his mind.
('47', 279, 2, 14, 525608) Infatuation, failure of memory and destruction of the mind are the successive symptoms of anger.
('47', 279, 2, 15, 525705) I find all this in the above letter according to my lights.
('47', 279, 2, 16, 525765) The writer is a good man but in a fit of anger he has forgotten what has been written in Navajivan.
('47', 279, 2, 17, 525865) All of a sudden he has become incapable of judging whether articles on social reforms can appear in a newspaper which exists only for swaraj.
('47', 279, 2, 18, 526007) The writer has narrowed down the very meaning of swaraj itself.
('47', 279, 2, 19, 526071) The gentleman seems to believe that swaraj means the transfer of power from British hands to Indian hands.
('47', 279, 2, 20, 526178) To my mind swaraj means regulated power in the hands of thirty crores of people.
('47', 279, 2, 21, 526259) Where there is such rule, even a young girl will feel herself safe and, if the imagination of a poet is correct, animals like dogs, etc., who live among human beings will have a similar feeling of safety.
('47', 279, 2, 22, 526464) We shall have to arrive at various basic decisions in regard to swaraj because under swaraj such decisions are not subject to officials in power but are based on truth and justice.
('47', 279, 2, 23, 526645) I have succinctly called
('47', 279, 3, 24, 526670) 1 The letter is not translated here.

('47', 297, 6, 21, 555950) 347. ECONOMIES OF CATTLE BREEDING
('47', 297, 7, 22, 555984) When I was convalescing in Bangalore two years ago, 3 Mr. William Smith, the Imperial Dairy Expert, gave me a precis of a statement he submitted to the Agricultural Committee in Poona.
('47', 297, 7, 23, 556169) I extract from it the following valuable information 4 and commend it to the attention of everyone interested in the economic well being of India.
('47', 297, 8, 24, 556316) 1 Raja Jang Bahadur Sinh of Barua, addressee’s husband 2 Addressee’s sister in law 3 April 19 to August 31, 1927 4 Not reproduced here.
('47', 297, 8, 25, 556452) William Smith had analysed the causes and recommended remedies for the poor condition of milch Cows and draught bullocks.
('47', 298, 0, 1, 556574) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 299
('47', 298, 1, 2, 556623) This is a tremendous problem.
('47', 298, 1, 3, 556653) The poverty of the cow is reflected in the poverty of the people.
('47', 298, 1, 4, 556719) The reader will note the emphasis put by Mr. Smith upon two points.
('47', 298, 1, 5, 556787) The milk producing quality of the cow does not affect her capacity for giving a proper draught animal.
('47', 298, 1, 6, 556890) In Mr. Smith’s opinion based on long experience the two go together.
('47', 298, 1, 7, 556959) The cow that gives a substantial quantity of milk will also give a substantial bullock.
('47', 298, 1, 8, 557047) The second point made by Mr. Smith is, that whilst the buffalo may apparently do good to the individual, she kills the cow and therefore kills agriculture.
('47', 298, 1, 9, 557203) Both these important things can only be handled by adequate education of those who own cattle.
('47', 298, 1, 10, 557298) of course if the State interested itself in the true welfare of the people as the States have done in many other parts of the world, the problem can be handled effectively inside of a few years but private effort too can do a great deal to arrest the growing decay of our cattle which are becoming an economic burden instead of being as they ought to be a blessing.
('47', 298, 1, 11, 557664) Young India, 24 10 1929
('47', 298, 2, 12, 557688) 348. ELECTED BOARDS
('47', 298, 3, 13, 557708) It came upon me as a shock to find the District Board of Moradabad issuing a circular forbidding school teachers from taking part in politics, i.e., even collecting funds from their pupils or others for Daridranarayana 1. That same Board gave me an address with a beautiful casket.
('47', 298, 3, 14, 557990) Probably the Board knew nothing aboutthe circular.
('47', 298, 3, 15, 558041) The loyal zeal betrayed in the circular no matter by whom evidently outruns the loyalty of Government schools and colleges which have been inviting me to address their students and presenting me with purses for khadi.
('47', 298, 3, 16, 558259) Government servants have openly given donations to the same cause.
('47', 298, 3, 17, 558326) It has come to be recognized that khadi as such had no politics in it, and that whilst there may be two opinions about its economic value, its undoubted moral value may not be ignored by any educationist.
('47', 298, 3, 18, 558531) Unquestionably it has its political side, but so have many other very important questions at present engaging the attention of the people as well as the Government.
('47', 298, 3, 19, 558696) Hindu Muslim unity and untouchability are pre eminently social questions, but they have today a political importance of the first magnitude, and they are items in the forefront of the Congress programme.
('47', 298, 3, 20, 558900) But no one has yet been known on that account to prevent Government servants from
('47', 298, 4, 21, 558982) 1 God in the form of the poor
('47', 299, 0, 1, 559012) 300 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 299, 1, 2, 559054) interesting themselves in either of these questions.
('47', 299, 1, 3, 559107) Indeed many District Boards have heartily joined the khadi movement and co operated with the A. I. S. A. in promoting this the only national cottage industry of universal application.
('47', 299, 1, 4, 559291) The only Board that has acted like the Moradabad Board and that has come under my notice is the District Board of North Arcot, which had the effrontery to issue the following warning:
('47', 299, 2, 5, 559475) P. Ranganatha Ayyar 1, 1st Assistant, Board Middle School, Arcot, is informed, that his conduct in having lent himself to the raising of subscriptions by pupils to the khaddar fund is blameworthy and should not recur.
('47', 299, 2, 6, 559693) As a whole time servant of the Board, it is his duty to attend to the duties assigned to him by the Head Master in the school, and he should not fritter away his time in other avocations calculated to undermine the discipline or the popularity of the institution.
('47', 299, 2, 7, 559957) He is hereby warned that a repetition of such conduct will entail summary removal from service.
('47', 299, 2, 8, 560053) 2. The subscription notebook filed by him is returned and it is advisable for him to destroy it at once.
('47', 299, 2, 9, 560158) Note the rudeness of the language that omits even the common courtesy due to an employee enjoying the rank of a schoolmaster.
('47', 299, 2, 10, 560284) Note too the excess of loyalty that demands destruction at once of an inoffensive little exercise book containing the names of equally inoffensive little children with the few coppers marked against their names.
('47', 299, 2, 11, 560496) I regret to have to inform the reader that the poor schoolmaster was dismissed by the ultra loyal North Arcot Board.
('47', 299, 2, 12, 560613) Whether it has since felt repentant I do not know.
('47', 299, 2, 13, 560664) I hope it has, In any case schoolmasters and others whom a fate similar to Sjt.
('47', 299, 2, 14, 560744) P. Ranganatha Ayyar’s may overtake need experience no despondency.
('47', 299, 2, 15, 560811) No able bodied honest man or woman who has no prejudice against honest labour has any occasion to starve for want of work.
('47', 299, 2, 16, 560934) The cry that I hear everywhere is that many public movements want good and true workers.
('47', 299, 2, 17, 561023) But though the dismissed persons may be indifferent about what may befall them in the execution of a public duty, the public dare not be.
('47', 299, 2, 18, 561161) The Boards are now overwhelmingly elective with elected chair men in most cases.
('47', 299, 2, 19, 561242) I expect that the circulars such as the one to which I have drawn attention are issued departmentally without the knowle dge of the members.
('47', 299, 2, 20, 561383) It is the duty of the members to take notice of every high handed and anti national action by chairmen or depart 
('47', 299, 3, 21, 561497) 1 Vide “Letter to Jawaharlal Nehru”, 5 6 1929
('47', 300, 0, 1, 561543) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 301
('47', 300, 1, 2, 561592) mental heads.
('47', 300, 1, 3, 561606) And it is equally the duty of electors to keep a strict watch over the misdeeds of the Boards for whose existence they are responsible and who are their mouthpieces.
('47', 300, 1, 4, 561772) Indeed if the electors only knew their rights and realized their duty, they would make any irregular or unpatriotic action by their Boards utterly impossible.
('47', 300, 1, 5, 561931) It is the apathy of the general public which renders these elective Boards often instruments of oppression rather than of service.
('47', 300, 1, 6, 562062) There is nothing to prevent the Boards from becoming powerful political bodies so long as they do not neglect or damage the social local service which is a first charge on their attention.
('47', 300, 1, 7, 562251) It is possible even to demonstrate that it is necessary, in order to ensure social efficiency, for them to take part to a discriminating extent in the national movement for political emancipation.
('47', 300, 2, 8, 562448) Young India, 24 10 1929
('47', 300, 3, 9, 562472) 349. LALAJI ANNIVERSARY
('47', 300, 4, 10, 562496) The Lalaji anniversary will be on us on the 17th November.
('47', 300, 4, 11, 562555) The question that every patriot would naturally ask himself or herself is: ‘What have I done during the year to vindicate Lalaji’s death?
('47', 300, 4, 12, 562693) What have I done to advance the cause of swaraj for which he lived and died?
('47', 300, 4, 13, 562770) What have I done for the so called untouchables whose cause he had made his own?
('47', 300, 4, 14, 562851) What have I done in response to the appeal made by Pandit Malaviyaji and Pandit Motilalji?’ There are many other questions which nationalists would ask themselves according to the emphasis they would put upon a particular characteristic in Lalaji’s many sided life, but my purpose is to suggest to all Congress Committees that they should celebrate the anniversary by making up the amount of the appeal for five lakhs issued by Pandit Malaviyaji and Pandit Motilalji.
('47', 300, 4, 15, 563319) 1 It is a matter of shame that we have yet been able to collect out of the five lakhs not more than’ two.
('47', 300, 4, 16, 563425) If sufficient exertion is put forth there should be nodifficulty in making up the deficit on or before 17th November.
('47', 300, 4, 17, 563543) If they will do so, they must begin the preparations in right earnest from now.
('47', 300, 5, 18, 563623) Young India, 24 10 1929
('47', 300, 6, 19, 563647) 1 For the appeal drafted by Gandhiji, vide “Apeeal for Lajpat Rai Memorial Fund”, 26 11 1928
('47', 301, 0, 1, 563740) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 301, 1, 2, 563782) 350. THE U.P. TOUR VI1
('47', 301, 2, 3, 563805) Here is the itinerary 2 for the week ending 18th instant.
('47', 301, 3, 4, 563863) PREJUDICES DIE HARD
('47', 301, 4, 5, 563883) From Barabanki we had to take the Express for Hardoi.
('47', 301, 4, 6, 563937) The train was crowded.
('47', 301, 4, 7, 563960) Gandhiji’s insistence upon third class travelling has become almost as rigid as before.
('47', 301, 4, 8, 564048) The party got seats not without some difficulty which was removed by the railway authorities.
('47', 301, 4, 9, 564142) Devdas Gandhi, whenever he is of the party, finds room for himself among the.
('47', 301, 4, 10, 564220) general travellers in order to make our party one less.
('47', 301, 4, 11, 564276) At Barabanki he found room only in a compartment which had a card stuck upon a window “for Europeans and Anglo Indians”.
('47', 301, 4, 12, 564397) He found in the compartment some Europeans and Anglo Indians and some Indians too.
('47', 301, 4, 13, 564480) There was no objection taken to him at Barabanki.
('47', 301, 4, 14, 564530) But at Lucknow two European ladies objected to him on the plea that he was not properly dressed.
('47', 301, 4, 15, 564627) He had a full khadi dhoti, vest and cap.
('47', 301, 4, 16, 564668) They asked Devdas to go out of the compartment and, as he says, used offensive language Young Gandhi would not oblige them.
('47', 301, 4, 17, 564792) The good ladies summoned the guard to their assistance.
('47', 301, 4, 18, 564848) Devdas Gandhi stuck to his guns.
('47', 301, 4, 19, 564881) The usual procedure followed as a matter of course.
('47', 301, 4, 20, 564933) The guard summoned the station master.
('47', 301, 4, 21, 564972) Then came the police.
('47', 301, 4, 22, 564994) Naturally there was the inevitable crowd.
('47', 301, 4, 23, 565036) Gandhiji was duly informed of what was happening.
('47', 301, 4, 24, 565086) He decided to leave Devdas free to do as he chose and to remain indifferent.
('47', 301, 4, 25, 565163) Professor Kripalani and others went to this ‘reserved’ compartment,while the argument was developing.
('47', 301, 4, 26, 565265) There was a missionary in the compartment.
('47', 301, 4, 27, 565308) The discussion between him and the missionary was fairly warm, for the Professor could not appreciate the latter’s argument that Devdas should yield because the good ladies objected to his dress.
('47', 301, 4, 28, 565504) The end of it all was that the police would not or could not arrest the offending wearer.
('47', 301, 4, 29, 565594) The train steamed out, and Devdas says the missionary and the ladies subsequently became friends.
('47', 301, 4, 30, 565692) The incident is tragic showing how prejudices die hard.
('47', 301, 4, 31, 565748) Europeans and Anglo Indians have not yet realized that the
('47', 301, 5, 32, 565807) 1 This and other items under this title signed ‘A’ were written by Gandhiji; vide “Letter to Mahadev Desai”, 18 11 1929. Although there Gandhiji mentions ‘three letters’ as having been written by him, actually six of them appeared over the initial ‘A’ and these are reproduced in this volume.
('47', 301, 5, 33, 566100) 2 Not reproduced here
('47', 302, 0, 1, 566122) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 303
('47', 302, 1, 2, 566171) dhoti is the national costume of the vast majority of India’s population.
('47', 302, 1, 3, 566245) So long as there are compartments reserved for Europeans and Anglo Indians, so long will race and colour prejudice assert itself giving rise at times to unforeseen consequences.
('47', 302, 1, 4, 566423) For the reservation feeds the insolent prejudice and keeps it alive.
('47', 302, 1, 5, 566492) In Devdas Gandhi’s case the label too was probably put up illegally.
('47', 302, 1, 6, 566561) The compartment was not stamped in the usual manner.
('47', 302, 1, 7, 566614) This insulting reservation can only be kept up so long as the multitude of passengers mutely and meekly submit to the injury.
('47', 302, 1, 8, 566740) No regulation which lacks popular support has any chance of being respected.
('47', 302, 1, 9, 566817) Let us hope that the courteous and successful resistance offered by young Gandhi will move the authorities to abolish the offensive reservation.
('47', 302, 2, 10, 566962) A TRUE SHRADDHA
('47', 302, 3, 11, 566978) The visit to Hardoi was interesting for several events.
('47', 302, 3, 12, 567034) The activity of one selfless woman had altered the complexion of things.
('47', 302, 3, 13, 567107) Shrimati Vidyadevi, the wife of Raja Jungbahadursinh of Barua, a small zamindari, has moved her husband and other relatives to a spirit of service.
('47', 302, 3, 14, 567255) She has broken down the purdah for herself and for those who have come under her influence.
('47', 302, 3, 15, 567347) She is a regular spinner, and her sister in law Shrimati Lakshmidevi spins exceedingly fine yarn.
('47', 302, 3, 16, 567445) A khadi piece woven in Barua out of her yarn was presented to Gandhiji who auctioned it for Rs. 105 at the public meeting in Hardoi.
('47', 302, 3, 17, 567578) Rani Vidyadevi gave up at the women’s meeting some costly jewellery.
('47', 302, 3, 18, 567647) The gifts at the women’s meeting amounted to nearly Rs. 1,700, Rs. 700 being in cash and jewellery worth about Rs. 1,000. The bulk of it came from this one family.
('47', 302, 3, 19, 567811) Moved probably by the same silent influence Kunvar Maheshvarsinh had a khadi store opened by Gandhiji in memory of his wife who died in January last.
('47', 302, 3, 20, 567961) The address presented to Gandhiji on the occasion stated that the late Shrimati Sarasvatidevi was a woman of learning, had torn down the purdah, was a regular spinner, and a regular worshipper of God.
('47', 302, 3, 21, 568162) She used herself to distribute free medicine among needy women and children, and took delight in sewing garments for the latter.
('47', 302, 3, 22, 568291) There could be no better shraddha or memorial to a woman so pure and devoted to the cause of the poor as the Shrimati was.
('47', 302, 3, 23, 568414) No wonder Gandhiji made her life the text of his address to the women’s meeting.
('47', 303, 0, 1, 568495) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 303, 1, 2, 568537) MISCELLANEOUS
('47', 303, 2, 3, 568551) I must pass by many interesting events, noting only a few as I pass by those that crowd upon my mind as I am writing these notes.
('47', 303, 2, 4, 568681) The visit to Moradabad was noteworthy for the fact of Gandhiji being the guest of an old Mussalman friend Maulvi Abdus Samad Saheb—a rare event nowadays.
('47', 303, 2, 5, 568835) He opened a new house for an old library, the donation of one citizen Lala Brajlal.
('47', 303, 2, 6, 568919) In Dhampur we found the khadi activity in full swing.
('47', 303, 2, 7, 568973) The orderliness of the reception evoked great praise from Gandhiji.
('47', 303, 2, 8, 569041) The noise, the jostling, etc., had tired him out.
('47', 303, 2, 9, 569091) He felt therefore refreshed as he alighted on the platform and moved through the motionless rows of men and women who had crowded at the station.
('47', 303, 2, 10, 569237) The work of the Arya Pratinidhi Seva Samiti too delighted Gandhiji.
('47', 303, 2, 11, 569305) In Hardwar an attempt was made by the so called orthodox Brahmins to boycott Gandhiji, but it failed signally.
('47', 303, 2, 12, 569416) The purse, which the most sanguine thought might not exceed Rs. 500, was fully Rs. 2,500 owing to the exertions of the Vice principal of the Kangri Gurukul, Pandit Devasharma Abhaya, assisted by a band of associates.
('47', 303, 2, 13, 569633) Due to his exertion there is also a khadi bhandar which is well nigh self supporting.
('47', 303, 2, 14, 569719) of the insanitation both moral and physical of this great and ancient place of pilgrimage I need say nothing at present, as Gandhiji proposes to write himself next week.
('47', 303, 2, 15, 569889) 1 I may not touch Dehradun and Mussoorie this week.
('47', 303, 3, 16, 569941) Young India, 24 10 1929
('47', 303, 4, 17, 569965) 351. SERVANT OR MASTER?
('47', 303, 5, 18, 569989) Whatever was said about volunteers in a previous issue 2 bears repetition.
('47', 303, 5, 19, 570064) I have noticed during every one of my tours that volunteers do not know whether they are servants or masters.
('47', 303, 5, 20, 570174) For instance, during meetings if some instruction is to be conveyed to someone, it sounds more like a command than a request.
('47', 303, 5, 21, 570300) When they lead me up to the platform, instead of requesting the villagers politely and gently to make way, they push them and order them in harsh tone and language to move off.
('47', 303, 5, 22, 570477) At stations, wherever I get off, there is naturally a crowd.
('47', 303, 5, 23, 570538) The volunteers, instead of politely requesting the crowd to make way, shout at them; so the people neither understand nor listen to them.
('47', 303, 6, 24, 570676) 1Vide “Physical and Moral Insanitation”, 31 10 1929, 2Vide “The Duty of a Volunteer”, 17 10 1929
('47', 304, 0, 1, 570773) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 305
('47', 304, 1, 2, 570822) the other hand, the uproar makes confusion worse confounded.
('47', 304, 1, 3, 570883) Not to mention my own distress, although the object of all these orders is to save me from hardships.
('47', 304, 1, 4, 570985) When the whole procession leaves the platform, no consideration whatever is shown to the passengers.
('47', 304, 1, 5, 571086) People trample on their luggage, push them about, and if a passenger is sitting in their path, he is shown no consideration either.
('47', 304, 1, 6, 571218) Similarly, when we proceed along a road and some villager walks in the middle of the road, volunteers consider it their duty to swear at him and remove him out of the way.
('47', 304, 1, 7, 571390) I can give many more such examples.
('47', 304, 1, 8, 571426) I don’t believe that this incivility is deliberate, but is due to lack of discretion and education.
('47', 304, 1, 9, 571526) The air is charged with notions of high and low.
('47', 304, 1, 10, 571575) The townspeople look down upon the rural folk.
('47', 304, 1, 11, 571622) When the kings set out in procession, their retinue accompanies them with great fanfare, even abusing the people without hesitation.
('47', 304, 1, 12, 571755) The white masters have only imitated this.
('47', 304, 1, 13, 571798) The foreigners are adept at copying such things.
('47', 304, 1, 14, 571847) We have also been influenced, unwittingly, by this atmosphere.
('47', 304, 1, 15, 571910) But in these days of public awakening volunteers must become true servants.
('47', 304, 1, 16, 571986) Their service should be sincere and silent.
('47', 304, 1, 17, 572030) The poor and the helpless must be served.
('47', 304, 1, 18, 572072) Hundreds are willing to serve famous leaders who are pestered with excessive and unnecessary attention; but very few come forward to serve the poor; and of those few, many consider that they are doing the poor a great favour by serving them.
('47', 304, 1, 19, 572314) The truth is that he who serves the poor discharges a small partof his debt.
('47', 304, 1, 20, 572391) India’s poor die of hunger, they have become helpless, and of all this misery, we the middle class people are the cause.
('47', 304, 1, 21, 572512) The volunteers too belong to this class.
('47', 304, 1, 22, 572553) It is we who have sustained ourselves by sitting on their backs so long and are doing so even today.
('47', 304, 1, 23, 572654) When the poor realize their right and their might, then they will become our masters and we shall be forced to serve them.
('47', 304, 1, 24, 572777) When that happens no one will call us volunteers; we shall certainly be called their slaves or servants.
('47', 304, 1, 25, 572882) Therefore, no volunteer should think even in his dream that when he serves the village folk courteously, respectfully and sincerely, he is doing anyone a favour.
('47', 304, 1, 26, 573044) His greatness and the greatness of the country lie in such service only.
('47', 304, 2, 27, 573117) [From Hindi]
('47', 304, 3, 28, 573130) Hindi Navajivan, 24 10 1929
('47', 305, 0, 1, 573158) 306 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 305, 1, 2, 573200) 352. LETTER TO HEMANTA S. CHATTERJEE
('47', 305, 2, 3, 573237) CAMP MUSSOORIE, October 24, 1929
('47', 305, 3, 4, 573270) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your letter of September 24th 1 and enclosure which I have now had time to read.
('47', 305, 3, 5, 573380) I must confess that your scheme for ensuring a better milk supply does not appeal to me in spite of the findings of various Committees to the contrary.
('47', 305, 3, 6, 573532) I am of opinion that there is no escape from municipalization of the milk supply if we are to make it uniformly cheap and accessible to the poorest citizen of Cawnpore.
('47', 305, 3, 7, 573701) If it is a fact that a municipality cannot handle such enterprise because of the likelihood of corruption I should imagine that no other institution will, whether private or public.
('47', 305, 3, 8, 573883) The secret of municipal government must consist in evolving honest enterprise by municipalities themselves setting the example.
('47', 305, 3, 9, 574011) It bodes ill for corporate life if municipalities cannot handle big enterprises with success, efficiency and comparative cheapness.
('47', 305, 3, 10, 574143) A municipality has facilities a private corporation can never command in a well ordered State.
('47', 305, 3, 11, 574238) There are two or three maxims which must be borne in mind for ensuring the supply of cheap and pure milk in a commercial centre like Cawnpore.
('47', 305, 3, 12, 574381) Milk must be largely produced in a municipal farm, afair distance from Cawnpore.
('47', 305, 3, 13, 574462) Secondly, there must be a method of ensuring cheap transport.
('47', 305, 3, 14, 574524) Thirdly, sale of milk should be a municipal monopoly even as the manufacture and sale of postage stamps is a monopoly of the Central Government.
('47', 305, 4, 15, 574669) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('47', 305, 4, 16, 574691) HEMANTA K. CHATTERJEE, B.A., LL.
('47', 305, 4, 17, 574724) B. CAWNPORE
('47', 305, 5, 18, 574736) From a microfilm: S.N. 15253
('47', 305, 6, 19, 574765) 1 Seeking Gandhiji’s opinion on a milk supply scheme proposed by the Public Health Committee

('47', 309, 2, 3, 580445) ON THE TRAIN, ON WAY TO MUZAFFARNAGAR,

('47', 309, 4, 6, 580530) Your minimum demand is for Rs. 2,500, and the maximum for Rs. 16,500. As far as I see things, there are risks even in the purchase of land.
('47', 309, 4, 7, 580670) My idea in suggesting that you should see Thakore Saheb was that you might accept the land if he offered a deed making a free gift of the land.
('47', 309, 4, 8, 580814) As I visualize the possibility of his taking back the land even after making an outright grant, you should drop the idea for the present.

('47', 309, 7, 15, 581361) 358. LETTER TO GANGABEHN VAIDYA
('47', 309, 8, 16, 581393) MUZAFFARNAGAR,
('47', 309, 9, 17, 581408) October 26, 1929
('47', 309, 10, 18, 581425) GANGABEHN,
('47', 309, 11, 19, 581436) Recently you have become slack in writing to me, and I have always been so.
('47', 309, 11, 20, 581512) However much I hurry, I cannot cope with each day’s programme of work and something or other is always left out.
('47', 309, 11, 21, 581625) As I cannot gather the courage to resist the people’s love and enthusiasm, even at the cost of over straining myself I yield to many of their wishes and am obliged to give them more time than I had intended.
('47', 309, 11, 22, 581833) As a result, letters remain unanswered, nor can I manage to write other letters which I may have intended to write.
('47', 309, 11, 23, 581949) I got your letter regarding Kaki.
('47', 309, 11, 24, 581983) There is no doubt that she was very fortunate.
('47', 309, 11, 25, 582030) She had no reason to wish to live longer.
('47', 310, 0, 1, 582072) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 311
('47', 310, 1, 2, 582121) I hope Bal 1 and Shankar 2 have now completely got over their grief.
('47', 310, 1, 3, 582190) I trust things are going on all right with the girls who have newly arrived.
('47', 310, 1, 4, 582267) May God give you the strength for all such services.
('47', 310, 1, 5, 582320) Your faith is such that you are bound to get it.
('47', 310, 1, 6, 582369) Do not count the expense in taking milk and fruit.
('47', 310, 1, 7, 582420) You are right in what you say about the girls.
('47', 310, 1, 8, 582467) We give them much, but there is much still which we can give and much that remains to be done.
('47', 310, 1, 9, 582562) I am, however, sure that, as we have been trying to give them the basic things of life, God is bound to grant us the strength to give them the rest.
('47', 310, 1, 10, 582711) We have not yet been able to train women workers who can give the girls all that they need, and no women workers from outside whom we would welcome have offered to help.
('47', 310, 1, 11, 582881) We should, therefore, have faith in what we have been doing and keep patience.
('47', 310, 1, 12, 582960) Take utmost care of your health.
('47', 310, 2, 13, 582993) Blessings from BAPU [From Gujarati]

('47', 310, 5, 16, 583093) MUZAFFARNAGAR, October 26, 1929
('47', 310, 6, 17, 583125) BHAISHRI MADHAVLAL, I wrote about one who is in samadhi in the waking state.
('47', 310, 6, 18, 583202) The person who is in samadhi and is not aware of the world does not need to be helped.
('47', 310, 6, 19, 583289) True samadhi can certainly be the purest service.
('47', 310, 6, 20, 583339) Silence can be the best speech and service.
('47', 310, 6, 21, 583383) But it should be natural.
('47', 310, 6, 22, 583409) Such a path is very difficult.
('47', 310, 6, 23, 583440) It is possible for one in a million.
('47', 310, 6, 24, 583477) There is much danger of self deception in it.
('47', 310, 6, 25, 583523) I have seen that happening.
('47', 310, 6, 26, 583551) The path of samadhi is not for the common people.
('47', 310, 6, 27, 583601) We may adopt it when the path of karma naturally leads us to it.
('47', 310, 6, 28, 583666) An action can be learnt by imitation, samadhi never.
('47', 310, 6, 29, 583719) We are now nearing a station.
('47', 310, 7, 30, 583749) From a copy of the Gujarati: Kusumbehn Desai’s Diary.

('47', 312, 3, 7, 586270) 361. LETTER TO ANANDANAND
('47', 312, 4, 8, 586296) DEOBAND,
('47', 312, 5, 9, 586305) October 26, 1929
('47', 312, 6, 10, 586322) BHAI ANANDANAND,
('47', 312, 7, 11, 586339) I got the copies of your letters about the Gita and about untouchability 1. The reference to you in the Introduction 2 is also enclosed.
('47', 312, 7, 12, 586476) The reference was necessary to show how I came to undertake tasks such as this in my life.
('47', 312, 7, 13, 586567) I have sent a note for Y.I. on the Manifesto about untouchability that has been published 3. It will be a great thing indeed if the Ekadashi is celebrated in the way suggested in the Manifesto.
('47', 312, 7, 14, 586761) Be that as it may, we should do our best and let the result be what it will.
('47', 312, 7, 15, 586838) If we cannot solve this problem, I again fear that it will not be possible to hold back the “untouchables”.
('47', 312, 7, 16, 586946) Justice being on their side, who can hold them back in this age of awakening?
('47', 312, 7, 17, 587024) How can talk of ahimsa appeal to them?
('47', 312, 7, 18, 587063) Our actions, too, are not a lesson in non violence to them.
('47', 312, 7, 19, 587123) If, therefore, they imitate us, we shall reap the fruit of our own folly.
('47', 312, 7, 20, 587197) I can understand the anger of the sanatanists, but it is wholly futile.
('47', 312, 8, 21, 587269) You know about Deoband, don’t you?
('47', 312, 8, 22, 587304) It is the biggest centre of Islamic studies, where Maulanas converge.

('47', 312, 10, 25, 587442) 362. WONDERFUL ACHIEVEMENTS
('47', 312, 11, 26, 587470) The Students’ Association of the Gujarat Vidyapith conducted an inquiry to find out the views of its ex students about national education, their ideological and financial position, etc., and has
('47', 312, 12, 27, 587665) 1 Vide “Temples for Untocuhables”, 28 11 1929. 2 To Anasaktiyoga; vide “Anasktiyoga” 3 By the Untouchability Committee; vide “A Great Manifesto”, 31 10 1929
('47', 313, 0, 1, 587822) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 313, 1, 2, 587864) brought out its findings in the form of a small pamphlet.
('47', 313, 1, 3, 587922) It is now a year since the pamphlet was published.
('47', 313, 1, 4, 587973) It has been constantly with me on my travels, and though it is rather late it will still not be out of place to give a summary of the results mentioned in the pamphlet, in view of its usefulness.
('47', 313, 2, 5, 588169) The number of graduates who passed out of the Vidyapith from 1921 to 1926 was 251. Omitting those from Sind and Madras, a questionnaire was sent to more than 200 students.
('47', 313, 2, 6, 588341) of them 82, including two ladies, sent in their replies.
('47', 313, 2, 7, 588398) The pamphlet mentioned above gives an excellent summary of their replies, which should be read by those eager to make a study of national education.
('47', 313, 2, 8, 588547) Here I can give only a few hurriedly jotted points:
('47', 313, 3, 9, 588599) Replies as to why they quit Government schools are as below:
('47', 313, 4, 10, 588660) Out of political fervour 33
('47', 313, 5, 11, 588688) Because of faith in non co operation 10
('47', 313, 6, 12, 588728) Because of conviction of the need for
('47', 313, 7, 13, 588766) national education 10
('47', 313, 8, 14, 588788) In obedience to the call of the nation 11
('47', 313, 9, 15, 588830) At the instance of relatives 6
('47', 313, 10, 16, 588861) Being carried away by the prevailing current 12
('47', 313, 11, 17, 588909) Total 82
('47', 313, 12, 18, 588918) Of these, one student writes the following about the conditions under which he non co operated:
('47', 313, 13, 19, 589014) “I left my college against the advice of the elders in my family and
('47', 313, 14, 20, 589083) caste, and against that of the institutions which were helping me.
('47', 313, 14, 21, 589150) I thus lost
('47', 313, 15, 22, 589162) the monthly scholarship of Rs. 10 which I was getting at the Government
('47', 313, 16, 23, 589234) college.”
('47', 313, 17, 24, 589244) The following are a few of the opinions given by the ex students about the atmosphere of the Gujarat Mahavidyalaya, i.e., the college section of the Vidyapith:
('47', 313, 18, 25, 589404) “There was great freedom.
('47', 313, 18, 26, 589430) A notable fact was that the Mahavidya laya
('47', 313, 19, 27, 589473) completely changed my life.
('47', 313, 19, 28, 589501) I might say that it brought about a rebirth for
('47', 314, 0, 1, 589549) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 315
('47', 314, 1, 2, 589598) “To begin with the atmosphere was political but afterwards it underwent a change.
('47', 314, 1, 3, 589680) On the whole, it was such as to foster noble thoughts, though one cannot say that it also gave the power to translate those thoughts into action or even prepared us for that.”
('47', 314, 2, 4, 589856) “The distinction of the Vidyapith lay in its religious and pure atmosphere.”
('47', 314, 3, 5, 589933) “Throughout the three years I spent there the atmosphere was so good and uplifting that I dare say one could not find it anywhere else in India.”
('47', 314, 4, 6, 590079) “The atmosphere was very helpful both for study and contemplation.”
('47', 314, 5, 7, 590147) “Gujarat Vidyapith shows us the path, direct and straight, as to how a man can lead the highest kind of life.
('47', 314, 5, 8, 590257) The atmosphere prevailing there offered me the best opportunities for the experience of life in the world —a gift by no means inconsiderable when one comes to think of its importance in one’s own life.”
('47', 314, 6, 9, 590460) “The atmosphere was very pure.
('47', 314, 6, 10, 590491) There was not that narrow mindedness which one comes across in Government schools and colleges.
('47', 314, 6, 11, 590587) Everybody had the utmost freedom which was very helpful in the intellectual development of the students.
('47', 314, 6, 12, 590692) At the same time there was also scope for the boys to abuse the freedom because not having had it before they could also misuse it.
('47', 314, 6, 13, 590824) Under the circumstances there is little danger of the boys’ mental deterioration.” At the time the pamphlet was prepared, the graduates were employed as follows: In educational institutions Total l.
('47', 314, 6, 14, 591023) Vidyapith 9 2. Recognized or unrecognized national schools 21 3. Government schools 7 37 In institutions for depressed classes l.
('47', 314, 6, 15, 591153) Institutions for untouchables 2 2. ,, Bhils 2 3. ,, Kaliparaj l 4. ,, Labour 3 8 Independent employment 1. Agriculture, business, etc.
('47', 314, 6, 16, 591288) 11 2. Private employment, business, office jobs, etc.
('47', 315, 0, 1, 591342) 316 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 315, 1, 2, 591384) 3. Legal practice 2 4. Journalism 3 5. Not engaged in any parti cular profession 3 82 The readers will note that out of 82 as many as 45 were earning their living through social service work.
('47', 315, 1, 3, 591576) As for the figures of their earnings, no one earned less than thirty rupees a month.
('47', 315, 1, 4, 591661) Twelve graduates were earning sixty rupees per month.
('47', 315, 1, 5, 591715) The number of those who had a monthly income of seventy five rupees was 15. One of the graduates was earning Rs. 200, another Rs. 130 and three earned Rs. 125. Thus those who earned from Rs. 50 to Rs. 200 were 57. Eighteen graduates could not send the figures for their incomes because they were engaged in independent business or professional work.
('47', 315, 1, 6, 592065) It would not be an exaggeration to say that these results are very satisfactory.
('47', 315, 1, 7, 592146) Graduates of Government universities are of ten found to be earning even less than 30 rupees a month.
('47', 315, 1, 8, 592248) Here there is only one who gets 30 rupees and very likely he too is doing so voluntarily as a sort of discipline.
('47', 315, 1, 9, 592362) Today there are many among the educated in India who are ready to take up service for no more than a living—for just enough to keep body and soul together.
('47', 315, 1, 10, 592518) We have seen that of the aforementioned, 42 are already engaged in social service work.
('47', 315, 1, 11, 592606) And this is indeed the ideal which the Vidyapith seeks to set before its graduates, namely, that they should take up some sort of social service work at just a subsistence wage.
('47', 315, 1, 12, 592784) As against this, the ideal in a Government university, if it can be called an ideal, is, understandably, career, i.e., a lucrative profession meaning mainly to secure Government service.
('47', 315, 1, 13, 592971) A national institution devotes itself to training national workers, while a Government university addresses itself to preparing Government servants whom we consider to be slaves.
('47', 315, 1, 14, 593150) In a national college service is its own reward while in a Government college there is the inducement of a rise in salary and the promise of a pension.
('47', 315, 1, 15, 593302) The only pension a national worker can look for lies in the hope that there is in every man the instinct of grateful appreciation of pure service and that the people cannot fail to develop love and regard for their benefactors.
('47', 315, 1, 16, 593530) That is why I regard the result mentioned above as excellent.
('47', 315, 1, 17, 593592) The figures for monthly income prove that the graduates of the national university are able to make enough
('47', 316, 0, 1, 593699) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 317
('47', 316, 1, 2, 593748) income even in the sphere of service.
('47', 316, 1, 3, 593786) And as time passes, and the spirit of sacrifice spreads, I hope to see a reduction made in the above earnings, not of course by force but voluntarily.
('47', 316, 1, 4, 593937) As long as crores of our people are starving, a man who takes two rupees when he can do with one is really guilty of thieving.
('47', 316, 2, 5, 594064) The following extracts are from the replies to the question “What would you prefer to adopt as your life work?” “To be a soldier in the struggle for the freedom of the country and society” “Any such activity as will enable me to take part in doing service to the country” “Education and khadi” “Harijan work or work in the primary or secondary schools in villages” “I will have the satisfaction of having done my life work if I could have the opportunity to serve the people in any form.” These graduates of the Gujarat Vidyapith admit the superiority of national education and its many advantages.
('47', 316, 2, 6, 594663) Nevertheless, they have not hesitated to express their view that national education in its present form is imperfect.
('47', 316, 2, 7, 594781) This freedom of thought raises the pamphlet’s worth.
('47', 316, 2, 8, 594834) The figures given below show that up to 1926 only a small number had appreciated the value of sacrificial spinning: Those who spin for an hour or more daily 5 Those who spin only for half an hour 10 Those who spin 1000 yards per month 9 Irregular spinners 9 Those who did not spin 49 82
('47', 316, 3, 9, 595121) This indifference towards a thing which people like me regard as a great yajna, whose importance has been ever recognized by the Congress in its resolutions, is certainly disappointing.
('47', 316, 3, 10, 595307) But I know that there has been an improvement in the situation after 1926 and I am therefore satisfied.
('47', 316, 4, 11, 595411) The number of those who stuck to pure khadi for their clothing was 56 which, though inadequate, may yet be regarded as fair, seeing that something is better than nothing.
('47', 316, 4, 12, 595582) of course, there were others who used khadi to a limited extent.
('47', 316, 4, 13, 595647) Those who did not use khadi explain
('47', 317, 0, 1, 595683) 318 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 317, 1, 2, 595725) their difficulties thus:
('47', 317, 2, 3, 595750) “We have to work among the people who belittle our value on account of the simplicity of khadi.
('47', 317, 2, 4, 595846) This results in less work for us and therefore less earning.” “The dearness of khadi, the difficulty of getting it, and the keen desire for fine mill cloth are a hindrance.” “Ready made garments of mill cloth are available at the shops at very cheap prices, It is not so with khadi.” That such excuses are put forward to explain why they do not use khadi shows that many do not yet know what a great help khadi is to the starving poor and what a great contribution it is making to our freedom struggle.
('47', 317, 2, 5, 596349) It is to be remembered that no country has won freedom in this world without suffering privations and difficulties.
('47', 317, 2, 6, 596465) It would be very useful if developments in respect of khadi and other things, subsequent to the publication of the pamphlet, could be made available.
('47', 317, 2, 7, 596615) I congratulate the editors on bringing out this pamphlet.
('47', 317, 2, 8, 596673) Every national worker can learn much from it.
('47', 317, 2, 9, 596719) The Association would do well to continue their inquiry.
('47', 317, 2, 10, 596776) It should be the primary object of the Association to maintain spiritual contact with all the graduates of the Vidyapith, share their joys and sorrows and not allow a slackening of the ideals for which the Vidyapith has been founded.
('47', 317, 3, 11, 597010) I feel that those who read this pamphlet cannot but come to the conclusion that the national schools and colleges have done much good to the country, and that the strength which we find in the students today owes its origin to these institutions.
('47', 317, 4, 12, 597257) I have had the same experience in regard to the results of the work of the Kashi Vidyapith as of those of the Gujarat Vidyapith which have been noted above and I am sure that the same will be found to be true, on examination, in the case of the Jamia Millia and the Bihar Vidyapith.
('47', 317, 4, 13, 597540) I also advise the Association to establish contacts with all the national universities, and collect and collate all information about them.
('47', 317, 4, 14, 597680) It may perhaps be desirable to hold occasional or annual conferences of the teachers and graduates of these universities.
('47', 317, 4, 15, 597802) Professor Gidwani had, in fact, attempted this.
('47', 317, 4, 16, 597850) If such a conference is held, it should not synchronize with the Congress week.
('47', 317, 4, 17, 597930) Our tendency to hold all conferences simultaneously with it is, I think, harmful.
('47', 317, 4, 18, 598012) It distracts people’s energy instead of concentrating it; and the people gain little from these conferences.
('47', 317, 4, 19, 598121) If a conference is worth holding it
('47', 318, 0, 1, 598157) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 319
('47', 318, 1, 2, 598206) should be held separately.
('47', 318, 1, 3, 598233) It is not possible that all people would be interested in all the conferences.
('47', 318, 1, 4, 598312) Rightly the Congress is the organization which should interest all people.
('47', 318, 1, 5, 598387) Therefore, during the Congress week, the people’s attention should be directed to the sole purpose of strengthening the Congress.

('47', 318, 4, 8, 598556) 363. LETTER TO FULCHAND K. SHAH
('47', 318, 5, 9, 598588) October 27, 1929
('47', 318, 6, 10, 598605) BHAISHRI FULCHAND, I have not replied to your letter.
('47', 318, 6, 11, 598659) I hope that Bhai Hemshankar is now completely free from his teeth trouble.
('47', 318, 6, 12, 598734) In my suggestion 1 to avoid personal criticism I did not think merely of practical wisdom, but it was and is a matter of principle also.
('47', 318, 6, 13, 598871) Just as it would be uncivilized on my part to criticize you behind your back or outside your home, though it would be a duty to do so in your face, it is also improper to criticize one princely State in the territory of another, particularly when the latter is known to be on friendly terms with the former.
('47', 318, 6, 14, 599179) I know that we do not always follow this principle, but that does not prove that as a principle it is wrong.
('47', 318, 6, 15, 599288) Such being my views, I hold it to be the duty of a person, who believes in the principle I have stated, to dissociate himself from an organization—in the present instance, the youth movement—which indulges in such criticism as a matter of principle and makes it its chief aim.
('47', 318, 6, 16, 599565) It is one’s duty to resign from an institution whose defects carry one in a direction one does not approve of .
('47', 318, 6, 17, 599677) There may be no objection to remaining, and occasionally it may even be a duty to remain, in the institution whose defects we hope to remove or remedy, keeping ourselves aloof from those defects.
('47', 318, 6, 18, 599873) I think I have fully replied to your letter from Broach, dated September 29. Now I turn to your second letter.
('47', 318, 6, 19, 599984) The problem of Wadhwan is a complicated one.
('47', 318, 6, 20, 600029) The chief question is what strength you have—you,
('47', 318, 7, 21, 600079) 1 Vide “Speech at Kathiawar Political Conference, Porbandar”, 22 1 1928.
('47', 319, 0, 1, 600152) 320 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 319, 1, 2, 600194) that is, your organization as a whole.
('47', 319, 1, 3, 600233) How far all the members of your organization can feel love for the wrongdoer is for you to examine.
('47', 319, 1, 4, 600333) If you are satisfied in the matter, you have the full right to offer satyagraha.
('47', 319, 1, 5, 600414) Whether you have the strength to offer it, whether the time for it is ripe, whether you have acquired the necessary fitness—all these questions should be considered beforehand.
('47', 319, 1, 6, 600591) This means that, in deciding the question, what is first needed is detailed knowledge of the facts;after that, all that is necessary is application of practical wisdom.
('47', 319, 1, 7, 600760) You alone know the facts.
('47', 319, 1, 8, 600786) If an error from the point of view of practical wisdom is committed, it can be overlooked.
('47', 319, 1, 9, 600877) After this you may act as you think fit.
('47', 319, 1, 10, 600918) If you wish to consult me in the matter, you may see me in the Ashram after November 25. But it seems that you will have already taken, before you get this reply, many of the steps you propose to take.
('47', 319, 1, 11, 601120) You know my tour programme.
('47', 319, 1, 12, 601148) If you so desire, you may write to me at any of the places included in the programme and ask me about any matter.

('47', 319, 4, 15, 601349) 364. LETTER TO RAOJIBHAI M. PATEL
('47', 319, 5, 16, 601383) MUZAFFARNAGAR,
('47', 319, 6, 17, 601398) October 27, 1929
('47', 319, 7, 18, 601415) BHAISHRI RAOJIBHAI 1, I got your letter.
('47', 319, 7, 19, 601456) I have no doubt at all in my mind about the need of running the kitchen and succeeding in it.
('47', 319, 7, 20, 601550) The problem of its management will be solved through actual experience.
('47', 319, 7, 21, 601622) Our duty is to see that though the burden and the responsibility rest on the women, we act in such a manner that the women do not feel the burden and the responsibility and yet are aware that they are theirs.
('47', 319, 7, 22, 601831) There is the well known illustration of Queen Victoria and her ministers.
('47', 319, 7, 23, 601905) Though the responsibility was the Queen’s, the ministers let no burden fall on her.
('47', 319, 7, 24, 601989) However, this after all is wisdom from a distance.
('47', 319, 7, 25, 602040) The main thing is to ensure that the experiment succeeds, whatever the method we follow in running the kitchen.

('47', 320, 6, 10, 602665) The accused were rather surprised to see Mahatmaji coming to them in jail and some of them actually exclaimed it was a great surprise that he had come to them.
('47', 320, 6, 11, 602825) Mahatmaji replied: I hope it would not be a painful surprise.
('47', 320, 7, 12, 602887) After the comrades were personally introduced, Mahatmaji said he would be satisfied if Dominion Status in terms of the Nehru Report were given immediately.
('47', 320, 7, 13, 603043) He would consider it independence, if, as is implied by the Nehru Provisions, it contained the organic ability of severance of connection.
('47', 320, 8, 14, 603182) Questioned if he would adopt the same attitude of thankful acceptance as he did in Amritsar on Montagu Announcements, if the new reforms were less than the terms of the Nehru Constitution, but a slight advance on 1917, Mahatma Gandhi said he would not accept them.
('47', 320, 9, 15, 603447) After this the Bombay comrades had a long discussion as to why Gandhiji did not help the 1928 general strike.
('47', 320, 9, 16, 603557) Asked why he did not give them help, when several workers visited Ahmedabad to collect funds for the strike, Gandhiji said he thought the strikers were wrong in their action....
('47', 320, 9, 17, 603735) [About] the grievances of the workers in the 1928 strike, he said none of the strike leaders had cared to see him and explain things.
('47', 320, 9, 18, 603869) [To a suggestion] that he should have at least helped the women and children who were starving, Gandhiji said instead of that he would have told the women to ask their men to go to work and feed them!

('47', 321, 1, 2, 604318) [On a remark] that unless the Congress accepted the programme of organizing the workers and peasants there would be no effect on the Government, Mahatmaji said he welcomed everyone to convince the Congress of any programme and put it through.

('47', 321, 1, 5, 604717) Big zamindars with the help of lawyers and intellectuals, [it was alleged,] forced a fixed tax per head on the peasants in their zamindari for contribution to Gandhiji’s purse.

('47', 321, 1, 10, 605453) A strike, opined Mahatma Gandhi, was non co operation and as such a good weapon in the hands of workers for the removal of genuine grievances.
('47', 321, 1, 11, 605596) To another question he replied: I will certainly become an independencewallah, provided Dominion Status is not granted or promised by responsible heads of the British Government in India and England by the midnight of 31st December next.
('47', 321, 1, 12, 605834) Whether the administration in such conditions would improve in quality depends on the personnel of the Government then.
('47', 321, 2, 13, 605954) He entertained hopes of attainment of Dominion Status within this period.
('47', 321, 2, 14, 606028) He explained that he suspended civil disobedience in Bardoli 2 not because Bardoli was not prepared but as a direct consequence of the outbreak of violence in Chauri Chaura.
('47', 321, 2, 15, 606202) Asked if Dominion Status was not forthcoming and another Chauri Chaura happened in the course of the contemplated civil disobedience whether he would advise another suspension of the programme, he replied: That is the weak spot in me and you have to bear with me.
('47', 321, 3, 16, 606466) Asked what he would do for the Meerut case, Mahatmaji said: If it were in my hands I would withdraw the charge, as in my scheme of things, holding opinions of any kind would be perfectly permissible.

('47', 322, 1, 3, 607100) He was never opposed to defence individually arranged but public subscriptions should not be utilized towards lawyers’ fees in political trials.
('47', 322, 1, 4, 607245) Concluding his interview, he remarked that in the whole of his tour of the province this was the most pleasant hour he had spent.
