('47', 322, 2, 6, 607468) 366. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, MEERUT
('47', 322, 3, 7, 607506) October 27, 1929
('47', 322, 4, 8, 607523) Mr. Gandhi .
('47', 322, 4, 9, 607536) gave a joint reply in Hindustani to the several addresses presented to him by the local bodies and the Congress Committee.
('47', 322, 4, 10, 607659) He thanked the citizens of Meerut for their contributions.
('47', 322, 4, 11, 607718) He said Meerut’s record of national service, though it fell short of the 1921 level, was a fairly good one.
('47', 322, 4, 12, 607826) Rs. 14,000 was no small amount but it failed to satisfy his demands.
('47', 322, 4, 13, 607895) He had taken upon himself a mission of service to Daridranarayana, the incarnation of poverty, and hence his needs would not be easily appeased.
('47', 322, 5, 14, 608040) Alluding to the Meerut alleged “conspiracy” case, he said the responsibilities of Meerut had increased a thousandfold in view of the trial being held there, a small city which was ill chosen for the occasion.
('47', 322, 5, 15, 608249) That city was lacking in suitable lawyers, books and other conveniences.
('47', 322, 5, 16, 608322) Mr. Gandhi exhorted his audience to try to bring about the acquittal of the accused.
('47', 322, 5, 17, 608407) Mr. Gandhi said: “I am not a Communist or any ist,” but the accused were their brothers, and even if they were wrong it was not for Government to bring them to book, but for their countrymen to bring them round.
('47', 322, 6, 18, 608619) Mr. Gandhi pleaded for an extensive use of khaddar, removal of untouchability and Hindu Muslim unity.
('47', 322, 6, 19, 608721) Thirty crores of Indians could move the whole world, and he took upon himself the task of getting the Meerut “conspiracy” prisoners out of jail if his countrymen took to khaddar.
('47', 322, 6, 20, 608900) He exhorted the people to give up liquor and other intoxicants, and criticized the excise policy of the ministers under local self government.
('47', 322, 6, 21, 609043) Twenty five crores of rupees was annually wasted on intoxicants.
('47', 322, 6, 22, 609108) He deprecated the policy of financing the Education Department out of excise revenues.

('47', 323, 1, 2, 609270) 367. LETTER TO REGINALD REYNOLDS
('47', 323, 2, 3, 609303) October 28, 1929
('47', 323, 3, 4, 609320) I was delighted to have your first letter from Sabarmati.
('47', 323, 3, 5, 609378) As I was motoring from a village I was thinking of you and lo!
('47', 323, 3, 6, 609441) as I reached Meerut at 11.30 I found your letter awaiting me.
('47', 323, 3, 7, 609503) I am sorry we shall not meet before 25th November.
('47', 323, 3, 8, 609554) In a way I am glad.
('47', 323, 3, 9, 609574) Your first experience of the Ashram will be on merits.
('47', 323, 3, 10, 609629) My presence at the Ashram prevents a dispassionate experience.
('47', 323, 3, 11, 609692) Anyway please conserve your health.
('47', 323, 3, 12, 609728) The best way to do it is to feel perfectly at home there and have all your necessary comforts supplied.
('47', 323, 3, 13, 609832) Use the sun hat freely in the hot sun.
('47', 323, 3, 14, 609871) Do not attempt suddenly to walk about barefoot.
('47', 323, 3, 15, 609919) Use the mosquitonet, if you find the mosquitoes about you.
('47', 323, 3, 16, 609978) Do not use much ghee in the beginning stages at least.
('47', 323, 3, 17, 610033) Avoid dal, try a little raw green vegetable whenever available.
('47', 323, 3, 18, 610097) Keep your bowels in good order, if necessary, by taking castor oil, epsom salt or an enema.
('47', 323, 3, 19, 610189) To ensure clearance, it is of ten better to go without one meal or to fast altogether for 24 hours, drinking freely hot water at intervals.
('47', 323, 3, 20, 610329) As you go on, I would like you to pick up a few Hindustani words daily.
('47', 323, 3, 21, 610401) Note down every word you pick up.
('47', 323, 3, 22, 610435) You can master the Devanagari character in 4 days’ time, if not earlier.
('47', 323, 3, 23, 610508) And please do not omit to get the meaning of the verses and hymns sung at the prayer time.
('47', 323, 3, 24, 610599) These two prayer times I hold to be more essential than mealtimes.
('47', 323, 3, 25, 610666) Do make it a point to give me a weekly letter giving me freely of your impressions.
('47', 323, 3, 26, 610750) May you feel and be really happy and healthy at the Ashram.
('47', 323, 4, 27, 610810) Yours, M. K. GANDHI

('47', 324, 6, 11, 611512) 369. LETTER TO KRISHNAN
('47', 324, 7, 12, 611536) October 28, 1929
('47', 324, 8, 13, 611553) MY DEAR KRISHNAN, I have been expecting to hear from you all these days.
('47', 324, 8, 14, 611626) So I was glad when I got your letter.
('47', 324, 8, 15, 611664) I do not know the merits of the exhibition controversy.
('47', 324, 8, 16, 611720) But no man is infallible.
('47', 324, 8, 17, 611746) It is enough if our associates do not err deliberately.
('47', 324, 8, 18, 611802) We should be ready to excuse one thousand mistakes unconsciously committed.
('47', 324, 8, 19, 611878) More when we meet.
('47', 324, 8, 20, 611897) Though my partiality for the common kitchen is well known I have no desire to influence anybody’s opinion.
('47', 324, 8, 21, 612004) And I know that if there are willing hands the kitchen will not be broken up.
('47', 324, 8, 22, 612082) What is needed is the will to co operate.
('47', 324, 8, 23, 612124) Where there is hearty co operation a kitchen is the easiest thing to manage.
('47', 324, 8, 24, 612201) There is really very little work to do when it is equitably divided, each attends thoroughly to his or her own portion.
('47', 324, 8, 25, 612321) Keeping time to the minute is of the greatest importance when many are working at the same thing.
('47', 324, 8, 26, 612419) One person getting out of time is like one note out of time spoiling the whole piece.
('47', 324, 8, 27, 612505) I would like all therefore to work away with hearty goodwill and there will be no more thought of a break up.

('47', 326, 3, 6, 614745) One must observe moderation even in serving, and it will probably help you to render good service if you follow the maxim, ‘Dharma without risking one’s health’.

('47', 326, 3, 9, 615131) No one has the right to encroach on that much needed rest.
('47', 326, 3, 10, 615190) As Diwali is now approaching, we should reconsider the question of the common kitchen.

('47', 327, 1, 2, 616024) 373. LETTER TO ASHRAM WOMEN
('47', 327, 2, 3, 616052) MEERUT, October 28, 1929
('47', 327, 3, 4, 616077) SISTERS, Today we are in Kripalaniji’s ashram in Meerut.
('47', 327, 3, 5, 616134) Here too, therefore, we feel the atmosphere of our Ashram.
('47', 327, 3, 6, 616193) I write to you today about our common kitchen.
('47', 327, 3, 7, 616240) Diwali is approaching.
('47', 327, 3, 8, 616263) I have already received several letters.
('47', 327, 3, 9, 616304) I write this to remove your fears.
('47', 327, 3, 10, 616339) You have now had one year’s experience.
('47', 327, 3, 11, 616379) The entire burden of the kitchen was carried by you.
('47', 327, 3, 12, 616432) I only enjoyed the benefits of the kitchen.
('47', 327, 3, 13, 616476) I, therefore, put no value on my opinion.
('47', 327, 3, 14, 616518) It is your opinion which should count.
('47', 327, 3, 15, 616557) I will, therefore, accept any decision at which all of you arrive.
('47', 327, 3, 16, 616624) But I do suggest this: Do not discuss the matter too much, nor take much time in deciding.
('47', 327, 3, 17, 616715) Discuss important points and come to a quick decision.
('47', 327, 3, 18, 616770) And whatever decision you arrive at, stick to it..
('47', 327, 3, 19, 616821) Only thus shall we progress.
('47', 327, 3, 20, 616850) There will always be arguments for and against a proposal, and we shall even make mistakes in our decisions, whatever they are.
('47', 327, 3, 21, 616978) You need not worry on that score.
('47', 327, 3, 22, 617012) It is very necessary to learn to come to a decision and stick to it afterwards.
('47', 327, 3, 23, 617092) It would be a different matter, of course, if we later feel that our decision was morally wrong.
('47', 327, 3, 24, 617189) There can be no legitimate occasion of clinging to a decision which required us to commit a sin.
('47', 327, 4, 25, 617286) Blessings from BAPU

('47', 328, 4, 10, 618008) 375. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('47', 328, 5, 11, 618036) October 28, 1929
('47', 328, 6, 12, 618053) Interviewed by the Free Press representative about the much talked of invitation to prominent Indian Nationalist leaders to be issued by the British Cabinet for a Round Table Conference to discuss the question of the future constitution of India, Mahatma Gandhi said that he was not much interested in it and he preferred to be silent in the matter.
('47', 328, 6, 13, 618403) He also preferred to be silent on the question of the programme to be settled in the Lahore Congress if Dominion Status was not granted by that time; but he reiterated his view that if Dominion Status was not granted within this year, he would be for complete independence from the next year.
('47', 328, 7, 14, 618696) The Hindu, 29 10 1929
('47', 328, 8, 15, 618718) 376. SPEECH AT MEERUT COLLEGE, MEERUT
('47', 328, 9, 16, 618756) October 28, 1929
('47', 328, 10, 17, 618773) Replying to the welcome address, Mahatmaji thanked the students and the staff for the purse which he said had surpassed all purses presented to him in proportion to the number of students of the Meerut College.
('47', 328, 10, 18, 618984) Mahatmaji expressed the fear that the welcome address given to him was not shown to all students and approved by them before being finally printed.
('47', 328, 10, 19, 619132) He knew it had been rather customary to praise guests lavishly in welcome addresses.
('47', 328, 10, 20, 619217) But he did not expect such welcome addresses from students.
('47', 328, 10, 21, 619277) A welcome address by students, said Mahatmaji, should contain at best two things.
('47', 328, 10, 22, 619359) Instead of being full of lavish praises it should contain much information about the students themselves as well as some instructions for them.
('47', 328, 10, 23, 619503) Mahatmaji was afraid he was not worthy of the lavish praises sung in the welcome address and he pointed out that the real praise of a man was to follow his ideals.
('47', 328, 11, 24, 619667) Continuing, Mahatmaji said he knew many students who did not support his ideals and were for present day Western civilization and as a matter of fact many such students had written to him to that effect.
('47', 328, 11, 25, 619871) So he did not know whether all the students
('47', 329, 0, 1, 619915) 330 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 329, 1, 2, 619957) of the Meerut College did subscribe freely to his ideals as expressed in the welcome address.
('47', 329, 1, 3, 620051) However, said Mahatmaji, if they wanted to serve the motherland they should at least know what samyama or self control was and they Should at least make attempts to practise self control.
('47', 329, 1, 4, 620239) The reason for weakness and fear of present day students was that they had forgotten to practise samyama.
('47', 329, 1, 5, 620345) Mahatmaji exhorted the students to observe celibacy and advised married students to observe samyama.
('47', 329, 1, 6, 620446) The students, he said, were soldiers and as such they should not be cowed down by threats.
('47', 329, 1, 7, 620537) He knew, that very of ten students were asked not to do this thing or that by the authorities of institutions they read in and very of ten such restrictions were sought to be enforced by threats.
('47', 329, 1, 8, 620733) He believed that students should not do many things but at the same time he hoped as soldiers the students should not allow themselves to be defeated by victimization.
('47', 329, 1, 9, 620901) The worst that might happen to them for not obeying improper dictations by the authorities was that they might be expelled from schools and colleges.
('47', 329, 1, 10, 621051) But certainly it did not matter much to them.
('47', 329, 1, 11, 621097) They might prosecute their studies in many other places.
('47', 329, 1, 12, 621154) Moreover, learning should never be regarded in terms of rupees, annas and pies, but it should be acquired for enlightening their souls.
('47', 329, 2, 13, 621290) Mahatmaji advised the students to take to khaddar which would give some relief to crores of their toiling and starving masses who were the real source of all their comforts in life including even their studies in schools and colleges.
('47', 329, 3, 14, 621525) Mahatmaji expressed regret in not being able to keep the plate and the welcome address.
('47', 329, 3, 15, 621613) He said that pledged as he was as a representative of Daridranarayana he could not keep those things.
('47', 329, 4, 16, 621715) At the conclusion .

('47', 331, 14, 22, 624780) The question of
('47', 332, 0, 1, 624796) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 333
('47', 332, 1, 2, 624845) pooling the prices of khadi coming from different provinces is very difficult till we reach standardized cloth and standardized prices for all India for ordinary seasons.

('47', 333, 0, 1, 626430) 334 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 333, 1, 2, 626472) 383. A LETTER
('47', 333, 2, 3, 626486) MEERUT, October 30, 1929
('47', 333, 3, 4, 626511) BHAI, I have your letter.
('47', 333, 3, 5, 626537) I would only caution you that if either of you feels disturbed by passion in the slightest degree you must immediately start living apart before the feeling takes definite shape.
('47', 333, 3, 6, 626716) If after thus living apart for three months you feel that self control has become stronger you may again resume the experiment of living together.
('47', 333, 3, 7, 626863) Thus gradually you can become free from passion towards each other.
('47', 333, 3, 8, 626931) Both of you must be firmly resolved in your mind in order to attain this.
('47', 333, 3, 9, 627005) Both of you should be so resolved to observe brahmacharya that while practising self control you should feel cheerful.
('47', 333, 3, 10, 627124) When the desire for self control is keen, however painful the effort, one feels joy in it even as a greedy man does in acquiring wealth.
('47', 333, 3, 11, 627261) The other point is the constitution of the Seva Sangh.
('47', 333, 3, 12, 627316) I am firmly of the view that it should not be made public at present.
('47', 333, 3, 13, 627386) But those who have accepted the underlying principles should fully practise them in their own lives.
('47', 333, 3, 14, 627487) Is not as if the objectives and the means laid down in the constitution were worthy of practise only collectively in an organization and not individually.
('47', 333, 3, 15, 627642) Your letter further confirms my view.
('47', 333, 3, 16, 627680) If your mind is unsteady, and an unsteady mind is always full of doubt, Manilal’s is not less so.
('47', 333, 3, 17, 627778) Besides he is prone to doubt.
('47', 333, 3, 18, 627808) Jamnalal’s is not unsteady.
('47', 333, 3, 19, 627836) But I have a real doubt whether you two and others who are likely to join the Sangh can be free from this weakness.
('47', 333, 3, 20, 627952) Since you know your weakness, you are somewhat indifferent to the formation of the Sangh.
('47', 333, 3, 21, 628042) Therefore my view is that for the time being you should thoroughly examine your own mind and practise the principles of the constitution independently in your life and find out from experience their truth or otherwise.
('47', 333, 3, 22, 628261) Other also who wish may do the same.
('47', 333, 3, 23, 628298) If after two or three months of experience the constitution is found to be good it can be made public.
('47', 333, 3, 24, 628401) The question then remains how in the meantime you are to shoulder the responsibility of Young Rajasthan.
('47', 333, 3, 25, 628506) If you have understood my way of working, write a letter immediately to Manilal and Jamnalalji
('47', 334, 0, 1, 628601) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 335
('47', 334, 1, 2, 628650) informing them that if they do not sent the required financial help within a certain time, you will stop Young Rajasthan.
('47', 334, 1, 3, 628772) You will lose nothing if that has to be done.
('47', 334, 1, 4, 628818) There are many field of activity for one who is keen to serve.
('47', 334, 1, 5, 628881) Be firm in your resolve that if no help is forthcoming from either of these two sources, you are not going to take it from any third source.
('47', 334, 1, 6, 629022) Also resolve not to have Young Rajasthan published from anywhere except Beawar.
('47', 334, 1, 7, 629102) The person who is resolved to follow the path of truth will learn to be indifferent even as to the things most dear to him.
('47', 334, 1, 8, 629226) My conviction that the path of non attachment taught by the Gita was the result of the realization that truth and non violence were supreme, grows stronger day by day.
('47', 334, 1, 9, 629394) The author of the Gita saw with his divine eyes that the results of truth and ahimsa are always good, but he also saw that man is not able to see them when he wishes.
('47', 334, 1, 10, 629561) And very often he is also not able to decide what is good and what is bad.
('47', 334, 1, 11, 629636) The author therefore showed him the path of non attachment.
('47', 334, 1, 12, 629696) After you come to a decision and inform me, I shall be ready to write to Jamnalalji and Manilal.
('47', 334, 1, 13, 629793) No question of yours now remains unanswered.
('47', 334, 1, 14, 629838) If you still feel confused and think it necessary to see me alone or with Haribhau 1, consult the dates of my tour programme and come to any place convenient to you.
('47', 334, 1, 15, 630004) There is a long and very good reply from Bhopal, but it is not meant for publication.
('47', 334, 1, 16, 630090) I have asked for permission to show it to co workers.
('47', 334, 1, 17, 630144) When I receive it, I will show it to co workers like you.
('47', 334, 2, 18, 630202) From a copy of the Gujarati: Kusumbehn Desai’s Diary.

('47', 334, 3, 20, 630270) 384. THE U.P. TOUR VII2
('47', 334, 4, 21, 630294) The foregoing has been, as the following itinerary 3 will show, a week of comparative rest so far as movement is concerned.
('47', 334, 5, 22, 630418) IN DEHRADUN Dehradun has long been a favourite health resort for Europeans.
('47', 334, 5, 23, 630494) It has an altitude of over 3,000 feet lying at the foot of beautiful Mussoorie described as the Queen of Hills.
('47', 334, 5, 24, 630606) It has now become popular with well to do Indians too.
('47', 334, 5, 25, 630661) It therefore boasts many
('47', 334, 6, 26, 630686) 1 Haribhau Upadhyaya 2 Vide footnote 2, “The U. P. Tour VI”, 24 10 1929 3 Not reproduced here
('47', 335, 0, 1, 630780) 336 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 335, 1, 2, 630822) educational institutions.
('47', 335, 1, 3, 630848) It has what has been euphemistically but incorrectly called the Indian Sandhurst School.
('47', 335, 1, 4, 630937) It has also several schools where boys for Cambridge Senior are prepared.
('47', 335, 1, 5, 631011) It has too the famous Anglo Vedic College founded in 1904 with an attendance of over 800 boys owing its existence to the munificent sole donation of 2_ lakhs by the late Thakur Poonamsinghji Negi.
('47', 335, 1, 6, 631208) It has the Kanya Gurukul, an offshoot of the Kangri Gurukul and conducted amid great difficulty by Shrimati Vidyavati Devi.
('47', 335, 1, 7, 631332) And when Gandhiji reached Dehradun it was holding a political conference with Sjt.
('47', 335, 1, 8, 631415) Purushottamdas Tandonji as its President.
('47', 335, 1, 9, 631457) Gandhiji was to stay there only for a day.
('47', 335, 1, 10, 631500) The programme therefore was fairly crowded.
('47', 335, 1, 11, 631544) It commenced with the laying of the foundation stone 1 of Shri Shraddhanand Abala Ashram on a spacious plot of ground.
('47', 335, 1, 12, 631663) In laying the foundation stone Gandhiji laid stress on the necessity of making the inmates of such institutions feel as members of a family with the manager as father or mother.
('47', 335, 1, 13, 631841) He therefore added: ‘The foundation of such ashrams is laid not in brick and mortar but in securing the services of a manager who would eat with the inmates and live with them as their father?
('47', 335, 1, 14, 632034) friend and guide,’ Addressing the many women who had gathered there Gandhiji said, ‘If you truly revere Shraddhanandji’s memory you will provide from among you a mother for this place.
('47', 335, 1, 15, 632219) That men mostly manage such institutions is but a penance they are doing for having grossly neglected the education and training of girls and otherwise deprived women of the opportunity of bettering themselves.’ At the Anglo Vedic College, where students presented their address and a purse of Rs. 500, Gandhiji asked the students to spread out in the villages as the Chinese had done and give the proper type of education and information both to the children and adults.
('47', 335, 1, 16, 632691) This they could do during their long vacations.
('47', 335, 1, 17, 632739) There was also the meeting of the so called untouchables.
('47', 335, 1, 18, 632797) They have adopted the name Raidasi from the great Chamar saint Raidas.
('47', 335, 1, 19, 632868) These are all well to do families at present.
('47', 335, 1, 20, 632914) From day labourers they have become owners of limekilns.
('47', 335, 1, 21, 632971) They presented a purse naturally for the Lalaji Memorial.
('47', 335, 1, 22, 633029) They owe much to the work done for and amongst them by the young men sent out by Lalaji.
('47', 335, 1, 23, 633118) Gandhiji told them that they should learn to help themselves by carrying on intensive internal reform.
('47', 335, 1, 24, 633221) Lala Beharilal, who is an elected member of the Union Board, is their leader owing his training to the Anglo Vedic
('47', 335, 2, 25, 633336) 1 On October 16
('47', 336, 0, 1, 633352) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 337
('47', 336, 1, 2, 633401) College.
('47', 336, 1, 3, 633410) No one could possibly detect any difference between him and any other educated young man.
('47', 336, 1, 4, 633500) Had I not known his antecedents, I should not have known that he was a tanner.
('47', 336, 2, 5, 633579) There was of course the Union Board address.
('47', 336, 2, 6, 633624) Gandhiji in reply said, ‘I cannot be satisfied unless you can make Dehradun a model town.
('47', 336, 2, 7, 633714) Your roads are good only in fashionable quarters.
('47', 336, 2, 8, 633764) The business centre where the workers and the poor live is not much better than when I saw it fifteen years ago.
('47', 336, 2, 9, 633877) You do not supply pure and cheap milk to the aged and the children.
('47', 336, 2, 10, 633945) Nor have you got rid of the drink curse in your midst.
('47', 336, 2, 11, 634000) And yet you have among you good Hindus, good Mussalmans and good Englishmen and you proudly inform me that you are all working in a spirit of co operation and goodwill.
('47', 336, 2, 12, 634169) Let the Union work for the benefit of the poor.’
('47', 336, 3, 13, 634218) The day closed with a monster meeting of women.
('47', 336, 3, 14, 634266) It was too noisy for Gandhiji to make any speech worth recording.
('47', 336, 4, 15, 634332) The next day on his way to Mussoorie he went to the Kanya Gurukul.
('47', 336, 4, 16, 634399) The girls recited in a beautiful voice an address composed in Sanskrit.
('47', 336, 4, 17, 634471) There was then a neat little speech by Shrimati Vidyavati recounting her trials and difficulties.
('47', 336, 4, 18, 634569) This was followed by a spinning competition in which Gandhiji, Shrimati Kasturbai and Shrimati Mirabehn had joined There was a big bundle of yarn too spun by the girls f or Gandhiji which he returned asking them to turn it into khadi and then send it to him.
('47', 336, 4, 19, 634828) In blessing the girls Gandhiji hoped that the institution would have its own abode instead of as now having to live in a state of uncertainty and suspense.
('47', 336, 5, 20, 634984) From the Kanya Gurukul we took on the way a purse from motor drivers’ association and then halted at Rajpur where the late Dr. Keshav Dev Shastri had his sanatorium and where Mrs. Shastri with her sister though American is living the life of a strict Hindu widow.
('47', 336, 5, 21, 635248) There were living there for the vacation over hundred boys of the Kangri Gurukul School.
('47', 336, 5, 22, 635337) Gandhiji unveiled there the portrait of the late doctor and planted a tree in his memory.
('47', 336, 5, 23, 635427) He received too an address from the boys and a pile of yarn which the boys had spun as also a purse which the boys had collected by their own labour.
('47', 336, 6, 24, 635577) IN MUSSOORIE
('47', 336, 7, 25, 635590) And then at last Gandhiji went uninterrupted to Mussoorie.
('47', 336, 7, 26, 635649) The cars do not go beyond Bhatta.
('47', 336, 7, 27, 635683) An uphill distance of nearly three miles had to be covered either on foot, by dandy or rickshaw or on
('47', 337, 0, 1, 635785) 338 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 337, 1, 2, 635827) horseback.
('47', 337, 1, 3, 635838) Gandhiji insisted on walking and got into a rickshaw only when he was about to enter the bazaar.
('47', 337, 1, 4, 635935) This however proved most trying for him.
('47', 337, 1, 5, 635976) Crowds pressed in upon the rickshaw from all sides.
('47', 337, 1, 6, 636028) The din and the dust and the shower of flowers choked him.
('47', 337, 1, 7, 636087) This went on for nearly an hour.
('47', 337, 1, 8, 636120) He sat dazed and dejected in the rickshaw feeling perfectly helpless.
('47', 337, 1, 9, 636190) Truly is a crowd’s affection embarrassing when it is blindly exhibited.
('47', 337, 1, 10, 636262) The Reception Committee had left no stone unturned to make Gandhiji as happy and comfortable as possible.
('47', 337, 1, 11, 636368) The weather was superb.
('47', 337, 1, 12, 636392) The snowy range sparkling in the morning sun opened upon the sleeping citizens silently calling them to wake up and remember and thank God who had created for them the mountains with their luxuriant foliage and the life giving waters that descended to the plains.
('47', 337, 1, 13, 636656) Mussoorie is the resort of rajas and their ranis who pass their idle hours in luxurious dissipation.
('47', 337, 1, 14, 636757) I understand that lakhs are spent in dances and the like to which we Indians are unused and which are as strong wine for us.
('47', 337, 1, 15, 636882) In this exciting pastime, I was told, even the ranis, who otherwise live in seclusion, take part pretty freely as deeply interested spectators when they cannot take part in it themselves.
('47', 337, 1, 16, 637070) Gandhiji found himself in this atmosphere like a fish out of water.
('47', 337, 1, 17, 637138) When therefore he received the Municipal and other addresses 1 he pointedly reminded the citizens of their duty towards the poor people.
('47', 337, 1, 18, 637275) The European members of the Municipality and some other Europeans had attended the public meeting.
('47', 337, 1, 19, 637374) And Gandhiji was called upon to speak to them in English.
('47', 337, 1, 20, 637432) Addressing them he said, ‘I do not envy you your amusements and enjoyments, but I would like you not to forget the poor in your midst.
('47', 337, 1, 21, 637567) Your very existence on a hill like this depends upon their unremitting toil.
('47', 337, 1, 22, 637644) They carry you and your luggage and furniture for a mere pittance.
('47', 337, 1, 23, 637711) They are said to get no adequate return for their labour.
('47', 337, 1, 24, 637769) They wear dirty rags, are said to live on ata 2 and salt and dwell in dirty, ill ventilated hovels.
('47', 337, 1, 25, 637869) You owe it to them to better their lot.’ The Hindi address mentioned the fact that though they had little untouchability in their midst, yet the only Hindu temple was barred against the so called untouchables.
('47', 337, 1, 26, 638079) Gandhiji expressed painful surprise that in Mussoorie where mostly enlightened people lived such a thing was tolerated.
('47', 337, 1, 27, 638199) He had therefore asked Devdas Gandhi to inquire into the affairs of the temple.
('47', 337, 2, 28, 638279) 1 On October 21 2 Flour
('47', 338, 0, 1, 638303) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 339
('47', 338, 1, 2, 638352) discovered that some trustees had actually flung open the temple to the untouchables.
('47', 338, 1, 3, 638438) But the permission lasted but a day.
('47', 338, 1, 4, 638475) Some enemy of Hinduism incited the unthinking Hindus of the bazaar to opposition.
('47', 338, 1, 5, 638557) They threatened the of fending trustees with excommunication.
('47', 338, 1, 6, 638619) The latter took fright and meekly yielded.
('47', 338, 1, 7, 638662) Gandhiji therefore vehemently urged the workers at their special meeting to bestir themselves and see to it that the temple was made accessible to the untouchables on the same terms as to the caste Hindus.
('47', 338, 1, 8, 638868) The only other public function was a ladies’ meeting.
('47', 338, 1, 9, 638922) This was largely attended by European ladies and the girls from a European girls’ college.
('47', 338, 1, 10, 639013) Gandhiji had again therefore to speak in English.
('47', 338, 1, 11, 639063) He said to them, ‘You can, if you will serve this country, do at least two things.
('47', 338, 1, 12, 639146) You can help the poor in a tangible manner by adopting khadi and you can help the total prohibition movement.
('47', 338, 1, 13, 639256) It is for you to shame your men into doing their duty towards Indian labour.
('47', 338, 1, 14, 639333) The drink curse has desolated many a labourer’s home.
('47', 338, 1, 15, 639387) There is no halfway house between drunkenness and prohibition.
('47', 338, 1, 16, 639450) Well to do men may pretend to be moderate.
('47', 338, 1, 17, 639493) But there is no such thing as moderation possible among labourers.
('47', 338, 1, 18, 639560) You can therefore create an atmosphere favourable to total prohibition and earn the silent blessings of the unfortunate victims.’

('47', 339, 2, 3, 640280) NON VIOLENCE v.
('47', 339, 2, 4, 640296) COWARDICE
('47', 339, 3, 5, 640306) Dr. Hardikar sends me an account of an assault said to have been committed on the 31st July last at Bagalkot on some volunteers of the Hindustani Seva Dal.
('47', 339, 3, 6, 640462) The volunteers were distributing handbills and marching with their bands playing without noticing a mosque which could not be seen as it was situated on a low level.
('47', 339, 3, 7, 640628) The band continued to play even when they had approached it.
('47', 339, 3, 8, 640689) Enraged men inside the mosque therefore came out and are alleged to have assaulted the volunteers with stones, sticks, pickaxes and other tools.
('47', 339, 3, 9, 640834) The volunteers, according to the description given by Dr. Hardikar, apologized for the mistake that was unconsciously made but the assault was continued.
('47', 339, 3, 10, 640988) The volunteers however never retaliated.
('47', 339, 3, 11, 641029) They decided also not to conduct any legal proceedings.
('47', 339, 3, 12, 641085) The question is whether this restraint could be called non violent or cowardly.
('47', 339, 3, 13, 641165) In my opinion, here there is no question of cowardice.
('47', 339, 3, 14, 641220) The volunteers would have been cowardly if they had run away.
('47', 339, 3, 15, 641282) On the contrary they are stated to have stood their ground and suffered the assault without retaliation at any stage.
('47', 339, 3, 16, 641400) Non violence and cowardice are contradictory terms.
('47', 339, 3, 17, 641452) Non violence is the greatest virtue, cowardice the greatest vice.
('47', 339, 3, 18, 641518) Non violence springs from love, cowardice from hate.
('47', 339, 3, 19, 641571) Non violence always suffers, cowardice would always inflict suffering.
('47', 339, 3, 20, 641642) Perfect non violence is the highest bravery.
('47', 339, 3, 21, 641687) Non violent conduct is never demoralizing, cowardice always is.
('47', 339, 3, 22, 641751) I can detect no cowardice in the conduct of the volunteers.
('47', 339, 3, 23, 641811) No one claims the highest form of bravery for them.
('47', 339, 3, 24, 641863) The assault, it is said, was so brutal that some Mussalman women who were nearby expostulated with the assaulters for continuing their assault in spite of the apology that was tendered.
('47', 339, 3, 25, 642049) If the facts are as they are related, in my opinion the conduct of the volunteers was exemplary and strictly non violent in terms of the Congress creed.
('47', 339, 3, 26, 642202) Opinions may differ as to the propriety of such conduct, but there can be no two opinions about the bravery of the volunteers.
('47', 339, 3, 27, 642329) It is undoubtedly in keeping with the creed that no court proceedings have been taken by the injured parties.
('47', 339, 3, 28, 642439) My own conviction is that the more the volunteers learn the law of suffering bravely and consciously, the greater will be their efficiency for service when the critical time comes.
('47', 340, 0, 1, 642620) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 341
('47', 340, 1, 2, 642669) WHO SHOULD PROTECT?
('47', 340, 2, 3, 642689) An Assam correspondent writes a fearful letter describing abductions of girls, married, unmarried and widowed, and he indignantly asks what measures are being taken to protect the honour of our women.
('47', 340, 2, 4, 642890) He sends me newspaper cuttings in corroboration of his statement.
('47', 340, 2, 5, 642956) It is possible, as I have been repeatedly told, that these cases are exaggerated, but whether they are or not there is no doubt that abduction in well organized society should be almost an impossibility.
('47', 340, 2, 6, 643160) But I know that newspaper reporting can do very little in the way of securing protection for the girls who are in fear of being abducted.
('47', 340, 2, 7, 643298) It is proof of rank cowardice on the part of relatives, friends and neighbours.
('47', 340, 2, 8, 643378) A society that is unable to protect its womenfolk is unfit to marry and procreate.
('47', 340, 2, 9, 643461) Licentious men will satisfy their lust whenever and wherever they can with impunity.
('47', 340, 2, 10, 643546) The only agitation that can or should be set up is to shame those who do not protect their womenfolk into doing their duty.
('47', 340, 3, 11, 643670) ADVERTISING LEWDNESS
('47', 340, 4, 12, 643691) Jairamdas, the Hon.
('47', 340, 4, 13, 643711) Secretary of the Foreign Cloth Boycott Committee, has sent me mild specimens as he calls them of indecent pictures which unscrupulous sellers of foreign cloth put in the pieces of calico, etc., they sell.
('47', 340, 4, 14, 643916) He tells me that there were pictures far more indecent than the specimens he has sent to me.
('47', 340, 4, 15, 644009) Whether the interpolation of these pictures is the work of the agents or of the principals it is difficult to say, but the pictures are there and they bear also names appropriate to the lewdness they advertise.
('47', 340, 4, 16, 644220) One is marked ‘Vilas Jivan’ 1 for instance The unscrupulous ways adopted for enticing simple folk to buy foreign cloth ought to disgust decent men and make them boycott foreign cloth even for these unscrupulous ways apart from any other reason.

('47', 341, 4, 10, 645514) 388. PHYSICAL AND MORAL IN SANITATION
('47', 341, 5, 11, 645552) There can be no doubt that at one time Hardwar and the other celebrated places of pilgrimage were really holy.
('47', 341, 5, 12, 645663) Their natural beauty, their ancient popularity would seem to show that at one time they were sanctuaries for the preservation and purification of Hinduism.
('47', 341, 5, 13, 645819) In spite of my innate love of Hinduism, in spite of my conservatism that ever seeks to respect and justify ancient institutions, these holy places have few man made attractions for me.
('47', 341, 5, 14, 646004) It was in 1915 that I first visited Hardwar 2 as a volunteer working under Pandit Hridaynath Kunzru who was in charge of the Seva Samiti organized by the Servants of India Society.
('47', 341, 5, 15, 646185) I was therefore able to come in intimate touch with many men and things which otherwise I would not have done.
('47', 341, 5, 16, 646296) I had gone there full of hope and reverence.
('47', 341, 5, 17, 646341) But whilst I realized the grandeur of the holy Ganga and the holier Himalayas, I saw little to inspire me in what man was doing in this holy place.
('47', 341, 5, 18, 646489) To my great grief I discovered insanitation both moral and physical.
('47', 341, 5, 19, 646558) I found during the recent visit 3 not much change for the better.
('47', 341, 5, 20, 646624) There is the same defilement of the mighty stream even in the name of religion.

('47', 343, 3, 13, 650419) 389. HIGH AND LOW
('47', 343, 4, 14, 650437) We say this man is high, that is low.
('47', 343, 4, 15, 650475) Sciences, both physical and metaphysical, tell us that we are all identical both physically and spiritually.
('47', 343, 4, 16, 650584) Scientists) having analysed the human body, state that our bodies are made up of the same five elements, there being no difference on account of origin, race or sex.
('47', 343, 4, 17, 650750) The ant and the elephant, the Brahmin and the sweeper, man and woman, the bodies of them all are composed of clay and the other things.
('47', 343, 4, 18, 650886) The Upanishads and other scriptures teach us that an inward view will reveal only one soul pervading us all.
('47', 343, 4, 19, 650995) So the subtle seeing Acharya Sankara has told usthat the differences apparent to us in name and form and such other things are all nothing but maya 1. Others call it upadhi 2 and some others call it moha 3 too.
('47', 343, 4, 20, 651206) Everyone admits that this conglomeration of names, forms, etc., is ephemeral.
('47', 343, 4, 21, 651284) In spite of a knowledge of these facts, the stress on the high and the low is not as pronounced in any other society as it is in the Hindu society.
('47', 343, 4, 22, 651432) One gentleman, who has had experience of this, writes: 4
('47', 343, 5, 23, 651489) 1 Illusion 2 Disguise, cover 3 Delusion 4 The letter is not translated here.
('47', 343, 5, 24, 651566) The correspondent had referred to the prevailing distinction between kachchi and pakki food—persons of a higher caste would not partake of kachchi food of offered by persons of a lower caste but there were no restrictions in accepting pakki food—and had asked whether khadi workers should not agitate against such distinctions which strengthened caste prejudices.
('47', 344, 0, 1, 651930) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 345
('47', 344, 1, 2, 651979) Two questions have been posed in this letter.
('47', 344, 1, 3, 652025) Should khadi promoters fall a prey to popular beliefs and observe kachchi pakki differences?
('47', 344, 1, 4, 652118) Should they admit the distinction between the high and the low?
('47', 344, 1, 5, 652182) It is my firm belief that, even for the sake of khadi, no khadi lover should give up his principles, resort to incorrect behaviour, or ever have recourse to evil ways even with the best of intentions.
('47', 344, 1, 6, 652383) Nothing good can ever be accomplished through unclean means.
('47', 344, 1, 7, 652444) The power that we look for in khadi will be completely destroyed if we resort to undesirable means in our work.
('47', 344, 1, 8, 652556) The annihilation of the distinction between high and low is a glorious result of khadi.
('47', 344, 1, 9, 652644) Now, the second question is why not agitate against this difference of kachchi pakki?
('47', 344, 1, 10, 652730) The agitation for the spread of khadi can only pertain to khadi.
('47', 344, 1, 11, 652795) Having given up the difference of kachchi pakki in one’s own life, one has nothing more to do in this direction.
('47', 344, 1, 12, 652908) One must also realize that there can be no greater propaganda than one’s own conduct.
('47', 344, 1, 13, 652994) What one wants others to do, one should do oneself.
('47', 344, 1, 14, 653046) This would be his most effective propaganda.

('47', 345, 5, 6, 654041) I still cannot say that the printing of the Ashram Samachar is such that it can be read in full.

('47', 345, 5, 13, 654698) The number of the labourers staying there must be known and it should be easy to give it.
('47', 345, 5, 14, 654788) We cannot have in the Ashram a separate class of labourers distinct from other inmates.
('47', 345, 5, 15, 654876) the labourers should be identified in some other way, because all of us are labourers.
('47', 345, 5, 16, 654963) We should drive this point into our heads as firmly as we can.
('47', 345, 5, 17, 655026) And we must give up in practice and in principle the idea which often persists that a particular job is the responsibility only of the labourers.
('47', 345, 5, 18, 655172) We should make a distinction between students and paid workers or members receiving maintenance and paid workers in keeping with our principles.
('47', 345, 5, 19, 655317) But even while making such a distinction we must strive to absorb the labourers among ourselves.
('47', 345, 5, 20, 655414) In other words, the number of labourers should diminish day by day and we should try to absorb among ourselves as many of the present ones as we can.

('47', 348, 1, 2, 658890) 394. ALL PARTIES LEADERS’ JOINT STATEMENTS1
('47', 348, 2, 3, 658934) November 2,1929 We, the undersigned, have read with careful consideration the Viceregal pronouncement on the question of India’s future status among the nations of the world.
('47', 348, 2, 4, 659109) We appreciate the sincerity underlying the declaration, as also the desire of the British Government to placate Indian opinion.
('47', 348, 2, 5, 659237) We hope to be able to tender our co operation to His Majesty’s Government in their effort to evolve a scheme of Dominion Constitution suitable for India’s needs.
('47', 348, 2, 6, 659399) But we deem it necessary that certain acts should be done and certain points should be cleared so as to inspire trust and ensure the co operation of the political organizations in the country.
('47', 348, 2, 7, 659592) We consider it vital for the success of the proposed Conference that: (a) a policy of general conciliation should be definitely adopted to induce a calmer atmosphere; (b) political prisoners should be granted a general amnesty; and (c) the representation of progressive political organizations should be effectively secured and that the Indian National Congress, as the largest among them, should have predominant representation.
('47', 348, 2, 8, 660022) Some doubt has been expressed about the interpretation of the paragraph in the statement made by the Viceroy on behalf of His Majesty’s Government regarding Dominion Status.
('47', 348, 2, 9, 660196) We understand, however, that the Conference is to meet not to discuss when Dominion Status is to be established but to frame a scheme of Dominion Constitution for India.
('47', 348, 2, 10, 660366) We hope that we are not mistaken in thus interpreting the import and implication of the weighty pronoun cement of H. E. the Viceroy.

('47', 349, 3, 6, 661781) 395. SPEECH AT CIVIC RECEPTION, DELHI
('47', 349, 4, 7, 661819) November 2, 1929 Mahatmaji, in replying to the address, said he was thankful to the Municipality for the honour done to him.
('47', 349, 4, 8, 661944) He expressed his regret for being late and said that doctors, pleaders and national servants were not masters of their time.
('47', 349, 4, 9, 662069) He congratulated the Municipality for the work it had done for the city, but he told the City Fathers that the service of the poor alone should be their primary duty.
('47', 349, 4, 10, 662236) Service to the poor, the needy and the helpless was the only real service that the Municipality could do.
('47', 349, 4, 11, 662342) Continuing, he said it was wrong for them to think that national work was out of the municipal scope.
('47', 349, 4, 12, 662444) To establish Hindu Muslim unity in the city was their prime function.
('47', 349, 4, 13, 662514) A municipality which did not perform its duty in this respect, simply because it was not included in its rules and regulations, failed in its duty.
('47', 349, 4, 14, 662662) He said: If today the City Fathers of Delhi resolve that they will completely root out discord and disunity from the capital of India they will be doing nothing more than their duty to their country.
('47', 349, 4, 15, 662862) I am a very poor man and regard myself as a representative of the poor— Daridranarayana—and you have presented me with an ivory box of great cost.
('47', 349, 4, 16, 663009) How can I keep it with me?
('47', 349, 4, 17, 663036) I present it to you and will charge you sovereigns for it.
('47', 349, 4, 18, 663095) (Laughter) I have no home and no safe where I can keep this precious box.
('47', 349, 4, 19, 663169) Being a municipality you cannot give me cash but I put it to auction and ask you to pay liberally.
('47', 349, 4, 20, 663268) Every rupee of it will give food to 16 helpless women, through spinn ing charkha and they will pray for your prosperity.
('47', 349, 4, 21, 663389) I have sold such boxes everywhere and have charged very heavy sums—up to Rs. 1,000 for a box.
('47', 349, 4, 22, 663483) Do not deal with me as a Bania, but deal with me as a representative of the poor.
('47', 349, 4, 23, 663565) (Cheers)

('47', 350, 1, 2, 663654) 396. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, DELHI
('47', 350, 2, 3, 663691) November 2, 1929
('47', 350, 3, 4, 663708) Mahatma Gandhi .
('47', 350, 3, 5, 663725) thanked the Congress Committee for “the long address”, the Mazdur Sabha for “a small address” and the public for the purse.
('47', 350, 3, 6, 663849) According to the rules of his tour, said Mahatmaji, the addresses ought not to have been read out but because he allowed the municipal address to be read over and thus “committed a sin”, he had to undergo more sins.
('47', 350, 3, 7, 664065) (Laughter) In a rather pathetic tone Mahatmaji said: Delhi, where the great Hakim Ajmal Khan and Swami Shrad dhanand once lived, is not nowadays giving the true lead to the country.
('47', 350, 3, 8, 664247) What can we helpless people do in the absence of the two great souls?
('47', 350, 3, 9, 664317) I feel pain when I come to Delhi.
('47', 350, 4, 10, 664351) Continuing, he said he had not come to Delhi for receiving addresses.
('47', 350, 4, 11, 664421) He had come to Delhi many times before, but this time he had come for a selfish purpose.
('47', 350, 4, 12, 664510) (Laughter) He had become greedy, said the Mahatma, for the sake of the poor and was begging money to provide khadi work to the teeming millions.
('47', 350, 4, 13, 664655) He felt pain in saying that Delhi had fared worse than even the small towns which had paid him more than Rs. 5,000. The citizens of Delhi, he knew, spent on luxuries and useless articles, but if even after their expenses, they would give him savings, that could have satisfied his hunger.
('47', 350, 4, 14, 664944) (Laughter)
('47', 350, 5, 15, 664955) The ladies and the students had paid their due share, but he expected more from the audience.
('47', 350, 6, 16, 665049) Reverting to the subject, Mahatmaji said Delhi was such an important and historic city that if the citizens of Delhi once resolved to unite themselves, it could become an ideal city for the whole country.
('47', 350, 6, 17, 665254) Pray to God to relieve us from the curse of disunity and I ask you what can the bold statements of leaders like the one made today achieve if Hindu Muslim unity is not established?
('47', 350, 7, 18, 665435) Delhi if it desired could successfully boycott foreign cloth and give lead to other cities.
('47', 350, 7, 19, 665527) There were many other trades open to the citizens of Delhi.
('47', 350, 7, 20, 665587) He also appealed to everyone in the audience to join the Congress as a member so that the Congress purse may no longer remain empty.
('47', 350, 7, 21, 665720) He appealed to Hindus to do away with the curse of untouchability which was against God’s nature and will.
('47', 350, 7, 22, 665827) He made a strong appeal for giving up liquor saying, “Give up this animal like habit.” Mahatmaji then referred to the address of the Mazdur Sabha.
('47', 350, 7, 23, 665974) He said the labourers knew him well and he knew them well, as he too was a labourer.
('47', 350, 7, 24, 666059) The labourers had every right to get good food and decent dress and it was the duty of
('47', 351, 0, 1, 666146) 352 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 351, 1, 2, 666188) labourers to perform their duties truthfully and properly.
('47', 351, 1, 3, 666247) I want to do away with the distinction between the master and the servant or labourer.
('47', 351, 1, 4, 666334) Our ancient civilization teaches us that there is no such status as master and servant but it is that of father and son, and if this relation is adopted there can be no dispute between capital and labour.
('47', 351, 1, 5, 666539) (Cheers) If the employers regarded themselves as fathers and guardians of labourers and labourers regarded the factories as their own, then both could give an ideal lesson to the world.
('47', 351, 1, 6, 666725) (Cheers)
('47', 351, 2, 7, 666734) He concluded: Our strength is immense, we need strong determination and well considered action.
('47', 351, 2, 8, 666830) I pray to God to bless us with a will and power to enable us to drive away fear and plunge into the field of action so that Mother India be free once again.
('47', 351, 2, 9, 666987) (Loud applause)

('47', 351, 4, 11, 667034) 397. HAS “NAVAJIVAN” BECOME DULL?
('47', 351, 5, 12, 667068) A simple minded lover of Navajivan writes: 1
('47', 351, 6, 13, 667113) Reading this letter, I was reminded of the well known artist’s argument.
('47', 351, 6, 14, 667186) I must wind up Navajivan if I were to collect the views of all the critics and act on them.
('47', 351, 6, 15, 667278) But I wish to do no such thing.
('47', 351, 6, 16, 667310) My colleagues and I are trying our best not to let Navajivan become dull.
('47', 351, 6, 17, 667384) Not one line is written which will not help the swaraj yajna.
('47', 351, 6, 18, 667446) That there is and may be a difference of opinion about the procedure of this yajna is proved by the critic himself.
('47', 351, 6, 19, 667562) Therefore, differences will always be there.
('47', 351, 6, 20, 667607) Now I know some readers who have liked the articles which this critic has not liked.
('47', 351, 6, 21, 667692) Anyone who comprehends the magnitude of the swaraj yajna should not find it difficult It to appr eciate the usefulness of the articles in Navajivan.
('47', 351, 6, 22, 667841) I know it very well that I shall never be able to make all the articles in Navajivan intere sting to all its readers.

('47', 351, 6, 25, 668196) They should under stand that articles which do not interest them might possibly interest others.

('47', 367, 7, 13, 694165) 421. SPEECH AT MUSLIM UNIVERSITY, ALIGARH2
('47', 367, 8, 14, 694208) November 4, 1929
('47', 367, 9, 15, 694225) The Mahatma .
('47', 367, 9, 16, 694239) apologized for his inability to speak standing since God was not pleased to keep him in normal strength.
('47', 367, 9, 17, 694344) He asked his hearers to pray to God to keep him deserving of the honour they had conferred upon him and to keep his heart unspoiled.
('47', 367, 9, 18, 694477) He said he had known from his very boyhood that Hindu Muslim unity was an integral part of Indian nationhood and he believed that national liberty was meaningless if Hindus and Muslims could not live together open heartedly with complete harmony.
('47', 367, 9, 19, 694724) He did not like that the two big communities should oppress the minority communities or should make them even feel that Hindu Muslim unity was a bad thing.
('47', 367, 9, 20, 694880) He rather wished the unity of the two to be a model for the whole world and a giver of peace.
('47', 367, 9, 21, 694974) He agreed with the late Sir Syed 3 that Hindus and Muslims were the two eyes of Mother India.
('47', 367, 9, 22, 695068) He exhorted the students to be as true and sincere soldiers of India as they were true sons of Islam.
('47', 367, 9, 23, 695170) He said further that having read and studied much of Islam and having long lived and even dined with Muslims, he knew the Islamic religion well.
('47', 367, 9, 24, 695315) He advised the students not to be a prey to ease and luxury since only he
('47', 367, 10, 25, 695389) 1 From Gandhiji’s presence at Aligarh and another letter to the addressee dated November 14, 1929 from Kalakankar; vide “Letter to Kalavati Trivedi”, 14 1 1 1929. 2 Vide also “The U. P. Tour IX”, sub title, “In Aligarh”, 14 11 1929. 3 Sir Syed Ahmed Khan
('47', 368, 0, 1, 695644) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 369
('47', 368, 1, 2, 695693) could serve the country well whose heart was simple and whose habits were simple.
('47', 368, 1, 3, 695775) He farther exhorted the students to pity the lot of the millions of poor people who were having hardly one meal a day.
('47', 368, 1, 4, 695894) In his opinion God could not be pleased with them merely by their daily readings of the Koran or by their daily prayers.
('47', 368, 1, 5, 696015) The real thing that could please God was their practical mercy and real compassion for the millions of their distressed brethren.
('47', 368, 1, 6, 696145) He, therefore, urged them to encourage khaddar.

('47', 369, 1, 4, 697287) 1 also.
('47', 369, 1, 5, 697295) Are you reading anything these days?
('47', 369, 1, 6, 697332) Even if you reserve only five minutes for reading the practice will be useful.
('47', 369, 1, 7, 697411) Those who carefully save their minutes add to their span of life, lessen the weight of their burdens and increase their knowledge.

('47', 369, 1, 14, 698080) Whatever time such a person gets he devotes to the work and if, after honestly doing his best, he cannot complete it he remains unconcerned.
('47', 369, 1, 15, 698221) He does not feel unhappy.
('47', 369, 1, 16, 698247) It would be difficult in the beginning to form the habit I have suggested.
('47', 369, 1, 17, 698322) But by and by it becomes a natural thing and one feels no effort.

('47', 371, 1, 2, 700702) 427. LETTER TO RAOJIBHAI M. PATEL
('47', 371, 2, 3, 700736) MATHURA, November 6, 1929
('47', 371, 3, 4, 700762) BHAI RAOJIBHAI, I got your letter.
('47', 371, 3, 5, 700797) When we have several tasks on hand and are not in a position to do full justice to all of them, we should arrange them in order of their priority and assign each its place so that we can know which task can be dropped.
('47', 371, 3, 6, 701016) And if all the tasks are of equal importance, we should drop those which are beyond our capacity to manage.
('47', 371, 3, 7, 701124) The latrines, the kitchen and the accounts—these three I regard as having the highest priority.
('47', 371, 3, 8, 701220) If the accounts are not correctly maintained, money will be wasted, our reputation will suffer and our conscience will be troubled.
('47', 371, 3, 9, 701352) I have often explained that care of the latrine and of the kitchen are aspects of the same task.
('47', 371, 3, 10, 701449) If either of them is imperfectly done, bodily health would suffer.
('47', 371, 3, 11, 701516) I have also shown that scavenging and cooking involve important moral and scientific principles.
('47', 371, 3, 12, 701613) A cook doing his or her duty religiously will not only cook the food well but will also observe the principles of good health, that is, of brahmacharya.
('47', 371, 3, 13, 701766) And a scavenger doing his or her duty religiously will not merely bury the night soil but also observe the stools passed by each and inform each person about the state of his or her health.
('47', 371, 3, 14, 701956) We have with us neither such an ideal scavenger nor such an ideal cook, but I have no doubt that the Ashram should produce a crop of them.
('47', 371, 3, 15, 702095) There are several defects about the kind of tank you suggest.
('47', 371, 3, 16, 702157) We cannot of course build a pukka tank.
('47', 371, 3, 17, 702197) We may dig a temporary pit.
('47', 371, 3, 18, 702225) But we can think about this further only when I go over there.
('47', 371, 3, 19, 702288) In any case this much is certain, that the shallower the pit the better.
('47', 371, 3, 20, 702361) The first nine inches of the soil is exceedingly valuable.
('47', 371, 3, 21, 702420) It is within this depth that the germs decomposing the stools, etc., live.
('47', 371, 3, 22, 702495) The effect of the sun’s rays also is the greatest up to that depth.
('47', 371, 3, 23, 702563) Moreover, a shallow pit is no obstacle to the use of night soil as manure wherever required.
('47', 371, 3, 24, 702656) Instead of burying night soil where we do at present, we may adopt this method.
('47', 371, 3, 25, 702736) We should get two pits made side by side, each eighteen inches deep and having a surface area of 36 sq.
('47', 371, 3, 26, 702840) After one pit is filled with night soil we might start using the other for the purpose and, after the night soil in the first pit has been transformed into manure, take the manure out leaving the pit to
('47', 372, 0, 1, 703043) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 373
('47', 372, 1, 2, 703092) dry up until the second pit gets filled with night soil buried there.
('47', 372, 1, 3, 703162) This method will serve the purpose behind Somabhai’s suggestion and largely remove the difficulty pointed out by you.
('47', 372, 1, 4, 703280) The lavatories should remain as they are, and we should master the art of keeping them as clean as possible.
('47', 372, 1, 5, 703389) For this one of us must shoulder the responsibility.
('47', 372, 1, 6, 703442) The working men will go on changing from time to time, and it is necessary that they should.
('47', 372, 1, 7, 703535) It is, therefore, essential to have one inspector.
('47', 372, 1, 8, 703586) It is not enough that he take a round in the morning and inspect the places.
('47', 372, 1, 9, 703663) He should inspect the lavatories at least thrice a day.
('47', 372, 1, 10, 703719) For maintaining greater cleanliness, it may also be necessary to have more buckets.

('47', 373, 1, 2, 704443) 429. THE U.P. TOUR–VIII1
('47', 373, 2, 3, 704468) ON THE PLAINS
('47', 373, 3, 4, 704482) Saharanpur was the first station visited 2 on the plains.
('47', 373, 3, 5, 704540) Besides the usual meetings of men and women there was the students’ meeting.
('47', 373, 3, 6, 704617) There was a meeting of the students and teachers of the Kashiram High School who together gave Gandhiji the largest purse of the tour comparing their numbers with the numbers of the other schools and colleges.
('47', 373, 3, 7, 704827) This evoked from Gandhiji a well deserved compliment as also the frank admission in their address that the khadi he saw them wear at the meeting was only purchased for the occasion and they assured him that what they had commenced they proposed to continue.
('47', 373, 3, 8, 705085) The wearing of khadi for the occasion only has taken place everywhere without there being any secret about it.
('47', 373, 3, 9, 705196) But this was the first occasion when a frank and penitent admission of weakness was made and a definite assurance of shedding it given.
('47', 373, 3, 10, 705332) I was told that the head master and the staff were earnest men and that they fully meant to carry out the promise they had made.
('47', 373, 3, 11, 705461) Taking Deoband on the way the next halt was at Muzaffarnagar.
('47', 373, 3, 12, 705523) From Muzaffarnagar we went to Meerut, taking Kandhla, Shamli and several other places on the way.
('47', 373, 3, 13, 705621) We settled down to a heavy programme in the Meerut district.
('47', 373, 4, 14, 705682) WITH THE PRISONERS
('47', 373, 5, 15, 705701) We reached Meerut at 11 a.m.
('47', 373, 5, 16, 705730) 3 and had to tackle a ladies’ meeting and a public meeting.
('47', 373, 5, 17, 705790) But Meerut was the place where the famous Communist trial is taking place.
('47', 373, 5, 18, 705865) Though as he remarked he was neither a Communist nor any other ist, he could not miss seeing the prisoners if he was permitted.
('47', 373, 5, 19, 705993) The Superintendent readily granted the permission and though it meant considerable interference with his rest and the day’s programme Gandhiji went to the jail precisely at 2 p.m.
('47', 373, 5, 20, 706173) and gave himself a happy 1_ hours’ time with the prisoners.
('47', 373, 5, 21, 706233) The party squatted on the coir matting that was spread on the floor.
('47', 373, 5, 22, 706302) The prisoners’ cell was an open well ventilated rectangle studded withcharpais for them.
('47', 373, 5, 23, 706391) The prisoners who were quite cheerful and gay greeted Gandhiji with ‘we frankly did not expect you to visit us’.
('47', 373, 6, 24, 706504) 1 Vide footnote 2, “the U. P. Tour VI”, 24 10 1929 2 On October 25, 1929 3 On October 27, 1929
('47', 374, 0, 1, 706599) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 375
('47', 374, 1, 2, 706648) Gandhiji at once replied, ‘Of course you did not.
('47', 374, 1, 3, 706698) You do not know me.
('47', 374, 1, 4, 706718) I may have my differences with you.
('47', 374, 1, 5, 706754) You may even cause me trouble at Congress meetings but my creed teaches me to go out of my way to show regard to my opponents and thus demonstrate to them that I can mean no ill to them.
('47', 374, 1, 6, 706941) Moreover in the present case by coming here I wanted in my humble way to show in a practical manner that this prosecution is wrong and that in any event it is atrocious that you should be put under a heavy handicap by being tried in an inconvenient place like Meerut where you cannot get the facilities obtainable in the presidency towns for conducting a proper defence.’ There was quite a variety of topics which the prisoners discussed with Gandhiji.
('47', 374, 1, 7, 707394) They wanted to know the implications of the Calcutta resolution about Dominion Status.
('47', 374, 1, 8, 707481) They wanted to know also why he was silent on Jatindra Nath’s self immolation, about strikes, etc.
('47', 374, 1, 9, 707580) Interesting though the whole of the conversation was, I must not attempt to give the whole of it.
('47', 374, 1, 10, 707678) Suffice it to say that Gandhiji kept them laughing the whole of the hour and a half he was with them.
('47', 374, 1, 11, 707780) One could see that he was loath to part with them and when he could stay no longer he told them that if they were not free men before the end of December he expected to join them early next year.
('47', 374, 1, 12, 707976) I must omit many other interesting events of the Meerut tour.
('47', 374, 2, 13, 708038) GANDHI ASHRAM Chaudhuri Raghubir Narain Singhji is an enthusiast in the national cause and a lover of khadi.
('47', 374, 2, 14, 708147) He was in charge of the tour in Meerut and the surrounding villages.
('47', 374, 2, 15, 708216) He had therefore prepared as heavy a programme as Gandhiji’s health could stand.
('47', 374, 2, 16, 708297) Out of the numerous engagements in Meerut itself and the rich experiences gained in the numerous villages visited I have time and space for picking out only two things.
('47', 374, 2, 17, 708466) The first is Acharya Kripalani’s Ashram and the second is the visit to the Chaudhuri Saheb’s own village Asaura.
('47', 374, 2, 18, 708579) The Ashram which is named Gandhi Ashram was established in l920 in Banaras when some students of the Hindu University left it and with Professor Kripalani established an Ashram.
('47', 374, 2, 19, 708757) Those who have remained staunch throughout have developed into good businessmen.
('47', 374, 2, 20, 708838) The members took up khadi work in 1921. The production then amounted to Rs. 48 and the sales to Rs. 3,01l [sic].
('47', 374, 2, 21, 708951) For the year ending October last the production was Rs. 129,189 8 0. The sales were Rs. 171,512 13 6. No wonder the Ashram has purchased property worth Rs. 35,000 away from the business centre
('47', 375, 0, 1, 709144) 376 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 375, 1, 2, 709186) and on spacious ground.
('47', 375, 1, 3, 709210) I regard it as a necessary and sound investment.
('47', 375, 1, 4, 709259) Every available room is occupied.
('47', 375, 1, 5, 709293) The Ashram has production, sales, dyeing, printing, washing and calendering departments.
('47', 375, 1, 6, 709382) Its prints are day by day increasing in popularity, as indigenous art is being introduced in its prints and innovations are being continuously made.
('47', 375, 1, 7, 709531) The price of one yard of 36” khadi in 1921 was as.
('47', 375, 1, 8, 709582) 9. Today that quantity but improved in quality sells at as.
('47', 375, 1, 9, 709642) 5. And yet they expect to reduce the price.
('47', 375, 1, 10, 709686) The Ashram prices compare favourably with the ruling prices throughout India.
('47', 375, 1, 11, 709764) It has 29 permanent workers, 14 apprentices and 11 servants.
('47', 375, 1, 12, 709825) The salary paid during the year was Rs. 12,123 4 6 averaging about Rs. 18 per month per head.

('47', 375, 2, 21, 710371) IN ASAURA
('47', 375, 3, 22, 710381) In Asaura of course there is a strong khadi atmosphere.
('47', 375, 3, 23, 710437) It would be strange if such was not the case in the zamindari of a khadi lover such as the Chaudhuri Saheb is.
('47', 375, 3, 24, 710548) But what delighted Gandhiji most was the discovery made in the ordinary course that the family mandir 1
('47', 375, 4, 25, 710652) which is open to the public has been open since the days of Non co operation to the so called untouchables.
('47', 375, 4, 26, 710760) And I have understood from the Chaudhuri Saheb himself that the throwing open the portals of the mandir to the untouchables has not in any way affected the attendance of the touchables.
('47', 375, 4, 27, 710946) Like the Lakshmi Narayan temple of Seth Jamnalal of Wardha this too has an elegantly built structure.
('47', 375, 4, 28, 711048) It adjoins the beautiful garden belonging to the zamindari.
('47', 375, 4, 29, 711108) There is a precious courtyard attached to it and the courtyard contains a school attended by the untouchables.
('47', 375, 4, 30, 711219) Here is an example for the zamindars to copy.
('47', 375, 4, 31, 711265) There are thousands of temples in the thousands of zamindaris.
('47', 375, 4, 32, 711328) There is nothing to prevent the zamindars from throwing open their temples to the untouchables and in other ways befriending them as the Chaudhuri Saheb has done.

('47', 376, 1, 2, 711572) 430. WHAT MAY YOUTH DO?
('47', 376, 2, 3, 711596) I got now some time ago a letter on behalf of the Agra Youth League asking the following question:
('47', 376, 3, 4, 711695) We are in the dark with regard to our main activities in future.
('47', 376, 3, 5, 711760) We wish to co operate with the peasants and neighbours of the locality but no practical method seems to be at hand.
('47', 376, 3, 6, 711876) We hope that you will kindly suggest some practical way out of the difficulty.
('47', 376, 3, 7, 711955) We think ours is not the only institution facing this difficulty.
('47', 376, 3, 8, 712021) Accordingly it is highly desirable that you should suggest a definite solution of this problem through the columns of Navajivan or Young India.
('47', 376, 3, 9, 712165) The address of the Youth League at Gorakhpur 1 contained a similar sentiment and also asked how to face the bread problem that stared the youth in the face.
('47', 376, 3, 10, 712322) In my opinion the two questions are intertwined and both can be solved, if the youth can be persuaded to make village life their goal rather than city life.
('47', 376, 3, 11, 712479) We are inheritors of a rural civilization.
('47', 376, 3, 12, 712522) The vastness of our country, the vastness of the population, the situation and the climate of the country have, in my opinion, destined it for a rural civilization.
('47', 376, 3, 13, 712687) Its defects are well known but not one of them is irremediable.
('47', 376, 3, 14, 712751) To uproot it and substitute for it an urban civilization seems to me an impossibility, unless we are prepared by some drastic means to reduce the population from three hundred million to three or say even thirty.
('47', 376, 3, 15, 712964) I can therefore suggest remedies on the assumption that we must perpetuate the present rural civilization and endeavour to rid it of its acknowledged defects.
('47', 376, 3, 16, 713123) This can only be done if the youth of the country will settle down to village life.
('47', 376, 3, 17, 713207) And if they will do this they must reconstruct their life and pass every day of their vacation in the villages surrounding their colleges or high schools and those who have finished their education or are not receiving any should think of settling down in villages.
('47', 376, 3, 18, 713473) The All India Spinners’ Association with all its multifarious branches and institutions that have sprung up under its protection affords an easy opportunity to the students to qualify themselves for service and to maintain themselves honourably if they will be satisfied with the simple life which obtains in the villages.
('47', 376, 3, 19, 713796) It maintains nearly 1500 young men of the country drawing anything between Rs. 15 to Rs. 150, and it can take in almost an unlimited number of earnest, honest and industrious young men who will not be ashamed of manual work.
('47', 376, 4, 20, 714021) 1 Gandhiji was in Gorakhpur district between October 4 and 7.
('47', 377, 0, 1, 714083) 378 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 377, 1, 2, 714125) Then there are national educational institutions affording a similar though limited scope, limited only because national education is not in fashion.
('47', 377, 1, 3, 714275) I therefore commend to the attention of all earnest young men who are dissatisfied with their existing surroundings and outlook to study these two great national institutions which are doing silent but most effective constructive work and which present the youth of the country with an opportunity both for service and for honourable maintenance.
('47', 377, 1, 4, 714622) Whether however they avail themselves of these two great nation building agencies or do not, let them penetrate the villages and find an unlimited scope for service, research and true knowledge.
('47', 377, 1, 5, 714817) Professors would do well not to burden either their boys or girls with literary studies during the vacation but prescribe to them educative outings in the villages.
('47', 377, 1, 6, 714982) Vacations must be utilized for recreation, never for memorizing books.
('47', 377, 2, 7, 715053) Young India, 7 11 1929
('47', 377, 3, 8, 715076) 431. KHADDAR FRANCHISE
('47', 377, 4, 9, 715099) Lala Har Dayal Nag writes a letter on the working of the khaddar clause in the Congress constitution.
('47', 377, 4, 10, 715201) I take from that letter the following relevant extract 1:
('47', 377, 5, 11, 715259) I was the President of the Tippera District Congress Committee of which the annual general meeting came off on the 27th ultimo.
('47', 377, 5, 12, 715387) The meeting was timed to be held at Comilla....
('47', 377, 5, 13, 715435) Just after my arrival I was asked by some friends not to give any ruling on the dress of the members and to allow all, including those who are not habitual wearers of khaddar, to vote.
('47', 377, 5, 14, 715620) I refused to comply....

('47', 381, 3, 8, 724178) 435. THE NATIONAL LANGUAGE
('47', 381, 4, 9, 724205) From the addresses I am receiving in the United Provinces I have come to know many things.
('47', 381, 4, 10, 724296) In this article I wish to consider them only from the point of view of language.
('47', 381, 4, 11, 724377) I have with me three examples from which I choose the following sentences 2: These three are examples of Hindi or Hindustani, that is, the national language.
('47', 381, 4, 12, 724535) One is stuffed with only Persian Arabic words which an average Hindu will not be able to follow.
('47', 381, 4, 13, 724632) Another is replete with Sanskrit words which an average Muslim can never understand.
('47', 381, 4, 14, 724717) The third is such that it can be grasped by any average Hindu or Muslim.
('47', 381, 4, 15, 724790) Here, Sanskrit or Arabic Persian words do not appear to be deliberately avoided or chosen.
('47', 381, 4, 16, 724881) If we wish to make Hindi the national language, if Hindus and Muslims both wish to build up unity, we cannot deliberately banish Sanskrit or Arabic Persian words.
('47', 381, 4, 17, 725044) That is to say, while writing or speaking the language, we should not harbour hatred in our minds towards each other or towards each other’s speech.
('47', 381, 4, 18, 725193) On the other hand, there should be love for each other.
('47', 381, 4, 19, 725249) When a Muslim finds a Hindu using Persian Arabic words, he feels pleased.
('47', 381, 4, 20, 725323) In the same manner, the Hindu’s regard for the Muslim grows when he aptly uses Sanskrit words also on occasion.
('47', 381, 5, 21, 725435) By adopting suitable words from all the three languages Hindi is enriched and gains in prestige; the language becomes sweeter.
('47', 381, 5, 22, 725562) The fact is, if we do not harbour hatred for a particular language, we shall not feel embarrassed in borrowing from it to enrich and develop our language.
('47', 381, 6, 23, 725717) Shri Ramnaresh Tripathi writes in the preface to his book

('47', 394, 3, 4, 743938) DEAR SATIS BABU, I have your letter.
('47', 394, 3, 5, 743975) You did not tell me anything about your going to Rajahmundry but I knew from Dr. Pattabhi that you had gone there and I was glad.
('47', 394, 3, 6, 744105) I understand what you say about Utkal.
('47', 394, 3, 7, 744144) I would love to go to Utkal after the Congress if I get the time.
('47', 394, 3, 8, 744210) But whether I do or not there need be no difficulty about finding funds for Utkal if they are really required, that is to say, deserved.
('47', 394, 3, 9, 744347) It would be quite good if you and Shankerlal go there before we meet at Wardha.
('47', 394, 3, 10, 744427) Sukhendu’s death is a murder.
('47', 394, 3, 11, 744457) 1 The world’s history shows that you cannot be violent towards one and non violent towards another.
('47', 394, 3, 12, 744557) All our violence is bound to recoil upon our heads more and more as we go on and if we do not retrace our steps.
('47', 394, 3, 13, 744670) We will have to discover a method of dealing with this violence among ourselves.
('47', 394, 3, 14, 744751) Of course there is not one word in Hind Swaraj that cannot be substantiated.
('47', 394, 3, 15, 744828) If I have to rewrite it today I may change the language but never the thought.
('47', 394, 3, 16, 744907) I hope you are much stronger.
('47', 394, 3, 17, 744937) How is Hemprabhadevi?

('47', 396, 1, 2, 747112) 457. LETTER TO MATHURADAS PURUSHOTTAM
('47', 396, 2, 3, 747150) ETAH, November 9, 1929
('47', 396, 3, 4, 747173) MATHURADAS 1, I have the letter you wrote while on your way to Karachi.
('47', 396, 3, 5, 747245) Has Jivandas’s death increased your responsibilities?
('47', 396, 3, 6, 747299) Has he made any provision for his widow?
('47', 396, 3, 7, 747340) Or can she support herself?
('47', 396, 3, 8, 747368) As I view things, it should be the duty of every husband devoted to his wife to teach her at the earliest opportunity to be self reliant.
('47', 396, 3, 9, 747506) To leave money for her is, according to me, the lowest of duties.
('47', 396, 3, 10, 747572) Of course, if one keeps the wife always dependent on oneself, the only course then is to leave money for her.
('47', 396, 3, 11, 747682) The logical thing is that, as a wife does not leave money for her husband and, if she does, the latter feels ashamed, a wife too, should feel so if the husband leaves money for her.
('47', 396, 3, 12, 747864) About the children, too, my thinking has been on the same lines, as you must have seen from my article in Navajivan.
('47', 396, 3, 13, 747981) In the light of this, your duty to the widowed sister lies, not in supporting her for life if she is penniless, but in teaching her to be resolute and self reliant.
('47', 396, 3, 14, 748146) The progress of the spinning wheel class is slow because still there are very few persons who recognize spinning as a science and are interested in it as a science.
('47', 396, 3, 15, 748311) Because of these two factors we do not have a tradition of good teachers.
('47', 396, 3, 16, 748385) Moreover, you will observe that we have not so far had even one single teacher who has clung to the work throughout after once taking it up.
('47', 396, 3, 17, 748526) As you have understood this secret, I hope that you will stick to this work and do well in it.
('47', 396, 3, 18, 748621) I hope that both of you are keeping good health.
('47', 396, 4, 19, 748670) Blessings from BAPU
('47', 396, 5, 20, 748690) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 3733
('47', 396, 6, 21, 748734) 1 An expert carder and khadi worker at Sabarmati Ashram

('47', 398, 7, 13, 750726) 462. LETTER TO RANCHHODLAL
('47', 398, 8, 14, 750753) ETAH, November 9, 1929
('47', 398, 9, 15, 750776) RANCHHODLAL, Your article is bound to contain technical terms and jargon which only experts can understand.
('47', 398, 9, 16, 750884) None the less you can so simplify it that readers with some general knowledge can follow its meaning if they read it carefully.
('47', 398, 9, 17, 751012) In the West many such attempts have been made.
('47', 398, 9, 18, 751059) Jules Verne’s books have been so written that even people who have not studied science are able to understand them and read them with interest.
