('47', 400, 1, 2, 753381) 464. A MISTAKE IN BARDOLI?
('47', 400, 2, 3, 753408) A correspondent writes: 1
('47', 400, 3, 4, 753434) Just as a person cannot see his own back, he cannot see his own faults!
('47', 400, 3, 5, 753506) Hence wise men have advised us that we should be prepared to see those faults in ourselves which others find in us and point out to us and we should not insult through anger or impatience those who do so.
('47', 400, 3, 6, 753711) Being aware of this, I have always welcomed those who have pointed out my faults.
('47', 400, 3, 7, 753793) But I am always faced with a serious dilemma: everyone does not see the same faults.
('47', 400, 3, 8, 753878) That which seems a virtue to some appears to be a failing to others.
('47', 400, 3, 9, 753947) What should a person like me do when faced with such a difficult situation?
('47', 400, 3, 10, 754023) When such a dilemma arises, if one is not convinced despite considering the critic’s observations dispassionately, one should follow the dictates of one’s inner voice.
('47', 400, 3, 11, 754191) I am in such a predicament with regard to Bardoli.
('47', 400, 3, 12, 754242) Until this day, I have felt that I have served the country and the world by calling off the Bardoli struggle.
('47', 400, 3, 13, 754352) I am confident that history will look upon it as a form of perfect satyagraha and not as an act of cowardice.
('47', 400, 3, 14, 754462) On my part, I have seen even its results to be excellent.
('47', 400, 3, 15, 754520) If I had deliberately continued the struggle, the nation would have been crushed.
('47', 400, 3, 16, 754602) As a result of the postponement of the struggle, the nation has made progress, though at a slow rate, its thinking power has increased and the awakening that followed in its wake has been stabilized.
('47', 400, 3, 17, 754802) The opinion expressed by the Governor of Bombay or any other official is irrelevant.
('47', 400, 3, 18, 754887) It is not possible for an outsider to think of a solution that suggests itself to a person directly involved.
('47', 400, 3, 19, 754997) I, as the leader, or my companions who are involved in the struggle alone can judge it.
('47', 400, 3, 20, 755085) A commander who gives up his own opinions as a result of being influenced by the criticism made by others is fit to be dismissed.
('47', 400, 3, 21, 755215) He must have the capacity to assess his own decisions; failing this, he should never take such a responsibility upon himself.
('47', 400, 3, 22, 755341) Having said so much in support of my decision, I am prepared to admit that it is possible that my being a Bania by birth prevents me from perceiving my cowardice.
('47', 400, 3, 23, 755504) If that failing remains, it is
('47', 400, 4, 24, 755535) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('47', 400, 4, 25, 755572) The correspondent had referred to the reported remarks about India being within an inch of swaraj when the non co operation movement was withdrawn after the Chauri Chaura incident in February 1922.
('47', 401, 0, 1, 755770) 402 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 401, 1, 2, 755812) unavoidable.
('47', 401, 1, 3, 755825) But it is for the people to decide whether to overlook this failing or to reject my services because of it.
('47', 401, 1, 4, 755933) People wish to be served and yet desire perfection—how can both these be possible?

('47', 401, 4, 19, 757007) 465. THE YOUTH AND AGRICULTURE
('47', 401, 5, 20, 757038) A co worker who has received modern education and wishes to become self reliant by taking to farming writes: 1
('47', 401, 6, 21, 757149) I sincerely regard myself as a farmer.
('47', 401, 6, 22, 757188) Some people were amused at my evidence in the court.
('47', 401, 6, 23, 757241) I had described my profession as farmer and weaver 2. Even today, if my ability is taken into consideration, I have no right to call myself a farmer, but I have no doubt that my flesh and blood are those of a farmer.
('47', 401, 6, 24, 757458) I am fascinated by the farmer’s life.
('47', 401, 6, 25, 757496) I am a worshipper of his natural virtues and I envy him his indifference to death.
('47', 401, 6, 26, 757579) When I see his sturdy physique, I take pity on my own frail body.
('47', 401, 6, 27, 757645) I have had personal experience of the fact that the common sense which he possesses can never be acquired in schools.
('47', 401, 6, 28, 757763) I do not feel ashamed of cleaning latrines, of sweeping or of handling the spade and the hoe; on the contrary, I like doing these things.
('47', 401, 6, 29, 757901) Hence I know that, if I give up that which I have come to regard as service or am forced to give it up, and I continue to be physically fit, I
('47', 401, 7, 30, 758044) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('47', 401, 7, 31, 758081) 2 Vide “Message to Bombay”, 11 3 1922
('47', 402, 0, 1, 758119) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 403
('47', 402, 1, 2, 758168) shall start farming that very day.
('47', 402, 1, 3, 758203) But I was not destined to do so and hence I have had to be content with living on a farm and inspiring my co workers to take to farming.
('47', 402, 1, 4, 758340) But because I have realized the importance of agriculture in this manner, I am happy when any educated person takes up this occupation.
('47', 402, 1, 5, 758476) Moreover, I am well acquainted with the hardships involved in it as I have come into close contact with farmers, and experiments in agriculture are being carried out under my direct supervision.
('47', 402, 1, 6, 758671) I have reproduced the above extract from my coworker’s letter in order to give some idea of those joys and hardships.
('47', 402, 1, 7, 758789) Without both, health and wealth, it is not possible to do farming.
('47', 402, 1, 8, 758856) Multi millionaires earn money by owning hundreds of thousands of bighas of land.
('47', 402, 1, 9, 758937) They do not till the land, but carry on business; their success is similar to that of the person who runs a factory with the help of workers.
('47', 402, 1, 10, 759079) But if those who have a limited sum of money invest it in farming, they must certainly have both the desire and the capacity to put in body labour.
('47', 402, 1, 11, 759227) No other profession requires the same degree of alertness as that required of a farmer.
('47', 402, 1, 12, 759315) If a farmer so desires, he can with the slightest effort become a yogi.
('47', 402, 1, 13, 759387) It is for this very reason that the saying has originated to the effect “Agriculture is the best of professions, business comes next and service is the most inferior one.” I have no doubt, therefore, that the larger the number of young men who take to farming, the better it will be for us.
('47', 402, 1, 14, 759678) I have not written at length about it as I know that it is a difficult path.
('47', 402, 1, 15, 759755) This precious profession cannot, however, be suggested to everyone.
('47', 402, 1, 16, 759823) Anyone who wishes to take up farming should, first of all, serve silently as a labourer under some farmer.
('47', 402, 1, 17, 759930) He should learn to use a plough, acquire the same knowledge as an ordinary farmer about the soil and crops, and learn well how to dig round and square pits.
('47', 402, 1, 18, 760087) He should then acquire a knowledge of farming from books written in the West.
('47', 402, 1, 19, 760165) Soil chemistry is a distinct subject.
('47', 402, 1, 20, 760203) Some improvement can certainly be brought about in our agriculture by obtaining some knowledge of it.
('47', 402, 1, 21, 760305) Hence if the educated young man who wishes to make a success of farming does not have inexhaustible patience, he should never take up this experiment.
('47', 402, 1, 22, 760456) Anyone who carries out the experiment must also develop self confidence.
('47', 402, 1, 23, 760529) Initial failures should not dishearten him.
('47', 402, 1, 24, 760573) Success has always been born out of failure.

('47', 403, 4, 7, 761023) WEAKNESS OF THE FLESH An unhappy gentleman writes: 2
('47', 403, 5, 8, 761076) Many persons have experienced the same age old difficulty as this gentleman.
('47', 403, 5, 9, 761153) Arjuna had put the same question to the Lord.
('47', 403, 5, 10, 761199) Mastery over the senses was offered as a remedy.
('47', 403, 5, 11, 761248) It was suggested that the soul should rest in itself.
('47', 403, 5, 12, 761302) Constant endeavour, self abnegation and devotion had also been pointed out as paths to self conquest.
('47', 403, 5, 13, 761404) Innumerable people have attained self purification through devotion alone.
('47', 403, 5, 14, 761479) This gentleman is well aware of his own weaknesses; hence his disease cannot be regarded as incurable.
('47', 403, 5, 15, 761582) He and those like him should exercise self control and keep themselves fully occupied in work in order to gain control over the mind and, along with this effort they should repeat Ramanama or use whatever epithet of God they like and have the faith that finally their effort is sure to succeed.
('47', 403, 5, 16, 761877) Again, we come across many persons who, having failed, give up their efforts and despite this discuss their vices with everyone, ask for a remedy, declare their inability to adopt it and obtain permission to do sinful deeds.
('47', 403, 5, 17, 762102) The correspondent should not commit this grave error through lack of effort.
('47', 403, 5, 18, 762179) He should have faith that God always responds to the cry of a person in distress.

('47', 404, 1, 2, 762590) 467. CONDITIONS FOR CO OPERATION1
('47', 404, 2, 3, 762624) It is my advice to readers that they should not evince undue interest in the leaders’ parleys, nor should they be very inquisitive about them.
('47', 404, 2, 4, 762767) For, despite promises from the Government and even if the promise of Dominion Status is translated into a law, if the people do not prove worthy of it, they will not be able to see its results at all.
('47', 404, 2, 5, 762968) However potent svarnabhasma 2 may happen to be, if one who takes it has no power to digest it, that bhasma is useless for one.
('47', 404, 2, 6, 763095) Exactly similar position obtains in regard to Dominion Status, independence, swaraj and freedom—or by whatever other name it is known.
('47', 404, 2, 7, 763230) As we keep developing our strength to win and preserve it, so and to that extent we shall have won swaraj.
('47', 404, 2, 8, 763337) If this reasoning is accepted there is no need for conferences and the like.
('47', 404, 2, 9, 763414) When a conference is held, one can merely conclude from it that the opponent is inclined to recognize to some extent our strength.
('47', 404, 2, 10, 763545) Suppose the Conference is to meet and there are even Congress representatives in it, and yet if atthat time the people’s power is at a low ebb, that cannot but affect the Conference.
('47', 404, 2, 11, 763728) Hence all those who are not required to attend the Conference should keep themselves engaged in constructive activities which are an expression of the people’s strength.
('47', 404, 2, 12, 763898) We do not yet know at all what the Viceregal pronouncement means.
('47', 404, 2, 13, 763964) Suppose the interpretation made in the leaders’ manifesto is correct, suppose the conditions stipulated by them are accepted, even then we cannot at all slow down the tempo of our present activities.
('47', 404, 2, 14, 764164) That is to say, rather than abate activities like boycott of foreign cloth, production of khadi, prohibition, Hindu Muslim unity, removal of untouchability, etc., we should accelerate their pace.
('47', 404, 2, 15, 764360) Instead of that happening, if the people go to sleep, nothing will materialize today or hereafter.
('47', 404, 2, 16, 764459) In other words, one cannot go to heaven unless one dies; or the winning of swaraj depends only on our own strength.

('47', 407, 5, 8, 768847) 471. LETTER TO ASHRAM WOMEN
('47', 407, 6, 9, 768875) SHAHJAHANPUR,
('47', 407, 7, 10, 768889) Silence Day, November 11, 1929
('47', 407, 8, 11, 768920) SISTERS, After this, I shall be required to write to you only on one more Monday.
('47', 407, 8, 12, 769002) It is being proved every day that the reason for frequent thefts in the Ashram is our own negligence.
('47', 407, 8, 13, 769104) We are negligent in two ways: We are not watchful enough, and, though frequently warned, some of us keep jewelry with them and some others keep money.
('47', 407, 8, 14, 769255) There will always be thieves in the world.
('47', 407, 8, 15, 769298) There are three ways of protecting ourselves against them.
('47', 407, 8, 16, 769357) One is that we should keep nothing with ourselves.
('47', 407, 8, 17, 769408) That is not quite possible.
('47', 407, 8, 18, 769436) If we keep things with us, to that extent we should remain watchful.
('47', 407, 8, 19, 769505) The third method is to let the thieves feel the fear of punishment through the Government, and to co operate with the Government in punishing them.
('47', 407, 8, 20, 769653) We have renounced this third course.
('47', 407, 8, 21, 769690) The first course is our ideal.
('47', 407, 8, 22, 769721) The second is the one that we follow at present.
('47', 407, 8, 23, 769770) We should have the fewest possible possessions, and be watchful about the few things we keep with us as being absolutely necessary.
('47', 407, 8, 24, 769902) Since this letter has turned out to be of common interest, let it also be read out at the time of the evening prayers.
('47', 407, 9, 25, 770021) Do not get disheartened by the burden of the kitchen.
('47', 407, 9, 26, 770075) Ask for whatever help you require, but do not give up in despair.
('47', 407, 9, 27, 770141) It does not matter if we do not embark upon some task; but, having undertaken it, we should do it at the cost of our lives.
('47', 407, 9, 28, 770265) God always helps those who
('47', 408, 0, 1, 770292) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 409
('47', 408, 1, 2, 770341) work steadfastly in this manner.
('47', 408, 1, 3, 770374) That is the lesson to be learnt in the story of Gajendramoksha 1 and in the bhajan about the male and female tortoise.

('47', 408, 6, 8, 770620) RAMNIKLAL, This theft has agitated me.
('47', 408, 6, 9, 770659) I see in it our fault and God’s grace.
('47', 408, 6, 10, 770698) If, despite our fault, we remain complacent, I would look upon it as a sign of God’s wrath.
('47', 408, 6, 11, 770790) It is my view that anyone who is found negligent in his duty of keeping watch should leave the Ashram.
('47', 408, 6, 12, 770893) There are certain tasks which permit no laxity.
('47', 408, 6, 13, 770941) A vaidya who gives his patient arsenic powder instead of salt ought not to be permitted to practise as a vaidya; this case is on a par with that.
('47', 408, 6, 14, 771087) It seems that even at 4 o’clock it is necessary to maintain a watch.
('47', 408, 6, 15, 771156) Though we have a rule that no one should keep any money in his room, why is it that the rule is not observed?
('47', 408, 6, 16, 771266) Personally I feel that those who violate the general rules of the Ashram should leave it.
('47', 408, 6, 17, 771356) I don’t think that asking people to leave the Ashram is a punishment; it is a form of non co operation.
('47', 408, 6, 18, 771460) You may consider whether the Managing Committee should make such a rule, but read out the above to all people as an expression of my feelings on the subject.
('47', 408, 6, 19, 771618) It is not the loss of ten rupees which I mind, but the fact that we are still so lax.
('47', 408, 6, 20, 771704) If Nathji has arrived there, ask him what his view is.
('47', 408, 6, 21, 771759) I certainly see our deficiency in the fact that we have not gone into the neighbouring villages.
('47', 408, 6, 22, 771856) That we have not been able to do so shows that we do not know how.
('47', 408, 6, 23, 771923) Think over how we can.

('47', 412, 1, 2, 776621) 478. LETTER TO RAMNIKLAL MODI
('47', 412, 2, 3, 776651) SITAPUR,
('47', 412, 3, 4, 776660) November 13, 1929
('47', 412, 4, 5, 776678) RAMNIKLAL, I got your letter.
('47', 412, 4, 6, 776708) I have arrived at a principle of conduct on the basis of experience, namely, that one should never think of doing good to others with a selfish motive.
('47', 412, 4, 7, 776860) If while pursuing his own interest a person incidentally does some good to others, he should notregard it as benevolence.
('47', 412, 4, 8, 776982) He earns no merit for such a deed either.
('47', 412, 4, 9, 777024) His neighbours may indeed benefit from what he has done, but the benefit results from the usefulness of the deed and not from the goodness of its author.
('47', 412, 4, 10, 777178) For instance, if a Bhangi cleans lavatories conscientiously, his work is of great benefit to others.
('47', 412, 4, 11, 777279) But he earns no merit for it, since he works for his livelihood.
('47', 412, 4, 12, 777344) As, however, his work is useful, society benefits from it as much as from that of any other person who might clean lavatories purely in a spirit of service.
('47', 412, 4, 13, 777501) In the same way, if anyone practises pranayame, etc., for the sake of health, the benefit he derives from these activities is limited to health.
('47', 412, 4, 14, 777646) His soul enjoys no peace through such praneyama.
('47', 412, 4, 15, 777695) This preface has reference to your question regarding our harassment at the hands of thieves.
('47', 412, 4, 16, 777789) We can clean villages, dispense medicines and take up similar other activities.
('47', 412, 4, 17, 777869) If, however, we start them now, they will have been prompted purely by self interest and we shall be given no credit for our work.
('47', 412, 4, 18, 778000) From the beginning we have cherished the intention of doing such work.
('47', 412, 4, 19, 778071) We should hold to it, and take up the work in future.
('47', 412, 4, 20, 778125) At the present time we can go into the villages only by declaring our interest in doing so.
('47', 412, 4, 21, 778217) I had drafted a leaflet with this aim.
('47', 412, 4, 22, 778256) It was even printed.
('47', 412, 4, 23, 778277) But, thanks to lack of faith on the part of the Ashram inmates, their timidity and their false sense of shame, its circulation was abandoned.
('47', 412, 4, 24, 778419) My position is still the same and even now I give the same advice.
('47', 412, 4, 25, 778486) I for one believe that we should go among the people and talk to them at present about nothing but our wretchedness and beg them to have pity on us.
('47', 412, 4, 26, 778635) If I get time, I will draft and send a leaflet for this purpose, else I will draft one after I return.
('47', 412, 4, 27, 778738) All of you may decide then whether or not to use it.
('47', 412, 4, 28, 778791) I am dictating this letter while visitors are coming and
('47', 413, 0, 1, 778848) 414 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 413, 1, 2, 778890) going, and so I cannot finish what I wish to say.
('47', 413, 1, 3, 778940) You may fill in the rest.
('47', 413, 1, 4, 778966) I wrote to you on Monday in regard to the signing of cheques.
('47', 413, 1, 5, 779028) About putting up a hedge, ask me after I return.
('47', 413, 1, 6, 779077) However, if you feel that you cannot wait till then, do what you think best.
('47', 413, 1, 7, 779154) I have not revised this.

('47', 416, 0, 1, 782403) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 417
('47', 416, 1, 2, 782452) 484. CONDOLENCES1
('47', 416, 2, 3, 782470) The tragic death of Sheth Narottam Morarjee removes from our midst a merchant prince who combined patriotism with commercial ambition.
('47', 416, 2, 4, 782605) As an employer of labour he combined humanity with its exploitation.
('47', 416, 2, 5, 782674) His latest enterprise, the Scindhia Steam Navigation Company, was conceived as much through patriotism as through ambition.
('47', 416, 2, 6, 782798) His charities were wide, discriminating and in keeping with the modern requirements..
('47', 416, 2, 7, 782884) The removal of such a son of India at this juncture is a great loss to the country.
('47', 416, 2, 8, 782968) His mantle has fallen upon the shoulders of his only son who is yet in the making.
('47', 416, 2, 9, 783051) But Sjt.
('47', 416, 2, 10, 783060) Shantikumar has all the patriotism of his distinguished father and if possible, a greater love of the labourers employed in his father’s many businesses.
('47', 416, 2, 11, 783214) I tender my condolences to him, his aged grandmother and the other members of the family with whom I have had the privilege of enjoying intimate relations.
('47', 416, 3, 12, 783370) Young India, 14 11 1929
('47', 416, 4, 13, 783394) 485. VILLAGE IMPROVEMENT2
('47', 416, 5, 14, 783420) I hope the reader carefully followed the articles by Lala Deshraj which were published in five parts.
('47', 416, 5, 15, 783522) 3 They constitute, I think, a dispassionate review of the famous experiment made by Mr. Brayne, the late Deputy Commissioner of Gurgaon District, known as the Gurgaon Programme.
('47', 416, 5, 16, 783700) Whilst the articles were being published, I took up Mr. Brayne’s book called The Remaking of Village India, being the second edition of his Village Uplift in India as it was originally called.
('47', 416, 5, 17, 783893) So far as one can judge from Lala Deshraj’s articles, the Gurgaon experiment for village remaking must be pronounced virtually a failure.
('47', 416, 5, 18, 784031) After Mr. Brayne’s back was turned upon Gurgaon, the people who were working under hisinspiration or pressure seem to have gone to sleep, the manure pits lying neglected, the new ploughs rusting and co education dissolving.
('47', 416, 6, 19, 784255) 1 A similar obituary appeared in Navajivan, 24 11 1929. 2 Gandhiji's articles on the same subject also appeared in Navajivan, 24 11 1929, 1 12 1929 and 8 12 1929. 3 In fact these articles appeared in four issues of Young India, 17 10 1929, 24 10 1929, 31 10 1929 and 7 11 1929. For Gandhiji's introductory remarks, vide “Is it Village Uplift”, 17 10 1929
('47', 417, 0, 1, 784610) 418 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 417, 1, 2, 784652) The reason for the failure is not far to seek.
('47', 417, 1, 3, 784699) The reform came not from within but was superimposed from without.
('47', 417, 1, 4, 784766) Mr. Brayne made use of his official position to put as much pressure as he could upon his subordinates and upon the people themselves, but he could not carry conviction by force, and conviction so essential to success was lacking.
('47', 417, 1, 5, 784997) Mr. Brayne thought that the results would convince the people.
('47', 417, 1, 6, 785060) But that is not how reform works.
('47', 417, 1, 7, 785094) The reformer’s path is strewn not with roses but with thorns, and he has to walk warily.
('47', 417, 1, 8, 785183) He can but limp, dare not jump.
('47', 417, 1, 9, 785215) Mr. Brayne was impatient and wanted to cover a long distance in one stride, and he failed.
('47', 417, 1, 10, 785306) When an official becomes a reformer, he must realize that his official position is not a help but a hindrance.
('47', 417, 1, 11, 785417) In spite of his Herculean efforts people will suspect him and his motives, and they will scent danger where there is none.
('47', 417, 1, 12, 785540) And when they do certain things, they often do them more to please the official than to please themselves.
('47', 417, 1, 13, 785647) The other handicap that Mr. Brayne laboured under was the almost fatal facility he had for receiving money.
('47', 417, 1, 14, 785755) In my opinion money is the last thing that a reformer needs in his campaign.
('47', 417, 1, 15, 785832) It comes to him unsolicited in exact proportion to his strict needs.
('47', 417, 1, 16, 785901) I have always distrusted reformers.
('47', 417, 1, 17, 785937) who have pleaded want of financial aid as an excuse for their ill success.
('47', 417, 1, 18, 786012) Where there is zeal, adequate knowledge and faith in oneself, financial assistance has always come; but Mr. Brayne relied more upon money for the success of his experiment than upon his faith in himself and the people.
('47', 417, 1, 19, 786231) So in spite of his having had Rs. 50,000 a year according to Lala Deshraj’s estimate, he complains that many things await development only for want of money.
('47', 417, 1, 20, 786389) His ambition is insatiable.
('47', 417, 1, 21, 786417) So much for the actual experiment itself.
('47', 417, 1, 22, 786459) The book deserves careful study apart from the experiment.
('47', 417, 1, 23, 786518) There can be no doubt about Mr. Brayne’s sincerity.
('47', 417, 1, 24, 786570) Every page of the book proves it.
('47', 417, 1, 25, 786604) The intrinsic worth of many of the author’s suggestions is indisputable.
('47', 417, 1, 26, 786677) The book is ably written, and everyone who wishes to do village reconstruction work should make haste to study Mr. Brayne’s volume.
('47', 417, 1, 27, 786809) The defects in the villages described by Mr. Brayne are as follows: 1. The peasant’s methods of farming are bad.
('47', 417, 1, 28, 786922) 2. His village is filthy; he lives in dirt, squalor, disease and suffering.
('47', 417, 1, 29, 786998) 3. He is the prey of epidemic diseases.
('47', 418, 0, 1, 787038) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 419
('47', 418, 1, 2, 787087) 4. He wastes all his wealth.
('47', 418, 1, 3, 787116) 5. He keeps his womenfolk in degradation and slavery.
('47', 418, 1, 4, 787170) 6. He pays no attention to his home or his village, and spends no time or thought over bettering himself and his surroundings.
('47', 418, 1, 5, 787297) 7. He resists all change; he is illiterate and ignorant of what progress village folk in other civilized countries and in other parts of his own country are making, and what he can himself make if he sets his mind to it.
('47', 418, 1, 6, 787518) There is much exaggeration in this description.
('47', 418, 1, 7, 787566) The Indian villager’s methods of farming are certainly not bad.
('47', 418, 1, 8, 787630) Many have testified that he has a workable knowledge of agriculture which is not to be despised.
('47', 418, 1, 9, 787727) The second and third defects have, I fear, to be admitted.
('47', 418, 1, 10, 787786) The fourth is largely, if not wholly, inadmissible if only because he has no wealth to waste.
('47', 418, 1, 11, 787880) The fifth, sixth and seventh are largely true.
('47', 418, 1, 12, 787927) The remedies suggested are eighteen.
('47', 418, 1, 13, 787964) I summarize them as follows: 1. Keep good cattle.
('47', 418, 1, 14, 788014) 2. Use modern implements.
('47', 418, 1, 15, 788040) 3. Use good seed.
('47', 418, 1, 16, 788058) 4. Put up Persian wheels.
('47', 418, 1, 17, 788084) 5. Stock the manure in pits.

('47', 427, 3, 14, 810074) From Aligarh taking several places on the way as usual we passed on to Mathura.
('47', 427, 3, 15, 810154) The absence in this celebrated holy place of Hinduism of anything to remind one of the nativity of Krishna, the first among the cowherds of the world as Gandhiji called him at the public meeting, preyed upon his mind, and in reply to the addresses Gandhiji emptied his soul before the meeting on behalf of the cow.
('47', 427, 3, 16, 810469) He said a visitor to Mathura and the surrounding places reported to be the birthplace and the playground of the divine keeper of the cow had a right to expect this part of the country to show the finest cattle in the world and to produce rich, pure unadulterated milk almost at the price of water even as it was said to have been in Krishna’s age.
('47', 427, 3, 17, 810817) A visitor would expect the people of Mathura to show the rigorous piety,
('47', 427, 4, 18, 810890) 1 On November 6
('47', 428, 0, 1, 810906) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 429
('47', 428, 1, 2, 810955) simplicity and bravery of Krishna.
('47', 428, 1, 3, 810990) He would also expect to find the despised untouchables to be treated with affection and everyconsideration.
('47', 428, 1, 4, 811098) ‘I see, as I go through the streets of Mathura, cattle with their bones protruding, cows who give so little milk as to be an economic burden.
('47', 428, 1, 5, 811240) I see in this holy place the slaughter house where the cow whom Krishna protected and venerated is slaughtered for man’s food.
('47', 428, 1, 6, 811367) Do not imagine that it is the Muslim or even the Englishman who is in the first instance responsible for this shameful state of things.
('47', 428, 1, 7, 811503) We Hindus are primarily responsible for it.
('47', 428, 1, 8, 811547) Cattle will be killed as they are fast becoming an economic burden on the land, and if they are not killed in India they will be shipped as they are already being shipped to Australia for its butcheries.
('47', 428, 1, 9, 811751) Hindus are in the first instance possessors of the vast majority of India’s cattle.
('47', 428, 1, 10, 811835) It is they who sell them to butchers or their buyers.
('47', 428, 1, 11, 811889) If we would but do our duty towards the divine child whom we affect to worship, we could study the science of cattle keeping and would make it a point of ensuring that they are superior to any cattle in the world in their capacity to give milk and bear burdens.
('47', 428, 1, 12, 812151) If we would do this we have to discard foolish prejudices and superstitions however ancient they may be.’
('47', 428, 2, 13, 812257) GOVARDHAN1
('47', 428, 3, 14, 812268) From Mathura we went to Govardhan on our way to Brindaban.
('47', 428, 3, 15, 812327) The sight that Gandhiji saw in Govardhan grieved him more even than in Mathura.
('47', 428, 3, 16, 812407) Govardhan was visited in the early morning at 7 o’clock.
('47', 428, 3, 17, 812464) As we passed through the ill kept street of Govardhan we faced a yoke of bullock and buffalo both with their protruding bones.
('47', 428, 3, 18, 812591) At the meeting we found men looking as if they had just risen from their sleep, youngsters in dirty clothes, with eyes and ears unwashed and without any lustre in their eyes, or intelligence in their features.
('47', 428, 3, 19, 812801) to add to his grief, the secretary who presented the khadi purse said: “This place is filled with Brahmins who are bhikharis—beggars—and so we are unable to give you a large purse.” This drew from Gandhiji a speech which showed his great grief.
('47', 428, 3, 20, 813046) He made no reference to the purse and would not make the appeal he invariably makes for money.
('47', 428, 3, 21, 813141) ‘You have brought me,’ he said, ‘to a place which stirs me to my depths.
('47', 428, 3, 22, 813214) I belong to a Vaishnava family.
('47', 428, 3, 23, 813246) From my childhood I have been taught to think of the birthplace and the playground of Shri Krishna as places which would make a man discard his sins if he
('47', 428, 4, 24, 813401) 1 On November 7
('47', 429, 0, 1, 813417) 430 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 429, 1, 2, 813459) visited them.
('47', 429, 1, 3, 813473) I had no such feeling as I passed through the streets.
('47', 429, 1, 4, 813528) This is the place where Krishna is alleged to have lifted with his little finger the hill of Govardhan and protected hiscowherd companions and their cattle from being deluged by the rains that were pouring upon them.
('47', 429, 1, 5, 813745) But the spirit of that sermon of humanity and its companion the cow I miss here.
('47', 429, 1, 6, 813826) Instead I see dilapidated cattle and I see before me men and boys without life or lustre and I am told about and I find Brahmins described as beggars.
('47', 429, 1, 7, 813977) Not so were those, the Brahmins of old.
('47', 429, 1, 8, 814017) They were those who had seen God face to face and imparted to all men the secret of so seeing God.
('47', 429, 1, 9, 814116) It was not on charity that they lived.
('47', 429, 1, 10, 814155) Their maintenance was found for them as a matter of privilege by those whom they endowed with divine knowledge.
('47', 429, 1, 11, 814267) They were in the days of Krishna the custodians of true religion.
('47', 429, 1, 12, 814333) They arrogated no superiority to themselves but they commanded respect and veneration by reason of their service of humanity.
('47', 429, 1, 13, 814459) I see no trace of this in sacred Govardhan.’ The meeting in Govardhan did not occupy more than twenty minutes, for we had to take several places before reaching our destination which was Brindaban.
('47', 429, 2, 14, 814657) IN BRINDABAN1
('47', 429, 3, 15, 814671) In Brindaban we stayed at the Prem Mahavidyalaya, that standing monument to the charity of that brave patriot Raja Mahendra Pratap.
('47', 429, 3, 16, 814803) I must not however tarry to describe this institution or the Ramakrishna Mission or the Gurukul—all of which Gandhiji visited.
('47', 429, 3, 17, 814930) At the public meeting there was the unveiling of the Raja Saheb’s portrait by Gandhiji and an address to the students of the Prem Mahavidyalaya.
('47', 429, 3, 18, 815075) Acharya Jugalkishore had purposely postponed the annual function of the Vidyalaya to the time of Gandhiji’s visit.
('47', 429, 3, 19, 815190) Gandhiji used the unveiling ceremony as an occasion for paying a glowing tribute to Raja Mahendra Pratap whose noble example of self sacrifice and patriotism he commended to all the zamindars.
('47', 429, 3, 20, 815383) to the students he said: ‘You will not have deserved the munificent donation of Raja Mahendra Pratap if you do not labour for your neighbours.
('47', 429, 3, 21, 815526) Your education, if it is a vital thing, must shed its fragrance in your surroundings.
('47', 429, 3, 22, 815612) You must devote a certain portion of your time daily to serving the people around in a practical manner.
('47', 429, 3, 23, 815717) You must therefore be prepared to take the spade, the broomstick and the basket.
('47', 429, 3, 24, 815798) You must become voluntary scavengers of this holy place.
('47', 429, 4, 25, 815855) 1 On November 7
('47', 430, 0, 1, 815871) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 431
('47', 430, 1, 2, 815920) That would be the richest part of your education, not learning by heart literary theses.
('47', 430, 1, 3, 816009) I learn that Brindaban contains a very large number of widows who have come principally from Bengal to pass the remainder of their lives in Brindaban.
('47', 430, 1, 4, 816160) The poor amongst them are paid a small pittance daily for repeating in congregation the divine name Radhe Shyam.
('47', 430, 1, 5, 816273) 1 It is to be hoped that those who are responsible for organizing this charity will give some work to the widows rather than make them feel helpless by doling out charity as against their repeating the name of God.
('47', 430, 1, 6, 816488) Surely a vain repetition can have no virtue about it.’
('47', 430, 2, 7, 816543) Young India, 14 11 1929
('47', 430, 3, 8, 816567) 489. AN IDEAL ADDRESS
('47', 430, 4, 9, 816589) In the last issue I had given some examples of the language used in addresses.
('47', 430, 4, 10, 816668) 2 At every meeting I receive three, four, or even more addresses.
('47', 430, 4, 11, 816734) In most of them I find nothing artistic.
('47', 430, 4, 12, 816775) Mostly the addresses are only full of fulsome praise of me.
('47', 430, 4, 13, 816835) In my opinion this shows lack of wisdom and ideas.
('47', 430, 4, 14, 816886) By flattering a person to his face we neither honour nor please him.
('47', 430, 4, 15, 816955) Much of my work would cease if I were to believe the words of praise applied to me.
('47', 430, 4, 16, 817039) God has given me a sense of humour; with this I laugh away all such epithets; and, because I try to practise the teachings of the Gita, to my knowledge praise and blame have no effect on me.
('47', 430, 4, 17, 817230) But, in this article, I have not set out to describe what effect the addresses have on me.
('47', 430, 4, 18, 817321) Here I only wish to tell the readers how an ideal address should be framed, so that people who present addresses in future may also get some help in preparing them.
('47', 430, 4, 19, 817486) An ideal address can be prepared by observing the following rules.
('47', 430, 5, 20, 817553) The language of an address should be such that both Hindus and Muslims alike can understand it.
('47', 430, 6, 21, 817649) 2. An address should not need a frame.
('47', 430, 7, 22, 817688) 3. As far as possible the address should be written on handmade paper.
('47', 430, 7, 23, 817759) Such paper can be secured if an attempt is made to obtain it.
('47', 430, 7, 24, 817821) Granted that hand made paper cannot compare with machine made paper, even so we should not let this handicraft die.
('47', 430, 7, 25, 817937) The survival of such handicrafts depends on the partiotism of the rich and the wise.
('47', 430, 8, 26, 818022) 1 The source has “Radha Shyam”.
('47', 430, 8, 27, 818054) 2 Vide “the National Language”
('47', 431, 0, 1, 818085) 432 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 431, 1, 2, 818127) 4. The address should only be written by hand.
('47', 431, 1, 3, 818174) If this becomes the rule, then the art of calligraphy will flourish.
('47', 431, 1, 4, 818243) Such an address.
('47', 431, 1, 5, 818260) should not be written by any and every person.
('47', 431, 1, 6, 818307) It should be written only by someone who is an adept at calligraphy.
('47', 431, 1, 7, 818376) It is quite a different matter to say that for the sake of publicity it is necessary to have an address printed.
('47', 431, 1, 8, 818489) In my opinion there is no necessity to distribute addresses in this manner.
('47', 431, 1, 9, 818565) Before the guest arrives, the address should be read out to the gathering.
('47', 431, 2, 10, 818640) 5. Nowadays, it has become the vogue that an address to be presented in the name of an association or society is prepared by some one individual without other members being consulted about it.
('47', 431, 2, 11, 818833) Our people are indifferent to such matters; therefore, whatever is to be said or to be done, only one person acts on behalf of all.
('47', 431, 2, 12, 818965) But the proper thing is for the contents of the address to be known to all the people who are giving the address.
('47', 431, 2, 13, 819079) Only then has the address any value.
('47', 431, 2, 14, 819116) For instance, if an address is to be presented in the name of students, a committee of the students should be formed; and even then, the address, when ready, should be approved by an assembly of all the students.
('47', 431, 3, 15, 819329) 6. An address should contain very few words of praise.
('47', 431, 3, 16, 819384) Rather, what has been done in accordance with the ideals of the addressee, and what would be done in the future, should be spelled out in the address.
('47', 431, 3, 17, 819535) together with this, particulars of the society or association presenting the address should be given in it.
('47', 431, 4, 18, 819643) If the above suggestions are followed, then, the addresses which are dull and meaningless today will become interesting and purposeful.
('47', 431, 5, 19, 819779) [From Hindi]
('47', 431, 6, 20, 819792) Hindi Navajivan, 14 11 1929

('47', 437, 6, 12, 827827) 500. LETTER TO ANAND T. HINGORANI
('47', 437, 7, 13, 827861) CAMP KALAKANKAR, November 14, 1929
('47', 437, 8, 14, 827896) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('47', 437, 8, 15, 827929) I remember having received during this tour the letter you refer to but travelling along with me it got itself lost in a pile of papers and escaped my attention altogether.
('47', 437, 8, 16, 828102) Pray, forgive me.
('47', 437, 8, 17, 828120) You certainly have my blessings, both you and your wife, and may you have a happy long life dedicated to the service of the motherland.
('47', 437, 8, 18, 828256) So far as I can see, you were right in leaving your father’s house and your father is also right in saying that you may not have it all your own way so long as you depend upon him even for maintaining you.
('47', 437, 8, 19, 828462) My own feeling is that no boy is fit to be married so long as he is not capable of maintaining himself and is actually not so doing.
('47', 437, 8, 20, 828595) I feel that even if a grown up young man is living in his father’s house he
('47', 437, 9, 21, 828671) 1 Vide “Honest Differences”, 21 11 1929.
('47', 438, 0, 1, 828712) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 439
('47', 438, 1, 2, 828761) should contribute his quota of labour to the household and earn his living so that both father and son feel interdependent and free to sever the joint life whenever either party so desires it.

('47', 440, 1, 2, 831478) 504. LETTER TO RAMNIKLAL MODI
('47', 440, 2, 3, 831508) KALAKANKAR,
('47', 440, 3, 4, 831520) November 14, 1929
('47', 440, 4, 5, 831538) RAMNIKLAL, I have your letter.
('47', 440, 4, 6, 831569) The laxity about sacrificial spinning which is growing among us strikes me as dangerous.
('47', 440, 4, 7, 831658) It is of course necessary that those who do not spin should give the reason why they do not do so.
('47', 440, 4, 8, 831757) But these external remedies are just attempts to keep up appearances.
('47', 440, 4, 9, 831827) Those who do not spin should declare what their real faith is.
('47', 440, 4, 10, 831890) I have held for many years that one external step remains to be taken.
('47', 440, 4, 11, 831961) All activities which are looked upon as yajna, that is, dharma or duty, have a fixed time assigned to them.
('47', 440, 4, 12, 832069) The namaz, the gayatri, etc., are performed at fixed hours.
('47', 440, 4, 13, 832129) This is themeaning behind the notion of mahurta 1. It would therefore be worth while to fix the hour for sacrificial activities as we have fixed hours for meals.
('47', 440, 4, 14, 832291) If we put upon these activities the same value in our hearts as we do with our lips, we would be able to solve all the difficulties which may arise in fixing such a time.
('47', 440, 4, 15, 832462) I can understand that all the members of an institution cannot spin at the same hour.
('47', 440, 4, 16, 832548) For instance, those who are engaged in cooking cannot spin at the same time as others.
('47', 440, 4, 17, 832635) We may even fix a separate hour when such persons may spin.
('47', 440, 4, 18, 832695) Think over this suggestion and, if you think it is practicable, discuss it with others.
('47', 440, 4, 19, 832783) We shall discuss it further after my return and then do what seems best.
('47', 440, 4, 20, 832856) If you do not think it has any significance, ignore it.
('47', 440, 4, 21, 832912) You may, if you wish to, remove the rule about the length of the time [for spinning].
('47', 440, 4, 22, 832998) If my suggestion can be carried out, the question of removing that rule will not arise.
('47', 440, 4, 23, 833086) If, however, you wish to fix the hour for spinning and not the length of time, you may do that.
('47', 440, 4, 24, 833182) Adopt whichever method will safeguard truth.
('47', 440, 4, 25, 833227) I had a wire from Mahadev today, telling me that Santok 2 had been operated upon for piles and fistula.
('47', 440, 4, 26, 833331) This seems to have been a sudden development, for I did not even know till now that Santok suffered from piles.
('47', 440, 4, 27, 833443) of course it was good that she was operated upon.

('47', 441, 4, 19, 834559) 505. A LETTER
('47', 441, 5, 20, 834573) KALAKANKAR, November 14, 1929
('47', 441, 7, 21, 834603) I should very much like to write about the Jam Saheb and other Princely states.
('47', 441, 7, 22, 834683) I know a great deal about them, but at present I can serve best by keeping silent.
('47', 441, 7, 23, 834766) Time is not yet for me to speak.
('47', 441, 7, 24, 834799) But that does not mean that I do not think about the states.
('47', 441, 7, 25, 834860) I think a great deal, I am learning a great deal, and if I live I will also gather the strength to speak.
('47', 441, 8, 26, 834966) In spinning, the time spent in joining the string, if it breaks, can be included in the hour to be spent in spinning.
('47', 441, 8, 27, 835084) But there is much room for self deception in that practice.
('47', 441, 8, 28, 835144) Hence after personal experience I have suggested that while fixing the time we should also fix the number of rounds.
('47', 441, 8, 29, 835261) Just as we fix the minimum of one hour for
('47', 441, 9, 30, 835304) 1 The name is omitted in the source.
('47', 441, 9, 31, 835341) 2 Vide also “Princely States”, 28 11 1929.
('47', 442, 0, 1, 835384) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 443
('47', 442, 1, 2, 835433) spinning, if we also fix the maximum or minimum of 160 rounds, there would be less room for self deception, because it is my experience that if we have not fixed the number of rounds to be spun, very often the appointed time may be spent in fixing the spinning wheel and we shall not have spun even one round.
('47', 442, 1, 3, 835743) That happened with me in Yeravda Prison.
('47', 442, 1, 4, 835784) So I set three types of conditions; so much weight and so much time.
('47', 442, 1, 5, 835853) In fixing the limit of weight I was prompted by a desire to spin fine yarn, because I had seen that at time I span a lot but the weight was excessive, so that the yarn proved to be only of three counts.
('47', 442, 1, 6, 836056) This made me angry with myself, and I decided to reduce the weight and spin the same number of rounds within it.
('47', 442, 1, 7, 836169) After that I learnt to spin fine yarn.
('47', 442, 1, 8, 836208) I can point out yet another necessary restriction.
('47', 442, 1, 9, 836259) But this is enough for the present.
('47', 442, 2, 10, 836295) From a copy of the Gujarati: Kusumbehn Desai’s Diary.

('47', 442, 3, 12, 836362) 506. LETTER TO KALAVATI TRIVEDI
('47', 442, 4, 13, 836394) KALAKANKAR, November 14, 1929
('47', 442, 5, 14, 836424) KALAVATI, I have your letter.
('47', 442, 5, 15, 836454) It is good that you have now got over the loss of your jewellery.
('47', 442, 5, 16, 836520) If we think deeply over it we shall find that nothing in this world belongs to any one individual.
('47', 442, 5, 17, 836619) When a certain thing that we had come to regard as ours is lost or destroyed we feel grieved.
('47', 442, 5, 18, 836713) But if we look upon a thing as belonging not to us but to God, there would be no grief.
('47', 442, 5, 19, 836801) The question then arises: If nothing belongs to anyone, who should take care of anything and why?
('47', 442, 5, 20, 836899) The answer is that though we are not the owners of a thing, we hold it, when it has come to us through our labour or through some other rightful means, in trust or guardianship for God.
('47', 442, 5, 21, 837085) It then becomes our duty to guard it.
('47', 442, 5, 22, 837123) And, if, in spite of our guarding it with diligence and care, it comes to be destroyed or lost we should not feel grieved.

('47', 444, 2, 3, 838844) Shri Jethalal Jivanlal Gandhi, Secretary of the Gujarat Vidyapith Graduates’ Association, writes: 2
('47', 444, 3, 4, 838944) The readers will see that this letter confirms what I said in my first article.
('47', 444, 3, 5, 839024) 3 If the prevailing atmosphere in the country is good, or if our youth shows the capacity to rise above it, the national schools will brim over with students.
('47', 444, 3, 6, 839183) Life throbs in the national schools.
('47', 444, 3, 7, 839220) If nothing more, it does at least produce in the students a spirit of service and self confidence.
('47', 444, 3, 8, 839319) The progress registered in spinning and the use of khadi may be considered satisfactory.
('47', 444, 3, 9, 839408) But, in my opinion, there is still room for improvement.
('47', 444, 3, 10, 839465) No one who has been in a national school for any length of time can afford to be half hearted in his use ofkhadi.
('47', 444, 3, 11, 839579) For instance, if one omits any part of a uniform, one cannot be said to be in uniform.
('47', 444, 3, 12, 839666) It has to be remembered that khadi is the accepted uniform of national schools and colleges.
('47', 444, 3, 13, 839759) Just as every right angle has 90 degrees, even so it is with the uniform to be used by the graduates of a national college.
('47', 444, 3, 14, 839883) We restrict the meaning of uniform only to the kind of cloth used.
('47', 444, 3, 15, 839950) There is no restriction about the type of clothes to be put on.
('47', 444, 3, 16, 840014) I think that it should be so.
('47', 444, 3, 17, 840044) The practice obtained in the gurukuls of olden times and prevails today in the well known schools of the West.
('47', 444, 3, 18, 840155) I am inclined to believe that there is a sound basis for it.
('47', 444, 3, 19, 840216) The graduates do not yet take sufficient interest in spinning for they have not still fully appreciated its value.
('47', 444, 3, 20, 840331) If they do, they can easily produce every month heaps of beautiful, well twisted fine yarn and it will not take much of their time.

('47', 445, 0, 1, 840898) 446 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 445, 1, 2, 840940) 510. COWDUNG CAKES OR MANURE?1
('47', 445, 2, 3, 840971) In the last chapter 2 we discussed human excreta and urine.
('47', 445, 2, 4, 841031) Since we make no use of animals’ urine like that of cows and buffaloes, it only serves to accentuate the filth.
('47', 445, 2, 5, 841143) Cowdung is mostly used for making cakes for fuel.
('47', 445, 2, 6, 841193) There is no reason to doubt at all that this is the least use—if not misuse—of cowdung.
('47', 445, 2, 7, 841281) This is like killing a buffalo for making a lash.
('47', 445, 2, 8, 841331) The heat produced by cowdung cake is considered to be mild.
('47', 445, 2, 9, 841391) It is used by those who smoke a hookah or chilam 3. In the Punjab there is a belief that cowdung cake fire is better for making ghee.
('47', 445, 2, 10, 841525) It is possible that there is some truth in it.
('47', 445, 2, 11, 841572) But all these arguments are advanced because we use cowdung as fuel.
('47', 445, 2, 12, 841641) If we make full use of cowdung, various other means can be found to produce a mild fire.
('47', 445, 2, 13, 841730) If cowdung cakes cost one pie each, the value of the same quantity of cowdung, if fully utilized, will be ten times more.
('47', 445, 2, 14, 841852) And if we take into account the indirect losses, they are hard to estimate.
('47', 445, 3, 15, 841928) To make full and good use of cowdung is to use it as manure.
('47', 445, 3, 16, 841989) Agricultural experts opine that, if we misuse cowdung for fuel, the fields suffer in fertility.
('47', 445, 3, 17, 842085) A field without manure is as dry as a sweetmeat without ghee.
('47', 445, 3, 18, 842147) I presume that there are no such farmers in India foolish enough to burn cowdung and buy chemical manure.
('47', 445, 3, 19, 842253) Moreover, farmers believe that the value of chemical manure when compared with cowdung manure is much less.
('47', 445, 3, 20, 842361) There are advantages as well as disadvantages in using chemical manure.
('47', 445, 3, 21, 842433) Although scientists are still making experiments, many of them believe that the use of chemical manure increases the quantity of yield and sometimes improves its appearance also, but the quality certainly suffers.
('47', 445, 3, 22, 842647) It is the opinion of some scientists that, by using chemical manure in a field of given area the yield of wheat would increase, the grain would be bigger in size and better in appearance, while the yield of wheat in a field of equal size having natural manure may be less, but will excel the former in sweetness and nutritional value.
('47', 445, 3, 23, 842982) It is possible that after sufficient research the value that is attached to chemical manure today will be considerably lowered.
('47', 445, 4, 24, 843110) 1 This appeared in the Shikshan ane Sahitya supplement.
('47', 445, 4, 25, 843166) 2 Vide “Does A Village Mean A Dunghill”, 22 9 1929 3 Clay pipe
('47', 446, 0, 1, 843229) VOL. 47: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1929 20 NOVEMBER, 1929 447
('47', 446, 1, 2, 843278) Whether it be so or not, there can be no two opinions that cowdung must be used only as manure.
('47', 446, 1, 3, 843374) Hence it is but the village level worker’s job to impart full knowledge about the use of cattle dung and urine as manure.
('47', 446, 1, 4, 843496) It is the volunteer’s duty to remove the people’s misconception about cowdung cakes, to find out some other substitute fuel, to explain to them by various means the value of cowdung arid urine as manure and to gain enough knowledge to be able to explain the above points to the people.
('47', 446, 1, 5, 843782) The subject is as profitable as it is interesting and, for an industrious researcher, there is a mine of knowledge in it.
('47', 446, 1, 6, 843904) Readers will see that in this as in regard to human excreta, money or great knowledge is not required, but what is needed is love, the love to which I referred in the last chapter.
('47', 446, 2, 7, 844085) [From Gujarati]

('47', 450, 1, 2, 851554) 514. LETTER TO RAM BINOD
('47', 450, 2, 3, 851579) CAMP ALLAHABAD, November 17, 1929
('47', 450, 3, 4, 851613) MY DEAR RAM BINOD, I have your letter 1 many days after your telegram.
('47', 450, 3, 5, 851684) From your letter I gather that you propose to take up a legal standpoint.
('47', 450, 3, 6, 851758) If you wish to do so I have nothing to say.
('47', 450, 3, 7, 851802) The Association mustthen decide according to the opinion of its legal advisers.
('47', 450, 3, 8, 851882) But I wish to put three things before you.
('47', 450, 3, 9, 851925) Firstly, I have never looked upon these proceedings as a legal arbitration.
('47', 450, 3, 10, 852001) Secondly, I was to be the final judge.
('47', 450, 3, 11, 852040) Satis Babu and Vithaldas Jerajani were to advise me.
('47', 450, 3, 12, 852093) Thirdly, so far as I am aware Satis Babu himself does not regard his judgment as a legal award.
('47', 450, 3, 13, 852189) On the contrary he considers it to be a judgment submitted to me for my approval.
('47', 450, 3, 14, 852271) I have never thought that even I was to give a legal award.
('47', 450, 3, 15, 852331) My one aim was to arrive at an amicable settlement.
('47', 450, 3, 16, 852383) You will now please let me know whether you propose to take up your stand upon law and regard the proceedings before Satis Babu as legal [or] as part of an attempt to arrive at an amicable settlement.
('47', 450, 4, 17, 852584) Yours sincerely, SJT.

('47', 452, 1, 2, 854744) 517. SPEECH AT ALLAHABAD UNIVERSITY
('47', 452, 2, 3, 854780) November 17, 1929
('47', 452, 3, 4, 854798) Mahatma Gandhi, expressing appreciation of the address and the purse presented, said what they had done was in the performance of their duty and so he thought that there was no occasion for congratulating the students and the staff on contributing to the Lajpat Rai Fund and for khaddar propaganda.
('47', 452, 4, 5, 855097) He referred to a letter 1 which he received after his visit to Lucknow from a student of Lucknow saying that he too had joined in contributing at Lucknow to the purse in the hope that from that moment those contributing would resolve to use always khaddar.
('47', 452, 4, 6, 855354) But this student expressed his surprise that after leaving Lucknow none appeared to be disposed to work for and use khaddar.
('47', 452, 4, 7, 855479) Mahatma Gandhi did not see any meaning in making those presents for khaddar and charkha if they were not at the same time determined to work for khaddar.
('47', 452, 4, 8, 855633) So I say that there would be no occasion for my expressing gratitude if it is not your resolve that from today you will work for khaddar.
('47', 452, 5, 9, 855771) It was, therefore, his earnest request that they should start doing the work, an appreciation of which they made by presenting the purse.
('47', 452, 5, 10, 855909) You say in your address that charkha has a great power but have you made up your mind to work it yourself?
('47', 452, 5, 11, 856016) I know you can if you only decide to do so.
('47', 452, 6, 12, 856060) He was sure that it would not in the least interfere with their studies nor would it affect their mental powers if the students only decided to give half an hour a day to spinning.
('47', 452, 6, 13, 856241) Mahatma Gandhi next appealed to the students to form their sangathan 2, for their organized effort only could bring swaraj.
('47', 452, 7, 14, 856365) He next paid a tribute to the late Lala Lajpat Rai.
('47', 452, 7, 15, 856417) Some thought, he said, that Lajpat Rai was an enemy of Mohammedans.
('47', 452, 7, 16, 856485) But I would say that he was the enemy of none.
('47', 452, 7, 17, 856532) Lalaji was an advocate of Hindu Muslim unity which was his creed and so was his religion and if you want to respect him you should at least do this that you should make an effort for bringing about unity.
('47', 452, 8, 18, 856737) The Leader, 20 11 1929
('47', 452, 9, 19, 856760) 1 Vide “Notes”, sub title, “Is It a Sale of Indulgences”, 21 11 1929. 2 Organization
('47', 453, 0, 1, 856845) 454 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('47', 453, 1, 2, 856887) 518. SPEECH AT CIVIC RECEPTION, ALLAHABAD
('47', 453, 2, 3, 856929) November 17, 1929
('47', 453, 3, 4, 856947) Mahatma Gandhi giving a joint reply to the addresses expressed his feeling of gratitude at the addresses presented by the Municipal and District Boards and also for the purse presented by the former Board.
('47', 453, 4, 5, 857153) He congratulated the Municipal Board on giving instruction in charkha to the children and hoped that the District Board also would introduce charkha in its schools.
('47', 453, 4, 6, 857318) He also congratulated the Municipal Board on having a leather working school.
('47', 453, 4, 7, 857396) Mahatma Gandhi said that as he regarded himself a spinner and cultivator he also considered himself a Chamar 1 in view of his having some knowledge of the Chamar’s craft as well.
('47', 453, 4, 8, 857575) He therefore ventured to make a suggestion in respect of the leather industry in India.
('47', 453, 5, 9, 857663) He noticed that these days from India nine crores of rupees were sent to foreign countries through the skins of the animals being sent out for tanning.
('47', 453, 5, 10, 857815) In order to save the drain of such a large amount annually, he desired that earnest efforts be made to find out some ways of improving the tanning industry in India.
('47', 453, 5, 11, 857981) Hitherto even the British had failed to compete successfully with the Germans.
('47', 453, 5, 12, 858060) Indians were, therefore, advised by Mahatma Gandhi to content themselves with chrome tanning only and to use shoes of chrome leather.
('47', 453, 5, 13, 858194) If that was done nine crores of rupees would be retained in the country.
('47', 453, 6, 14, 858267) Proceeding, Mahatma Gandhi said that he was shocked to hear that like Hardwar, the sacred rivers of Prayag were also allowed to be polluted by sewage water of the Municipality.
('47', 453, 6, 15, 858444) This news caused much pain to Mahatma Gandhi.
('47', 453, 6, 16, 858490) The Board thereby not only polluted sacred rivers but also threw in the river thousands of rupees, for otherwise sewage water could be beneficially utilized.
('47', 453, 6, 17, 858648) He expressed his surprise at the Board being unable to do anything in that respect.
('47', 453, 7, 18, 858732) Mahatma Gandhi emphasized the need for making arrangements for the supply of good milk to their constituents.
('47', 453, 7, 19, 858842) The Boards, in his opinion, would not be considered to have discharged their duties if they did not make arrangements for that.
('47', 453, 7, 20, 858970) He failed to understand why the Boards had hitherto failed to do such a simple thing.
('47', 453, 8, 21, 859056) Concluding, Mahatma Gandhi asked the audience to go to that evening’s public meeting with their pockets full of money to contribute towards the Lajpat Rai Fund as that was the day of Lala Lajpat Rai’s death anniversary when they should try to give away as much as they could.
('47', 453, 8, 22, 859332) The Leader, 20 11 1929
('47', 453, 9, 23, 859355) 1 Leather worker

('47', 454, 1, 2, 859421) 519. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, ALLAHABAD
('47', 454, 2, 3, 859462) November 17, 1929
('47', 454, 3, 4, 859480) Mahatma Gandhi said that it was not for the first time that he had come to Prayag.
('47', 454, 3, 5, 859563) Pandit Motilal Nehru brought him generally whenever he desired and whenever he liked.
('47', 454, 3, 6, 859649) But this visit.
('47', 454, 3, 7, 859665) he said, was his first visit to Allahabad on the mission of begging for Daridranarayana.
('47', 454, 4, 8, 859754) Allahabad had given him more than Rs. 30,000 of which more than Rs. 16,000 was the share of Daridranarayana.
('47', 454, 4, 9, 859863) For that Mahatma Gandhi offered his congratulations but cautioned the citizens not to feel that they had given him much.
('47', 454, 4, 10, 859984) Considering the population of two lakhs of Allahabad the collection of a sum of Rs. 30,000 or Rs. 40,000 was not a great achievement.
('47', 454, 4, 11, 860118) He knew that in Allahabad there were men who could pay Rs. 40,000 each, if they only so desired.
('47', 454, 4, 12, 860215) Mahatma Gandhi’s feeling was that when he left Allahabad he would have with him at least Rs. 35,000.
('47', 454, 5, 13, 860316) But, he said, he wanted sixty crores of rupees and they could get sixty six crores if all Indians decided to use only khaddar.
('47', 454, 5, 14, 860443) The use of khaddar would save the drain of sixty six crores of India’s money annually to foreign countries and sixty six crores so saved would be sent into the villages.
('47', 454, 5, 15, 860613) He paid a tribute to the Raja of Kalakankar and the Lal Sahib of Samastipur 1 who, he said, brought out their precious clothes of foreign stuff and got them burnt.
('47', 454, 5, 16, 860777) Mahatma Gandhi, therefore, asked the citizens of Allahabad to resolve from that day to use nothing but khaddar.
('47', 454, 6, 17, 860889) Mahatma Gandhi next paid a tribute to the late Lala Lajpat Rai’s memory and expressed suprise that although a year had passed they had not been able to collect even five lakhs of rupees.
('47', 454, 6, 18, 861076) He referred to the appeal 2 issued under the signatures of some leaders for the Lajpat Rai Memorial Fund and the suggestion of Pandit Motilal Nehru that they should collect at least two lakhs on the day of the first anniversary of the death of Lala Lajpat Rai.
('47', 454, 6, 19, 861337) If they put their heart into the work he did not think it was a great thing to collect two lakhs.
('47', 454, 7, 20, 861435) If they had the least respect, Mahatma Gandhi added, for the late Lala Lajpat Rai they should give as much as they could that day for the Memorial Fund.
('47', 454, 7, 21, 861588) Allahabad was the place where the present and future Presidents 3 of the Indian National Congress lived, it was the place where the Committee 4 was located and where a big university was established and so if they would not get money here where else would they be able to get it?
('47', 454, 7, 22, 861868) Lala Lajpat Rai, he said, had given his life in the work for swaraj and India

('47', 458, 3, 11, 867549) 525. LETTER TO ASHRAM WOMEN
('47', 458, 4, 12, 867577) PRAYAG, Silence Day, November 18, 1929
('47', 458, 5, 13, 867616) SISTERS, I write about an idea which occurred to me from Santok’s operation.
('47', 458, 5, 14, 867693) Indian women feel reluctant to get themselves examined by doctors.
('47', 458, 5, 15, 867760) This is a wrong attitude.
('47', 458, 5, 16, 867786) We have suffered much because of it.
('47', 458, 5, 17, 867823) This sense of shame has its origin not in purity but in impurity.
('47', 458, 5, 18, 867889) I should like the women in the Ashram to get rid of this superstition.
('47', 458, 5, 19, 867960) If Dr. Haribhai had not been permitted to operate upon Santok, the operation would not have been performed and her life would have been in danger.
('47', 458, 5, 20, 868107) No woman should hesitate to let herself be examined even by a male doctor.
('47', 458, 5, 21, 868182) Since the patient would be accompanied by her relatives and friends, she need have no fear.
('47', 458, 5, 22, 868274) Perhaps you do not know that I had called in a male doctor at the time of Ba’s last confinement.
('47', 458, 5, 23, 868371) She had an operation once and that too was done by a male doctor.
('47', 458, 5, 24, 868437) Ba lost nothing by this.
('47', 458, 5, 25, 868462) In such matters, all that is necessary is to change one’s attitude.
('47', 458, 5, 26, 868530) That is why I have put this matter before you.
('47', 458, 5, 27, 868577) If you wish to ask me anything about this, do so on Tuesday the 26th.

('47', 459, 2, 3, 868841) PRAYAG, Silence Day [November 18, 1929] 1
('47', 459, 3, 4, 868883) NANDKISHORI, You have asked a pertinent question.
('47', 459, 3, 5, 868933) Whether one’s love is pure or not can be judged only by its manifestation.
('47', 459, 3, 6, 869008) The love of a mother indulging her offspring with luxuries proceeds from ignorance.
('47', 459, 3, 7, 869092) That wife’s love is selfish who is reluctant to stay away from herhusband even in the interest of his dharma.
('47', 459, 3, 8, 869202) We can note innumerable such instances.
('47', 459, 3, 9, 869242) Those people who do not wish to observe the rules have no place in the Ashram.
('47', 459, 3, 10, 869321) But the others, who are making honest though unsuccessful efforts, do have and should have a place.
('47', 459, 3, 11, 869421) In the Ashram we do not follow the policy of punishment for transgression of the rules or for other lapses.
('47', 459, 3, 12, 869529) May you ever pass your life in such a thoughtful manner.

('47', 463, 4, 8, 875127) 533. A LETTER
('47', 463, 5, 9, 875141) ALLAHABAD, November 19, 1929
('47', 463, 6, 10, 875170) .1, I should not have asked what your mental condition was.
('47', 463, 6, 11, 875230) Where one forget the past, thinks not about the future and only wants to be engrossed in the present duty, no question arises about one’s mental condition being either good or bad.
('47', 463, 6, 12, 875411) The mind of one who fully keeps it occupied in the immediate duty is bound to be pure, just as a machine that is kept in working order will be free from dirt.
('47', 463, 6, 13, 875570) It is wrong to say that he who is only striving is necessarily a pretender; one may only say that pretence is likely to creep into his conduct.
('47', 463, 6, 14, 875714) Striving which has an element of pretence in it is no striving at all.
('47', 463, 6, 15, 875785) The same is true about a moral teacher.
('47', 463, 6, 16, 875825) He may develop hypocrisy.
('47', 463, 6, 17, 875851) But though one may be imperfect, one can avoid hypocrisy.
('47', 463, 6, 18, 875909) In Kaka’s words there is self condemnation in the attempt to express humility.
('47', 463, 6, 19, 875988) No other meaning is to be read in to them.
('47', 463, 7, 20, 876031) From a copy of the Gujarati: Kusumbehn Desai’s Diary.
('47', 463, 7, 21, 876085) S.N. 32579/10
